Until recent years, science has been a male-dominated profession. ⁠
⁠
And that bias, it turns out, is reflected not just in its practitioners. ⁠
⁠
A team of researchers at the Natural History Museum in London have carried out a thorough review of the animal specimens in their own collection and in the collections of four other great museums.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to learn why they have found that, among birds and mammals at least, there is a noticeable preference for cocks, stags and drakes over hens, hinds and ducks.⁠
⁠

⁠
Known and celebrated for his painfully monotonous demeanour and unflinching facial expression, the political outsider took 90% of the votes from those aged 18 to 25.⁠

To find out how viral videos, memes and nicknames helped catapult Mr Saied to the top spot, tap the link in our bio.⁠

⁠Each day at least 40,000 people cross from Venezuela to Villa del Rosario in Colombia. ⁠
⁠
Most return, laden with bulging sacks and suitcases containing fresh food, clothing and medicines. ⁠
⁠
But about 1,500 do not, joining the 4.6m Venezuelans who have left their country in search of work, safety and a better life.⁠
⁠
While the first wave of migrants consisted largely of businessmen, professionals and workers, Colombian police say "bandits and delinquents" are starting to follow "because there's nothing left to rob" in Venezuela.⁠

Click the link in our bio to read why it is such a threat that Venezuela is now exporting criminals along with refugees.⁠

Should a devoutly religious pharmacist be allowed to refuse to provide contraception to an unmarried teenager?⁠
⁠
And should a worker be able to denounce the conduct of a colleague based on his or her religious beliefs?⁠

⁠Australia's government is proposing anti-discrimination protections for those with religious beliefs.⁠
⁠
Essentially many of them work in the same way as laws against discrimination on the grounds of sex, race, disability and so on.⁠

Tech titans are mostly two-headed beasts, in the sense they not only operate a market but compete in it too. ⁠
⁠
Amazon owns the world's biggest e-commerce marketplace and also sells products on it under its private labels.⁠
⁠
Apple hosts the app store on the iPhone but also offers its own apps.⁠
⁠
This creates incentives for these firms to promote their wares unfairly, for instance by showing them at the top of the result pages of their search engines.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why breaking up Big Tech would please investors—but is unlikely to happen.⁠

The protests that have convulsed Chile have taken every conceivable form. ⁠
⁠
They began after metro fares in Santiago were raised by 30 pesos (four US cents) at peak times to 830 pesos. ⁠
⁠
Anger then began to express itself in arson and looting and spread to other cities, and at least 20 people died.⁠
⁠
Sebastián Piñera, the centre-right president, at first took a tough line⁠—but his tone changed as protests grew.⁠
⁠
Now he has set a new direction. Click the link in our bio to read why the country may not follow.⁠

Asked why the London Fire Brigade had not done more to prepare for the Grenfell Tower fire, its head had a glib answer.⁠
⁠
"I wouldn't develop a training package for a space shuttle landing in front of the Shard," said Dany Cotton.⁠
⁠
So unlikely was such a blaze judged to be, and so correct the policy of recommending people stay put, that she argued the fire brigade ought to share little blame for the tragedy in 2017, in which 72 people died.⁠
⁠
"I would not change anything we did on the night," she said.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why the inquiry into the tragedy did not support her judgment and laid out⁠—in detail⁠—the institutional failings of her organisation.⁠

Narendra Modi's government has failed to acknowledge looming dangers to India's economy and is now struggling to cope with an alarmingly sharp slowdown.⁠
⁠
In the first half of 2019 new banking credit to businesses crashed by a shocking 88%, and growth fell from 8% in 2018 to just 5% this year. ⁠
⁠
For a large and diverse economy, this remains a respectable figure.⁠
⁠
But demographic pressures mean that India must sustain growth of 7.5% just to keep unemployment in check—and needs to do even better if it hopes ever to catch up with China.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why India's current economic challenges are not due to some big external cause.⁠

An impeachment trial has several trappings of a court trial: lawyers, evidence, jurors, verdict.⁠
⁠
But the proceedings and judgment are fundamentally political. ⁠⁠
A removed official has no appeal. ⁠
⁠
And there are no set rules of evidence, no due-process requirement and of course no gag rule for jurors—senators must stay mum inside the chamber but can talk freely to the press.⁠

⁠This sun-baked salt plain in Botswana might not look particularly impressive—but if the latest research is correct, everybody alive today can trace their ancestry to it.⁠
⁠
About 200,000 years ago, Makgadikgadi was lush.⁠
⁠
Both it and the delta were part of a lake, the largest in Africa, surrounded by wetlands.⁠
⁠
For wildlife, the result was a veritable paradise.⁠

The concept of "Open Skies" emerged early in the cold war.⁠
⁠
In 1955 President Dwight Eisenhower suggested that America and the Soviet Union should not only exchange maps of all their military installations, but also allow the other side to fly over.⁠
⁠
The idea was to build confidence that an attack was not being planned. ⁠
⁠
Nikita Khrushchev laughed off the idea as an "espionage plot".⁠
⁠
But when the Berlin Wall fell and the Soviet Union dissolved, the idea was revived and the agreement was signed in 1992.⁠
⁠
Now, however, Donald Trump is set to rip up this arms-control treaty.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to find out why Russia needs Open Skies more than America does.⁠
⁠
Credit: Alamy #fly #flying #planespotting #plane #planes #aeroplane #airplane #aircraft #aviation #avgeek

Hippos are thriving in Colombia, partly because of the absence of big cats and hyenas, which are their predators in other parts of the world.⁠
⁠
Other species are not faring so well, however.⁠
⁠
The hippos are competing for food and destroying their habitats.⁠
⁠
That is a threat to the local manatees, an endangered species in Colombia.⁠
⁠
And hippo dung sucks oxygen from riverside marshes, dooming some fish.⁠
⁠
So what can be done? Click the link in our bio to read why scientists are working on a form of birth control for these hungry hippos.⁠

For a conservative city, Beijing has a remarkable gay nightlife.⁠
⁠
One club called Destination is listed as a "comrade bar" on China's most popular navigation app, Baidu Maps.⁠
⁠
That does not mean it is a watering hole for Marxists, however.⁠

⁠
Now this venue has become a beacon for gay Chinese across the country. ⁠

There is an old joke about a new arrival in Hell, who is given the choice by Satan of two different working environments. ⁠

In the first, frazzled workers shovel huge piles of coal into a fiery furnace. ⁠
⁠
In the second, a group of workers stand, waist-deep in sewage, sipping cups of tea. ⁠
⁠
The condemned man opts, on balance, for the second room.⁠
⁠
As soon as the door closes, the foreman shouts “Right lads, tea break over. Time to stand on your heads again.”⁠

Felons were unable to vote in Florida—one of four American states that had created such a rule—for 150 years.⁠
⁠
Last year a constitutional amendment was overwhelmingly approved that restored the voting rights of ex-felons, other than those convicted of murder and sexual offences. ⁠
⁠
But Florida then passed a law that, depending on your view, either clarified or, in effect, invalidated this change. ⁠
⁠
It stated that felons must pay all fines, fees and restitution before they can vote.⁠
⁠
That may sound reasonable enough—but a series of extra charges means the sums quickly add up for poorer people. Click the link in our bio to learn why.⁠

What might an impeachment trial of Donald Trump look like?⁠
⁠
Although it takes only a majority vote to impeach in the House of Representatives, conviction requires the backing of two-thirds of senators present: 67, if 100 attend. ⁠
⁠
At least 20 Republicans, along with all 47 Democrats, would have to find Mr Trump guilty. That seems unlikely.⁠
⁠
No American president has yet been removed—though in 1868 Andrew Johnson escaped by just one vote (his trial features in this image).⁠

Professor Harold Bloom could read 400 pages in an hour.⁠

America's colossus of literary criticism, who died this month aged 89, led the charge to keep great literature alive.⁠

⁠

Any Londoner will tell you that if you're running late for a 9am meeting in the city, ditch a cab and take the Tube. ⁠
⁠
Between 7.30am and 8.30am, drivers in Britain's capital spend 70% more time in traffic than if they were on the road during times of lower congestion. ⁠
⁠

⁠
These days motorists pay £11.50 ($14.80) to enter a 34-square-kilometre zone in central London during peak times.⁠
⁠
And that fee is likely to continue to rise. Tap on the link in our bio to find out why. ⁠

The long-term effects of breathing in dirty air are well known. In some places it can be as bad for you as smoking 25 cigarettes a day. ⁠

But there may be a more immediate danger linked to toxic air. ⁠

A seven-year-long study of 397 American counties took crime data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and air-pollution data from the Environmental Protection Agency. ⁠

As this chart shows, the researchers found that being exposed to more PM2.5 (particulate matter less than 2.5 microns in diameter) is associated with an increase in violent crimes, such as assault.⁠

What happened to crime rates the last time America banned some pollutants? Tap on the link in our bio to find out. ⁠

In South Asia the mistreatment of females starts in the womb, with the selective abortion of girls. It continues after birth. ⁠

In Europe, giving addicts places to shoot up without fear of arrest are common. The first one was set up in Bern, Switzerland, at the height of the AIDS epidemic in 1986. ⁠Since then they've popped up all over the place. As this map shows, the Netherlands alone has 31 sites in 25 cities. ⁠
⁠
Most offer clean needles and have medical staff on hand to treat those who have overdosed on heroin with naloxone, which temporarily reduces the drug’s effect on the brain and kick-starts breathing.⁠
⁠
America's first safe-injection clinic could soon open its doors in Philadelphia. Opponents argue such places lead to more overdoses. Are they right? Tap on the link in our bio to find out. ⁠
⁠

In 1970 George Akerlof penned one of the most famous papers in economics.⁠
⁠
"The market for lemons" shows how, in markets where sellers know more than buyers, trade can dry up.⁠
⁠
His example is not fruit but used cars—a "lemon" is one with hidden defects.⁠
⁠
Buyers want reliable wheels, or "peaches".⁠
⁠
Not knowing which they are buying, they shave their offers.⁠
⁠
That puts off peach-sellers, some of whom exit the market, raising the chance of buyers getting a lemon, pushing prices down still further.⁠
⁠
It becomes impossible to sell a peach for what it should be worth.⁠
⁠
Such "adverse selection" can be found in markets from insurance to education.⁠
⁠
But a new paper examines the extent to which lemons really are a problem. Click the link in our bio to read about it.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @satillustration #economics #economist #finance #business

Almost half of young sub-Saharan Africans finish secondary school. But just 9% of them progress to tertiary education (vocational colleges and universities). As this chart shows, that's far below the share in other regions. ⁠

I⁠t is 400 years since the slave trade to North America began. ⁠This image played a pivotal role in its abolition in Britain. ⁠
⁠
Thomas Clarkson, an influential abolitionist, managed to get his hands on a diagram of the slave-ship Brookes. Clarkson and others reworked the plate to show the Brookes loaded with 482 slaves, lined up in rows and squashed together. ⁠
⁠
In 1789 they published 700 posters of this image. It caused a sensation, bringing home the horrors of the “middle passage”, during which many slaves either killed themselves or died of disease, starvation and cruel treatment. ⁠Parliament finally voted to abolish the slave trade in 1807.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Russell Boyce⁠ #history #slavetrade #slaveship #abolition #famousimages ⁠

Eva Perón, Argentina's charismatic and controversial first lady, died on July 26th 1952 aged just 33.

Her husband was Juan Perón, a populist president who united conservatives, Industrialists, trade unionists and the army in a movement that resembled the fascism of southern Europe.

His second wife, Eva, was beloved by many for helping to raise wages and opening public institutions, including hospitals, schools and orphanages. ⁠

Her enduring popularity is one reason that Peronism remains a potent force in Argentina today. (Note: We’ve updated our original caption with additional context about her and her life.)

Temperatures are running high in Hong Kong.
As usual, Sunday’s anti-government march involving hundreds of thousands of protesters began peacefully. 
But after dark some activists marched to the central-government’s building, which was daubed with slogans in large black characters, including “Down with the Chinese Communist Party”. Police later used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse those crowds.
Meanwhile, at a station in the north of the territory, people wearing the black shirts favoured by protesters were attacked by stick-wielding men in white shirts as they emerged from their train on their way home. 
Other members of the public were caught up in the violence too; 45 people were injured and one person is in a critical condition.
Tap on the link in our bio to read how stability in the territory is being challenged as never before since the British left in 1997.

Credit: Tyrone Siu/Reuters

From @1843mag: They’re not G-Men. They’re not Mafiosi. They’re just the male population of Ravenna, popping out to get some cheese, in the days when the fedora was near-compulsory. Some theorise that the hat fell from fashion after the second world war because it reminded men of their army days. ⁠
⁠
In Italy, perhaps Marcello Mastroianni’s luxuriant quiff was partly responsible. But in 1950, when this photograph was taken by Jean-Philippe Charbonnier, “La Dolce Vita” was a decade away. ⁠
⁠
To read Matthew Sweet's visual history of the hat, tap the link in our bio. Image: Getty #Ravenna #fedora

From @1843mag: “It has a stark beauty all its own.” That was Neil Armstrong’s conclusion as he took his first small step onto the Moon’s surface. Thanks to the lack of atmosphere, the pictures that he took, of the desert plain around him, are remarkably sharp. The black of the sky and the shadows was so dense a new photographic ink had to be developed to properly convey it.⁠

⁠Our cover story this week looks forward to the next 50 years in space. Half a century after Neil Armstrong planted his foot on the surface of the Moon, a new era of space exploration is beginning. ⁠

The night sky teems with stars above the Lovell Telescope at Jodrell Bank Observatory, which has been added to UNESCO’s World Heritage List. ⁠
⁠
At the beginning of its use in 1945, the site housed research on cosmic rays detected by radar echoes. Jodrell Bank has had substantial scientific impact in fields such as the study of meteors and the moon, the discovery of quasars, quantum optics, and the tracking of spacecraft. Between the 1940s and 1960s there was a transition from traditional optical astronomy to radio astronomy, which led to radical changes in the understanding of the universe.⁠
⁠
Credit: PA/Peter Byrne #stargazers #MilkyWay #JodrellBank #UNESCO

Our cover story this week is the global crisis in conservatism. In two-party systems, like the United States and (broadly) Britain, the right is in power, but only by jettisoning the values that used to define it. ⁠
⁠
In countries with many parties the centre-right is being eroded, as in Germany and Spain, or eviscerated, as in France and Italy. In Hungary the right has gone straight to nationalist populism. “To be conservative”, wrote the philosopher Michael Oakeshott, “is to prefer the familiar to the unknown, to prefer the tried to the untried, fact to mystery, the actual to the possible, the limited to the unbounded, the near to the distant.” ⁠
⁠
The new right, however, are aggrieved and discontented. They are pessimists and reactionaries. They look at the world and see what President Donald Trump once called “carnage”. You do not have to be a conservative to find that deeply troubling.⁠
⁠
To read more about the global crisis in conservatism click the link in our bio. #TheEconomist

Before a vaccine became widely available in the 1960s, measles was an inevitable childhood disease.⁠

General Director of the Rijksmuseum Taco Dibbits (L) and CEO of AkzoNobel Thierry Vanlancker (R) examine "The Night Watch" by Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn at the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam. ⁠

This year marks the 350th anniversary of Rembrandt’s death, and the painting is his most famous masterpiece. It will undergo the most innovative restoration in the history of art thanks to a partnership between the museum and the company. ⁠

This careful process will take place in public. The picture will remain on the wall of the museum, encased by a clear glass chamber where the conservators will get to work. To add even more pressure, the restoration will be broadcast to the world online via live video feed. ⁠

From @1843mag: You can tell when a jackfruit is ready to pick by its bloated, uncomfortable look, like an ageing gourmand after the cheese course, and its distinct onion breath. It is laughably easy to cultivate; in Brazil it’s classed as an invasive species. Take a machete to the rind and inside you’ll discover an abundance of satiny, pale-golden “arils” or bulbs – fleshy outgrowths surrounding the seeds. In flavour terms, the flesh is often said to resemble banana, pear, bubble gum or a combination of all three. Jackfruit can be hard to find, primarily because it’s so perishable. Tinned ripe jackfruit is readily available, however, and tastes not unlike ripe mango wrapped in slivers of parmesan and Bayonne ham. To read the rest of @NikiSegnit's introduction to the jackfruit, and discover why it's a rubbish substitute for meat, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Photo: Paul Zak #jackfruit #instafood

From @1843mag: Everyone knows the croissant story, don’t they? Viennese bakers, under siege by the Ottomans in 1683, are slaving over their ovens in the small hours when they hear scrapings and rumblings underground. They raise the alarm, the guards apprehend a gang of stealthily tunnelling Turks, and the bakers are rewarded with the right to bake pastries in the shape of Islam’s crescent moon flag. In fact, this burrowing-Turks story is false: the croissant is really an industrial-age walk-in, with a triumphalist cover story that streaked around the world long before the murky truth could get its boots on. To read the real origin story of the croissant, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: Getty #croissant #breakfast

From @1843mag: Ignore the words and this poster looks fun: the simple lines, the three primary colours with a dash of pink; three figures, jumping, perhaps dancing. Take in the words, and you hear the scream. By the late 1980s, AIDS felt like the most visible threat to life in America. When Keith Haring made “Ignorance = Fear” in 1989, one American was being diagnosed with HIV every minute. Four were dying of AIDS every hour. By 1991 the epidemic had claimed the lives of 100,000 Americans. But nobody was talking about the epidemic in any meaningful way. Haring's work helped to change that. To read our Cheat's Guide on Haring, whose work is now on show at @TateLiverpool, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: Collection Noirmontartproduction, Paris #KeithHaring

People and places all over the world will be adorned in the colours of the rainbow to mark the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, which sparked the movement for LGBT rights. ⁠
⁠
On June 28th 1969 a routine raid on the Stonewall Inn in New York did not go to plan. While the police waited outside the gay bar for their wagons, a crowd began to form. Officers became flustered and rough, and when one struck a female patron with a baton the throng became agitated. Pennies, bottles and stones began to fly; chants filled the streets of Greenwich Village. A riot erupted—one that would continue on the streets around Stonewall for five days, but that would also galvanise a much wider movement. America’s LGBTQ citizens stepped out from their underground venues, and into the street.⁠
⁠
That was 50 years ago. This photo was taken on June 24th 1990, 20 years on from Stonewall, and it's clear that the LGBTQ community's relationship with the law had changed considerably by then. Darryl Brantley, a waiter at a bar on the site of the old Stonewall Inn, poses with NYPD officers while dressed in a Playboy bunny outfit as they wait for the Pride parade to pass by. Credit: Thomas Garguilo/AP  #lgbt #lgbt+ #gayrights #stonewall #gay #humanrights #pride #rainbow

Swipe to see our two covers for this week. 
In Britain we report on the City of London. Its prowess is something to behold. It hosts 37% of the world’s currency dealing and 18% of cross-border lending. It is a hub for derivatives, asset management, insurance and investment banking. It generates a quarter of its income from the continent, and Europe gets a quarter of its financial services from London. Yet Brexit threatens to rupture Britain’s financial links with the European Union. And if Labour wins the next election under Jeremy Corbyn, Britain will end up with its most left-wing government since 1945. Either would make the EU poorer and damage London’s position. Together, they could change the workings of the global financial system.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
In our other editions we ask how to contain Iran? It is poised to breach the nuclear deal it signed with America and other powers in 2015. Although it is not about to become a nuclear-weapons power, it is once again using its programme to heap pressure on America. That adds an explosive new element to an already-volatile mix, which has seen strikes on six ships, the downing of an American drone and a cyber-attack on Iran. Neither President Donald Trump, nor America’s allies, nor Iran wants a big new war in the Middle East. Yet Mr Trump’s strategy of applying “maximum pressure” on Iran is making war more likely. Before things escalate out of control, both sides need to talk. #TheEconomist

Keeping pets is hardly novel, however for better or worse, an almost global pet culture is emerging. The pet industry uses the word “humanisation” to describe many of the changes they see.  It does not imply that people think their pets are actually human although many cats and dogs have Instagram accounts, and a few people have symbolically married their pets. It’s more a case of pet owners believing that their animals can do human-like things, such as understand them, calm them and love them. They have also come to believe that pets should be treated more like humans. For the full story see The International section of The Economist. We have two covers this week. 
In Asia and America we glimpse the future of the United States through its two most populous states, Texas and California. One in five Americans calls them home; by 2050 one in four will.  Does America work better as a low-tax, low-regulation place or one where it is the government’s job to tackle problems? The results will determine what sort of country America becomes. 
In Europe we analyse the career of the overwhelming favourite to become Britain’s next prime minister. Boris Johnson has assumed different guises at different times. As mayor of liberal, cosmopolitan London in 2008-16 he preached the virtues of immigration and the single market. As a leading light in the Leave campaign he effortlessly switched to criticising migration and warning of the dangers of Turkish membership of the EU, which he had previously advocated. Today he talks up the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal. As the Brexit saga drags on, Britain is growing ever more polarised. In a starkly divided country, which gallery would Mr Johnson play to? #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: It is 2.45am in Holborn, London. Mohammed, a bus driver, is trying to wake one of his passengers. He claps loudly over the sleeping man’s head, shakes him gently by the shoulder. “I think he’s probably pretending to be asleep”, he says. “They do sometimes. I won’t try too hard. I feel sorry for them...I just let them ride the bus all night if they want.” Mohammed has been driving the same route – the N27, which runs from Turnham Green to Chalk Farm – for nearly 30 years. He drives a sleek double decker, but doesn’t like the new buses. He misses the old Routemaster: he liked the noise it made and the fact that people could jump on and off it, and that sometimes they fell off. To see the rest of @jondayhoming and @dougie_wallace's photo essay on London’s nightshift, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. #London #Londonbus #Londonbynight

From @1843mag: One hundred and thirty years ago, Queen Margherita of Savoy was visiting Naples when she saw street vendors with trolleys selling flatbread topped with chopped tomatoes. In what was possibly the first example of a royal takeaway, she ordered a courtier to get one for her. Pizza lore relays that one pizzeria owner invented a new pizza in her honour, adding mozzarella and basil to the tomato to represent the red, white and green of the Italian tricolore. You see pizza everywhere in the world but until recently it was hard to find a genuine Neapolitan pizza outside Italy. No longer. Restaurants serving Neapolitan pizza are thriving, as customers eschew baroque combinations of toppings in favour of simple margheritas. To discover why the original doughboy is making a comeback, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: @yukisugiura.photo #Naples #foodporn #pizza #Neapolitanpizza

Our cover this week reports on perhaps the biggest protests in Hong Kong since the end of colonial rule in 1997. The arguments are about a technicality, but their implications go to the heart of what makes Hong Kong unique. Many firms choose a base there because it has ties to China’s huge market while also upholding the rules that govern economies in the West. If, as proposed, the law changes to allow extradition to mainland China, dissidents taking on Beijing may face harsh treatment in Chinese courts. Businesspeople risk a well-connected Chinese competitor dragging them into a hostile jurisdiction. Hong Kongers rightly fear that the future of their city is at stake. #TheEconomist

Scientists from Northwestern University have unveiled the most detailed simulation of a black hole yet seen. The simulation proves theoretical predictions about the nature of accretion disks; bright rings of gas, dust and other stellar debris that swirl around black holes. Astrophysicists found that the inner-most region of an accretion disk aligns the black hole’s equator, proving the so-called Bardeen-Petterson effect.  Researchers believe that studying the nature of accretion disks is key to understanding how black holes evolve and function. Credit: Alexander Tchekhovskoy & Matthew Liska/Northwestern University/University of Amsterdam/AFP #astronomy #cosmology #blackholes #astrophysics #space #universe

From @1843mag: Rachel Hewitt goes on a seven-mile run every day, returning home just before the sun sets. But on the day the clocks changed, she misjudged things and left the house when it was already dark. As she ran along a deserted track, she wondered, "Am I an idiot to have come out here, in the dark, alone?" For Hewitt, running combines a sense of profound freedom with moments of euphoric joy. But sometimes she thinks of the women attacked or murdered while running, and her elation is replaced with the fear that as she runs alone, a man will abduct, rape or kill her. To read her essay on female runners, and why a woman pulling on a pair of trainers is still an act of defiance, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Illustration: Shout #running #feminism #sexism #shoutillustration

From @1843mag: On June 2nd, a cruise ship sailing down the Giudecca canal in Venice crashed into a dock. It is perhaps the most extreme example of how tourism is ruining the world's most beautiful city. In 1988, Paolo Costa, an economics professor, former mayor and former boss of the nearby Venice Port, estimated that the physical capacity of the historic centre was 20,000 visitors daily. The average daily flow now is 80,000 – more at the height of summer. In 2017, Edward Lucas went to Venice to ask whether the city can be saved. To read his piece, hit @1843mag, click on the link in their bio and search "Not drowning but suffocating". Illustration: Vince McIndoe #Venice #overtourism

Donald Trump won office by denouncing Mexico as a place to which good American jobs go and from which evil migrants come. He has threatened to rip up trade deals and close the border. Each time, Mexican officials try to soothe him with compliments and compromise, because they cannot punch back hard. Only about 15% of the United States’ exports go to Mexico, but a whopping 80% of Mexico’s exports head the other way. “There is nothing we have in our arsenal that is equivalent to what the United States can do to us,” says Andrés Rozental, a Mexican former diplomat and minister. For full story see the Americas section of The Economist. Credit: EPA/Jorge Nunez  #theeconomist #nafta #mexico #donaldtrump #trade #usa #unitedstates #tradedeal

Our cover this week examines America’s weaponisation of economic tools as a means of asserting its power. The sudden imposition of punitive tariffs, the blacklisting of technology companies, the threat of isolation from the dollar payments system and the tightening of sanctions all demonstrate the awesome force a superpower can project when unconstrained by rules or allies. President Donald Trump must view this scene with satisfaction. But his tactics could spark a crisis and are eroding America’s most valuable asset—its legitimacy. America’s central position in the global trade network gives it vast power. But Mr Trump should remember that if you abuse it, ultimately you will lose it. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Most cats want to come and go as they please, even if they live several storeys above ground. Which is why many residents of Bern, Switzerland have built outdoor climbing aids to help their feline friends make the descent from high windows and balconies. Catalogued in Brigitte Schuster’s forthcoming book, “Swiss Cat Ladders”, they come in all shapes and sizes. Some consist of no more than a wooden plank or thin pegs affixed to a drainpipe. Others are complex, scaffolding-like structures that zig-zag up four storeys. At least one lucky cat even has a tiny spiral staircase. Human burglars, be warned: the cat-ladders aren’t strong enough to hold your weight. To read about the other sights and sounds trending around the world, hit @1843mag, click on the link in their bio and look for “All the rage”. Image: Brigitte Schuster #catwalk #catsofinstagram

From @1843mag: In the spring of 1917, when Europe’s armies were mired in bloody stalemate, Marcel Duchamp, a young sculptor who had fled France to join the roiling New York art world, took a porcelain urinal, flipped it on its back, signed his name as “R. Mutt” and christened the piece a work of art. He paid $6 to show it as “Fountain” in the inaugural exhibition of the American Society of Independent Artists. At an emergency meeting, the organisers rejected it. Though they prided themselves on championing everything new and progressive, this was too much. It wasn’t art. Or was it? To read our sister magazine's Cheat's Guide to Duchamp’s infamous urinal, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. These should be hopeful days for those battling malaria. Deaths from the disease have fallen to around 435,000 a year, from perhaps five times that number a century ago. On May 22nd the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared Algeria and Argentina malaria-free, bringing to 38 the number of countries now officially rid of the disease. But two big clouds darken the outlook. One is the stubborn persistence of malaria south of the Sahara. The other is the emergence of new strains of the disease resistant to the available treatments. For the full article please see this week's International section of The Economist. Credit: Alamy/Ben Langdon  #health  #malaria #WHO

Our cover this week reports on how Brexit could cause a constitutional crisis. America, France and Germany have rules set down in black and white. Democracy in the Mother of Parliaments has blossomed for over 300 years under an “unwritten” constitution. But a battle is looming between the next prime minister, who may well opt to leave the EU without a deal, and Parliament, which insists on one. It is unclear who should prevail­­—or even how to choose between them. Meanwhile Scotland is moving towards another push for independence, and Brexit could cast doubt on the legal basis of citizens’ rights. The constitution that Britons counted on to be adaptable and robust could soon start to feed chaos, division and Anglo-Scottish mistrust. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Merdacotta, meaning “baked shit”, is a terracotta-like material made from mixing cow dung with clay. It was invented by Gianantonio Locatelli, a dairy farmer in Emilia-Romagna in northern Italy, after he realised that his 3,500-strong herd produced 50,000 litres of milk and 150,000kg of manure, far more than his farm’s annual output of Grana Padana cheese. Determined to do something useful with the waste, he experimented with mixing it into clay, and baking it as bricks, floor tiles, tableware – and toilets. This exhibit features in a new exhibition at the @vamuseum in London about the future of food production. To see more highlights from the show, tap @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: Henrik Blomqvist #food #design

From @1843mag: James Ellroy, whose books include “The Black Dahlia” and “L.A. Confidential”, is America’s pre-eminent crime novelist. His early decades were marked by personal suffering: he was 10 when his mother was murdered, and by 20 he was an addict and petty thief who sold his own blood to make ends meet. Now his lifestyle is peaceful, housebound and nearly Amish in its lack of material indulgence. On an average day, he will eat a bowl of plain oatmeal and drink several cups of black filter coffee, engage in various acts of “prayer and ponder”, check in with his assistant by fax or on the landline, and take naps. Apart from writing the occasional movie treatment or magazine piece, Ellroy’s only commitment is the monkish, monomaniacal pursuit of what he identifies as “God’s calling for me as a novelist”. To read 1843’s interview with Ellroy, and to find out why he has finally seen the light, tap @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: Alec Soth #books #jamesellroy #crime #fiction

“The Republican Party will soon be known as the party of health care—you watch,” President Donald Trump declared in March. Republican reluctance to embrace health care, despite the president’s best efforts, is understandable. On the one hand, America’s health-care system is woefully dysfunctional: the country spends about twice as much on health care as other rich countries but has the highest infant-mortality rate and the lowest life expectancy. For the full article search "Republicans are struggling to fix America’s dysfunctional health-care system" at economist.com #healthcare #Republican #US #DonaldTrump

From @1843mag: This structure, a model of a mountain shelter designed in 1936 by Charlotte Perriand, never went into production. That's a shame, because it is a masterpiece. Perriand had an unexpected source of inspiration: a children’s merry-go-round. She borrowed the idea of a portable structure with a metallic skeleton and a roof like a carousel’s top. She then selected aluminium for the 12 panels that make up the refuge’s exterior, which made it light and easy to assemble. What’s really striking is how small but capacious the structure is. It has a diameter of just 3.8 metres, yet, thanks to Perriand’s ingenious use of space, it can easily fit eight people inside, along with everything that a mountaineer might need for a weekend in the Alps. To read more about this ingenious piece of design, tap @1843mag and click on the link in the bio. #architecture #CharlottePerriand #design

Our cover this week looks at the busy, busy world of work. The popular view is automation is destroying jobs and that work has become low-paid and precarious. The zeitgeist has lost touch with the data. In reality, the rich world is enjoying a jobs boom. Two-thirds of the members of the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries, enjoy record-high employment among 15- to 64-year-olds. A greater share of people with only a secondary education or less is in work now than in 2000. Even so, more high-skilled jobs are being created than menial ones and wage-growth is rising. In America, traditional full-time jobs made up the same proportion of employment in 2017 as they did in 2005. The jobs boom will not last for ever. Eventually, a recession will kill it off. Meanwhile, it deserves a little appreciation. #TheEconomist

Data from Untappd, a beer-rating site with 7m (mostly American) users, show that pontificating pint-swillers turn their noses up at mass-market lager. Among the 5,000 beers its users reported drinking most often, lagers—made with “bottom-fermenting” yeast, which yields a light-bodied, mild brew—are rated 3.29 out of 5 on average. The rest get an average of 3.69. When grouped by the words in Untappd descriptions (many copied from labels), the best-rated terms are ones mostly used for ale, such as “tropical” and “dark”. Yet despite such poor reviews, the specific beers Untappd users say they drink most often are lagers. 
To find out why why beer snobs guzzle lagers they claim to dislike, search "Familiarity Fosters contempt" on economist.com #lager #beer #ale #alcohol #data #chart

From @1843mag: If ever a place felt like it was made for Instagram, it is Santorini. The southernmost island in Greece’s Cycladic region, it is famous for its expansive sunsets and blue and white domed churches. “Social media has turned [it] from just another travel destination into one of the most popular in the world,” according to the island's deputy mayor. But not everyone is celebrating Santorini’s exploding popularity. The hordes of tourists that descend upon the island every year are proving hard to manage. Since 2015, photojournalist Josh Haner has travelled the globe to document the impact of climate change. Swipe to see a selection of photos from his Carbon's Casualties series: 
1) Visitors walk past Grand Prismatic Spring in Yellowstone National Park, where higher temperatures have brought rapid
changes.

2) Two polar bears play in the shallow waters near the Arctic village of Kaktovik. Because the sea ice they rely on for hunting seals is receding, bears have flocked to this area looking for an alternative food
source on land. 
3)  During low tide a woman tends to her mangrove trees on the north shore of Buariki, North Tarawa. She planted the trees in an effort to slow the coastal erosion that affects her island.

4) As algae decreases with rising ocean temperatures, scientists believe that marine iguanas may reabsorb parts of their skeleton in order to decrease their size and increase their chances of survival on a smaller diet. 
Carbon's Casualties will be on display at Somerset House as part of Photo London from May 16th-19th 2019.  Credit: @joshhaner/The New York Times #climatechange #globalwarming #nature #photojournalism

Our cover this week examines the growing rivalry between China and the United States. The two superpowers used to seek a win-win world. Today winning seems to involve the other lot’s defeat—a collapse that permanently subordinates China to the American order; or a humbled America that retreats from the western Pacific. It is a new kind of cold war that could leave no winners at all. #TheEconomist

Has the Brexit vote put foreign investors off Britain? Remainers point to cancelled plans by Japanese carmakers, American banks and others. But Leavers say Britain is more alluring than ever. Last month the country topped a ranking by EY, an accountant, of attractiveness for investors. This week Facebook chose London as its base for expanding its WhatsApp messaging service. Who is right? Thais do not see that much of their king, who spends most of his time in Germany. But for three days starting on May 4th he was on near-constant display for a long and lavish series of ceremonies surrounding his coronation. It all began with a ritual purification at the royal residence in Bangkok. Holy water was poured over the head of Maha Vajiralongkorn, the tenth monarch of the Chakri dynasty. It had been collected from all 76 of the country’s provinces, as well as from around Bangkok. Courtiers and officials wore spotless white uniforms and prostrated themselves before their monarch.

The king changed into an embroidered golden suit for an anointing ceremony. Then he lowered onto his own head a pointed helmet of a crown weighing more than 7kg thanks to its crust of gold and diamonds. A royal procession the next day saw the stony-faced monarch paraded through Bangkok on a gilded palanquin. Accompanying troops roasted in the heat. In a separate procession, respectful elephants dropped awkwardly to their knees. 
For the full article search "Crown and spectre" at economist.com Credit: EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock/Rungroj Yongrit #elephants #Thailand #coronation #tradition

From @1843mag: Twins do not appear in the Stephen King novel on which “The Shining”, a film directed by Stanley Kubrick, was based, but Kubrick’s assistant suggested he write them in anyway. Thankfully, Kubrick listened. In their matching Mary Janes and blue frilly dresses, designed by Milena Canonero, they are two of the most sinister figures in the film. They owe something of their mystery to Diane Arbus’s unnerving photograph, “Identical Twins, Roselle, New Jersey” (1967), which Kubrick saw in a retrospective of her work at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1972. His fists clenched on the tabletop, Bon Kalindo, an opposition mp, leans forward conspiratorially to list the magical properties of albino body parts. Place the fibula of one under a bottle of Coke and it will fizz manically, until the top pops off. Pass it in front of a torch and the light will go out. Most handily of all, a bone correctly inserted into a machine made by a reputable witch doctor will cause large amounts of cash to fly out; it’s the magnetic liquid albinos have in their bones, you understand. Sensing scepticism, Mr Kalindo brushes it aside. You are not from here, he says.

For some in Malawi, a belief in the numinous runs deep. Medicine men post flyers boasting of potions and charms to neuter rivals, punish the unfaithful or rekindle lost ardour. Such superstition is not uncommon in much of the world. But in Malawi, it can carry dark undertones. The most potent spells require ritual human sacrifice, according to a local journalist who has approached witch doctors under cover. Murders are not uncommon. Women and children are killed for their breasts and genitals. Albinos, who number no more than 10,000 in Malawi, are said to carry the most powerful magic and are thus most at risk. 
For the full article search "White magic" at economist.com Credit: AFP/Gianluigi Guercia #Malawi #albinism #superstition

From @1843mag; Most of us picture Arizona as a badland of sandstone, desert, cacti and shrubs. But a river winds through the desert here. Clear and green, swirling with weeds, the Salt River is silky and cool on sunbaked skin. @Kate_Rew instinctively forges across the current with a few strong strokes, swims upstream, then turns herself into the flow for a quick float back down. She used to mess about in rivers just like this when she was a kid. The pleasure is just as compelling now, the happiness it provokes as simple and complete. To read about the delights of wild swimming, hit @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. Image: @MichaelTurek #wildswimming#saltriver #sonoradesert

Though their numbers have been falling for years, America’s small banks are, by and large, in fair shape. According to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (fdic), a regulator, the 4,979 community banks reported an average return on equity of 10.6% last year—less than bigger banks, but nearly two percentage points more than in 2017 and the most since the financial crisis. Only 3.4% lost money, the lowest share on record. For the full article search "They know their customers" at economist.com Photo shows Security-First National Bank, Jefferson Boulevard and University Avenue, Los Angeles, California, 1932. Credit: Dick Whittington Studio/Corbis via Getty Images #b&w #vintage #historical #bank #America #USA #California

These are times of turmoil in Venezuela but in some parts of Caracas that is well hidden. There is no visible security outside the residence of the Spanish ambassador. And no clue that inside is Leopoldo López, formerly Venezuela’s best-known political prisoner, who has been a “guest” of Spain since he escaped from his captors in the early hours of April 30th, the day it briefly appeared the dictatorship of Nicolás Maduro might fall. An air of normality is precisely what Mr Maduro is attempting to cultivate, as he hopes to continue doing what he is oddly good at—staying in power. Fans of “Star Wars” will never, in reality, be able to watch the Boonta Eve Classic Podrace on Tatooine. But they might find a pretty good substitute on the streets of Monaco, Berlin and New York over the next few months. The fifth Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile Formula E Championship, a class of motorsport that admits only electric-powered cars, has a lot of the hallmarks of podracing—and not only because the cars, with their high-pitched, almost insect-like drones, sound eerily similar to the intergalactic racers portrayed in “The Phantom Menace”. Blade-like points at the front and a huge wing at the back give them speed. Add sufficient power to these aerodynamics and you have something capable of reaching 280kph. That is pretty nifty, even by the standards of established Formula 1 racing. For the full article search "Formula E" on economist.com Credit: Kenzo Tribouillard/AFP #motorsport #racingcars #FormulaE #RobinFrijns #Netherlands #Paris #France

Services make up the bulk of the American economy, and rural regions are facing two demographic challenges. First, more people are moving out than are moving in. And to make matters worse, highly educated residents make up a disproportionate share of the leavers. States in the middle of the country contain an outsized share of residents without college degrees, whereas those on the coasts suck up the educated high-fliers, with some exceptions (Texas has been able to buck the trend, largely thanks to a budding tech sector). Although the depopulation of America’s “heartland” is well-known, the internal redistribution of educated professionals —so-called “brain drain”—poses new economic, social and political difficulties for affected areas. The consequences of a prolonged brain drain could be dire. Because America’s electoral system over-represents small states, the less-educated people living in places with shrinking populations could become more politically influential, even as their numbers decline. #US #braindrain

Bleaching is bad for coral. It happens when heat-stressed polyps, the sessile animals that construct coral reefs, eject the photosynthetic algae which usually reside within them. These algae are symbionts, providing nutrients to their hosts in return for shelter, so losing them is harmful to polyps and often results in their death. The higher temperatures brought about by global warming have therefore led to worries that more frequent episodes of bleaching might result in the loss of entire reefs. The first animals arrived a couple of decades ago from Peru, where they are mainly farmed for their soft fleece. Our cover this week reports on rising tensions between America and Iran. As a carrier strike-force steams towards the Gulf, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, has said that his country will no longer abide by the nuclear deal it signed with world powers in 2015. Policy is being dictated by hardliners. American hawks believe in using economic pressure to topple the Iranian regime and bombs to stop its nuclear programme. Iranian mullahs and their Revolutionary Guards, who despise and mistrust America, are tightening their grip at home and lashing out abroad. The potential for miscalculation is large and growing. #TheEconomist

Three-quarters of land has been "severely altered" by man-made activity, according to the report. From @1843mag: In this strikingly confident print, the Norwegian painter Edvard Munch, whose work is now on show at the British Museum, depicts himself leaning casually against the frame, his pallid face hovering preternaturally amid a dense thicket of black cross-hatch. His forearm, glowing as if irradiated, is nothing but bare bone. The name and date at the top of the heavy slab is reminiscent of a tombstone. This unsettling memento mori, painted in 1895, is an early instance of Munch’s lifelong preoccupation with the iconography of death. From @1843mag: Ballroom Blitz, Beirut, 2.30am. Hidden inside a former Harley Davidson showroom, Ballroom Blitz is the latest in a series of high-end clubs that have sprung up in old factories and abandoned buildings in the eastern outskirts of Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. On Friday nights, partiers ride an industrial lift up to the club, which has a large central dance floor, a smaller gilded space known as the Goldroom and an open-air terrace, all connected by disorienting curving tunnels, lit in startling colours. DJs from Europe are flown in to play for the crowd, which is made up of young, bohemian Lebanese and foreign revellers who party until sunrise. Leopoldo López is Venezuela's most famous political prisoner. He had been under arrest since 2014 but was freed from house arrest, by his guards from SEBIN, the feared intelligence service, on April 30th 2019. He vowed to pursue all of those behind the uprising. “Sooner, rather than later, they will go to prison to pay for their treason and crimes,” he said. Mr López and his family took refuge in the Spanish ambassador’s residence. Spain is refusing permission for Venezuelan authorities to enter and arrest him. Our cover this week examines how smartphones and other digital technologies are disrupting banking. In Asia payment apps are a way of life for over 1bn users. In the West mobile banking is reaching critical mass—49% of Americans bank on their phones—and tech giants are muscling in. Change poses risks. Because the financial system is embedded in the economy, innovation tends to create turbulence, as when securitisation fed the subprime crisis. Yet the benefits of technological change are likely to be vast. If the world’s listed banks chopped expenses by a third, the saving would be worth $80 a year for every person on Earth. Rotten service will improve and the system will get better at its vital job of allocating capital to firms and consumers. #TheEconomist

Time-travel: By one estimate, more photographs are taken every two minutes than there were in existence 150 years ago. Few people nowadays would brave a journey without a camera. Less known is the fact that a few 19th-century travellers were the same—and all the hardier for the equipment they had to schlep. 
At the Louvre in Abu Dhabi, more than 250 of these early photographs are now on display. Highlights include the work of Muhammad Sadiq Bey, an Egyptian engineer whose wet-plate collodion camera captured the first shots of Mecca (first image) and Medina. Kassian Cephas, the first Indonesian professional photographer, documented Javanese court rituals, local religious festivals and Borodobur, a 9th century Buddhist temple. The Abdullah brothers captured sultans, aristocracy and visiting kings in late-Ottoman Constantinople. The history of photography is usually cast only in a Western light. This new exposition offers a bigger picture.

From @1843mag: Timbuktu, a byword for exotic remoteness, has loomed large in the western imagination for centuries. In medieval times the city was a stopping-off point for trade caravans, carrying gold, slaves, salt and ivory, that crisscrossed the Sahara on their way from the west-African kingdoms to the Mediterranean. It became fabulously wealthy. In the 14th century the Malian King Mansa Musa I – possibly the richest man the world has ever known – travelled through Timbuktu on a pilgrimage to Mecca with an entourage of 12,000 slaves and enough gold to cause hyperinflation in Mecca, Cairo and Medina. But by the 19th century Timbuktu’s glory days were long gone – and the Timbuktu of 2019 is an even sorrier sight. Decades of neglect by the Malian government and desertification in the surrounding countryside has left it impoverished. Today, it’s too dangerous for all but the hardiest travellers. To read more about Timbuktu, from the city’s golden past to the complicated conflict tearing it apart at present, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Our cover this week considers the best way to stop the rot in South Africa, a country beset by corruption, economic stagnation and unemployment. After the atrocious nine-year presidency of Jacob Zuma, the case for dumping the ANC, which has ruled uninterrupted since the end of apartheid in 1994, is strong. Even so, we conclude that the ANC’s current leader, Cyril Ramaphosa, is best placed to sort out the mess. He is an honest reformer and a skilful politician. But he will need a convincing win in next month’s elections if he is to clean up his party and revive the nation.
#TheEconomist

From @1843mag: The Rational Dress Society was formed in 1881 to liberate women from the harness of tight-fitting corsetry. Look Burt Rutan up on Wikipedia and it will claim he has retired. This aeroplane casts doubt on that statement. Mr Rutan is probably the most original aircraft designer in the world, and Stratolaunch, as the craft is known, is perhaps his pièce de résistance. It made its maiden flight on April 13th from the Mojave Air and Space Port in California. By wingspan (117 metres) it is the largest plane ever to have flown. It was built by Mr Rutan’s company for Stratolaunch Systems, a firm he founded jointly with the late Paul Allen, who, in turn, had co-founded Microsoft. Its purpose is to carry rockets (which will fit between the two fuselages) as close to space as possible before they are launched into orbit, thus saving fuel. When commercial operations will start is not yet clear. Credit: Stratolaunch/EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock #aeroplane #BurtRutan #Stratolaunch

From @1843mag: According to Anton Meier, one of only a few people to ever observe the Swiss artist, healer and spiritualist Emma Kunz at work, her drawings were often made as part of a process of divination. As she was drawing Work no. 20 in 1939, for example, she is said to have suddenly perceived that “America would develop a weapon capable of destroying the world” – and subsequently became so alarmed that she stopped drawing at once. It isn’t immediately clear what about the image suggests an atomic bomb; does the hole at the centre represent loss, or an abyss? Perhaps we are looking at a mushroom cloud from below: the white circle is the stem, the diagonal lines gills, and the pink outer rim the meat of the mushroom. To read more about Kunz, whose works often have the highly interpretable quality of Rorschach ink blots, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. From @1843mag: Wild orcas have never, as far as we know, attacked human beings. Only captive orcas – kept in cramped artificial tanks and forced to perform tricks – have done that. But that knowledge didn’t quite still our correspondent’s fears. Tim Ecott spent two days in northern Norway watching the whales from the safety of a fishing boat, his desire to see orcas up close fighting with his survival instinct. Eventually, he slipped over the side – finding himself at eye level with a killer whale three times his length and 40 times his weight. Like sharks and lions, the orca is designed to hunt and kill. But it is also bigger, stronger and brainier. To read more about this blood-freezing encounter, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. From @1843mag: To 21st-century eyes the bicycle seems unremarkable. But when modern-style “safety” bikes – with pedals, brakes and rubber tyres – first appeared in the 1890s, they were seen as agents of radical social change. Beloved of socialists and suffragettes, bicycles became associated with emancipation and progress. Female cyclists abandoned impractical Victorian clothing for trousers or bloomers. Bikes had an immediate social impact in one area in particular: dating. Cyclists could now travel beyond their own communities, greatly increasing the number of potential marriage partners. In recent years another technology has expanded people’s social circles and dramatically broadened their romantic opportunities: online dating. Like bicycles, apps and websites bring together people who might otherwise not have met, but on a far larger scale. In America more than a third of marriages now start with a digital match-up. To learn more about the similarities between the two revolutionary technologies, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Our cover this week runs a ruler over the tech unicorns—privately held firms worth over $1bn. Next month Uber will raise some $10bn in what may be this year’s biggest initial public offering. Airbnb and WeWork could follow Lyft, which has already floated, and Pinterest, which is about to do so. In China an IPO wave rumbles on. Thanks to fashionable products and armies of users, these firms have a total valuation in the hundreds of billions of dollars. But there is a snag. The unicorns lack the economies of scale and barriers to entry their promoters proclaim. Tighter regulation will constrain their freedom to move fast and break things. Tech entrepreneurs need to rethink an unsustainable approach to building firms and commercialising ideas. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: A common English expression refers to the privileged few who are born “with a silver spoon in their mouth”. South Koreans, for their part, divide the world into geumsujeo, “golden spoons”, and heuksujeo, or “dirt spoons”. The opioid addiction sweeping America is devastating. But there is one small but significant silver lining: organ donations. In 2017 one in eight deceased organ donors in America died from an overdose, compared to one in 100 in 2000. Fatal drug overdoses usually kill by starving the brain of oxygen. As far as organ donation is concerned, brain death is the more useful kind. That is because it takes some time for the heart to register the loss of brain function and stop beating—at which point organs begin to deteriorate rapidly. This is good news for the 6,500 Americans who die on the waiting list for transplants each year—as well as for the 114,000 who are currently on the list, most of whom will not get lucky this year. And for some of the families bereaved by the opioids tragedy, the possibility that their loved ones may give a new lease of life to others may be a flicker of light in the darkness. #organdonation #America #USA

From @1843mag: A pioneering school of design founded in Germany 100 years ago, the Bauhaus was supposed to be a model of equality and progress. Women eagerly enrolled, but they faced prejudice. "Where there is wool", he said, "there is a woman who weaves, if only to kill time." Yet female Bauhauslers (pictured) had a lasting influence. They not only designed some of the school's most beautiful objects, they also helped to shape its philosophy. To read more about their work, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: T. Our cover this week examines the threat to one of the great achievements of economics—central-bank independence. The world has grown used to low and stable inflation under the stewardship of technocrats. But President Donald Trump is laying siege to the Federal Reserve, Brexiteers are rubbishing the Bank of England and the Turkish president has been in a tug-of-war with his central bank. In India a pliant insider has cut rates ahead of an election. And the European Central Bank is poised to become part of a wider political struggle over who runs Europe’s institutions. As an economic slowdown looms, there is a need for a debate on central banks’ objectives and tools. But not one like this. #TheEconomist

Every day between 100 and 600 tonnes of rock hurtles into Earth’s atmosphere. The reason so little of this bombardment makes it to the planet’s surface is that much of it is burnt up by atmospheric friction, which creates the fireball that is the visible sign of a meteor’s arrival. As for the bits that do get through, once landed, they are known as meteorites. Roughly 60,000 objects of meteoritic origin have been picked up and catalogued. Most are fragments from a much smaller number of individual falls. Of these falls, only 36 were observed as they arrived with enough fidelity to calculate the orbit of the original meteor before it entered the atmosphere. For the full article search "Space rocks" at economist.com Credit: ESO/B. Tafreshi #space #astronomy #meteors #LaSilla #Atacama #Chile #telescope #EuropeanSouthernObservatory #ESO

From @1843mag: People outside Japan tend to think of Japanese design in terms of ritualised minimalism, formality and restraint. Consumers turn to Muji’s austere housewares, Uniqlo’s alluringly plain fashions and Marie Kondo’s “Japanese art” of decluttering for a sense of escape and renewal, an antidote to the speed and complexity of modern life. Designer Oki Sato’s prodigious output shares some of this clean simplicity, but none of its mirthless rigidity. His work includes such flights of fancy as Manga Chairs (2016), whose wild spokes evoke the lines that suggest motion in comic-book panels. When a client commissions him, he tries to make something “they themselves don’t even realise they want…There’s an element of surprise. Surprise is what makes people happy.” To read about more of Sato’s creations, including “shivering bowls” moulded from a material so wobbly that they tremble like jellyfish at the slightest touch, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. #design #japan #nendodesign #okisato #decluttering

From @1843mag: Will Gadd was halfway up the ice, scaling one of the last remaining glaciers on the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania. It was a race against his lungs: would he run out of breath before he got to the top? The base of the ice was at around 18,000ft (5,500 metres), and the air was so thin that he felt as though he were pinned to the ice by sheer exertion. Six-year-old Osman Joel Hernandez, who is part of a caravan of thousands traveling from Central America en route to the United States, plays with a hula hoop as he rests in a makeshift camp in Juchitan, Mexico. 
Mr Trump’s anti-immigration rhetoric kept people away at first. Border apprehensions dropped in the 18 months after he won the presidency in November 2016. People who put off their journeys then are now making them. Tougher American policies on its border, such as separating children from parents and slowing the processing of asylum claims, are not deterring migrants. Many of them see this as a “now or never moment”, analysts say. People-smuggling gangs encourage that belief. To read our full article search "Donald Trump cuts off aid to Central America" on economist.com

Since mid-March the Guggenheim, the National Portrait Gallery and the Tate galleries will not accept future gifts from the Sackler family, prolific philanthropists who own Purdue Pharma, a firm that created an opioid, OxyContin, and claimed it was not terribly addictive. In November a French report argued that museums should hand back to former colonies artworks that were acquired by force or “through inequitable conditions”. Since colonialism was inequitable, that implies France should hand back almost everything. To some this is an attack on cultural temples. But the campaigns ought to be distinguished from each other. The arguments for returning art acquired in dodgy ways are stronger than the arguments for giving back money. To take an egregious example of looted art, the Benin bronzes were stolen from a royal palace in what is now Nigeria during a punitive British expedition in 1897. They ended up in European and American museums. Because the raid cannot possibly be defended, and because the bronzes would make more sense as a group, they should go back. For the full article search "Culture vultures" at economist.com
Credit: Getty Images/Dan #Beninbronzes #museums #PurduePharma #London #Nigeria

From @1843mag: In the days of typewriters, making each page perfect meant typing and retyping until your hands were raw. Then along came the first Macintosh computer, and life was transformed. Suddenly you could perfect your prose by moving chunks of text around. Cow gum and strips of paper which had long been used to design layouts were replaced with desktop publishing software. Even though it was a strange object in a hideous beige colour, the Mac gave writers and designers a new sense of possibility. Our Masters forecast is lukewarm on Tiger Woods. Modern greats pale in comparison with peak Tiger. So does modern Tiger.

The best-known measure of golfers’ ability is the Official World Golf Rankings (OWGR). Players earn OWGR points based on their order of finishing in each event and the previous rankings of other golfers taking part. However, the OWGR make no use of individual scores once play begins. As a result, a golfer who performs brilliantly—but loses to a rival who plays even better—gets fewer points than one who ekes out a win because everyone else had a bad day. Is this the best way to evaluate skill? We think not.

EAGLE (Economist Advantage in Golf Likelihood Estimator), our prediction model for men’s major golf tournaments, ignores competitors’ results and relies on players’ personal scoring records, adjusted for course conditions and difficulty. Starting with the Masters, we will launch an online visualisation showing EAGLE’s forecasts of every golfer’s chances of victory and odds of each possible score on each hole. #data #golf #OWGR

From @1843mag: You can buy a rolex on any street corner in Kampala – just don’t expect it to tell the time. A chapati wrapped tightly around an omelette, the “rolex”, or rolled eggs, is a quintessentially Ugandan snack. The greasy meal has spread from student hangouts to stalls on every roadside, creating work for many young men who otherwise struggle to find jobs. The ministry of tourism now holds an annual rolex festival. Posh restaurants sell their own versions. But unlike its glitzy namesake, the edible rolex is always best bought on the street. To read more about what the world is eating, watching and singing, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: Sasha Martin #uganda #kampala #africa #rolex #food

Our cover this week takes a break from the Brexit tragicomedy to ponder something far more consequential: the advent of synthetic biology. For the past four billion years or so the only way for life on Earth to produce a gene was by copying a gene it already had. No longer. Genes can now be written from scratch and edited repeatedly, like text in a word processor. The ability to engineer living things which this provides represents a fundamental change in the way humans interact with the planet's life, potentially greater in impact than the dawn of agriculture or the exploitation of fossil fuels. Our cover leader and an accompanying Technology Quarterly assess the promise and peril of the nascent human capacity to redesign life. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Pole-dancing has a problem with men. And not the one you’re thinking. What began as circus sideshow performed by women in the 1920s, found its seedier side in the 1960s and took off as a fitness fad in the noughties is now on its way to becoming a sport. But before the International Olympic Committee will recognise it, “pole”, as its acolytes prefer to call it, needs to attract more male competitors. Just five men took part in the first world pole championships in 2012. In an attempt to appeal to the kind of men usually found doing CrossFit or parkour, the International Pole Sports Federation has introduced new, more masculine disciplines like the intimidating-sounding “Ultra Pole”. To find out if these efforts have paid off, and what our correspondent discovered about the sport in a studio in south London, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: Alamy #pole #poledancing #fitness #ultrapole #london

We have two covers this week, swipe to see our animated versions.

In most of the world we look at Binyamin Netanyahu, fighting an election campaign that could see him surpass David Ben Gurion to become Israel’s longest-serving prime minister. King Bibi is a political giant who embodied muscular nationalism, chauvinism and the resentment of elites long before such populism became a global force. Now he faces his greatest danger, in the form of criminal charges for corruption. As the threat has grown, he has railed against the free press, the judiciary and shadowy forces. Israeli politics is turning into a contest between genuine achievement and demagoguery on one side and the rule of law on the other. All who care about democracy should watch closely.

Our cover in Britain dissects a week in which Theresa May, the prime minister, has offered to resign and Parliament has seized control of Brexit—sidelining the executive for the first time in over a century. Sadly, Mrs May’s sacrifice does nothing to solve Britain’s Brexit mess. Her resignation depends on Parliament voting through her deal after two crushing defeats. Even if she succeeds (a very big if), Parliament remains hopelessly divided about Britain’s future relationship with Europe. If her deal fails and Parliament forces its own alternative on her, she could resist. If she goes, the next prime minister’s Brexit plan will have no popular mandate. Brexit remains as radically uncertain as it has ever been. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Vienna’s coffee houses are places “where time and space are consumed, but only the coffee is found on the bill”. So reads the UNESCO description of these institutions. Time and space may satisfy a Viennese philosopher, but for most, a wedge of cake complements caffeine far better, and none more so than sachertorte. According to legend the cake dates back to 1832 when Prince von Metternich, Austria’s leading statesman, ordered dessert for an official dinner. The task fell to Franz Sacher, a 16-year-old Jewish apprentice. His solution was a chocolate cake – a flavour far less common then than now – and so the sachertorte was created. To read more about Austria’s trademark dessert, which was the subject of a seven-year legal battle, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: Alamy Jake Read #vienna #austria #food #foodhistory #chocolate #sachertorte @sacherhotels #dessert

From @1843mag: African-American men were murdered, wrote Ida Wells-Barnett, an African-American journalist who led a campaign against lynching in the late 19th century, on the pretext of false accusations of rape, “alleged well poisoning”, “insulting whites”, “stealing hogs”, or being “saucy to white people”. In many cases African-Americans were lynched for no recorded offence at all. Bryan Stevenson, the founder of the Equal Justice Initiative (EJI), argues that slavery morphed into lynch law, which then morphed into segregation and today, into mass incarceration – all of which reflect a desire to control and subjugate black people physically. Part of the reason racism persists today, he believes, is because Americans have not honestly confronted their history. To encourage America to face up to its racist past, the EJI has erected a memorial in Alabama to the thousands of victims of lynching. To read more about it, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: Getty #america #history #memorial #alabama #americanhistory

Unicorns are horned mythical creatures that do not exist. In the world of technology they have multiplied in recent years, at least if you define them as privately held startups valued at more than $1bn. Some 330 such firms exist globally, according to CBInsights, a data provider. All told, venture capitalists value them above $1trn. Ride-hailing apps, which allow passengers to summon cars driven by their owners, form a particularly fertile subspecies. 
As The Economist went to press on March 29th one of these “taxicorns”, Lyft, was about to float its shares on the Nasdaq exchange in New York at a price which would value the firm at more than $23bn. Other unicorns may now rush to the stockmarket. Uber, the world’s biggest ride-hailing firm, is likely to do so in a few weeks (on March 26th it bought Careem, a Middle Eastern rival, for $3.1bn). Other candidates include Pinterest, which lets users create digital pin-boards, and Slack, a corporate messaging service. Once they list, of course, companies cease to be unicorns. Will the magic disappear, too? #Lyft #IPO #Nasdaq #unicorn #magic #technology #business  #startup

From @1843mag: In 2010 Demis Hassabis founded DeepMind, a company that aspired to build the world’s most powerful artificial intelligence. AGI, which stands for artificial general intelligence, is a hypothetical computer program that can perform intellectual tasks as well as, or better than, a human. It will be able to complete discrete tasks, like recognising photos or translating languages – things our phones can already do. But it will also understand physics papers, compose novels, devise investment strategies and make delightful conversation with strangers. In 2014 Google acquired DeepMind, giving Hassabis the money to hire some of the world’s top computer scientists and brain researchers. But five years later, it is unclear whether Hassabis is any closer to building AGI – or how long Google is prepared to wait for a return on its investment. To find out more about the battle to control the future of AI, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: David Ellis #ai #agi #tech #deepmind #google

From @1843mag: The island of Murano is not what it used to be. For centuries this dot of land 2km from Venice was the centre of the global glass industry, its densely packed furnaces churning out chandeliers, vases, goblets and gewgaws. But towards the end of the 20th century, things started to change: an influx of cheaper glass from China put many Venetian companies out of business, and many consumers no longer wanted the elaborate pieces that many Murano blowers specialised in. In recent years, however, designers and entrepreneurs have been working hard to put Murano back on the map. WonderGlass, a company founded in 2013 by an Italian father and son, commissions international designers to create pieces in collaboration with Murano’s traditional glassblowers. To read more about the people breathing life into a historical industry, hit @1843mag and follow the link in the bio. Image: Baker & Evans #glass #design #murano #venice #glassblowing

From @1843mag: In “Birthday”, the American painter Dorothea Tanning portrayed herself standing on a threshold, half-dressed in a costume made of roots and lichen. She is stark, self-possessed and poised. An infinite procession of doors opens into the distance. A strange, winged creature – dog, lemur or demon? – stands beside her like a witch’s familiar. The mysterious world of Tanning is on show at Tate Modern in London. The exhibition is a large-scale survey of the artist known for her links with Surrealism, the cultural movement born in Europe in the mid-1920s that rejected a rational view of the world. Instead, the movement tapped the creative power of the unconscious: a world of dreams, nightmares, altered states and unexpected encounters.
