The steady countdown to zero new cases of polio has stopped, and last year even went into reverse, with cases in 2018 surpassing 2017. As the eradication endgame drags on, another problem is becoming more visible: cases of vaccine-derived polio. In rare occasions, the weakened virus in the oral vaccine, used in developing countries, can mutate into a form resembling the paralysing wild virus. That happens when the virus in the vaccine, which a vaccinated person excretes for a short time, is ingested by someone unvaccinated, and passed on further; the first people in the chain of transmission get some immunity but if the chain persists for over a year, the virus gradually accumulates mutations that make it dangerous again. In 2018 nearly 100 vaccine-derived cases emerged, in five countries. They now outnumber cases from the wild virus, a tip of the scale that is a side-effect of the nearing end of polio. Credit: AFP/Peter Parks #polio #vaccination

France’s new sales tax on big technology firms, including Google and Facebook, kicked in on January 1st, with the aim of bringing in €500m ($575m) a year. The French government has led calls to squeeze more tax revenue from digital giants, but a national levy wasn’t its first choice; it had pushed for a European Union-wide tax, but this was stymied by opposition from Ireland, Sweden and others. While Eurocrats have another go at forging consensus—with a new deadline of March—a dozen member states have either announced plans to follow France’s lead or say they may do so. From @1843mag: Our ninth most popular image of 2018 shows a scene from Pingyao, a fascinating city located halfway between Beijing and Xian, where the famous terracotta army of China’s first emperor is located. Pingyao dates from the 14th century, the height of the Ming dynasty, and is contained within high walls topped with 72 watchtowers. The perimeter’s menacing grandeur is the first sign of the city’s historical importance: first as a trading centre on the silk route; then, from the early 19th century, as the heart of China’s banking industry. It was here, in 1823, that the country’s first clearing house was founded. The banks collapsed along with the Qing dynasty in 1911, and Pingyao fell on hard times. But its poverty proved to be its salvation. Long ignored, it escaped the ravages of the Cultural Revolution. Image: @getty #travel #china #pingyao

Looking back on 2018 we select some of the outstanding illustrations to have accompanied articles in the newspaper and digital editions over the past 12 months. Swipe to see ten of our favourites:

1.  The case for a second referendum — Regularly illustrating stories about Brexit in fresh and entertaining ways proved a real challenge, yet Luca D’Urbino excelled at this throughout 2018. 
2. Rape as a weapon of war — Visually representing such a sensitive topic with tact is not easy. Andrea Ucini struck the balance perfectly in creating a powerful but tasteful image. 
3. Putting the data into dating — Noma Bar’s deceptively simple illustrations use negative space to create images that often carry double meanings.
4.  What if there was no moon? — Mike McQuade’s elegant artwork accompanies an abstract idea (from our annual “The World If” supplement) that the Moon and early life on Earth might be more closely linked than we thought. 
5. Japan’s rapprochement with China — Swiss illustrator Till Lauer creates artwork for our weekly Banyan column. His delightful style is at once simple, bold and impactful. 
6. I know what you’ll do next summer — “Data Detectives”, our Technology Quarterly on surveillance and justice, was illustrated entirely in “graphic novel” style by Simon Myers over 17 narrative cartoon-strip cells.
7. Against the tyranny of the majority — Gastón Mendieta's distinctive style provided the brand identity for The Economist’s Open Future initiative, tackling broad and complex areas of debate such as migration, assisted dying and freedom of speech.
8. Parents worry more about bullying than anything else — Lisa Tegtmeier cleverly puts you in the victim’s shoes with a strong, colourful illustration.
9. Working longer hours has drawbacks — Paul Blow illustrates Bartleby, a new weekly column introduced in the summer, where he imagines the themes of work and management as charming, witty visuals.
10. The Economist’s books of the year — Joey Guidone beautifully and simply ties together imagery of books with wintery scenes for December’s “Books of the Year” feature.

#illustration #graphics #design #2018 #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Our second most popular image of 2018 depicted this graffito, a quotation from Daphne Caruana Galizia, a Maltese journalist, who was murdered by a bomb that exploded beneath the driver’s seat of her car. She founded an enormously popular blog called Running Commentary, which covered the darker side of Maltese politics. On a good day, her website received 300,000 visits – the population of Malta is under 450,000. Running Commentary made Caruana Galizia not just a household name but something of a celebrity. People noticed her when she took her three sons to school or her dog for a walk; her words were sprayed on city walls. She became part of the fabric of Maltese life – until October 16th 2017, when it was all over in a flash. Image: @gettyimages #daphnecaruanagalizia #malta #features

In a farmhouse a little way from Hardangervidda, a vast and wild plateau in central Norway, five elderly figures are gathered in the kitchen, warmed by a cast-iron stove, their feet in woollen socks. Their host is Torger Moeller, a wiry 77-year-old with a white beard, who chomps gently on a curved, unlit pipe. He carved much of the house's furniture himself and fitted the pale pine planks to its walls.  The next day they will start retracing a path taken by a group of Norwegian commandos a generation older than them, who, in February 1943, attacked a plant at Vemork, on the southern edge of the plateau. For the full story search "Telemark" at economist.com Credit: Adam Roberts #Telemark #Norway #WWII

From @1843mag: Our most popular image of 2018 was this striking photograph of a Saiga antelope. It is an ancient species, which once coexisted with hairy mammoths, sabre-toothed tigers and the real-life stars of the “Ice Age” films. Recently, the number of these long-nosed antelopes has dropped dramatically – as a result of disease (thought to have been a by-product of climate change) and poaching (the males’ horns are used as painkillers and anticonvulsants in traditional east Asian medicine). By creating portraits that emphasise animals’ personalities, @timflachphotography aims to bridge the “otherness” dividing them from humans, which he believes is essential to getting us to care about endangered creatures. #saigaantelope #animals #timflach

From @1843mag: Our seventh most popular image of 2018 depicts a riot of ploughshare tortoises, scrabbling around on the sand and on each other. They resemble a bowlful of unpolished opals: precious, rare. Apart from the hexagonal shapes, the eye is drawn to the letters and figures scarring their backs. These have been engraved in the shells to put off thieves. Once you learn that, the disfigurement turns into an enhancement. Image: @timflachphotography #tortoise #photography #animals #conservation

In 1958 Lillian Oppenheimer founded the Origami Centre, now known as Origamiusa. It did much to bring together traditions from east and west and also opened up, on a personal level, the art's link to science. Acknowledged “masters” of Origamiusa have included Michael LaFosse, a marine biologist, and John Montroll, an electrical engineer. It was surely not a coincidence that one of Oppenheimer’s highly mathematical children, Martin Kruskal, spent time studying the folding-up of spacetime inside black holes. In 1989 a few such enthusiasts convened the first meeting devoted to exploring what origami could contribute to science and engineering. Robert Lang, an origami artist and former laser physicist, says that meeting in Ferrara, Italy, "played an outsized role in the triggering of the explosive growth that we're now in the middle of, because it brought together isolated individuals and fields". He should know. Since hanging up his lab coat and taking origami on full time Dr Lang has had a hand in a mind-bending array of pursuits both academic and artistic, penning 22 origami how-to books along the way. At the sixth sequel to the meeting in Ferrara, the one in Oxford, he is treated like a rock star. These are a few of his creations. This is one of our Christmas articles. For the full version search "Origami" at economist.com Credit: Robert J. Lang, http://langorigami.com @RobertJLang #origami #art #engineering

From @1843mag: Our third most popular image of 2018 was of a scene from “Dogman”, an Italian low-life tragicomedy by Matteo Garrone, the director of “Gomorrah”. Its hapless anti-hero is Marcello, a scrawny dog-groomer who is stuck in a desolate concrete suburb on the edge of Rome but who is happily devoted to his daughter and canine customers. The trouble is that he’s also devoted to Simoncino, a neighbourhood thug with fists the size of boxing gloves and a head that looks like it’s made of breezeblocks. Marcello supplies him with cocaine and drives his getaway car but gets nothing but bullying in return. Still, no dog can be kicked for ever without eventually biting his owner – will Marcello rebel against the hulking sociopath who holds his leash? #dogman #italy #film #whattowatch

Moscow’s maximum security Lefortovo jail, where the KGB held its most important prisoners, has seen its share of revolutionaries, commissars, dissidents, ministers, oligarchs, governors and generals. Next to the leading actors, Alexander Shestun is just a spear-carrier. Until recently, he was a mayor of the district of Serpukhov, an outlying city in the Moscow region. But he matters more than his humble job title suggests. His rise and fall give a rare insight into power in Russia and its main lever—the Federal Security Service (FSB). From @1843mag: Our fourth most popular image of 2018 was this photograph of a pangolin, a rough-scaled creature that could soon become extinct. As the earth’s only scaly mammal, it is particularly prized. In China, pangolin scales are used in traditional medicine: the state supplies 26 tonnes of scales to hospitals each year, and they can legally be bought in pharmacies. In Vietnam and elsewhere too, pangolin is a culinary delicacy. As a result, it is the most trafficked species of animal in the world. A global network of some 160 international smuggling routes funnels hundreds of tonnes of animals and scales, many of them to China. Image: @getty #pangolin #mammal #endangered #dispatch

Ethan was born in 2006 in San Diego. He was a healthy baby; the knot in his umbilical cord seemed inconsequential. But by the end of his first year, he wasn’t hitting development milestones. His mother noticed that Ethan wasn’t sitting up or crawling at the same stage as her first two boys. They made many visits to doctors and the family worked intensively with Ethan over the next few years. But no one could give them a diagnosis. The cerebellum is understood to be the brain’s quality assessment centre, ensuring that actions the higher brain has decided on go according to plan. As well as supervising the smooth running of the body through endless cycles of error correction, the cerebellum helps the brain and the body to learn from their mistakes and miscommunications. “The cerebellum does the same thing to emotion and cognition that it does for motor control,” says Jeremy Schmahmann, a neurologist at Harvard Medical School who focuses on the cerebellum. Just as physical movements are monitored, controlled and regulated by the cerebellum, so too, it turns out, are other sorts of thought, including speech and emotional work. The set of mental actions required to remain calm under pressure, for instance, runs through the cerebellum. All this takes place far below the threshold of consciousness. It is a sort of internalised automation, allowing process to go on in the background without any attention. You don’t know that you are doing it. But you would notice very quickly if you stopped. Ethan had his first brain scan in 2010, just after his 4th birthday. By this stage, his doctors had begun to suspect a damaged cerebellum. But that was not what the scan showed. His cerebellum was not damaged. It was absent; there was a featureless dark fluid-filled hole where the cerebellum would be. His brain—or his body, depending which way round you look at it—lacked an autopilot. This is one of our Christmas articles. To read the full remarkable story search "Team Ethan" at economist.com Credit: Logan Mock-Bunting #neurology #brain #science #USA

From @1843mag: Our fifth most popular image of 2018 was this painting, “One Second Before Awakening from a Dream Provoked by the Flight of a Bee Around a Pomegranate” (1944), by Salvador Dalí. The painting was inspired by a dream that his wife, Gala, recounted to him. In her dream, the bee has become a tiger, the bee sting a bayonet. Posing as Dalí’s model, Gala appears in hundreds of Dalí’s drawings and paintings. He was sexually fascinated by her but, by his own account, was afraid of sex. Image: Fundacio Gala-Salvador Dali #dali #gala #art #barcelona

Baijiu ("white liquor"), is the most-drunk spirit on earth, but less than one percent is consumed outside China. Chairman Mao called it China's "national liquor". Each year Chinese consumers spend three times more on baijiu than on beer and 15 times more than on wine. Today there are perhaps 10,000 baijiu distillers in China, producing 10bn litres each year, more than twice the annual global production of vodka, the next most popular spirit. Baijiu is a broad family of grain-based spirits selling for anything between a few dollars and a few thousand dollars per bottle. The primary ingredient is sorghum, or sometimes rice. In contrast to whisky or beer-making, these grains are fermented while solid. This requires them to be mixed with a fermenting agent and then heaped in mounds, packed in buried jars or sometimes sealed pits. The pungent product is distilled by heating in a still that operates like a steamer, to produce high-alcohol liquid. Production can take anything from a week up to nine months. The spirit is then aged in large ceramic jars. What results is a startling variety of products, commonly drunk above 50% proof. Photos taken in Chengdu, China, on September 20th 2016. This story is one of our Christmas features. For the full version search "Baijiu" at economist.com Credit: Bloomberg/Qilai Shen #China #liquor #baijiu

At the salon in Paris in 1857, Jean-François Millet exhibited a painting called "Des glaneuses" ("Gleaners"). It caused a scandal. Millet had long made a point of painting peasants at their labours, but this big canvas was his strongest provocation. Into a decorous world of silks and parasols it introduced rough women, plump in their homespun skirts, rumps in the air, grubbing for ears of grain dropped after the harvest. One critic complained of "ugliness and grossness unrelieved". Another said it made him think of the scaffolds and pikes of the Terror of 1793. Millet had seen the women differently. He found them dignified, doing their work in a sanctifying late-summer light, companions to his peasant "Angelus". In this, as well as their humble roughness, he caught the essence of gleaning. To begin with, it is not scavenging. To scavenge means to search for things that others have discarded, as children rummage for plastic bottles and phone parts on the rubbish tips of Delhi. Nor is gleaning foraging, which is to gather foodstuffs from the wild, as fashionable restaurateurs scramble for chanterelles and samphire. Nor is it scrumping, which is stealing, usually on a dare. Items which are gleaned are the good and usable fruit of human activity; they have not been discarded, merely overlooked, or thought not worth bothering with. This story is one of our Christmas features. For the full version search "Gleaning" at economist.com Credit: Bridgeman #gleaning #tradition #agriculture #countryside #Millet #art

From @1843mag: Our sixth most popular image of 2018 shows the interior design of the Concorde, the first – and still only – supersonic passenger aircraft, and possibly the only non-military aircraft to amass a cult following. With all of its 106 seats priced at first-class levels and its own dedicated lounge at the airports it served, the aircraft appealed to the business set of the 1970s. But although the check-in and waiting experience was luxurious, the aircraft itself had tiny windows, a low cabin ceiling and similar knee room to today’s economy class. Image: @british_airways #concorde  #supersonic  #aircraft  #travel  #lookcloser

From the 19th century, the three-toed Emu started to spread its flightless wings from its native Australia and became a prized oddity in zoos worldwide. A century on, the emu was also seen as a potential source of red meat, a healthier version of beef. It was in this guise, as livestock, that the emu came to Texas in the 1980s. It did not end well for most of the emus, or most of their owners. Enthusiasm and emu-friendly regulations saw the price of a breeding pair of emus, just a few hundred dollars in the late 1980s, rise to a whopping $28,000 by 1993. This is one of our Christmas articles. For the full version search "The great Texas emu bubble" at economist.com Credit: Alamy/Sean Burges and NaturePL/Owen Newman #emu #Texas #farming

Over the next two weeks, @1843mag will share our most popular images from 2018. This image, our tenth most popular of the year, shows whirling dervishes twirling, mimicking the circuit of blood through the body and the planets around the sun. To commemorate the Sufi poet Rumi’s “marriage to Allah”, his followers – and well-wishers from around the world – celebrate his “wedding night” with an unusual party every year in Konya, the Turkish city that houses his tomb. Drummers and a reed player set the pace, as dervishes, looking like brides in their demure white frocks, imitate the dance that Rumi taught them. Image: Robert Harding #rumi #sufism #whirlingdervishes #poetry #dance #turkey #travel #vautlevoyage

Queens is New York's second biggest borough and the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge is part of a 9,000-acre national park, America’s first to be located entirely within a city. It has a serene, whispering, undulating beauty made more wondrous by the flight paths above it, and the world famous skyline on the distant horizon. Manhattan has energy and money; Brooklyn has hipster cachet and old-world, brownstone beauty; the Bronx has pugnacity; Staten Island has apartness. Queens has no clear defining quality (and it is most definitely not hip, whatever the estate agents may tell you). But it has the vibrancy of a whole world. It is a place where people get on with things without the navel-gazing self-regard common in the rest of the city.And the people who do so come from all over the world.. Around 160 languages are spoken across the borough; residents hail from almost 200 countries. Nearly half its residents are foreign-born; most speak a language other than English at home. Few places can boast the linguistic, ethnic, religious and cultural diversity of Queens. It is possible that in no other place does such diversity work so well. To wander its streets is to walk through what makes America great. This is one of our Christmas articles. For the full version search "Queens" at economist.com Credits: Alamy and Getty Images #NewYork #USA #America #Queens #JamaicaBayWildlifeRefuge

The Falangcai Poppy Bowl is a little larger than a sugar bowl. The biscuit is fine and semi-translucent when held up to the light. It belongs to the most exclusive production of the Qing dynasty (1644-1912): made in Jingdezhen in the early 1700s, then sent to Beijing for finishing in palace workshops within the Forbidden City. In October 2018 it was sold by Sotheby's, an auction house, for 169m Hong Kong dollars (over $20m) to an Asian private collector. This story is one of our Christmas features. The end of the year is the one time when our cover design and our first leader part company. Our cover this week depicts a blue-and-white porcelain bauble decorated with a crane, an origami boat, a swimmer, an artist and much more— all feature in our double issue. Our first leader contemplates the uses of nostalgia. Politicians have always exploited the past but just now, rich countries and emerging economies are experiencing an orgy of reminiscence. Pessimism and nostalgia are powerful forces shaping today’s politics. To harness them, you must first understand them. #TheEconomist

Over the past few decades, the science of animal cognition has changed people’s understanding of other species. In several, researchers have discovered emotions, intelligence and behaviour once thought to belong exclusively to humans. But the law has changed slowly, and in one respect barely at all. Most legal systems, whether based on common law or civil codes, treat the subjects of law as either people or property. There is no third category. Legal persons possess rights—guaranteed protections. Property does not. Because domesticated animals are economic assets, the law has always regarded animals as property. Some lawyers and animal-rights advocates say the time has come to change that, arguing that it is justified both by science and by rising concerns about animal welfare. Opponents reply that to give animals rights would not only be unprecedented but, by erasing distinctions between them and people, would undermine something fundamental to being human. For years, people seeking to improve the lives of animals have sponsored animal-welfare laws. “The law is a patchwork,” says Kristen Stilt, who teaches animal law at Harvard Law School. Animals still lack rights, but the bright line separating them from people has been dulled by sentience laws and rulings in India, Argentina and Colombia. As a judge said, in a case brought on behalf of a chimpanzee in an American zoo, “the question will have to be addressed eventually... Should such a being be treated as a person or as property, in essence a thing?” For the full story search "Do they have rights" at economist.com Credit: Alamy #animals #law

From @1843mag: The number of self-inflicted injuries and fatalities in the name of attention-seeking is growing: between 2014 and 2018 more than 200 people worldwide died while taking a selfie. Joanne Orlando, a researcher in technology and learning at Western Sydney University, blames the mechanics of social media, which prize constant validation from others. Since people are more likely to comment on dynamic selfies than static ones, many are reluctant to upload anything that looks too ordinary. Algorithms on many platforms reinforce that tendency. If a particular pose or shot proves popular, then it is served up to more people. Other users, seeing its success, may try to match or outdo the stunt in order to be rewarded by that same process. From @1843mag: Philip Hamilton (@hamiltonunderwater), a seasoned underwater photographer, has spent the past five years seeking out the most striking sea creatures. His aim is to bring awareness to the deadly fate awaiting many marine animals thanks to warming waters and other environmental hazards. “A single photo can be the most powerful conservation tool,” he says. Here, he captures an Australian sea lion looking into the lens with imperious disdain, as if he has just been disturbed from his afternoon nap in the soft vegetation at the bottom of a clear ocean. It is an intimate portrait, the apparent perfection of his sleek fur and well-groomed whiskers conjuring an image of a retired colonel. According to the Seal Conservation Society, there are an estimated 10,000-12,000 Australian sea lions remaining in the world, a number that may be declining. From @1843mag: This is the age of the trainer – or, as so many more people on the planet call it, the sneaker. What was created in the 19th century as a rubber-soled, simply uppered form of footwear named “sand shoes” or “plimsolls” has evolved in the 21st into a product of fantastic variety upon which hundreds of millions of people spend tens of billions of pounds a year. The Nike Dunk Low SB is one of the 21st century’s most-collected and -coveted sneaker designs. In 2005 the Pigeon edition sparked a minor riot in Manhattan when it was released in limited numbers, making the front page of the New York Post. The edition pictured here is the eBay Dunk; it is one of just two pairs ever made. It was named after eBay because it was auctioned on the website, reaching a price of $26,000. The other pair, this sample, was chainsawed into pieces to ensure the uniqueness of the sold-off lot. To discover how a simple shoe became an emblem of cool style, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #trainer #sneaker #shoes #ebaydunk #style #lookcloser

From @1843mag: “I have always been attracted to trees,” says @stefano_boeri, an Italian architect who completed what he calls the world’s first vertical forest in central Milan in 2014, pictured here. The two residential towers are planted with 800 trees, 4,500 shrubs and 15,000 plants spilling over ceramic terraces, a ravishing billboard of urban forestry. These buildings, along with other projects such as a passenger lounge in Shanghai’s Pudong Airport that was inspired by a dense jungle canopy, are part of his mission to soften up our cities (and do his bit in the fight against climate change). “It changes every day, changes every season,” he says of the vertical forest, “creating an explosion of colour.” To learn more about the surprising growth in popularity of foliage as a design element, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #verticalforest #buildings #cities #trees #foliage #green #nature #design

At least robots cannot grow beards. Temporary summer jobs, many of them in agriculture, are often taken by migrants who return home afterwards. Temporary winter jobs, by contrast, more often go to locals. The difference is in part because winter work usually requires language skills and is less likely to be covered by special visa schemes, says Andrew Chamberlain of Glassdoor, an employer-review site. Which points to a merry Christmas for job-seeking Americans. But the tight jobs market is speeding up a longer-run trend, which may in time flatten seasonal spikes in demand for labour. That is automation. Amazon is ahead of the pack here, too. It is hiring 20,000 fewer workers in America this winter compared with last year, which Mark May, an analyst at Citigroup, attributes to greater use of robots in the retail giant’s fulfilment centres. Since many retail and delivery tasks are ripe for automation, this trend could terminate swathes of holiday jobs. That would make the season less of a scramble for employers. But the economy as a whole could lose out in a less obvious way. Many people need extra cash over Christmas, and the annual hiring binge means they can easily find work. Some decide to continue, even if that had not been the original plan. UPS says that it ends up hiring a third of its seasonal package-handlers for permanent jobs. Holiday work thus acts as a path from economic inactivity into the labour force.  For the full story search "Spirit of Christmas yet to come" at economist.com Credit: Reuters/Mark Makela #SantaClause #FatherChristmas #shopping #retail #USA #America #Christmas

We have two covers this week. Outside Britain we look at family offices, the personal investment firms that roam global markets rooting out opportunities for their super-rich owners. Largely unnoticed, family offices have become a force in investing, with up to $4trn of assets—more than hedge funds and equivalent to 6% of the value of the world’s stockmarkets. As they grow bigger in an era of populism, their gilded patrons are sleepwalking into a political storm

In Britain we look at the fallout from the coup attempt against the prime minister over her plan for Brexit. Theresa May has seen off the hardliners, but the scale of their rebellion has demonstrated that she has no realistic hope of getting her Brexit agreement through Parliament. And it is not just her plan: none of the possible Brexits commands a majority in Westminster. Mrs May needs to recognise that she and the country have only one way out of this impasse. That is to go over the heads of MPs and ask the people directly. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: In 1770 a chess-playing robot, built by a Hungarian inventor, caused a sensation across Europe. It took the form of a life-size wooden figure, dressed in Turkish clothing, seated behind a cabinet which had a chessboard on top. The Mechanical Turk’s clockwork arm could reach out, move pieces on the board and beat even the best players at chess. But this apparently intelligent machine actually depended on a human chess player cleverly concealed in its innards. It turns out that something very similar is happening today. Just like the Turk, modern artificial-intelligence (AI) systems rely on help from unseen humans. Training a “deep learning” system involves showing it millions of examples of an input (such as photographs of animals) and telling it what the correct output is (“cat”, “dog”) in each case. Once trained, the system can then correctly identify animals in pictures it has not seen before. But the training process requires huge numbers of correctly labelled examples – and those must be created by humans. To find out why an 18th-century conjuring trick helps explain how humans interact with modern technology, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: When Maximilian Büsser decided seven years ago to create his first table clock, he was inspired by the space-age toys of his childhood in the 1970s. Every year, the company he founded, @mbandf, launches an inventively designed timekeeper in collaboration with the French and Swiss clockmaker, L’Epée 1839. The most controversial piece in MB&F’s armoury is Arachnophobia, a giant spider containing an eight-day movement in a linear arrangement, with the clockwork set in the arachnid’s heady and body. Inspired by “Maman”, a huge spider sculpture created by artist Louise Bourgeois in 1999, Büsser says Arachnophobia represents his personal fascination with irrational fears: “I wanted to create a cross between real and mechanical and it has created more reaction than any other piece I have made”. From @1843mag: Street photography is an art form that requires the photographer to be both invisible and confrontational. This image was taken by Vivian Maier, a nanny by profession and amateur photographer active during the mid-20th century. It is arresting not only for its vivid colours – a greying lady gussied up in a cherry-red coat and hat; the canary-yellow lines of the streetscape – but also for the withering look the woman appears to be giving Maier. Most of Maier’s subjects are oblivious to her snooping. This one is unsettlingly wise to it. From @1843mag: Twenty years ago, no Chinese meeting began without a solemn, two-handed exchange of business cards. But in Beijing today every professional and private task leads eventually to WeChat, an all- purpose, all-seeing, Chinese messaging app. For foreign users, WeChat feels like Twitter, email, Facebook, text-messaging service and contactless debit card, all rolled into one. Any encounter that is likely to be repeated involves an exchange of WeChat contacts, achieved by one smartphone scanning a QR code generated by another. Users often represent themselves on the platform with semi-anonymous, whimsical avatars of animals – meaning you could be chatting with a hairy ginger cat to find out how much income tax you owe, or Officer Judy Hopps, the police-bunny from “Zootopia”, a Disney film, to schedule an interview with China’s president, Xi Jinping. Cuteness aside, WeChat’s blending of the private and public is disconcerting, as our correspondent discovered. To read more, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. We have two covers this week, swipe to see both. 
In Britain, as Parliament steels itself for a vote on Theresa May’s plan for leaving the European Union, we set out the best way to cope with the problem that no version of Brexit is likely to command a majority. Many argue that MPs must vote for what they believe to be a damaging plan, out of respect for the referendum. They are wrong. It is far from clear that Mrs May’s plan reflects the will of the people. It breaks many of her own negotiating red lines, never mind the promises made by referendum campaigns. The government has largely given up arguing that its deal will be good for the country, instead insisting that it is what democracy demands. Yet no one can claim to intuit what the people want. The only way to know is to ask them in a second referendum.

In our other editions we analyse the crisis engulfing France’s president, Emmanuel Macron. His election in May 2017 seemed to herald new optimism about France, Europe and the world. In office he has reformed labour markets, training and education. Yet along the way, Mr Macron forgot that democracy requires the constant forging of consent. This week, as yellow-jacketed protesters rioted in Paris and blocked fuel depots and roads in the countryside, France looked unreformable. It is depressingly easy to conclude that have-your-cake-and-eat-it populism will always triumph over reform, but all is not lost for Mr Macron. The right policies, the right politics and, above all, a dose of humility could yet save his presidency. #TheEconomist

Lucianah Nyawira, a 21-year-old Kenyan, participates in "Mr & Miss Albinism East Africa", a contest organised by the Albinism Society of Kenya to promote social inclusion and raise the self-esteem of albinos. Ms Nyawira was born with this genetic condition, in which people lack pigments in their skin, hair and eyes. The condition affects one in 20,000 people worldwide and is more common in Africa. Albinos’ pale skin is easily burned by the sun, and makes them vulnerable to skin cancers. Further, because their eyes are sensitive to harsh light, most albinos suffer from poor vision. Albino's also experience prejudice in society; children are bullied in school, adults struggle to find work. Albino women are at higher risk of rape because of a myth that sex with an albino can cure HIV. Photo taken in Nairobi, Kenya on November 30th 2018. People pay their last respects to former President George H.W. Bush as he lies in state at the Capitol in Washington on December 4th 2018. His forte, and first love, was foreign policy. Instinctively, he thought in terms of global power games; fortuitously, his time as president coincided with the end of the cold war, a heady and fascinating moment. With Mikhail Gorbachev he struck up an easy working friendship, and in 1991, in the wake of the Gulf war, he even had a moment of comprehensive vision: a new world order, based not on force but on the rule of law, which America would strongly lead. From @1843mag: As the space race was heating up in the late 1950s, scientists from NASA were charged with finding a watch that would survive the extreme conditions of space travel. Rather than develop one from scratch, a NASA technician walked incognito into a shop in Houston, bought a series of chronographs – watches that display time and can also be used as a stopwatch – and took them back for the agency to test them. NASA subjected each timepiece to extreme temperatures, shocks, vibrations, humidity, acceleration and high pressure. One passed every test: the @omega Speedmaster, launched in 1957 (renamed the Speedmaster Professional in 1966). It remains NASA’s watch of choice for space missions and one of Omega’s most popular lines: the brand has created more than 100 different special editions, sold under catchy names like “Dark Side of the Moon” (pictured here). From @1843mag: On a crowded pier in San Francisco, sandwiched between a shop selling clothes for “urban cowboys” and one selling merchandise for the local basketball team, is Lefty’s, one of the last remaining shops for left-handed people. A shop that caters to just 10% of the population is never going to make a lot of money, especially when left-handed can-openers and notebooks can be found in a couple of clicks on Amazon. But no website can capture the technicolour wonderland that Lefty’s packs into its tiny square-footage. Inside, posters with the names of famous lefties, such as Barack Obama and Paul McCartney, line the walls, and you can buy left-handed scissors and “no-smudge” pens. Lefty’s encourages its clientele to celebrate their unusual dexterity – a far cry from past decades, when left-handers in America and Europe were frequently mocked by school teachers or forced to write with their right hands. To find out why American lefties have never had it so good, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: James Wilson and Aryn Braun #lefthanded #sanfrancisco #leftys

Few people go into teaching for the money. In most countries, teachers earn less than similarly well-educated workers in other professions. Various reasons are suggested for this, such as job security, parent-friendly working hours and generous pensions. Another possible reason is their workload: the last lesson of the day often ends by mid-afternoon and teachers benefit from the long holidays granted to their students. However, they also toil outside the classroom, preparing for lessons, marking homework and being harangued by pushy parents. In a recent survey across 35 countries conducted by the Varkey Foundation, an education charity that favours higher status for teachers, the average respondent among 35,000 adults estimated that teachers worked 39 hours per week. Yet the average teacher among 5,500 surveyed claimed to work 43.

Despite underestimating teachers’ workload, people still think they are underpaid. In 28 of the 35 countries surveyed, teachers make less than the public deems fair. The average respondent said that a fair wage would be 31% more than teachers actually earn. However, not everyone who tells a pollster that pedagogues should be more generously paid will vote for higher taxes to make that easier. Nor will many parents cheer the idea of larger classes, which would also make it easier to pay teachers more. #data #chart #teaching #education

From @1843mag: Ashurbanipal, self-styled “king of the world”, ruled Assyria from 669 to 631 BC. The breadth and diversity of his empire demanded extensive infrastructure and efficient bureaucracy, so he created a “Royal Mail” service. This meant information could be dispatched quickly and effectively between officials in command of the empire’s various states. These officials, known as “magnates”, were often eunuchs who had submitted to castration to prove that they prized loyalty to the king over continuing their bloodline. The beardless features of this official – the mark of a eunuch – shows that he belonged to this elite group. To see more art from the court of Ashurbanipal, the last great ruler of the Assyrian empire, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #ashurbanipal #assyria #history #lookcloser

Around the world, suicide rates are falling as a result of urbanisation, greater freedom and some helpful policies. America is the notable exception: since 2000, its suicide rate has risen by 18%, compared with a 29% drop in the world as a whole. It could learn from the progress made elsewhere, and more lives could be saved globally with better health services, labour-market policies and curbs on booze, guns, pesticides and pills.

It is time to debunk the last and most dangerous of the Brexit fantasies: the idea that, if all else fails, Britain can prosper outside the European Union without signing an exit deal. The reality is that "no deal" amounts to a very bad deal that would cause chaos and affect daily life like nothing outside wartime. So far the decision to leave the EU has slowed Britain down, rather than derailing it, but a no-deal exit could result in a wreck. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: From afar, a pangolin looks like a dinosaur, the living face of the Cretaceous period. And like the rough-scaled creatures it resembles, pangolins could soon become extinct: their evolutionary position as the earth’s only scaly mammal has turned them into the most trafficked type of animal in the world. A global network of some 160 international smuggling routes funnels hundreds of tonnes of animals and scales, many of them to China. There, pangolin scales are used in traditional medicine: the state supplies 26 tonnes of scales to hospitals each year, and scales can legally be bought in pharmacies. Others see pangolin as a culinary delicacy. In Vietnam and elsewhere too, the pangolin is a sought-after beast. Attempts to breed pangolins in captivity rarely succeed – but Save Vietnam’s Wildlife, an NGO, is determined to save the species from extinction. To read our correspondent’s dispatch from a refuge for pangolins in Vietnam, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @getty #pangolin #mammal #endangered #dispatch

From @1843mag: At 31 years old, Robert Icke is Britain’s most radical and exciting young theatre director. Since 2013 he has been associate director of the @almeida_theatre in London, where he has made his name with a series of revelatory adaptations of classic plays, including “Hamlet”, “Uncle Vanya” and the “Oresteia”. He has dedicated himself to upturning convention: it irks him, he says, that so much lazy, derivative theatre goes unchallenged. Icke’s audacious staging, from the stripped-back minimalism of “Mary Stuart” to the CCTV footage that provided the backdrop to “Hamlet”, and his willingness to rewrite texts, no matter how revered their authors, has led one reviewer to characterise his plays as “dyno-rod theatre, blasting open clogged pipes to show how galvanising staple theatrical plots can be”. At the height of a devastating drugs epidemic in the 1990s, authorities estimated that about 100,000 Portuguese, or 1% of the population, were heroin users. But since 2001, when Portugal decriminalised most drug use, the number of addicts has plummeted. Under this law, illegal drugs remain illegal and dealers are prosecuted. But possession for personal use is an administrative offence, not a criminal one. Anyone caught with a 10-day supply or less is ordered to visit the local Commission for Dissuasion of Drug Addiction. Rehabilitation programmes and opiate substitutes, such as methadone, are available to all users who want to quit. The number of problem heroin users has since fallen to about 33,000. The government can claim only partial credit; drug epidemics tend to fizzle. But decriminalisation and treatment helped cut Portugal’s overdose rate to one of the lowest in Europe. As for America, in 2016 it had 63,600 fatal overdoses. In Portugal there were 27. To read more about why harm reduction is the right way to treat drug abuse, search "Chill pill" at economist.com #drugabuse #addiction #Portugal #Europe

From @1843mag: Mickey Mouse was born in November 1928, when Walt Disney needed to come up with a new character after his previous animated hero – Oswald the Lucky Rabbit – had been effectively stolen from him by unscrupulous distributors. Legend has it that Mickey was inspired by a mouse that had scurried into his study some years earlier. By the 1950s, Mickey was a veritable media sensation, with films, comic strips, television programmes, merchandise and even amusement parks to his name. In 1953, to mark his quarter-century, Mickey’s official portraitist, John Hench, painted this perky picture, which expresses the character’s unique personality. As Disney described him, “We thought of a tiny bit of a mouse that would have something of the wistfulness of [Charlie] Chaplin, a little fellow trying to do the best he could”. From @1843mag: As the French first lady, Brigitte Macron has won admirers and managed to keep them. While Emmanuel Macron’s approval rating as president sunk to 34% in August this year, down from 66% when elected, that of his wife remained at a healthy 67%. She seems to appeal in particular to the young and the over-65s. When the first lady visited a lycée in Dijon earlier this year, one observer described the reaction of the pupils as “quasi-hysterical”. Celebrity magazines have dubbed the phenomenon “Bibimania”. But unlike in America, where the current First Lady Melania Trump is under constant scrutiny for her perceived inability to meet the demands of her role, the position of the French first lady comes with no particular expectation: “I don’t feel like a first lady,” Macron told “Elle” magazine last year, considering the term to be merely “the translation of an American expression”. Capitalism has a real problem, we argue—just not the one that protectionists and populists like to talk about. Life has become far too comfortable for some firms in the old economy, and in the new economy, tech giants have amassed formidable market power. A revolution is needed to unleash competition, force down abnormally high profits and ensure that innovation can thrive. A competition revolution could also help restore the public's faith in capitalism.

In Britain we consider the beginning of the Brexit endgame, now that a draft divorce deal has been agreed on between Britain and the European Union. It has prompted several ministerial resignations, and getting it through Parliament looks like a tall order. Having spent the past two years arguing about the national interest, politicians must now decide where they think it lies. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Within any single country, the rules dictating what constitutes an appropriate breakfast are far clearer than those that define lunch or dinner. Mention bacon and eggs in Britain and few will doubt that you are describing breakfast. A French person would sneer at the thought of eating a croissant at any time other than morning. The conservatism of breakfast is all the more striking given the way in which people devour foreign dishes at other times of day. Londoners eat Japanese sushi for lunch, Indian curries for dinner and Turkish kebabs when drunk and ravenous; New Yorkers enjoy everything from ferocious Laotian larb to Ethiopian injera. So why are most people less hungry for foreign flavours in the morning? From @1843mag: Edward Burne-Jones believed that art had no greater moral purpose than to find out what is beautiful. No matter his source material – the Pre-Raphaelite found inspiration in medieval legend, Greek myth, timeless fairy tales and biblical stories – beautiful women remained one of his favourite subjects to draw and paint. Here, he sketches Amorous Desire from Edmund Spenser’s “The Faerie Queen” with softly sensuous features – ruffled hair, puckered lips and a long exposed neck. The gentle application of shadow enhances the defined bone structure that makes so many of his female figures striking and instantly recognisable as his own. There have been 119 murders in London this year. That is about the same as the number killed in the whole of 2017, excluding terrorist attacks. Four in ten victims were 24 years old or younger. The media has good reason to pay close attention to murders in the city. Stabbings are far more common in London than anywhere else in the country, and not only because it is so much bigger: it sees more violence per person than less populous areas do. Yet the biggest increases in knife crime have been outside London (see chart). Since 2010-11 it has risen by a tenth there, and by a third in the rest of England and Wales. During the same period, knife crime leapt more sharply than the national average in the patches around Sheffield, Leeds and Liverpool. The number of stabbings began to tick up in North Wales, Norfolk and Essex well before they did in London. What explains the rise? Labour blames spending cuts: the number of police officers has fallen by 15% since 2010. Another plausible explanation is a shift in the drugs market. A boom in the supply of crack cocaine has encouraged city gangsters to expand into towns once dominated by small-time dealers. Competition has sparked violent turf wars. #data #chart #knifecrime #London

From @1843mag: Following the vote to leave the European Union, Britain – or parts of it anyway – is going through the stages of grief. While the prime minister is bargaining, and many members of parliament are in denial, millions of Britons are still angry. Last month a march through London calling for a new referendum attracted 700,000 placard-wielding Remainers. But the sort of protest 1843’s correspondent found himself at last Thursday was much smaller and more intimate. Helen Masacz, an artist with an impish streak of humour, had invited the public to deface her portrait of Boris Johnson, the country’s most prominent Brexit-supporting politician, at the opening night of an exhibition at a gallery located on London’s ritzy Pall Mall. Masacz first exhibited the portrait in 2010, when her subject was London’s broadly popular mayor. By the time the painting was returned to her, the artist found that her opinion of Johnson had changed, as had that of many other Britons. So, rather than letting him be immortalised as a statesman on canvas, she invited others to add to the portrait. Capitalism has a real problem, we argue—just not the one that protectionists and populists like to talk about. Life has become far too comfortable for some firms in the old economy, and in the new economy, tech giants have amassed formidable market power. A revolution is needed to unleash competition, force down abnormally high profits and ensure that innovation can thrive. A competition revolution could also help restore the public's faith in capitalism.

In Britain we consider the beginning of the Brexit endgame, now that a draft divorce deal has been agreed on between Britain and the European Union. It has prompted several ministerial resignations, and getting it through Parliament looks like a tall order. Having spent the past two years arguing about the national interest, politicians must now decide where they think it lies. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Modernist art was frequently nurtured through intimate collaboration – as the poet Federico García Lorca and the Surrealist artist Salvador Dalí prove. Lovers between 1925 and 1928, they were ardent supporters of each other’s work. Perhaps it was the confidence that came from this support that allowed them each to explore the other’s discipline. Dalí dabbled in poetry; Lorca became a draughtsman, producing wildly imaginative ramblings that respond to the work of Dalí. From @1843mag: You may think that sipping from a tall flute is the most elegant way to drink champagne. But according to Gérard Liger-Belair, a physicist and “bubble-ologist” at the University of Reims, the flute’s iconic shape causes a build-up of carbon dioxide in the headspace of the glass that interferes with the process of nosing. If you really want to get the full aroma of a champagne, he says, then you’re better off drinking out of a white-wine glass. It also helps if the glasses haven’t been cleaned too well; the fibres cast off from paper and cloth create the tiny air pockets that bubbles need to form. If you poured champagne into a glass that was surgically clean, it wouldn’t bubble at all. To learn more about the surprising science behind champagne’s famous fizz, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @getty #champagne #flute #glass #drink #taste

From @1843mag: In “Casino Royale”, the first of Ian Fleming’s Bond books, James Bond meets Felix Leiter, a CIA operative, in the casino bar. After ordering Leiter’s scotch, Bond “looked carefully at the barman. ‘A dry martini,’ he said. ‘One. In a deep champagne goblet…Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large, thin slice of lemon peel.” The following night, Bond named the martini Vesper, after the woman he had just met and would soon love. It’s an early example of the attention to detail and undiluted glamour that gave Fleming’s books their cinematic feel. The international intrigue speaks for itself: how could being a dapper, globetrotting spy fail to excite? And cocktails were key to Bond’s image – and his allure. Democracy in Latin America is in trouble. That is the message of this year’s survey of opinion in 18 countries by Latinobarómetro, a pollster based in Santiago, Chile. The proportion of people who are dissatisfied with how democracy works has jumped from 51% in 2009 to 71%. The share that is content has dropped from 44% to 24%, its lowest level since the survey began more than two decades ago. That does not mean most Latin Americans are ready to dump democracy, which has become the norm across the region only since the 1980s. More than half say that it is better than any other system, though that has dropped by 13 percentage points over the past eight years. Disillusioned democrats lean towards indifference. The share who are neutral has risen from 16% in 2010 to 28%, while support for authoritarian government is steady, at about 15%. “People don’t like the democracy they are experiencing,” says Marta Lagos, the head of Latinobarómetro. In Latin America’s two biggest countries, Brazil and Mexico, that sentiment has resulted in the election of presidents this year who until recently would have been widely considered too radical to lead their countries. If disillusionment deepens, future elections could bring presidents who test the region’s democratic norms. #data #chart #Brazil #Mexico #Latinobarometro

On our cover this week we look at what the outcome of the mid-term elections means for American politics. A starkly divided country now has a divided government.  Democratic control of the House of Representatives will provide some welcome oversight of the White House. But behind the results is a structural shift that will make the country harder to govern for the foreseeable future. Thanks to their strength in cities and suburbs, Democrats represent a majority of America’s voters. Republicans dominate geographically, having tightened their grip on less populous, more rural states. In a country where one chamber of the legislature is based on population and the other on territory, this division is a recipe for gridlock, poor governance and, eventually, disenchantment with the political system itself. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Alfred the Great is one of England’s most famous monarchs, known as much for his military prowess as his commitment to educating his people. This tear-shaped rock crystal, inlaid with enamel and encased in glimmering gold, is a fitting testament to Alfred’s love of literature and learning. Known as the Alfred Jewel, it is inscribed with the words AELFRED MEC HEHT GEWYRCAN – or, in modern English, “Alfred ordered me to be made”. Historians believe it formed the bulbous end of an aestel, a device used to follow along with a text while reading. The dragon-shaped head has a hole for its “mouth”, into which an narrow ivory stick would have been placed to point with. From @1843mag: At the height of the Renaissance, Michelangelo, the most famous sculptor in the world, received a secret invitation from the Ottoman sultan to travel to Constantinople. The sultan wanted him to design a bridge over the Bosphorus to unite Europe with Asia, and promised the artist an extravagant sum. Michelangelo was intrigued by the challenge, not least because his rival, Leonardo da Vinci, had earlier presented his own design for the bridge, which had been judged a failure. In 1506 he disembarked in the Ottoman capital; the city drew him in immediately. In a short but magical novel, “Tell Them of Battles, Kings and Elephants”, Mathias Enard conjures up Michelangelo’s love affair with Constantinople. From @1843mag: You are what you eat. The atoms in your body come from the food and drink you consume – and, to some extent, from the air you breathe. That is not terribly surprising. What few people realise, however, is that about half the nitrogen atoms in your body have passed through something called a Haber-Bosch reaction. This chemical process, invented just before the first world war, did as much to change the world during the 20th century as the atom bomb or the microchip. Its story deserves to be more widely known, not just because it revolutionised agriculture but because it offers hope today for a fight whose front line is fast approaching: the battle against climate change. To find out more about the Haber-Bosch process and why it should give us confidence that we can fight climate change, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: Kaii Higashiyama captivated post-war Japan with his landscapes done in nihonga (traditional Japanese) style; in the 1960s the Yokohama-born painter was Japan’s most celebrated artist. Simple images such as a lone horse amid trees, or a road leading into the distance, often painted solely in hues of blue, oozed serenity in the wake of war. They evoke a spiritual sensation by encouraging the onlooker to pause and contemplate nature’s beauty – little wonder his work adorns the walls of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo and Toshodai-ji temple in Nara. Visitors can see what all the fuss is about at the National Art Centre, which is holding a retrospective of his work until December 3rd. Our cover this week looks at what is at stake in America’s mid-term elections on November 6th. The country is more divided and angry than it has been in decades. Politicians routinely treat each other as rogues, fools or traitors; pipe bombs and a mass-shooting at a synagogue have tainted the close of the campaign. Toxic federal politics prevents action on vital issues, from immigration to welfare; it erodes Americans’ faith in their government; and it dims the beacon of American democracy abroad. The mid-term elections are a chance to stop the rot—and even to begin the arduous task of restoring faith. #TheEconomist

On October 31st 2018 the Pakistani Supreme Court overturned the verdict of the lower courts and acquitted Asia Bibi of blasphemy, an offence punishable by death. In 2009 Asia Bibi, a member of Pakistan's tiny Christian minority, was labouring alongside Muslim women in a field. It was hot and they were thirsty so she went to fetch water from a well. Before handing the jug to her companions she took a sip. Being of a different faith, she should have waited to drink last from a shared vessel. The fallout from that momentary lapse has been nine years facing execution, locked up in a windowless cell away from her four children. Salman Taseer and Shahbaz Bhatti, two politicians who had dared to speak in her defence, were murdered in 2011.  In this photo, taken on October 12th 2018, supporters of  Tehreek-e-Labbaik, a political party formed by supporters of the murderer of Mr Taseer, march through Karachi demanding Ms Asia's death. Credit: AP/Fareed Khan #Pakistan #humanrights #AsiaBibi

The Capitol at daybreak in Washington, DC. The mid-term elections are just over a week away. Our mathematical model of the race calculates that the Democrats’ most likely share of votes cast for House candidates (excluding third parties, and adjusting for districts where candidates run unopposed) is just over 54%. That would be a bigger opposition-party wave than those of 1994, 2006, 2010 and 2014, and fall just short of 2008, when voters pummelled Republicans during the financial crisis. It is consistent with a narrow Democratic House majority, of around 12 seats. Nonetheless, a takeover is far from assured. Thanks to gerrymandering and to the concentration of Democratic voters in big cities, the Democrats need to win about 53.5% of the vote—roughly their margin in their wave of 2006—just to exceed a 50/50 chance of taking control. Photo taken on October 26th 2018. Credit: AP/Alex Brandon #silhouette #dawn #WashingtonDC #USA

From @1843mag: As you hit adolescence, clothes help you find your tribe and grow into yourself. But some 21st-century teenagers prefer virtual outfits to a pair of Levi’s and Dr. Martens. 125m people around the world play Fortnite, a video game that is just over a year old. Although Fortnite is free to download, its developer is making more than $100m in revenue every month in “micro-transactions” – including “skins”, or outfits, for your avatar. Each “skin” affords its own level of status. The coolest right now is a sleek black suit based on the one worn by action protagonist John Wick, played by Keanu Reeves. Perhaps youth-tilted fashion business shouldn’t bother advertising via Instagram influencers or sports-star sponsorship deals. They should just get themselves a skin on Fortnite Island instead. From @1843mag: Throughout art history, women in creative partnerships with men have been relegated to the position of muse, imitator or domestic support. Gustav Klimt had many female muses whom he immortalised in his lavish, gold-leafed portraits. But his interest in ornamentation was inspired by his long relationship with the fashion designer Emilie Flöge. Klimt’s sideline was fashion photography and he often took pictures of Flöge in her latest designs, which included reform dress, the loose-fitting fashions favoured by modern, liberated women. Despite Klimt’s endless affairs – he fathered six children with three different women – Flöge and Klimt continued their professional and personal collaboration until his death in 1918. To see more images of modern artistic couples and their labours of love, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #klimt #moderncouples #art #lookcloser @barbicancentre

From @1843mag: “An ‘Esquire’ cover of me drowning in a can of Campbell’s soup? I love it!” Andy Warhol told the magazine’s art director, George Lois. The Sixties were the heyday of both ‘Esquire’ and pop art, the movement which made Warhol famous. Lois, who is said to have been the inspiration for Don Draper, the protagonist of “Mad Men”, was dismissive of pop art and, when ‘Esquire’ did a story about it, designed a spoof cover. He later said of his design that “you could look at it as just funny or…as how fame swallows people.” In those pre-computer days, the photo effect was achieved by dropping marbles into the soup to create a hole filled with a cut-out of Warhol. “When we put Andy into the soup, we almost lost him,” Lois drily remarked. To read about the stories behind other creative magazine covers, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #warhol #esquire #madmen #coverstories #lookcloser

From @1843mag: Rest easy: “Dogman” is not another superhero movie, but an Italian low-life tragicomedy from Matteo Garrone, the director of “Gomorrah”. Its hapless anti-hero is Marcello, a scrawny dog-groomer who is stuck in a desolate concrete suburb on the edge of Rome but who is happily devoted to his daughter and canine customers. The trouble is that he’s also devoted to Simoncino, a neighbourhood thug with fists the size of boxing gloves and a head that looks like it’s made of breezeblocks. Marcello supplies him with cocaine and drives his getaway car but gets nothing but bullying in return. Still, no dog can be kicked for ever without eventually biting his owner. British audiences can head to theatres starting today to find out if Marcello rebels against the hulking sociopath who holds his leash. Our cover this week holds out Australia as an example for the world. Rising incomes, low public debt, an affordable welfare state, popular support for mass immigration and a broad political consensus: in most of the rich world such blessings are a distant dream, in Australia they are a proud reality. The country has been growing for 27 years without a recession. The public finances are in excellent long-term shape. Half of Australians are either immigrants or the children of immigrants. What is Australia’s secret? #TheEconomist

Salah bin Jamal, son of Jamal Khashoggi, the 59-year-old Saudi journalist murdered at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul earlier this month, meets Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on October 23rd 2018. King Salman and the Crown Prince reportedly offered their condolences on the death of Mr Khashoggi. The meeting took place at the royal palace in Riyadh on the same day that Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, gave a speech setting out some of the evidence his security forces have gathered. He stated that the "savage" murder was premeditated and organised by senior Saudi officials. Turkish investigators have released the names and photos of 15 Saudis flown to Istanbul on private jets hours before Mr Khashoggi entered the mission. They included spies, special-forces officers and a coroner. Mr Erdogan called for the perpetrators to be returned to Turkey for trial. For more search "The kingdom and the cover-up" on economist.com. Credit: Saudi Press Agency/AFP #JamalKhashoggi #SaudiArabia #Turkey

An ancient Greek trading ship dating back more than 2,400 years has been found virtually intact at the bottom of the Black Sea, off the Bulgarian coast. The 23-metre vessel dates back to around 400 BC and is being hailed as the world's oldest known intact shipwreck. It is one of more than 60 identified by the Black Sea Maritime Archaeology Project, including Roman ships and a 17th-century Cossack raiding fleet. The vessel was one of many trading between the Mediterranean and Greek colonies on the Black Sea coast. Photo released on October 23rd 2018. From @1843mag: In the Australian television drama “Safe Harbour”, five wealthy, beautiful white Aussies are on a yachting holiday in the Timor Sea when they chance upon a sinking boat full of people desperate to start new lives. The holiday-makers face a difficult dilemma: tow the boat to safety and risk having both vessels sink, or summon the authorities, who might deport the asylum-seekers? They vote in favour of the first option. But in the night someone cuts the rope connecting the two boats. Questions abound. Who was responsible? Why did they do it? And what happens when, years later, the captain of the yacht gets into a taxi-cab driven by an asylum-seeker who survived? From @1843mag: Women across continents, centuries and cultures have taken up weaving at home or in factories in order to earn pocket money or contribute to the household finances. Rarely was the practical task of textile creation considered an artistic pursuit. One woman changed that. Anni Albers, a German artist who studied at the Bauhaus art-and-design school, transformed the ancient craft of weaving into a Modernist art form by proving that woven textiles were just as relevant to high art as they were to everyday design. Her experiments with colour, material and form changed textile design forever – but despite Albers’s artistic contributions, she remained less well known than her male Bauhaus peers. A new retrospective exhibition at the Tate Modern in London recognises her for the visionary she was. To view some of her colourful, geometric textile designs, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Helen M. Post, Western Regional Archives, State Archives of North Carolina #annialbers #bauhaus #modernism #art #lookcloser @tate

In the past 12 months, the hashtag “#MeToo” has been tweeted 18m times according to Keyhole, a social-media analytics company. The phrase has come to encapsulate the idea that sexual misconduct and assault are underreported. Yet surveys suggest that this year-long storm of allegations, confessions and firings has actually made Americans more sceptical about sexual harassment. In the first week of November 2017, YouGov polled 1,500 Americans about their attitudes on the matter, on behalf of The Economist (swipe to see data for each survey question). In the final week of September 2018, it conducted a similar poll again. When it came to questions about the consequences of sexual assault and misconduct, there was a small but clear shift against victims. The change of opinion has been more pronounced among women than among men. But rather than breaking along gender lines, the #MeToo divide increasingly appears to be a party-political one. One effect of the fight over Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court may have been to turn #MeToo into yet another issue pitting Republicans against Democrats. On each of these three questions, the gap between Trump and Clinton voters in percentage points is at least six times greater than the one between men and women. #data #infographic #survey

From @1843mag: This week marked one year since Daphne Caruana Galizia, a Maltese journalist, was murdered by a bomb that exploded beneath the driver’s seat of her car. She founded a blog called Running Commentary, which covered the darker side of Maltese politics. The term “blog” undersells its influence. On a good day, her website received 300,000 visits – the population of Malta is under 450,000. Running Commentary made Caruana Galizia not just a household name but something of a celebrity. People noticed her when she took her three sons to school, her dog for a walk, or went to her sister’s house in the evening; her words were sprayed on city walls. She became part of the fabric of Maltese life – until October 16th 2017, when it was all over in a flash. To read about the investigation into Caruana Galizia’s mysterious death, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @gettyimages #daphnecaruanagalizia #malta #features

Canada has become the second country to make the sale and use of recreational marijuana legal (Uruguay made recreational cannabis legal in 2013). On October 17th 2018 the new law came into effect. There are restrictions on how much marijuana can be carried in public and how much cannabis can be grown. Penalties for exceeding these limits, buying from an unlicensed dealer or unlicensed dealing will be severe. Over the next year, edible cannabis products will gradually be approved for sale through approved outlets. Medical marijuana was legalised for Canadians in 2001.

One year ago today, a man broke into Daphne Caruana Galizia's car. He placed a bomb under the driver's seat, relocked the door and walked away. When Ms Caruana Galizia, Malta’s most intrepid and controversial journalist, drove away from her home the bomb was remotely detonated. One of her sons saw his mother's car explode. When he ran to the site where the little rented Peugeot had landed, 80 metres from the road, he found twisted metal and body parts. Ms Caruana Galizia had been writing about Maltese political corruption and acquired an influence few journalists achieve: “Daphne was the last ethical voice left. She was the only person speaking about right and wrong.” says Manuel Delia, a fellow-blogger and former opposition Nationalist Party government official. In this photo Michael and Rose Vella, Daphne Caruana Galizia's parents, hold photos of their daughter during a vigil on September 16th 2018, to mark eleven months since her murder, in Valletta, Malta. Credit: Reuters/Darrin Zammit Lupi #Malta #investigativejournalism #journalism #DaphneProject #DaphneCaruanaGalizia

A shockingly thin child is treated in hospital for malnutrition in Hajjah province, Yemen. The United Nations (UN) is warning that 13 million people in Yemen are facing starvation. It's calling on the military coalition, led by Saudi Arabia, to halt air strikes which are killing civilians, and contributing to what the UN says could become "the worst famine in the world in 100 years". Yemen's civil war began four years ago, when Houthi rebels, backed by Iran, seized much of the country, including the capital Sana'a. Yemen relies on imports for 90% of its food. The Saudi-led coalition laid siege to the rebel-held port of Hodeida from the moment it entered the war. Its bombing has badly damaged facilities, disabling the cranes which unload cargo. As supplies have dwindled, levels of hunger have risen sharply. According to the UN, as of March 2018 the number of Yemeni children suffering from severe acute malnutrition has increased by 90% in the last three years. Photo taken on October 1st 2018. Credit: PA/Xinhua/Mohammed Mohammed #Yemen #famine #war #UnitedNations

From @1843mag: “Magic realism” is most often thought of as a literary genre, one that blends fantastical elements with a more lifelike depiction of the world. Yet the term was coined in 1925 by Franz Roh, a German art historian, who observed that many artists in the Weimar Republic rejected the idealistic style fashionable before the first world war in favour of a realism with uncanny elements. While much of the work on show is bleak, savage and pessimistic, we also see energy and optimism – and occasionally even humour. The Weimar magic realists returned again and again to the circus as a theme, never with more striking results than in Albert Birkle’s fifth portrait of the acrobat Schultz (1921), capturing the extravagant facial expressions for which the performer was renowned. From @1843mag: When Faye Toogood, the British furniture designer, first encountered the Rosary Chapel, designed by an ailing Matisse in 1949, she experienced a spiritual effect so profound that she had to sit down. The chapel, which is located in Vence, France, was a site on Toogood’s architectural pilgrimage of Provence. Although small and unassuming, Matisse’s design reduces colour, texture, material and pattern to their essential forms. The stained-glass windows are a shocking azure blue and are decorated with leaf prints; the walls are simple white stucco adorned with his painted murals. Toogood, captivated by the space, based her last collection of furniture, Assemblage 5, on the chapel. From @1843mag: If you were in a distant city and wanted to find a drink, what symbol would you look for? The answer, on a map or in bright neon, is a vertical line bisecting a horizontal one, with an inverted triangle on the top: the martini glass. It was first seen in its current form at the Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes in Paris in 1925 – the birthplace of Art Deco. At first it was used as just another vessel for champagne. But as Art Deco caught on, so did the Jazz Age predilection for cocktails, especially those made with gin, Prohibition’s principal illicit booze. This was good for the martini, a mix of gin and vermouth whose origins are as hazy as someone who has had four of them. To find out more about how the martini glass became an indispensable element of a classy night out, click on the link in 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #martini #builttolast #design

Worldwide, old people are far more likely than any other age group to kill themselves. But in Britain they have become among the least likely. Between 1986 and 2017 the suicide rate among the over-60s dropped by about 60%. This trend puzzles experts, but several changes may help to explain why British pensioners are less likely to kill themselves. 
One is that their quality of life has got much better. The number of old people living in poverty is close to its lowest-ever level. After housing costs, their incomes almost equal those of working households, a radical change from the mid-1990s, when the elderly were far poorer than others.

Their health is also much improved. Better diagnosis and treatment of mental illness, in particular, has helped, since around 90% of suicides involve disorders like depression. Doctors have got better at spotting dementia, which can make people suicidal. And better painkillers mean chronic conditions such as arthritis are less debilitating, and therefore less of a strain on mental health. Fit pensioners are less lonely than invalids, since they get out and socialise more. #data #infographic #happiness #elderly

From @1843mag: Trapped in the Po Valley, Milan is drenched in smog for much of the year. Look north on a clear day, though, and you can see the grey peaks of the Alps. Exploring them isn’t hard. Pack your hiking boots and head to Valtellina, a beautiful region near the Swiss border. Tirano, a handsome town surrounded by mountains and vineyards, is only two hours away from Milan by train. Once you are there, lace up your boots and pick a hiking trail. One of the best leads to Baruffini, a hamlet clasped to the rocks above town. It takes about three hours there and back, so leave enough time in the village to visit its lovely church. As financial markets take fright, our cover this week looks at the next recession. Last year growth was accelerating around the world. Today, America alone is booming. As interest rates diverge, emerging markets will find it harder to service dollar debts—which could blow back to the rich world. Although a re-run of the crisis of 2008 is unlikely, many economies are ill-prepared to deal with even a mild recession. Central banks do not have much room to cut interest rates and politicians may balk at unconventional monetary policy, deficit spending or co-ordinated international action. The time to prepare is now. #TheEconomist

The last known image of Jamal Khashoggi, a prominent Saudi journalist living in self-imposed exile. On October 2nd he visited the Saudi consulate in Istanbul to collect some paperwork. Feeling unsafe, he asked his fiancée to wait outside and to call a member of Turkey’s ruling party if he did not emerge. He hasn't been seen since. Acquaintances feared he had been detained inside or abducted and flown back to Saudi Arabia against his will. Turkish police now believe he may have been murdered on the premises.
It is no mystery why Saudi Arabia might have wanted to silence Mr Khashoggi, a critic of the powerful crown prince, Muhammad bin Salman. He wrote frequently in Arabic, penned a regular column for the Washington Post, and kept close ties with countless diplomats and journalists. For over a year he used that platform to criticise growing repression in Saudi Arabia and urge an end to the war in Yemen. But he was hardly a radical. Mr Khashoggi was part of the Saudi elite, close to members of the royal family. In the 2000s he advised Turki al-Faisal, a former spy chief who became Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to Britain and America. He often stressed that his criticism was nasiha, friendly counsel, and not a rejection of the monarchy.
Image captured from CCTV video obtained by Hurriyet, a Turkish newspaper, and released on October 9th 2018 as Turkish officials announced that the Saudi Consulate will be searched as part of an investigation into Mr Khashoggi's disappearance. Credit: CCTV/Hurriyet via AP #Istanbul #Turkey #JamalKhashoggi #journalism #SaudiArabia
