"Girl with Balloon", created by Banksy in 2006 and given to a friend, self-destructs on October 5th 2018. This photo, posted on Banksy's Instagram page, captures the moment when staff at Sotheby's in London realise that the painting they have sold for £1m is now in shreds. Immediately after the auctioneer's hammer came down an alarm sounded and the canvas started to move down towards a shredding mechanism hidden in the bottom of the frame. The anonymous, famously anti-art establishment, street artist and prankster posted the image along with the comment "Going, going, gone...". How the self-destruct mechanism was triggered is the subject of conjecture, but Banksy has often railed about the prices his artworks sell for. Credit: Banksy/Sotheby's @Banksy #Banksy #art #auction #red #balloon

From @1843mag: The year is 1004 and at the party celebrating her marriage to the son of the doge of Venice, Maria Argyropoulina, niece to the emperor of Byzantium, has scandalised the guests. Her crime: using a fork to eat. At the time, people generally cut up food with knives and transferred it to their mouths with their fingers. Forks did exist, but they were large, two-pronged implements used for toasting or carving meat. Maria, however, used one of these to put food in her mouth. Her wayward behaviour was immediately condemned by the clergy. When Maria died of the plague two years later, it was seen as divine punishment for her decadence. Yet today we would look down on anyone who didn’t use a fork. To learn how the fork transformed from a heretical utensil into an everyday object, and what it tells us about the trajectory of technological adoption, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @gettyimages #fork #utensils #technology #rewind

From @1843mag: This photograph of Tsar Nicholas II and his family was taken from one of the 22 photo albums compiled by Herbert Galloway Stewart, a British tutor employed by the tsar’s sister. Between 1908 and 1918, Stewart photographed the extended Romanov family at home in St Petersburg and on their Crimean holidays. In contrast with official photographs, which depict the Romanovs as stiff and inaccessible in their luxurious finery, these casual snaps give viewers insight into their relaxed family life. The albums were only recently rediscovered in the archives at the Science Museum in London. They now feature in a new exhibition about the Romanovs' links with medicine and science – both in life and in death. To discover how science dispelled myths about Russia’s tragic imperial family, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. This week our cover focuses on China’s investment in Europe, which has soared in recent years. Many investments are private, profit-seeking and harmless, but China is also buying political influence. The Czech president, Milos Zeman, wants his country to be China’s “unsinkable aircraft-carrier”. Last year Greece stopped the EU from criticising China’s human-rights record at a UN forum. Hungary and Greece prevented the EU from backing a court ruling against China’s territorial claims in the South China Sea. Europe’s experience matters to the rest of the world, which also takes Chinese money, ­and even more to America, which is Europe’s chief ally. What can Europe do to enjoy the benefits of Chinese investment but minimise the threats? #TheEconomist

The bald eagle is a conservation success story. By one estimate America had some 100,000 nesting pairs in 1782. By 1940 Congress noted that the eagles faced probable extinction, and passed an act that forbade people to do them any harm. By 1963 only 487 nesting pairs survived in mainland America, though Alaska had a healthier population. In June 2007 federal officials said it no longer even counts as an endangered species. The national total is probably substantially higher today, though in places like Vermont state rules still count the bird as threatened. Photo shows a bald eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) in Kachemak Bay State Park, Kenai Peninsula, Alaska. For the full article search "How the bald eagle soared again" at economist.com Credit:FLPA/Bernd Zoller #eagle #baldeagle #birds #wildlife #conservation #USA #Alaska

Almost a year has passed since American news outlets first published stories containing allegations of sexual assault about Harvey Weinstein, a film-studio boss who has since been charged with multiple counts of rape. Victims of harassment in workplaces of all sorts, from S&P 500 companies to small-and medium-sized firms to startups, have come forward in unprecedented numbers to share their harrowing experiences. Customers, investors, boards, employees, stock analysts and even insurers increasingly ask for information on what a company does for women, including the protection it affords against harassment. Equileap, which ranks firms on gender-equality criteria, now includes sexual-harassment policies. It is seeing strong demand for such data. That is partly because the headline costs of a scandal are clear: shares of several big firms have fallen sharply after executive departures. A survey carried out by Pew, a research outfit, this week found that the majority of Americans consider men and women equally capable of being leaders in politics and business. Yet in the time that #MeToo has been trending the number of female Fortune 500 CEOs has fallen. Progress in closing the pay gap has stalled in several rich countries. Until the barriers that stop women from having an equal stab at reaching the top are cleared away, #MeToo will struggle to succeed. #data #GraphicDetail

As America fights over Brett Kavanaugh and the Supreme Court, we look at the #MeToo movement. A year after Harvey Weinstein was accused of being a sexual predator, women who speak out are taken more seriously and men who abuse are more likely to pay a price. The bad news is that in America, where #MeToo began and where it has gone furthest, men’s predation of women risks becoming yet one more battlefield in the all-consuming culture wars.

In Britain we report on the Brexit-obsessed state of politics. The referendum to leave the European Union was a desperate call for broad change—a call that Theresa May’s government has failed to answer. However, as the party conferences proceed, fundamental ideas that have underpinned Western governments of all stripes for decades are at last beginning to be questioned from both right and left. Some of the new ideas are promising; others downright dangerous. #EconomistCover

From @1843mag: When asked to reimagine an apartment in a Renaissance palazzo in Mantua, Diego Cisi and Stefano Gorni Silvestrini, founders of Archiplan Studio, wouldn’t let history intimidate them. The flat was filled with fragile traces of the past, including original terracotta tiles and fragments of 16th-century frescoes in the dining room. Rather than being precious about preservation, they were convinced that different layers of history could cohabit happily. The result is a bold amalgamation of old and new. Instead of restoring or effacing the original pastoral landscapes decorating the dining-room walls, they simply surrounded them with pastel-green, so the new paint echoes the palette of the old art. To see more pleasing rooms from an Italian palazzo, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Davide Galli #italy #design #housestyle

Buildings still lie in ruins in Mokha, Yemen on September 22nd 2018. Mokha, a coastal city in the south west of the war-torn country, was retaken from Houthi rebels in early 2017, as part of Yemen's Saudi-led military campaign which has moved west along Yemen's coast. Prolonged fighting has left millions of Yemenis homeless and millions more at risk of starvation. Credit: Getty Images/Andrew Renneisen #civiliansinwar #Yemen #goats #photography #war

From @1843mag: Think “Weimar” and you think decadence and doom. There is certainly plenty of both on display in “Magic Realism: Art in Weimar Germany 1919-33”, a new exhibition at Tate Modern in London. But rather than presenting the Weimar Republic as a brief, ill-fated interlude born of one set of horrors and foreshadowing another, the organisers of the exhibition have selected artworks that give a more nuanced impression of the era. This painting by Rudolf Schlichter of his wife, Speedy (a name she preferred to her given one, Elfriede), portrays her with intense, detailed realism, yet the background – the strange, twisted landscape, the moon and ominous sky – give it the other-worldly atmosphere of a science-fiction book cover. To see more examples of uncanny realism from Weimar Germany, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @tate #magicalrealism #weimar #germany #lookcloser

From @1843mag: On October 16th 2017, as Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia was speeding downhill in her car, a bomb exploded beneath the driver’s seat of her Peugeot 108. Her murder appeared to be the melodramatic climax of the most persistent theme in her often controversial reporting. Malta is often held up as one of the European Union’s successes – since 2011, the Catholic country has legalised divorce and same-sex marriage – but Caruana Galizia believed that these liberal gestures masked a darker and more troubling reality. At different times she described the island as a “nest of thieves”, a “den of crooks” and a “slew of ineptitude, violence and corruption”. In the aftermath of the bomb, two questions lingered like smoke. Who was making her death into a statement? And what were they saying? To learn more about this troubling murder in Malta, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @reuters #daphnecaruanagalizia #malta #features

From @1843mag: Is the romantic comedy dead? The “Hollywood Reporter” thought so when it wrote its obituary in 2013, declaring “gone are the days when light comedic pairings like ‘When Harry Met Sally’…or ‘50 First Dates’ reliably packed multiplexes”. But Netflix wholeheartedly disagrees, having funded nearly a dozen original rom-coms in 2018 alone. One of its recent feature films, “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before”, has impressed critics and audiences alike with its independent heroine, its enlightened male lead and its representation of Korean-American characters. From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic, a health divide has fallen across Europe. Although in global terms citizens of the EU live long (2.5 years more than in America and 4.6 years more than in China), the continent is divided. At the farthest ends of the spectrum, Spaniards from Madrid can expect to live to 85, but Bulgarians from the region of Severozapaden are predicted to live just past their 73rd birthday—a gap of almost 12 years. 
Money might be thought to be at the root of the problem, but the facts do not bear out this view. Portugal, southern Italy and large parts of Spain have incomes per head similar to parts of eastern Europe, yet enjoy higher life expectancy. Scotland and the north-east of England also have high death rates from chronic disease. Some countries prefer to spend their money on social policy, others on weapons. But in general, health systems in eastern Europe are simply “not comparable to western Europe,” says Zoltan Massay-Kosubek of the European Public Health Alliance, an NGO. 
To find out why the final curtain falls earlier in ex-communist countries, search "Why life expectancy is lower in eastern Europe" on economist.com #data #map #Europe #health #inequality

From @1843mag: Brigitte Macron, France’s first lady, is on the cover of the new issue of 1843. Rather a lot about this quietly influential woman’s life has been unusual. As a married mother-of-three and a teacher at a Jesuit high school in Amiens, she fell for a pupil in her drama class who was 24 years her junior. Despite the obstacles to their romance, they eventually married – and he ended up the president of France. Their improbable relationship prompted family censure, popular unease and malicious rumours. But the most unexpected twist in Brigitte Macron’s story is her current popularity in France: at the age of 65, she is forcing the French to question what it means to be a woman and, in particular, a woman of her age. To find out if Brigitte Macron is a new model for French women, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Getty  #brigittemacron #france

Our cover this week examines next month’s elections in Brazil—and the possible victory of Jair Bolsonaro. The country's economy is a disaster, street crime is rising and its politics are thoroughly rotten. Enter Mr Bolsonaro, the latest in a parade of populists—from Donald Trump in America to Rodrigo Duterte in the Philippines and a left-right coalition featuring Matteo Salvini in Italy. Mr Bolsonaro would be a particularly nasty addition to the club. Were he to win, it might put the very survival of democracy in Latin America’s largest country at risk. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: At the height of summer, Rio de Janeiro’s heat can be suffocating. To beat the heat, retreat into Brazil’s lush rainforests and romantic villages for fresh air, wildlife and a spot of culture. Paraty, an UNESCO-listed port town midway between Rio and São Paulo, is a well-preserved example of 18th-century Portuguese architecture. The historic town – a grid of white, terracotta-tiled buildings with balconies painted in crayon colours – sits right on the water’s edge. Thanks to a constant stream of international festivals, Paraty is always bustling. It also offers galleries, cachaça bars, and island-bound boat rides for those in search of quieter forms of seaside relaxation. To find out about four other destinations worthy of an excursion from Rio, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Alamy #riodejaneiro #paraty #escapefrom

From @1843mag: In marrying the complexities of technology and the simplicity of nature, the Bone Chair is a design of the times. Joris Laarman, a Dutch designer, began working on it after seeing a documentary featuring Claus Mattheck, a German expert on biomechanics. Mattheck had researched the efficiency with which natural objects like bones grow and created an algorithm that Laarman then applied to furniture design. “If Mother Nature wanted to create a chair,” Laarman said, “it would be something like the Bone Chair.” To hear more about the design of the Bone Chair, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #bonechair  #jorislaarman  #reedkrakoff  #iwishiddonethat

As you would expect in a country at war, Yemen bristles with guns. The forces of the internationally recognised government carry Kalashnikovs. So do the Iranian-backed Houthi rebels, who toppled it in 2015. But it is not just the combatants who pack heat. The country has more privately owned guns per person than any except America, where prosperous gun-lovers can afford far more. Many Yemenis sling rifles over their shoulders or tuck handguns into their trousers before going out. Markets sell everything from pistols to bazookas. You cannot go far in most cities without seeing someone with a gun. For the full story search "Yemen tries gun control" at economist.com Credit: EPA-EFE/Yahya Arhab #Yemen #photography

From @1843mag: The Concorde is the ultimate symbol of the jetset lifestyle. It might have been narrow, low-ceilinged and short on legroom, but the seats were leather, the food was gourmet, champagne was on tap, you weren’t on board long enough to get uncomfortable and you had a chance of a singalong with Paul McCartney. It’s no surprise that luxury brands such as Rolex wanted to be associated with the supersonic airliner. In this stylish ad, they position themselves as the watch brand for high-speed aviators: “When the Concorde takes off on its experimental flights through the sound barrier, the watch on board will be Rolex.” To see more striking advertisements from the visual archive of Lawrence Azerrad, a Los Angeles-based graphic designer and Concorde admirer, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. The definition of liberalism has long been the source of disagreement. For Open Future, an initiative aimed at sparking debate around liberal values, we aimed to build a bibliography of liberalism in its it many forms. On August 2nd we published an initial list of 11 liberal thinkers and their works, and asked for your help in identifying others. Your reaction has been overwhelming. In six weeks, we have received nearly 900 responses, suggesting over 300 different thinkers, from readers all around the world. The most popular names ranged from philosophers and politicians, to columnists and poets. From your submissions, we were able to highlight truly original, and often overlooked, liberal giants. For example Jane Addams, a mainstay of American schoolbooks and a radical social reformer who remains conspicuously absent from the pantheon of liberalism’s most recognisable thinkers. You can watch rigorous debates about liberal values streamed live from the Open Future festival today in Hong Kong, London and New York: 
https://openfuturefestival.live/

From @1843mag: For those who believe in the distinction between high and low art, video games have long been near the bottom of the pile. Fortunately, “Videogames Design/Play/Disrupt”, which opened at the @vamuseum in London this week, addresses video games on their own terms. “Journey” follows a pilgrim-like character on a trip through a desert to a distant mountain. In contrast to other modern video games, which emphasise graphic realism, “Journey” uses an abstract, symbol-laden style that subverts the perception of the genre as aesthetically uninteresting. According to the Air Carrier Access Act, pigs might indeed fly. Technically so might dogs, cats, miniature horses, kangaroos, possums, parrots, hamsters, ducks, turkeys, ferrets, lizards, snakes, turtles and a variety of other animals seldom seen at 35,000 feet. Although individual airlines have policies that bar many of these creatures from boarding, the Air Carrier Access Act, established in 1986, prohibits commercial airlines from discriminating against passengers with disabilities. Differentiating between those with genuine disabilities, who are allowed to travel with service animals, and those seeking a free flight for pets, is the responsibility of airlines. For the full story search "It’s emotional" at economist.com Credit: Alamy/Victor Zastolskiy #kangaroo #flying #aircraft

This week we celebrate our 175th anniversary with a manifesto for renewing liberalism through a programme of radical reform. The Economist was founded in 1843 to champion free trade, free markets and limited government. Since then, liberalism has been a powerful engine for prosperity and individual freedom. Yet, although liberalism began as a restless, agitating world view, liberals have become comfortable with power. They have lost their hunger for reform. In our cover leader and a ten-page essay, we set out how liberalism must change. #TheEconomist

UNESCO inscribed the Indonesian craft of creating Batik on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2009, stating: "Batik is dyed by proud craftspeople who draw designs on fabric using dots and lines of hot wax, which resists vegetable and other dyes and therefore allows the artisan to colour selectively by soaking the cloth in one colour, removing the wax with boiling water and repeating if multiple colours are desired. The wide diversity of patterns reflects a variety of influences, ranging from Arabic calligraphy, European bouquets and Chinese phoenixes to Japanese cherry blossoms and Indian or Persian peacocks. Often handed down within families for generations, the craft of batik is intertwined with the cultural identity of the Indonesian people and, through the symbolic meanings of its colours and designs, expresses their creativity and spirituality." Photo taken on September 12th 2018. Credit: AFP/Adek Berry #Batik #crafts #art #design #handdyed #fabric #Indonesia #culture #heritage  #UNESCO

Gun violence has killed 6.5m people worldwide since 1990; greater than the number that succumbed to typhoid fever or alcohol-related deaths. A new paper published by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington provides perhaps the best global estimates to date of how severe that violence is. The paper finds that in 2016 alone some 250,000 people were killed by guns (the study excludes deaths from war and at the hands of police). Gun violence is worst in the Americas: in El Salvador, Guatemala and Venezuela, it exceeds 30 firearm deaths per 100,000 people, the vast majority of it murderous. In America, twice as many people killed themselves with a gun in 2016 than were murdered by one. It is not all grim reading. Overall, per head of population, firearm deaths are decreasing, largely because suicide is becoming less prevalent. #data #graphicdetail #gunviolence

Here is an extract from our obituary of Chicha Mariani, a remarkable woman, the co-founder of Argentina’s Abuelas de Plaza de Mayo who died on August 20th 2018, aged 94. 
They looked like any other group of middle-aged grannies, Chicha Mariani and her friends. At a café called Las Violetas in northern Buenos Aires in the late 1970s and early 1980s they regularly sat with their matés and medialunas, chatting. On Thursdays, in white headscarves, they would go to the centre of the city and walk round the Plaza de Mayo, in front of the presidential palace, joining the Mothers there to ask what had happened to the thousands who had been “disappeared” by the military regime. On other days, Las Violetas was their secret plotting place.

Before long, photos of grandchildren might come out. Chicha shared hers proudly: dear little Clara Anahí, with her lively dark eyes and lots of flyaway first chestnut hair, always smiling. But there were no photos of her older than three months, for on November 24th 1976 she had disappeared in a military raid.

Chicha had been at home that day in La Plata, not as usual teaching art history in secondary school. She was sewing a bathrobe for Clara Anahí, worrying about the rash she had after her measles injection, when she heard tanks go down the road. Their purpose, it turned out, was to destroy the house where her son Daniel, his wife Diana and a few companions, all Montoneros violently opposed to the regime, were printing a newspaper. She knew nothing of politics, but heard the explosions. Everyone was killed, apart from Daniel. The army murdered him later, her studious economist son; and the only thing that kept her living then was the thought that Clara Anahí had survived.

She was sure of it. The baby had been pulled from under her mother’s body, or found hidden under towels in a bath. She had been handed to some officer. These were the whispers. And she was then given, as all such babies were, to some “properly Argentinian” couple, instead of to her grandmother, as she should have been.

For the full article search "Hope against hope" or in the Obituary section at economist.com Credit: Facebook/Maria Isabel Chorobik #Argentina

From @1843mag: A garlicky fermented cabbage dish with an aroma like wet socks may not sound too appetising, but most Koreans are crazy about kimchi. The national fare of both North and South Korea, the dish is typically made with cabbage, spices and fermented fish for a briny tang. Recently, kimichi’s appeal has gone global: Japan and China have developed a taste for it and flooded the market with cheap imitations. This has earned the wrath of Koreans. From @1843mag: An increasing number of companies are opening shops, not so much to sell things – there’s the internet for that – but to advertise their ethos and to entertain. Although it is principally an online retailer, Glossier, a beauty brand aimed at millenial women, has built its reputation on elaborate pop-up stores. Last year it unveiled this space in Manhattan decked out in red velvet curtains to coincide with the launch of a new perfume. Visitors were invited to enter a tiny room inside and push a big red button, which opened an aperture in the wall. Then a hand in a red rubber glove would emerge and spray perfume on the visitor’s wrist. One woman filmed her visit and posted it on YouTube. “This is the future,” she said, “and I don’t know what I think of it.” To see more examples of imaginative shop design, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @kris_tamburello #shopping #retaildesign #instagram @glossier

Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt with his daughter and wife in the American Embassy, Prague. Ambassadorial residences are silent witnesses to history, home to generations of diplomats, venues for endless dinners. Some are architectural gems: the German residence in Delhi, the British one in Washington, the Dutch in Beijing. Norman Eisen, now of the Brookings Institute, a think-tank, reckons the American residence in Prague is exceptional, too. He became enamoured of it while living there as America’s ambassador to the Czech Republic. Read our review of his book "The Last Palace: Europe’s Turbulent Century in Five Lives and One Legendary House" at economist.com. Credit: Getty Images/LIFE Picture Collection/Nat Farbman #Prague #CzechRepublic #Czechoslovakia

From @1843mag: Aircraft, like sports cars and motorbikes, are machines with charisma. Possibly the only non-military aircraft to gather a cult following is Concorde. The first – and still only – supersonic passenger aircraft took its maiden flight 50 years ago next year. This image shows Concorde’s original interior design: with all of its 106 seats priced at first-class levels and its own dedicated lounge at the airports it served, the aircraft appealed to the business set of the 1970s. But although the check-in and waiting experience was luxurious, the aircraft itself had tiny windows, a low cabin ceiling and similar knee room to today’s economy class. To see more photographs from the ravishing visual archive of Lawrence Azerrad, a Los Angeles-based graphic designer and Concorde admirer, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Our cover this week, ten years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, asks whether the world has learned the lessons of the financial crisis. Lehman failed after losing money on toxic loans and securities linked to America’s property market. Its bankruptcy unleashed chaos around the world. The good news is that banks are more resilient and better regulated. However, finance still has much to fix. Housing loans are mismanaged, the euro remains inherently unstable, offshore dollar finance has ballooned. Meanwhile, fracturing geopolitics only makes a hyper-globalised industry like finance harder to deal with. #TheEconomist

Free at last. The prudish wording of India’s colonial-era penal code of 1860 has long cast a baleful shadow over gay people. Section 377 banned “carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal”. This was taken to bar homosexual intercourse along with bestiality and incest. Even heterosexuals could be prosecuted for enjoying oral or anal sex. The ban on gay sex was struck down by a Delhi court in 2009. It was then reinstated by the Supreme Court in 2013, which said parliament should deal with the matter. However, on September 6th the court reversed itself. A broader bench ruled, to general applause from Indian liberals, that the law does not, after all, criminalise homosexuality. The decision is final. The chief justice, Dipak Misra, called the ban on gay sex “irrational, indefensible and manifestly arbitrary”. At issue was the meaning of “the order of nature”. One judge, Indu Malhotra, said that being gay should be understood as a “variation”, not an “aberration”, of human nature. For the full story search "India unbans gay sex" at economist.com. Photo shows celebrations in Mumbai on September 6th 2018. Credit: EPA-EFE/Divyakant Solanki #LGBT #LGBTrights #humanrights #Mumbai #India

The signs are ominous. Idlib province is home to 2m-3m civilians. It is also the last bastion of Syria's rebel forces. Among them are fighters aligned with Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which controls about 60% of Idlib and is a former al-Qaeda affiliate. As the fighting has driven people from their homes in Homs, the suburbs of Damascus and Aleppo, they have been funnelled into Idlib. Now they have nowhere to go. It is expected that within weeks the Syrian regime and its Russian backers may launch one of the biggest battles of the war, to crush the rebels and regain control of this pocket of resistance on the border with Turkey. Government victory in Idlib would spell the end of the armed rebellion against Syria's president, Bashar al-Assad. Photo shows rebel soldiers in Idlib province on September 3rd 2018. For the full story search "The fate of Idlib" at economist.com Credit: AFP/Nazeer al-Khatib #Syria #Idlib #war #civiliansinwar

It was twenty years ago today Sergey and Larry taught the world to say "Google". Co-founded by Sergey Brin and Larry Page, both students at Stanford University, California, Google was incorporated as a private company on September 4th 1998. In August 2004 Google had its IPO. Shortly after going public Google acquired the technology that led to Google Maps. Over the next two years Google acquired Android and YouTube. Today its parent company, Alphabet, is the world's third most valuable company.
Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin, photographed on bean bags at Google's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif on November 11th 2000. Credit: AP/Randi Lynn Beach #Google #anniversary #technology

Facing starvation in Yemen. A malnourished 4-year-old girl waits to be weighed while receiving treatment in the malnutrition department of a hospital in Sanaa, Yemen on September 2nd 2018. Millions of people in war-torn Yemen are unable to secure even one meal a day. The UN has released a report accusing the governments of Yemen, the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia of committing war crimes—including rape and torture—during Yemen’s four-year civil war. The report said the Houthi rebels, who are fighting the government and its backers, are to blame for many of the same crimes. A catastrophic fire has destroyed one of the world's great collections of cultural heritage. At some point after the National Museum in Rio de Janeiro closed on September 2nd 2018, fire broke out in the former royal palace. The museum was celebrating its bicentenary this year. It housed a collection begun in 1818 by King John VI of Portugal, consisting of some 20 million items of scientific, historical and cultural importance. An irreplaceable treasure trove of heritage, assembled over 200 years, was incinerated within a single hour. From @1843mag: In the last several years Western companies have rushed to develop products that look, taste and feel as close as possible to meat and dairy dishes. In China plant-based foods have been used to mimic meat for hundreds of years. In the time of the Tang dynasty (AD618-907), an official hosted a banquet at which he served convincing replicas of pork and mutton dishes made from vegetables; in the 13th century, diners in the capital of the southern Song dynasty, had a wide choice of meat-free restaurants, including those that specialised in Buddhist vegetarian cuisine. The tradition is still alive in contemporary China. To discover more about the ancient Chinese art of imitation, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: Brett Ryder #vegan #food #china

Thrive Multi Visual, an agritech startup from Shropshire, is devising a chicken-weighing robot based on the rover developed by NASA to explore the red planet. The company plans to kit out the vehicle with cameras that can weigh chickens by sight alone. Thermal-imaging gear and other gadgets will monitor indicators such as body-heat and humidity. An indoor GPS system, also adapted from space technology, will allow the robot to drive itself around and self-charge, while sensors will prevent it from running over laggards that are slow to strut out of its way. If it works, the chicken rover will greatly reduce the work involved in looking after the birds—handy for farmers fearing labour shortages after Brexit. For the full story search "Harwell, we have a problem" at economist.com Credit: Thrive Multi Visual #chickens #farming #spacetechnology #NASA #Mars

From @1843mag: Last summer Ukrainian architect Daria Zinovatnaya (@zinovatnaya) was asked to reimagine a young couple’s apartment in Poznań, Poland. The task was not easy. The apartment was small – just three rooms – and Zinovatnaya’s style is big. The basis of her work is colour and geometry, much of it inspired by Russian Suprematists, a group of abstract artists from the early 20th century who employed dizzying patterns and bright, intersecting shapes. So how would she design a home that was both true to her style but not overwhelming? “The main goal was to make an unusual place that was cosy,” she says. According to the National Honey Board, per person consumption of the regurgitated nectar has doubled in America since the 1990s. As demand has increased, prices have followed. Domestic production has not. In 2016 American bees produced 73,000 tonnes of honey, or 35% less than they did 20 years ago. This has given honey-sellers an incentive to dilute it with cheaper things like corn, rice and beet syrup. According to the US Pharmacopeia’s Food Fraud Database, honey is now the third-favourite food target for adulteration, behind milk and olive oil. For the full story search "The scourge of honey fraud" at economist.com Credit: Alamy/Andrey Kuzmin #bees #honey #USA

Cubans are ingenious in their use of condoms in part because they are cheap. Children in Havana use them as slingshots. At birthday parties and concerts they are makeshift balloons. Women use them to secure their ponytails. Drivers use lubricated ones to shine the dashboards of their vintage Chevys. Revellers sneak them into nightclubs, filled with rum. Fishermen use inflated ones as floats. Winemakers stretch them over the necks of large glass bottles, which they use instead of oak casks. An erect one means fermentation is still producing carbon dioxide; a deflated one means that the process is complete. For the full article search "Where the rubber hits the road" at economist.com Credit: AP/Ramon Espinosa #Cuba #wine

Our cover this week considers Silicon Valley, which has become a victim of its own success. There is no credible rival for its position as the world’s pre-eminent innovation hub, but there are signs that its influence is peaking. High costs, clogged roads and the dominance of the local tech giants are reducing the region’s dynamism and prompting startups and investors to go elsewhere. If Silicon Valley’s relative decline heralded the rise of a global web of thriving, rival tech hubs, that would be worth celebrating. Unfortunately, the Valley’s peak looks more like a warning that innovation everywhere is becoming harder. #TheEconomist

Today a defamation case against Alex Jones, host of Infowars, opens in Texas. Families of nine of the twenty children killed in the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Newtown, Connecticut are suing Mr Jones. He has repeatedly posted claims that this massacre of six and seven-year-olds was faked by people wishing to promote tighter gun control laws. Six teachers also died in the shooting. Mr Jones's repeated reports that the parents are actors and the massacre never happened incited such hatred among his followers that one grieving family has had to relocate seven times to avoid attacks. A groundbreaking debate is under way for social media platforms like Apple, Facebook and Twitter: where to draw the line between a responsibility to remove offensive content and freedom of speech. This photo shows a friend of five of the victims, holding a poster of all the children who died, at a rally on July 21st 2014 in Greenwich, Connecticut. Credit: AP/Jessica Hill #SandyHook #Texas

The flag above the White House is flown at half mast for Senator John McCain, a former presidential candidate, who died on August 25th 2018. Following public comment when the flag was raised to its full height on August 27th, it was again lowered, and will stay lowered until the day of Senator McCain's interment. Under the United States Code, for a deceased president the flag is lowered to half mast for 30 days. For a vice president, chief justice, state governor or speaker of the House of Representatives it is 10 days. For a senator the flag is to be lowered on the day of their death and the following day. At the direction of the president this can be extended and other prominent figures can also be accorded this mark of respect. President Trump arranged this for both Billy Graham, a preacher, and former First Lady Barbara Bush. Credit: AFP/Mandel Ngan #WhiteHouse #flag

From @1843mag: Overflowing inboxes, constant alerts, access to all the music ever recorded, and a deluge of high-quality television: we are suffering from information overload. This phenomenon may seem quintessentially modern, but it dates back centuries. Half a millennium ago, the printing press was to blame. “Is there anywhere on Earth exempt from these swarms of new books?” moaned Erasmus in 1525. The German polymath Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz grumbled in 1680 of “that horrible mass of books which keeps on growing”. One solution was to develop a new set of mechanisms to classify and retrieve information: the scholarly journal. To discover how we can combat information overload today, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Getty #rewind #tech #informationoverload

From @1843mag: The barbarities of slavery are nowadays well known, but perhaps more shocking to modern eyes even than the sight of slaves toiling on a plantation is an image such as this from Atlanta in the 1860s, showing an auction house for trafficked humans lodged casually among tobacconists and homeware stores. Rendered for the first time from monochrome into colour, the photograph is more arresting still – a reminder of how, right up to the time of abolition, the trade in slaves carried on in plain sight, in spite of the international censure directed at those who perpetuated it. From @1843mag: Salvador Dalí enjoyed improbable mash-ups. In “Gala Placidia. Galatea of the Spheres” (1952), Renaissance art meets atomic theory. After Hiroshima, Dalí became fascinated by nuclear physics and the idea that matter was, no matter how solid it seemed, in essence discontinuous, made up of distinct atomic particles. This painting depicts a bust of Gala, Dalí’s wife, through a matrix of spheres suspended in space. In Greek mythology, the sculptor Pygmalion falls in love with Galatea, a beautiful statue he’s created, after Aphrodite brings it to life. An exhibition at the National Art Museum of Catalonia, in Barcelona, looks at Dalí and Gala’s five-decade-long relationship and the stunning works of surrealism that emerged from it. To see more such paintings, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Fundacio Gala-Salvador Dali #barcelona #art #GalaDali

From @1843mag: The border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland runs through Lough Foyle, a sandy bay with steep hills on both sides. Fishing villages hug the shore and it often teems with birds. On still summer days the water is like a mirror, but storms roll across Lough Foyle too. Some people like to blame Manannan mac Lir for these storms, a Celtic sea-god associated with the lough. Others like to blame Britain’s decision to leave the European Union, which risks once more turning the lake into a hard border. To learn about the communities living in uncharted waters, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @briandohertyphotographer #travel #ireland #brexit

By the time Alexander Dubček became head of Czechoslovakia's Communist Party a sense of change was already in the air. From January 5th 1968 onwards this blossomed into the movement for liberalisation that became known at the Prague Spring. But on August 21st 1968 the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies invaded. They re-established Moscow's control, crushing any hope of self-determination. Czechoslovakians would not be free of Russian control until the Velvet Revolution occurred in 1989. Photos show resistance in Wenceslas Square, Prague to the Soviet-led invasion on August 21st 1968. Credit: Press Association/Czech News Agency #PragueSpring #Prague #CzechRepublic #Czechoslovakia

Our cover this week looks at American politics. It is easy to lose perspective amid the twists and turns of the investigations swirling around President Donald Trump. But this week something significant changed. Michael Cohen, Mr Trump’s former fixer, told a court that during the campaign he was directed by Mr Trump to pay hush money to two women, “for the principal purpose of influencing the election”. Congressional Republicans are now defending someone who would probably be indicted on federal conspiracy charges if he were not in the Oval Office. Should a president be above the law? #TheEconomist

On August 21st 2018 Duncan Hunter, a Republican congressman from California, and his wife were indicted for filing false campaign reports and spending $250,000 of campaign funds on personal expenses. According to the indictment, which Mr Hunter claims is politically motivated, he spent over $20,000 of campaign funds on family trips to Italy and Hawaii. When the congressman (a former Marine) wanted to “buy [some] Hawaii shorts” but was low on funds, his wife suggested that he buy the shorts at a golf pro shop, so they could “falsely describe the purchase later as ‘some [golf] balls for the wounded warriors'." His name remains on the ballot for the 50th District in November's mid-term elections. Photo shows Duncan Hunter with his wife during a photo-op swearing-in ceremony in Washington DC, January 5th 2011. Credit: AP/Alex Brandon #California #USA #congress

Greece is gradually coming out of the deepest depression suffered by any rich country since the second world war. The economy is growing and unemployment is falling. On August 20th, eight years after it first sought help, the country has emerged from its final bail-out programme with official creditors. The three bail-outs cost Greece €300bn ($350bn)—without counting interest payments or the effects of harsh austerity. Although debt remains a crippling 180% of GDP, Greece should once again be able to raise money, thanks to an agreement with creditors that extends the maturity of some loans by ten years. Greece’s recent progress is welcome, but the country still faces immense difficulties. Photo taken in Athens on August 8th 2018. Credit: AFP/Louisa Goulimaki #Parthenon #Acropolis #Athens #austerity #GreeceEconomy

Supporters gather to mark the 100th day that Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian film director, has sustained his hunger strike on August 21st 2018. In front of the Russian embassy in Kiev, they demanded his release and all 64 Ukrainian political prisoners (some of whom are listed in the poster on the right). Since our last update many high-profile names within the film industry have joined calls for his release. A group of Czech filmmakers announced a rotating fast in a show of solidarity over the next five days, including Václav Kadrnka, Zuzana Kříhová, Eva Papoušková, Radim Špaček and Roman Vávra. On August 15th more than 100 other international filmmakers and artists wrote an open letter, published in Le Monde, a French newspaper. They included Ken Loach, a British director, Margarethe von Trotta, a German director and actress and Jean-Luc Godard, a Swiss-French filmmaker.

Mr Sentsov was arrested at his home in Crimea in 2014 by members of Russia's Federal Security Service. At his trial the prosecution failed to prove any link to "terrorist acts" and the key prosecution witness stated in court that he had given his testimony under duress. Instead of the trial collapsing, Mr Sentsov was given a 20-year sentence in a Siberian penal colony. He has survived on water and nutrients supplied via intravenous drip. In 2014 Russia was suspended from membership of the G8 over its invasion and annexation of Crimea. Credit: EPA-EFE/REX Shutterstock/Stepan Franko #Ukraine #FreeSentsov #Crimea #SaveOlegSentsov #protest #Kiev #OlegSentsov #films #CzechRepublic

A study by researchers from Facebook, Harvard, NYU and Princeton analyses the social “connectedness” of Americans, as measured by friendship links on Facebook. Using aggregated and anonymised data, the authors find that Americans with tightly clustered social networks comprised mainly of friends located within a short distance of their home tend to have lower incomes, lower levels of education and lower life expectancies. Those with more geographically dispersed social networks tend to be richer, more educated and healthier. These findings may prove valuable to policymakers. In their analysis of the relationship between social-media connections and trade, the authors note that each ten percentage-point increase in a state’s social connectedness to a foreign country is associated with 4.7% more imports from that country, and 6% more exports. Lawmakers looking for ways to reduce America’s $800bn trade deficit might consider strengthening relationships with those beyond their borders. #data #graphicdetail #trade

Venezuela's socialist economic model continues to unravel, meaning purchases of basic items such as a bar of soap or a kilo of tomatoes require piles of cash. A government plan to curb hyperinflation came in to force on Monday. New banknotes denominated in "sovereign bolivars" are now legal tender, with five zeros taken off. The Venezuelan government hopes that its new economic plan will curb the country's hyperinflation. But economists have warned that the new measures do not address the root causes of inflation in Venezuela and that the printing of new notes could actually exacerbate inflation. Ahead of the changes, many Venezuelans stocked up on whatever staple goods they could get hold of amid longstanding shortages. Credit: Reuters/Carlos Garcia Rawlins #Venezuela #inflation #economy #photography

Seeing her son for the first time in 67 years, Lee Keum-seom, who is 92, weeps as she hugs Ri Sang Chol, who is 71. In the 1950s the Korean War and the subsequent division of the country tore thousands of families apart. There have been previous reunion events, but the last was three years ago. Just 89 South Koreans and 83 North Koreans were allowed to briefly meet up at the Mount Kumgang (Diamond Mountain) resort in North Korea on August 20th 2018. After just a few, infinitely precious, hours the families were again split up. Given their age, most will probably never see each other again. Credit: Korea Pool via AP #Korea #NorthKorea #SouthKorea #reunion

From @1843mag: “Into the valley of Death/Rode the six hundred”, wrote Alfred, Lord Tennyson, commemorating the ill-fated charge of the Light Brigade at the Battle of Balaclava during the Crimean war. Roger Fenton’s monochrome picture of that same valley, taken shortly after the rout of Lord Cardigan’s cavalry in 1854, was one of the first photographs of a battlefield to be published in the West. “The Colour of Time”, a book by the historian Dan Jones (@d_a_n_jones) and the artist Marina Amaral (@marinaarts), opens with Fenton’s confection, which has for the first time been rendered into full colour, along with 199 other photographs taken between 1850 and 1960. A humpback whale (Megaptera novaeangliae) breaches in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of the Uramba Bahía Málaga National Natural Park on August 12th 2018. There is a strong bond between mothers and their young, who will be nursed for up to a year. While swimming they frequently touch each other with their flippers, which can grow up to 16ft (5m) long. A humpback continues to grow for its first ten years. They can reach between 48 and 62ft (14-19m) in length, weigh up to 40 tons and live for 50 years. Research shows that whales communicate with each other as part of an ocean-wide community. Their songs can be picked up by whales many hundreds of miles away. Our cover this week looks at romance in the digital era. Online dating has transformed the biggest decision most people make, that of choosing a mate. Globally at least 200m people use digital dating services every month. In America more than a third of marriages now start with an online match-up. We explore the consequences of this massive social experiment on the most intimate of human decisions, and conclude that the union of algorithms and dating is for better more than for worse. #TheEconomist

This is an excerpt from our obituary of Luc Nkulula, a founder-member of Lutte pour le Changement (Struggle for Change), who died on June 10th 2018. He had campaigned since 2012 for democracy in Congo. 
The fire took hold at around midnight. It was so fierce and sudden in the wooden house in Himbi, outside Goma, in eastern Congo, that Luc Nkulula could not get through the lounge to the main door. Nor could he climb out of his bedroom window, which was barred against thieves. He managed to stuff his laptop and some papers through, the most important things. Then the blazing curtain fell on his back, and he could not fight it off. His sister Amen, coming in from the outside privy, heard a noise like an explosion and saw him burning. After an hour, firemen came; by then, the house was ashes. Investigations by a state procurator blamed an overheated battery, but Mr Nkulula’s friends were sure he had been killed by the government in Kinshasa. 
To read the full obituary search "Under the volcano" on economist.com Credit: KEYTv/YouTube #LucNkulula #Congo #obituary #Lucha

From @1843mag: Six years ago scientists in laboratories on either side of the Atlantic worked out how to edit the code of life – to tweak the information that makes our eyes green, muscles strong or IQs high. Jennifer Doudna, a biologist, was among those leading the charge. CRISPR is a family of DNA sequences found in bacteria that microbes use to defend themselves against viruses. Cas9 is a protein found in CRISPR that cuts up the DNA of invading viruses. Doudna and her team discovered that Cas9 can be trained to do the same to any length of any DNA – even the human genome. To learn more about Doudna’s wall-shattering discovery of CRISPR-Cas9 and what the serious ethical implications are of gene editing, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @bradtorchia #crispr #transhumanism #doudna

Many animals are herbalists. Pregnant elephants eat particular leaves to induce the births of their calves. Birds keep bloodsucking bugs at bay by weaving insect-repelling plants into their nests. Examples of animals employing the products of other animals for medical purposes are, by contrast, rare. But one case has just come to light. Louise Peckre of the German Primate Centre, in Göttingen, has found that red-fronted lemurs treat threadworm infestations with millipede juice. Millipedes have chemical defences, particularly benzoquinones. Ms Peckre watched red-fronted lemurs in Madagascar gnawing on benzoquinone-rich millipedes and rubbing the remains around their anuses, then swallowing them. Human beings, who are frequent hosts of threadworms, can deal with them using drugs such as benzimidazole, which are similar in structure to benzoquinone. Ms Peckre therefore suspects that her lemurs are employing millipedes in lieu of a trip to the pharmacy. Photo of red-fronted lemurs, Madagascar. For the full article search "Scratching an itch" at economist.com. Credit: Alamy /Papilio #Madagascar #lemur #medicine

From @1843mag: “One Second Before Awakening from a Dream Provoked by the Flight of a Bee Around a Pomegranate” (1944), by Salvador Dalí, was inspired by a dream that his wife, Gala, recounted to him. In her dream, the bee has become a tiger, the bee sting a bayonet. Posing as Dalí’s model, Gala appears in hundreds of Dalí’s drawings and paintings. He was sexually fascinated by her but, by his own account, was afraid of sex. An exhibition at the National Art Museum of Catalonia, in Barcelona, looks at Dalí and Gala’s five-decade-long relationship, its trials and tribulations, and the stunning works of surrealism that emerged from it. Image: Fundacio Gala-Salvador Dali #barcelona #art #GalaDali

From @1843mag: Aisha was just 18 when she left her village in Indonesia to become a domestic worker in Saudi Arabia. For ten years she endured crushing loneliness, constant surveillance, virtual imprisonment, seven-day weeks and 16-hour workdays. After she returned to Indonesia, wishing to start a family, money soon ran low and she was forced to leave once again to Saudi, leaving her five-month old child behind. Aisha’s story is shared by millions of migrants who leave home and face hardship, separation and incredible odds to make a better life for themselves and their families. To read Aisha’s story of migration, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo montage: James Wilson #migration #domesticwork

The vast majority of the world’s school calendars include summer holidays. Their length ranges from three weeks in South Korea to three months in America, Italy and Latvia. In the popular imagination, school summer holidays conjure up a picture of carefree youthful exploration. But many parents rely on the term-time services that schools give their offspring, such as supervision and meals. Come the holidays, they can suddenly find their schedules and budgets stretched. Researchers also say that the long break often sets back children’s learning, and that children from poorer backgrounds are disproportionately affected.  Photo taken on July 26th 1939 at Hugh Myddleton School, Clerkenwell, London, at the start of the summer holidays.  Credit: Getty Images/Price/Fox Photos #summer #schoolsout

From @1843mag: It is half-twilight, half-daytime. A streetlamp is lit outside a house, shrouded in shadow, but the sky above is brilliant turquoise. Light and time are manipulated, but gently. “People who look for symbolic meanings fail to grasp the inherent poetry and mystery of the image,” the Belgian surrealist painter René Magritte wrote. “The Dominion of Light” (1954) resists interpretation. The centrepiece of an exhibition about Magritte @SFMOMA is a semi-circle of seven versions of “Dominion of Light”. The viewer sits among them, immersed by the weirdness. To explore more of the poetry and mystery of Magritte’s paintings, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Painting: Musees Royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique. #painting #magritte #surrealism #sanfrancisco

A visitor looks into the recovery ward at an obstetric fistula repair centre in Maiduguri, Nigeria on August 1st 2018. If a difficult labour is not attended by an obstetrician or midwife it can go on for days. Contractions force the baby's head against the pelvis. Delicate tissues in the rectum, vagina and bladder are crushed. This is excruciatingly painful and after a few days of being deprived of blood some of these tissues die, leaving a small hole (fistula). The baby is often stillborn, but the mother's suffering doesn't end there. These holes are the source of lifelong, life-changing incontinence as urine and or fecal matter leak into the vagina. The women are ostracised by their communities because they have begun to smell so bad. They are deprived of dignity, friends, support, social interaction and work. Around 15,000 surgical repairs are carried out each year by charitable organisations, but for every one it is believed more than 50 women go untreated. Organisations like www.safehands.org and www.fistulafoundation.org are working to give these women back their lives and their dignity. Credit: Reuters/Afolabi Sotunde #women #health #medicine

Droning on, and on. Zephyr S has just set a new flight-endurance record for a drone, of 25 days, 23 hours and 57 minutes. The previous endurance record, of just over 14 days, was set in 2010 by the Zephyr 7, an earlier version of this aircraft. The Zephyr 7 was developed by QinetiQ, a British defence company. In 2013 QinetiQ sold the Zephyr programme to Airbus, a European aerospace firm. The model S, with a wingspan of 25 metres, weighs less than 75kg and lacks an undercarriage. It will soon be joined by a bigger, more advanced version, the model T. The point is to show that solar-powered aircraft of this sort can compete with satellites in the markets for Earth observation and telecommunications. That eventually they will stay aloft for months. For the full article see "Zephyr, a high-flying drone, sets an endurance record" at economist.com Credit: Airbus #drone #technology #flight #solarflight #satellite

One of the internet’s most odious conspiracy theorists has had his videos and podcasts removed from Apple, YouTube, Spotify and Facebook. Alex Jones, who has a radio show and runs a few websites, including Infowars, has raised doubts about, among other things, the murders of 26 children and teachers in the Sandy Hook mass shooting, claiming the story was manufactured by gun-control advocates. Mr Jones’s websites peddling this rubbish are still fully operational. Mr Jones has, naturally, seen machinations in this too: the decisions by Apple, swiftly followed by others, to remove his material from their platforms feed with comic precision into his conspiracy theorising about mainstream media. “Apple, Spotify, Facebook and YouTube all banned Infowars within 12 hours of each other”, an Infowars writer wrote on August 6th. This is proof that the “purge was a co-ordinated effort” to meddle with the mid-term elections November rather than a good-faith effort to enforce the sites’ rules about hate speech. Photo taken on July 19th 2016. From @1843mag: As a young Muslim growing up in north-western England in the early nineties, Adnan Sarwar was bored with going to the local mosque every day and tired of people spitting on him in the street calling him a Paki. He wanted a life of freedom and adventure so – filled with fantasies of going to war – he joined the British army. Next thing he knew, it was 2003 and he was in Iraq, following the invading American army towards Baghdad as part of a bomb-disposal squad. Fifteen years on, he writes about the ludicrous yet oddly inspirational Americans soldiers he met, the tedium of waiting for something to happen – and the sinking feeling of having one's porn mags confiscated. There are three main justifications for imposing a tax on a specific good. One is common to all levies: it raises money for the government. The second is that its use inflicts costs on third parties that are not factored into its price. The third is to discourage the use of undesirable products. Critics of such taxes have argued that they are ineffective because the goods they target tend to be addictive, making consumers relatively unresponsive to changes in price. In fact, study after study has shown that sin taxes do tend to reduce consumption. However, the people who are put off by higher prices may well be those who drink alcohol or fizzy drinks only sparingly and are not obese. These consumers impose no obvious costs on the rest of society, but are taxed the same as true sinners. #TheEconomist #sintaxes

From @1843mag: When he was young, the Hungarian novelist László Krasznahorkai often slept in pubs and at railway stations. Because he had nowhere to work, he would construct sentences in his head. Now Krasznahorkai is a writer of renown. His readings sell out; fans queue up for his autograph. Yet he still drafts his novels in the same way: in his head. For Krasznahorkai, the whirls and eddies of language capture the reality of human thought and emotion. The snappy, short sentences we’re more used to reading in modern fiction are “artificial”, he says. When we say “I love you” it means not a terse statement of fact, “but an entire flow of words and feelings. And there’s no way just to put a dot at the end of it.” To read our profile of the great European novelist, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Eyevine #LászlóKrasznahorkai #literature

As lethal fires, heatwaves and drought spread across the northern hemisphere, analysis suggests that Europe’s sweltering summer would have been less than half as likely were it not for human-induced climate change. Despite efforts to curb global warming, greenhouse-gas emissions are rising. Investments in oil and gas are up; in renewables they have stalled. It is tempting to think these are temporary setbacks—that people, with their instinct for self-preservation, will muddle through to victory over climate change. In fact, mankind is losing the war. #TheEconomist

Abolition of the death penalty has become a specific goal of the Catholic church. The Vatican announced on August 2nd 2018 that teaching on use of the death penalty has been changed. It is now inadmissible in all cases. The Catechism of the Catholic Church had previously allowed for the death penalty in limited specific cases. Pope Francis has now said the it is "an attack on the inviolability and dignity of the person" and that the Catholic church will work with determination to achieve the abolition of capital punishment worldwide. The golden touch: Nestled in the forested hills of central Vietnam two colossal concrete hands emerge from the trees, holding up a glimmering Cau Vang , or “Golden bridge”, in the Ba Na Hills near Danang. The bridge was designed to evoke an image of the “giant hands of Gods, pulling a strip of gold out of the land,” according to Vu Viet Anh, Design Principal at TA Landscape Architecture, the company that designed the unusual structure. Its pedestrian walkway sits at over 1,000 meters above sea level offering majestic views of the tree canopy below. Since it opened in June, visitors have flocked to the 150 metre-long bridge, to take selfies and marvel at this novel piece of architecture. Credits: Reuters/Kham and AFP/Linh Pham #CauVang #GoldenBridge #Vietnam #bridge #architecture #design #tourism

Gerda Taro, born Gerta Pohorylle, was a pioneering German-Jewish war photographer who died aged 26 while covering the Spanish Civil War in 1937. During the Battle of Brunete, Miss Pohorylle was standing on the running board of a car transporting wounded soldiers when a Republican tank crashed into it. She died the following day. Gerta Pohorylle was the companion and professional partner of the acclaimed photographer Robert Capa, born Endre Friedmann. Miss Pohorylle significantly contributed to the early work credited to their joint alias "Robert Capa". Eventually she created her own alias, Gerda Taro, and began to publish her work separately. Sadly her legacy remains largely unknown and her work has been overshadowed by Capa’s. But she is now considered one of the world’s first frontline female war photographers, and was the first to die in action. Today would have been her 108th birthday. Credit: Alamy/The History Collection #photojournalist #GerdaTaro #RobertCapa #womenphotographers #warphotography #photojournalism

Actors and directors hold placards reading #FreeSentsov during an appeal on behalf of Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian film director, at the end of the premiere of "Class Act: East-West" in Kiev on July 3rd 2018.  Since our last update Mr Sentsov has continued his hunger strike, demanding the release of all 64 Ukrainian political prisoners held in Russia. Today is the 80th consecutive day that Oleg Sentsov, a vocal opponent of Russia’s 2014 annexation of Crimea, has refused food. He was arrested at his home in Simferopol in May 2014. According to Amnesty International members of the FSB, Russia's Federal Security Service, put a plastic bag over his head and suffocated him until he passed out before removing him and transporting him to Russia for trial. They threatened him with rape and murder to force him to “confess” to organising “terrorist acts”. Mr Sentsov has always maintained his innocence. No single piece of evidence was presented to the court to prove Mr Sentsov’s personal involvement. The case against him should have collapsed when the key prosecution witness stated in court that he had testified against Mr Sentsov under duress. Instead Mr Sentsov received a 20-year prison sentence, being served in Siberia. His lawyer told the Associated Press that Mr Sentsov is receiving nutrients intravenously and drinking water. He is very weak and has lost more than 20kgs (44lbs) in weight. Russia was suspended from membership of the G8 over its invasion and annexation of Crimea. Credit: AFP/Genya Savilov #SaveOlegSentsov #OlegSentsov #Ukraine #Kiev #Russia #hungerstrike #protest #Crimea @amnesty

The Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) was established in 1928 by Rev John Flynn to provide medical aid to remote communities around Australia. From one single plane, the RFDS has expanded to a fleet of 69 aircraft and 115 road vehicles, operating out of 24 airbases around the country, which employ over 1500 people. One third of the population lives in remote areas of Australia's 7.7 million square kilometres, making this healthcare and emergency service a lifeline. Earlier this year Prime Minister Turnbull announced $84 million dollars would go to the RFDS for dental and mental health programs as part of the federal budget. Credit: Getty Images/Lisa Maree Williams #Australia #RFDS #FlyingDoctors #medicine #emergencyservices #flying #doctors

Two elections, both free and fair? Zimbabweans voted today in the first polls since Robert Mugabe was forced to resign after 37 years in power. Although international observers have been welcomed for the first time in years, the election isn’t expected to be exactly free and fair. Emmerson Mnangagwa, who became president after November’s coup, is expecting victory. His strongest challenger is Nelson Chamisa, leader of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. There are concerns over army interference, a voter roll including dead people and a ballot paper conveniently placing Mr Mnangagwa at the top. 
In Pakistan's general election, the prime-minister-elect’s victory this week was, some suspect, eased by the military’s invisible hand. Almost every party except Imran Khan’s raised accusations of vote-tampering. Groups claimed that security officials ordered their polling agents out of the voting stations before a final tally had been reached. Photos taken on July 30th 2018. Could there be microbial life in a lake 1.5km beneath Mars's surface? There is no shortage of water on Mars. Astronomers reckon there is at least 5m cubic kilometres of ice locked up beneath the planet’s dusty regolith. Now the question of whether any of it is liquid seems to have been settled in spectacular style. In a paper published in Science on July 25th, Roberto Orosei of the National Institute for Astrophysics in Italy, and his colleagues, report the discovery of a lake of liquid water 20km across, buried 1.5km beneath Mars’s surface. The discovery is exciting from a purely geological point of view. But the biggest question is whether anything might be alive down there. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech #aliens #UFO #lifeonMars #MarsLake

From @1843mag: A fundamental paradox of human psychology is that thinking can be bad for us. When we follow our own thoughts too closely, we can lose our bearings, as our inner chatter drowns out common sense. A study of shopping behaviour found that the less information people were given about a brand of jam, the better the choice they made. When offered details of ingredients, they got befuddled by their options and ended up choosing a jam they didn’t like. The psychologist Gerd Gigerenzer argues that to make good decisions in a complex world, you have to be skilled at ignoring information. This is because much of our behaviour is based on deceptively sophisticated rules-of-thumb, or “heuristics”. To learn more about the psychology of overthinking, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #psychology #behaviouraleconomics #overthinking

From @1843mag: The Cornish pasty is a delicacy in an unlikely place: Mexico. In the early 19th century, the tin mines in Cornwall, the county on England’s rugged southwestern tip, fell into decline. Many miners crossed the Atlantic in search of work. They had an especially warm welcome in Mexico, whose war of independence from Spain (1810-1821) had left its infrastructure battered and its mines flooded. Trekking 250 miles through swamps, thicket and rainforests, hundreds of Cornish miners settled around the silver mines of Real del Monte, a mountainous town in the state of Hidalgo in central Mexico. They brought the tools and expertise needed to dig for treasure, as well as a treasure of their own: a half-moon-shaped pocket pie with a meat and vegetable filling. To learn more about the delightful travels of the Cornish pasty, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Alamy #food #cornishpasty #migration #specialrelationship

From @1843mag: “Self Portrait as Saint Catherine of Alexandria”, a 17th-century painting by Artemisia Gentileschi, was bought for a whopping £3.6m ($4.7m) by London’s @national_gallery earlier this month. This is a big deal because Gentileschi’s painting is one of just 21 by female artists in the museum’s collection of more than 2,300 works of art. Also, many of Gentileschi’s paintings have strong, fierce female heroines as their subject. Saint Catherine of Alexandria was martyred in the 4th century after the Roman Emperor Maxentius sentenced her to death for protesting about his persecution of Christians in Egypt. The Romans tried to kill her by tying her to a spiked wheel, but the contraption broke at her touch. She escaped momentarily, only to be beheaded. To discover more about Gentileschi's heroines, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #painting #gentileschi

Little remains of Palestine’s capital-in-exile. Yarmouk, on the southern edge of Damascus, Syria’s capital. It was once the Palestinians’ largest and liveliest refugee camp, sheltering displaced Iraqis and Syrians too. But in May 2018 two weeks of relentless bombing by the regime of Bashar al-Assad and his Russian backers reduced it to rubble. Of the 350,000 people who once lived in Yarmouk, only a few hundred remain. In 2015 the jihadists of Islamic State (IS) took control of most of Yarmouk. Jabhat al-Nusra, an erstwhile al-Qaeda affiliate, grabbed the rest. When the regime was not fighting them, they battled each other. Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, has remained neutral during Syria’s war and some Palestinian groups even fought with the regime on the camp’s frontlines. But there is little hope that things will return to the way they were. “We’ll increasingly face a climate in which we cannot continue to live,” says a refugee from Yarmouk, now in London. From @1843mag: The shelves of Wu Chi-kai’s workshop in Hong Kong are stacked with hollow glass rods. Each contains a layer of phosphorus and is pumped with neon or argon gas that lights up when electric current passes through it. To bend the rods, Wu heats them just to the point of pliability, a delicate procedure because the glass will shatter if it gets too hot. In its heyday, neon-lit Hong Kong literally outshone communist China. But the industry had dwindled by the turn of the century because of competition from the mainland and the introduction of cheaper LED lighting. Gentrification has also played a part in the decline: as neighbourhoods become more upmarket, old buildings are torn down and, with them, their neon signs. Wu Chi-kai is one of the few remaining neon artists. Click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio to read more. Photograph: Caroline Carter #hongkong #neon #art

From @1843mag: The Wassily chair is one of those rare designs that is absolutely modern in spirit but also very comfortable. It was designed in 1925 by Marcel Breuer, a Hungarian-born modernist designer. Many other revolutionary chairs have come along since, but you can’t sit in most of them for any real length of time. Breuer wanted his furniture to be used – not to be put in a museum. Peter Ghyczy, a designer famous for his Garden Egg Chair (1968), tells 1843 why he wished he had designed the Wassily chair and how it has inspired his own work. From @1843mag: This portrait of the playwright Samuel Beckett, capturing his deep-etched brow, winged eyebrows and an expression that is both knowing and guarded, was taken in 1976 by Jane Bown, a photographer for the Observer. It was one of just five frames she took at the stage door of the Royal Court theatre as Beckett was trying to avoid her. Bown was unusual in that she preferred to dispense with the usual tricks of her trade – the lights and reflectors and darkroom shimmies – relying instead on her eye and her ability to melt into the background. She shot on 35mm film, almost always in black and white, and rarely took more than 10 minutes on an assignment – sometimes less. She was also one of the best portrait photographers of her time – Lord Snowdon described her as “a kind of English [Henri] Cartier-Bresson”. See more of Jane Bown’s photographs of 20th century Britain, on display @proudgalleries, by clicking on 1843’s handle and following the link in their bio. New data released by the Bureau of Labour Statistics show that, as a whole, America appears to be getting more rest. The agency asks a representative sample of some 25,000 Americans to log and time every activity during the course of their day. The data demonstrate that from 2003 to 2017 the amount of sleep increased by a minute each year, on average. The average American now rests for eight hours and 48 minutes per night. Some of this increase is probably the result of an ageing population: the average American was two years older in 2017 than in 2003. When plotted against age, sleep patterns form a U-shape: the old and young sleep the most and the middle-aged sleep the least. The bend now is steeper for men. By their mid-30s, men get about about 15 minutes’ less sleep than women do, whereas in the 70s the averages for both sexes were identical. #data #sleep #rest #health #UnitedStates #America

From @1843mag: A boy and his adopted mother, Daufuskie Island, South Carolina, 1952. The madeleine memories of lots of Americans were made on their parents’ porches, the rhythm, temperature and scents eliding in a childhood haze. Often they come from a time before air conditioning, which instigated the porch’s post-war decline. Cars hurt, too: they meant more fumes and less foot traffic, so fewer passers-by and impromptu hellos. Television drew people inside, to follow distant, fictional narratives instead of the micro-theatre of the pavement. People began to prefer backyard decks to streetside exposure. They became too busy to loiter in the evening; the aspiration to unbounded leisure that the porch represents increasingly seemed too remote to pursue. But the porch didn’t die and, in many new developments, it is being revived, as homeowners flee the forces that threatened it in the first place – all those inauthentic electronic connections and overburdened working lives. Discover why the porch still defines the character of houses in the southern states of America by clicking on 1843’s handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: @magnumphotos #porch #architecture

From @1843mag: Paris is overwritten. Step into Shakespeare and Co. and you’ll find yourself gazing into an abyss of Books About Paris to which every hack in a century with a typewriter and a ticket has contributed. The problem is less where to start than where to stop. There are of course the classics, such as Balzac’s “Colonel Chabert”, Zola’s “L’Assommoir” or Dumas’s “The Count of Monte-Cristo”. A lesser-known gem for fans of boho lit is “Prince Charming”, a memoir by Christopher Logue, a poet who spent several reprobate (but well-connected) years in a 1950s Paris slum. But to discover six works that will take you off the beaten track, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: Jason Ford #books #paris

We have two covers this week. In the Americas and Europe, ahead of the NATO summit in Brussels on July 11th and 12th, we look at the growing transatlantic rift. America did as much as any country to create post-war Europe. The alliance it fostered won the cold war and then built democracy in newly liberated eastern Europe. But tensions—over NATO contributions, divergent priorities and values and, lately, the demands of Donald Trump—are tearing it apart. That should worry Europe, America and the wider world.

In Asia, the Middle East and Africa we report on the plight of women in India. They are less likely to work there than in any G20 country except Saudi Arabia. And their exclusion is getting worse. Since 2005, India’s economy has doubled and the number of working-age women has doubled, yet 10m fewer women have jobs. The economic cost is immense—if Indian women were able to work as Indian men do, the country would be on the way to middle-income status. The human cost, in lost potential, autonomy and fulfilment, is greater still. #TheEconomist

If wishing for words that might finally allow people to say what they mean is a long-standing phenomenon, The Bureau of Linguistical Reality in San Francisco is an index of modern ideas. For the uneasy combination of gradually unfurling disasters like climate change and the 24-hour cycle of breaking news, there is "ennuipocalypse". For the proliferation of new technologies aimed at solving problems “which will in turn eventually produce their own unintended by-products and problems”, there is "teuchnikskreis". For the choice between letting your plants die and overusing water in the midst of a drought, there is "gwilt". For more see "Neologisms" in our Prospero Blog at economist.com Credit: Alamy/photocreo.com #words #culture #language #America #USA

Alive. Ten days after going missing all 13 members of a Thai youth football team have been found alive in the Tham Luang Nang Non cave complex, Chiang Rai. Rescuers have been frantically trying to lower the water level in the caves by redirecting rivers, pumping out rainwater and digging out the accumulated debris and silt that blocks passageways. The three man team from the British Cave Rescue Council that found the boys had to dive through long narrow, shallow flooded channels with zero visibility. But this is just the first, very welcome, stage. Extracting everyone safely is problematic and more rain is forecast. Meanwhile, fresh water and very specific food will be provided. From @1843mag: “The Wonder Down Under”, a “user’s guide to the vagina” written by two medical students, sold out in three days when it was published in Norway last year. Sprinkled with pop-culture references, it is clearly intended for young women. But the peppiness is accompanied by lots of stats and studies, and there are plenty of surprises for grown-ups too. Did you know that sperm can live in the Fallopian tubes for up to seven days? Or that pubic hair heightens sexual sensitivity? Also, the book’s main character, so to speak, is the clitoris. And it turns out it’s bigger, much bigger, than you could possibly imagine.
