China's urbanisation is a marvel. The population of its cities has quintupled over the past 40 years, and now totals 813m. By 2030 roughly one in five of the world’s city-dwellers will be Chinese. Bigger cities are associated with higher productivity and faster economic growth. As a result, the government has sought to foster the rise of mammoth urban clusters, anchored around giant hubs and containing dozens of smaller—but by no means small—nearby cities. The plan calls for 19 clusters in all, which would account for nine-tenths of the country’s economic activity. China would, in effect, condense into a country of super-regions. Three are already well on track: the Pearl River Delta, next to Hong Kong; the Yangtze River Delta, which surrounds Shanghai; and Jingjinji, centred on Beijing. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: After the second world war, Giacometti fell in with a group of philosophers and writers in Paris, including Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and Jean Genet, who were busy questioning the meaning of existence. The next 15 years would be the most prolific period of Giacometti’s life, as he filled his cramped and dusty studio with elongated sculptures of men and women. Modelled aggressively in plaster and cast in soot-dark bronze, these pieces vibrate with a melancholic solitude, whether they are presented alone or in groups. Reedy, impressionistic and as slender as whippets, they evoke both the horrors of war and its fraught aftermath. To discover the transformation of Giacometti’s sculptures after the war, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Ernst Scheidegger. #giacometti #art #sculpture @guggenheim

From @1843mag: Gang members clutch a Bible at the San Francisco Gotera prison. A common saying in El Salvador is that the only way to quit a gang is in a body bag. But Pentecostalist churches are trying to offer a way out alive. In 2009 a prisoner named Nilson Bonilla announced that God had chosen him to be pastor of a new congregation called the Last Trumpet, and he convinced six other prisoners to join him. The movement has since mushroomed. Though without structural changes, the gang troubles in El Salvador are unlikely to disappear. From @1843mag: For a new post-Soviet generation, constructivism looks less like a failed experiment than a potential point of pride. Along with other diamonds in the rough, the Melnikov House, one of Moscow’s most famous constructivist landmarks, is being restored. Built during the late 1920s, the house served as a private residence for Konstantin Melnikov, an architect who later fell foul of the Stalinist regime and in 1937 was banned from practising. Composed of two intersecting cylinders, the rounded walls feature a constellation of hexagonal windows that spread light through the building at all times of day. A wide spiral staircase runs through the centre of the home, stretching from the low first floor through a spacious living room and up to a dreamy studio space. To explore the rich history of Soviet architecture, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #architecture #design #russia

Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian film director is still on hunger strike in a prison camp in Siberia. Since we last posted an update Mr Sentsov, an ethnically Russian-Ukrainian citizen, has continued to refuse food and demand the release of all 64 Ukrainian political prisoners from Russian jails. Today marks the 47th day he has gone without food. Mr Sentsov was born in Crimea and considered it to be part of the Ukrainian state that emerged from the Soviet collapse in 1991. (Nearly every country apart from Russia shares this view.) He was in Crimea in 2014 when Russian soldiers in plain uniform staged a coup there, an action for which Russia was suspended from the G8 group of nations. Oleg Sentsov attended a protest against the annexation and helped deliver food to besieged Ukrainian soldiers. He was seized by Russian security services and taken to Russia where he was charged with “terrorism”. In 2015 he received a 20-year sentence for supposedly plotting to blow up a statue of Lenin and set fire to a door in the Crimean office of Russia’s ruling party. Lenin’s statue was not blown up, and no one was injured in the fire. Mr Sentsov was innocent—the main witness said he had been forced to give false testimony, and withdrew his statement in court. Ukrainian residents demonstrate in support of Mr Sentsov on June 23rd 2018 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. Credit: Press Association/Sipa USA/Paulo Amorim #OlegSentsov #Ukraine #protest #FreeOlegSentsov #Crimea #Amsterdam #Netherlands #humanrights

Our cover this week considers Netflix, the tech giant everyone is watching. It now produces more entertainment output than any TV network and more feature films than any Hollywood studio. What lessons does it have for other firms, and can it go on keeping everyone happy? #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: An accent is such a big part of our identity. It’s like wearing a big sign saying “I am American”, “I’m from Liverpool”, or in Britain perhaps, “I am working-class”. We assume that accents are set early, not just any old sign but an authentic and immutable one. We don’t trust those people known to have changed their accents. Who are you trying to fool?, we wonder. As for those in-betweeners by nature, they face a life of being asked where they’re from and having to answer “it’s complicated.” To read the side-splitting account of an American father despairing at his son’s English accent, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: Thomas Cole, the 19th-century father of American landscape painting, turned to the past to study what the future might hold. His cycle of history paintings, “The Course of Empire”, depicts the rise of a civilisation from hunter-gatherers to agriculturalists to urbanites and its sudden and dramatic collapse. In an echo of the decline of the Roman empire, power has made the people in this painting, the third in the series, prosperous but also decadent – unwitting agents in their imminent demise. Implicit here was a critique of America’s emerging capitalist class and the European empires. To see the other paintings in Cole’s series, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Painting: “The Consummation of Empire” (1835–6) @national_gallery #thomascole #civilisation #rome #painting

From @1843mag: Canada may not be the first place one thinks of as a wine-growing region, but the inhabitants of Canada’s Niagara peninsula know ice wine well. The drink is made from grapes that freeze on the vine; freezing forces water out of the grapes, leaving just a tiny drop of nectar inside. The peninsula is where 90% of global production takes place and where most of it is drunk. But that may be about to change. This sweet, syrupy but complex and extremely palatable wine is trickling into the more upscale outlets in Britain and across the world. To discover more about the rise of these rare wines, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: IDS/Plainpicture #wine #canada

Sierra Leone is one of the world’s poorest countries, but it is better at beating back tropical diseases than almost anywhere else in Africa. Fifteen years ago as much as half the population was infected with the worm that causes onchocerciasis, or river blindness. Yet by 2017 only 2% of people carried the worm, and there had been no new cases recorded of people going blind from onchocerciasis in a decade. Elimination is expected by about 2022. Swipe through the maps to see this dramatic decrease. But how has Sierra Leone achieved this? Each year it provides drugs for four major diseases to everyone at risk. Treating people at roughly the same time reduces the chances of them reinfecting one another. It also saves money because health workers can visit each village only once instead of several times a year. #TheEconomist #SierraLeone #tropicaldisease #health

A marvelous new exhibition at the @vamuseum in London traces the links between her life, her style and her work, showcasing artefacts that have never before left Mexico City. This week we have two covers about two men. Both of them go by their initials and both may be tempted to lead their countries astray.

In the Americas we look at Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who seems destined to win Mexico’s presidential election on July 1st. AMLO, as he is known, has a folksy air of incorruptibility that enchants many Mexicans. But the nationalist populism he offers is unlike anything Mexico has seen since the early 1980s. When AMLO promises a “radical revolution”, some worry that he will be as good as his word.

In our other editions we report on Muhammad bin Salman, the crown prince who is shaking up Saudi Arabia. The country is uniquely disliked by Westerners, yet the world has a vital interest in its fate. Under MBS, as he is known, cinemas have opened; music is performed in public; and this weekend women will for the first time be allowed to drive. The trouble is that MBS has developed a taste for authoritarianism at home and recklessness abroad. #TheEconomist

Some good news for the jaguar (Panthera onca). According to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) the population of wild jaguars in Mexico grew 20 percent during the last eight years. There are now believed to be around 4,800 individuals. This success story is the result of an intensive effort by the government in collaboration with local people, academics and NGOs to preserve the jaguar's habitat. In March 2018 the United Nations took a further step to secure their long-term future, when 14 Latin American countries signed a regional conservation program for big cats, valid until 2030. Photo taken at Laguna Om Nature Reserve, Quintana Roo and released by WWF on June 14th 2018. Credit: AFP/WWF/HO #conservation #wildlife #jaguar #Mexico #WWF

Streaming platforms like Tidal, Deezer and 7digital are translating their entire catalogues into music files that play at studio quality. After a news-packed week, we have three animated covers. Swipe to see them all. In Asia and the Americas we assess the “historic” meeting between President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un. If this week’s flimsy agreement is to amount to anything, America must be tough-minded and eagle-eyed. 
In Britain we try to make sense of yet another week of Brexit chaos. Parliamentary arithmetic and the need to keep an open border in Ireland are leading inexorably to a softer deal, in which Britain stays close to Europe.

In continental Europe we look at how democracy suffers under strongmen like Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Around the world, the least-bad system of government ever devised is in trouble. It needs defenders. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Harry Benson, a photographer for the “Daily Express”, covered the Beatles for 32 months from early 1964, and ended up defining their image. For this photograph he encouraged them to indulge their reputed fondness for a pillow fight. John Lennon replied it would make the band look childish. Then he blindsided Paul McCartney with a pillow. The public saw happy, irrepressible scamps enjoying the most wholesome bedroom pursuit imaginable. “Every photographer comes down to one picture,” Benson notes, “and that is mine.” Discover more of Benson's portraits of the band by clicking on 1843’s handle and following the link in their bio. #beatlemania #thebeatles #harrybenson

A two-week-old wild rabbit cleans its ears on the island of Skomer, less than a mile off the coast of Pembrokeshire, Wales on June 9th 2018. The island is surrounded by a marine nature reserve and is itself a protected area having been designated a Site of Special Scientific Interest. This haven for wildlife has a huge bird population that includes puffins, short-eared owls and peregrine falcons. There are populations of dolphin, Atlantic grey seal and harbour porpoise in the waters around it and in spring the whole island is carpeted in bluebells. Credit: Reuters/Rebecca Naden #Skomer #Wales #island #nature #wildlife #conservation

A bicycle leans against the wall of a home entombed by volcanic ash, spewed from the Volcan de Fuego in San Miguel Los Lotes, Guatemala on June 11th 2018. Credit: AP/Rodrigo Abd #volcano #photography  #Feugo #Guatemala

From @1843mag: In 1959, with the help of a $500 loan from his father, Jim Olson, of Seattle-based design practice @olsonkundig, built a wooden bunkhouse overlooking Puget Sound. The building was tiny but as time went by he began adding to it. In 1981 he built two more cabins to create a bedroom and bathroom, and in 2003 he added a living room. He then brought the parts together under one roof, creating a series of covered walkways. The house stands in a forest of ancient firs, its central section stained dark so that it almost disappears into the hilly landscape behind it. To discover more about the growth of this magical lakeside retreat, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Credit: Kevin Scott #design #jimolson

The big leaves of the Victoria giant water lily, which have grown to almost two metres in size, on display in the Victoria House at the botanical garden in Berlin, Germany on June 14th 2018. After extensive restoration work the greenhouse will be re-opening on June 16th. Credit DPA/Jens Kalaene #Berlin #BotanicalGarden #lily #flowers #botanic #Germany

Fans around the planet are squabbling over who has the best chance of winning the World Cup. The betting markets suggest that there is little to separate Brazil, Germany, Spain and France, who between them have roughly a 60% probability of victory. But The Economist has tried to answer a more fundamental question: what makes a country good at football in the first place? We built a statistical model that aims to identify the underlying sporting and economic factors that determine a country’s long-term footballing performance. We downloaded the results of all international games since 1990 (which have been collected by Mart Jürisoo, a data scientist) and tested which variables have been correlated with the goal difference between teams. #worldcup #football #data #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Although Cuba will not be taking part in the World Cup finals this year (they haven’t qualified since 1938), a certain Cuban tune is guaranteed to make an appearance. “Guantanamera”, beloved of football fans around the world, was written in the late 1920s by Joseíto Fernández, a musician from Havana nicknamed “the king of the melody”. To explore the rich history of what is perhaps the most versatile and global football song of all time, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Getty. Montage: James Wilson. #guantanamera #fifa #worldcup

School children perform a dragon dance in Yanshan County, Hebei Province on June 14th 2018, ahead of the upcoming Dragon Boat Festival which will be celebrated on June 18th 2018. Credit: PA/Xinhua/Fu Xinchun #dragonboatracing #dragon #dance #China #Hebei

The end of the holy month of Ramadan is determined by observing the position of the moon. The date can vary around the world. Eid al-Fitr is the religious holiday that marks the end of Ramadan, when Muslims stop fasting and celebrate with family and friends. Photo taken on June 14th 2018 in Lhok Nga (Lho-nga or Lhoknga), Aceh, Indonesia.  Credit: EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock/Hotli Simanjuntak #EidalFitr #Indonesia #Ramadan #Ache #silhouette #telescope #moon

After a news-packed week, we have three covers. Swipe to see them all. In Asia and the Americas we assess the “historic” meeting between President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un. If this week’s flimsy agreement is to amount to anything, America must be tough-minded and eagle-eyed. 
In Britain we try to make sense of yet another week of Brexit chaos. Parliamentary arithmetic and the need to keep an open border in Ireland are leading inexorably to a softer deal, in which Britain stays close to Europe.

In continental Europe we look at how democracy suffers under strongmen like Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Around the world, the least-bad system of government ever devised is in trouble. It needs defenders. #TheEconomist

"Catso Violet" (1967) by James Turrell, an American artist, is one of the works on show at the "Unlimited" show, part of Art Basel in Switzerland, June 12th 2018. Mr Turrell was born in Pasadena, California in 1943. For forty years he has been exploring the use of light and space in his work. "Unlimited" is Art Basel's exhibition platform for projects that transcend the limitations of a classical art-show stand, including out-sized sculpture and paintings, video projections, large-scale installations and live performances. Credit: AP/Georgios Kefalas/Keystone #art #ArtBasel #JamesTurrell #Basel #Switzerland

The Serranía de Chiribiquete national park in Colombia is among 30 new nominations submitted to the UNESCO World Heritage Committee. Located in the Amazonian jungle departments of Caquetá and Guaviare, the 2,782,353-hectare national park is the largest of Colombia's protected natural areas. In addition to astonishing rock formations and majestic mountains, this park includes some of the most abundant ancient rock art in the world. Countries around the world are submitting their applications for the status prize of World Heritage Site. Credit: AFP/Guillermo Legaria #UNESCO #WorldHeritageSite #Colombia #SerraniaDeChiribiquete
A pool being cleaned at a thermal spa in Harkany, Hungary on June 11th 2018. Photo taken with a drone. Credit: REX/Shutterstock/Tamas Soki/EPA-EFE #Hungary #drone #photography

You could almost hear the soundtrack as this super raccoon embarked on a perilous climb up the side of the UBS Tower in St. Paul, Minnesota on June 12th, 2018. The raccoon (whose true identity is still a mystery) became an instant social media star with thousands of Twitter users following its every move. Inch by gruelling inch, the raccoon scaled the 23-storey building, defying gravity and logic (some speculated it was planning a sneak attack on roof-top pigeon nests). Fans of #mprraccoon breathed a collective sigh of relief when, in the early hours of the following morning, the scruffy superhero was captured using a live trap baited with cat food. Credit: Minnesota Public Radio via AP/Evan Frost #Minnesota #spidercoon #catfoodburglar

At sunset a group of friends pose for a photo as they prepare to break their Ramadan fast at Rabat beach, Morocco on June 9, 2018. Credit: AP/Mosa'ab Elshamy #Morocco #sunset #beach #celebration #Ramadan

Messi hair: A hair-razing portrait of Lionel Messi, the Argentinian football player has been created by  hairdresser Mario Hvala at his salon in Novi Sad, Serbia on June 10th, 2018. Mr Hvala is offering clients the opportunity to sport a football superstar like Lionel Messi or Cristiano Ronaldo ahead of the World Cup, which kicks off on June 14th 2018. Credit: AFP/Vladimir Zivojinovic #football #LionelMessi #WorldCup #Serbia #sport

President Donald Trump meets with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un at the Capella resort, Sentosa Island, Singapore on June 12th 2018. Mr Kim will be thrilled. He has now implicitly been recognised as an equal by a sitting American president, something both his father and grandfather wanted but never achieved. North Korean flags stood alongside America’s. Mr Trump said it was an “honour” to be sitting down with the North Korean despot. Mr Kim observed, as they walked down the corridor for their first one-on-one meeting, that many people would think they were in a fantasy “from a science-fiction movie”. Credit: AP/Evan Vucci #nuclear #DonaldTrump #KimJongUn #peace #NorthKorea #UnitedStates

Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian film director, is now on day 30 of his hunger strike. Mr Sentsov was arrested in Crimea on May 11th 2014 by Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB). He was accused of being involved with a terrorist cell (allegedly plotting to blow up a statue of Lenin) in Crimea. Mr Sentsov’s real offence was to oppose Russia’s annexation of his native Crimea, helping deliver food to Ukrainian soldiers trapped on their bases after the Russian invasion. At trial in 2015 he was sentenced to 20 years in prison. Supporters held a rally "For a free Russia without repression and arbitrariness" in Moscow, Russia on June 10th 2018. Credit: EPA/REX/Shutterstock/Maxim Shipenkov #protest #hungerstrike #Ukraine #Russia #Crimea #OlegSentsov

This bodhi tree has famously wrapped itself around a sculptured head of the Buddha at Wat Mahathat temple in Thailand's ancient capital of Ayutthaya. The sight attracts many tourists to the temple. Photo taken on June 11th 2018. Credit: PA/Sipa USA/Chaiwat Subprasom #Thailand #Buddha #sculpture #nature #temple #Ayutthaya #tourism

It's quite unusual for a G7 Summit photo to go viral. This one did on June 9th 2018. Taken by the German government photographer, it shows President Donald Trump with Chancellor Angela Merkel and other attendees during the G7 Summit in La Malbaie, Quebec, Canada.  The composition of the picture has people seeing echoes of paintings by artists from Leonardo Da Vinci to Norman Rockwell, often being posted with alterations to the image or a new caption. John Bolton, Mr Trump's national security adviser (2nd from right) tweeted the photo with a caption that concluded: "The President made it clear today. No more." Credit: AFP/Bundesregierung/Jesco Denzel #DonaldTrump #G7 #Canada #G7Summit #Merkel

Snorre, a seal pup, catches fish at the seal sanctuary in Norddeich, Germany on June 8th 2018. The sanctuary and research centre houses pups that have become separated from their mothers and found alone on North Sea beaches. After being nursed for around two months the seals are self-sufficient and ready to be released back into the wild. Credit: EPA/REX/Shutterstock #seal #sealpup #fish #Germany #nature #conservation

Housekeeping. At the newly opened "Line Village" theme park in Bangkok, Thailand, a member of staff cleans the exhibit of Line social media character "Choco" on June 8th 2018.  Line, a social media messaging app, is hugely popular in Thailand, with over 40 millions users. Credit: AFP/Jewel Samad #LineVillage #Choco #Thailand #Bangkok

From @1843mag: Sandy Wood and Alex Laufer are on their second careers. Wood previously worked as a lawyer, while Laufer ran a biotech lab in Silicon Valley. In 2013 they decided to quit their jobs and took the plunge as entrepreneurs, opening their own distillery in Washington D.C. Last autumn, at long last, they released the first bourbon to be produced in the District of Columbia since the end of Prohibition in 1933. In cities around the world, thousands of white-collar workers are fleeing their desks to become brewers, bakers and pickle-makers. To discover the personal stories behind the artisanal boom, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: @ball_albanese #artisans #crafteconomy #OneEightDistillery

An artist works in the chapel at Dresden Castle in Dresden, Germany on June 6th 2018. The castle dates from around 1485 but was considerably altered and enlarged over the years. It was almost entirely destroyed in the intense bombing raids by Allied forces in 1945. Only part of the Green Vault and basement survived. Efforts were made to restore it after the war but it wasn't until 1995 that a comprehensive restoration project was undertaken. Today this majestic building is a thriving mix of museums, exhibition space and offices. Credit: DPA/PA/Sebastian Kahnert #Dresden #castle #chapel #crafts #painting

From @1843mag: Stanley Kubrick began his career as a photographer. Born in the Bronx in 1928, he left high school in 1945, and went straight to “Look” magazine. Two years later, it included a short profile of the 19-year-old “veteran”, accompanied by an unsmiling headshot. “In his spare time,” notes the article, “Stanley experiments with cinematography and dreams of the day when he can make documentary films.” This shot is from an unpublished profile of Rosemary Williams, a chorus girl hoping for her big break on Broadway. Kubrick was 21 at the time. To discover more of the young Kubrick’s photography, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @museumofcityny #kubrick #photography
A nomadic herder with one of her charges in Konya, Turkey on June 8th 2018. Credit: Credit: Getty Images/Anadolu/Abdullah Coskun #nomad #goat #Turkey

A fine cooling mist descends over Indian Muslims during Friday prayers at a mosque in Allahabad, India on June 8th 2018. Many Muslims around the world are marking the holy month of Ramadan with prayer and by fasting from dawn until dusk. Credit: AP/Rajesh Kumar Singh #India #Ramadan #prayer #mosque

From @1843mag: The story goes like this: when asked by one of his regular customers in 1971 for a bit of sauce for his chicken tikka, Ali Ahmed Aslam, the owner of Glasgow’s Shish Mahal, splashed in a tin of tomato soup, yoghurt and spices. The resulting curry, which he named chicken tikka masala, proved to be a hit. Unsurprisingly, Indian foodies have different takes on its origins: some believe it was invented by the royal chefs of the Mughal period; others that it first cropped up in the Punjab, coincidentally also in 1971. To dive deeper into the origins of this bastion of the British curry house, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Alamy #curry #food #chickentikkamasala

Time for the squad to show if they are match fit, as they are put through their paces at the robotics laboratory of the University of Applied Sciences, Leipzig, Germany on June 6th 2018. Computer science students are assessing the performance of their players before they fly out to compete in "RoboCup 2018", the World Cup for intelligent robots being held in Montreal, Canada between June 18th and 22nd 2018. Credit: DPA/Waltraud Grubitzsch #Leipzig #Germany #robots #football #soccer #WorldCup #RoboCup #Montreal #Canada

Like many countries in Latin America, Argentina outlaws most abortions. Women who undergo them can be jailed for four years (or longer if the baby is deemed to be viable outside the womb). The law makes exceptions for pregnancies that are the result of rape or that endanger the mother’s health or for fetuses that are malformed. Nearly a half-million abortions a year take place, say campaigners for less restrictive laws. On June 13th the lower house of Argentina’s congress will vote on a bill to legalise elective abortions within the first 14 weeks of gestation. Elective abortion is now legal for just 3% of women in Latin America and the Caribbean. If Argentina votes to allow it, that will rise to 10%. #reproductiverights #Argentina

From @1843mag: “Bliss it was in that dawn to be alive, but to be a flamingo was very heaven.” Well, Wordsworth didn’t quite say that, but if he had seen this flock of flamingos, he might well have. Wildlife photographer @franslanting shot these birds in Lake Nakuru in Kenya’s Great Rift Valley, where millions flock to feed and court. A self-taught photographer, he was a scientist before he became captivated by the wonders of the natural world and determined to convey its beauty. View more of Lanting’s breathtaking photography by clicking on 1843’s handle and following the link in their bio. #franslanting #photography #flamingos

In Game 5 of the NHL Stanley Cup Finals, the Washington Capitals beat the Vegas Golden Knights 4-3 in Las Vegas on June 7th 2018. The Caps became Stanley Cup champions for the first time in their 43 NHL seasons. Credit: AP/John Locher #icehockey #NHL #LasVegas #sport #USA

Royal Navy veteran Patrick Thomas looks towards the beach ("Gold Beach") at Lion-sur-Mer where, shortly after the start of the D-Day landings on June 6th 1944, his landing craft was hit by a mine, killing most of his unit before they made it onto dry land. A handful of surviving Normandy veterans were paying their respects to fallen comrades.  The D-Day landings involved 156,000 Allied troops from 13 countries, including Canada, the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, Czechoslovakia and Free France, launching an audacious attack on the coast of France, which would eventually result in the defeat of Nazi Germany. Credit: Getty Images/Matt Cardy #veteran #France #D-Day #WWII

Disinfectant is sprayed in public places as part of an anti-cholera campaign in Sana'a, Yemen on June 7th 2018. A small scale outbreak in Yemen was first reported in October 2016, but the number of cholera cases surged last year because of damage from Saudi airstrikes which led to the collapse of the sewage system in Sana'a. Elsewhere seasonal rains caused further pollution of wells, limiting access to clean drinking water. The World Health Organisation and its partners have also launched a vaccination programme to combat the spread of the disease. Credit: AFP/Mohammed Huwais #cholera #anticholera #health #Yemen

Our cover this week looks at America’s foreign policy under President Donald Trump. He may chalk up a success at next week’s summit with North Korea and his tough tactics on trade could well yield concessions. Yet, in the longer term, his bullying, transactional approach to allies and enemies will not serve America or the world well. #TheEconomist

Chelsea Pensioners gather for the annual Founder's Day Parade at the Royal Hospital Chelsea in London, England on June 7th 2018. The event celebrates the founding of the hospital by Charles II in 1681. Some 300 veterans of the British Army, who are over the age of 65 and would otherwise face living alone in their old age, live on the premises. For Founder's Day, also known as Oak Apple Day, each Pensioner wears oak leaves on their uniform to commemorate the escape of Charles II after the Battle of Worcester, when the future King hid in an oak tree to avoid capture by Oliver Cromwell's Parliamentarians. #FoundersDayParade #RoyalHospitalChelsea #London #ChelseaPensioners #tradition #veterans

Gypsy, Romany and travelling communities attend the opening day of the Appleby Horse Fair in the town of Appleby-in-Westmorland, England on June 7th 2018.  The annual event is expected to attract 10,000 travellers from across Britain to socialise and buy and sell horses. Under a charter granted by James II in 1685, the fair remains an important opportunity for these communities to come together in celebration of their heritage and culture. Credits: AFP/Oli Scarff, Getty Images/Ian Forsyth #ApplebyHorseFair #England #horses #travellers

Visitors walk between abandoned houses covered with vegetation in Houtouwan on Shengshan Island, Zhejiang province, China.  Houtouwan's sturdy brick houses were once home to a thriving community of around 2,000 fishermen and their families. The inhabitants eventually migrated to mainland China in search of better prospects. The village has been left largely untouched ever since, and over time has transformed into a jungle of overgrown greenery.  Photo taken May 31st 2018. Credit: AFP/Johannes Eisele #abandonedvillage #Houtouwan #China
Poppies growing in a cornfield are silhouetted against the setting sun in Biegen, Germany on June 5th 2018. Credit: AFP/dpa/Patrick Pleul #nature #silhouette #poppies #sunset #flowers

Firefighters are working to identify the many people killed in the ash-covered village of San Miguel Los Lotes, southwest of Guatemala City. Officials say that around 200 people are still unaccounted for and at least 75 are known to have died since Guatemala's Fuego volcano began erupting over the weekend. Photo taken on June 6th 2018. Credit: AFP/Johan Ordonez #VolcandeFuego #Guatemala #volcano #disaster #firefighters

Grayson Perry RA, a British artist and frequently himself a work of art, launches the 250th Royal Academy of Arts Summer Exhibition in Piccadilly, London on June 5th 2018. Mr Perry and his committee of fellow Royal Academicians selected over 1,300 works from the thousands submitted. This year one gallery is designated a "Room of Humour" and includes work by Martin Parr, a photographer who so gloriously and humorously captures the essence of Britishness. The Summer Exhibition runs from June 12th until August 19th 2018. Credit: Reuters/Peter Nicholls #art #exhibition #RoyalAcademy #London #SummerExhibition #GraysonPerry

On World Environment Day: Successive tides have deposited a sinister layer of foliage on a coastal forest in Thanh Hoa province, around 150 km south of Hanoi, Vietnam. Photo taken on May 18th 2018 shows a woman gathering shells.  About eight million tonnes of plastic waste are dumped into the world's oceans every year - the equivalent of one truck of plastic being tipped into the sea every minute of every day. Over half comes from five Asian countries: China, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam, according to a 2015 study in Science journal. Credit: AFP/Nhac Nguyen

Harvey Weinstein leaves the State Supreme Court in New York City after pleading not guilty to three charges on June 5th 2018. Mr Weinstein's reported conduct triggered the #MeToo movement in 2017. Some rebalancing of gender representation in Hollywood is underway, but there is a long way to go. About one in six TV episodes is directed by a woman. Of the top 100 films in 2017, 8% were directed by women. That seems paltry, but in 2016 it was 4%; in 2010 just 2%. Male actors command twice the screen time of female ones and have about two-thirds of speaking parts in successful films, a ratio little changed from the 1940s. Women, still, are often ornaments or victims, love interests or damsels in distress. Credit:Getty Images/Spencer Platt #Hollywood #gender

Larry, official title Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office, takes a moment to strike a confident pose for the press on the pavement outside the prime minister's residence, 10 Downing Street, London. These may be uncertain times with the countdown to Brexit, but Larry wanted it known that there is no need to worry, he has his paws on the Leavers of power (most particularly Palmerston, Chief Mouser at Boris Johnson's Foreign and Commonwealth Office). Credit: PA/Kirsty O'Connor #London #DowningStreet #LarrytheCat #keepcalmandcarryon #catsofinstagram

Emma Gonzalez, a high school senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida and a co-founder of the #NeverAgain movement, pauses during an interview on June 4th 2018. The six minute shooting at the school left 17 dead, wounded 17 more and traumatised many others. A day after graduating from the high school, Ms Gonzalez and a group of survivors announced a multi-state bus tour to "get young people educated, registered and motivated to vote." Credit: AP/Wilfredo Lee #MarchforOurLives #guncontrol #voterregistration #Florida #guns #EmmaGonzalez

The barest of necessities: People scrape a living scavenging on a rubbish dump located on the outskirts of Mumbai, India. Photo taken June 4th 2018. Credit: Reuters/Francis Mascarenhas #dailylife #teddybear #India #Mumbai #poverty
Our #EconEspresso quotation of the week is from American actress Marilyn Monroe. Get a head start each day with Espresso, our daily morning briefing, on iPhone and Android #TheEconomist

A sand lizard sits on a branch after being relocated in Berlin, Germany, June 1st 2018. An industrial estate will be created on the former marshalling yard Berlin-Schoeneweide, previously home to a large sand lizard population. More than 1000 protected sand lizards have been collected since 2016, and moved to specially adapted locations around Berlin. Credit: DPA/Sina Schuldt #sandlizard #Berlin
A worker arranges strands of vermicelli noodles to dry at a factory on the outskirts of Chennai, India, June 1st 2018.  Credit: AFP/Getty Images/Arun Sankar #noodles #India #vermicelli

From @1843mag: We're only just beginning to understand the impact of loneliness on our wellbeing. Take Rebecca, for example. Nothing about her life looks sad. She’s strikingly attractive and professionally successful. “Lots of people can’t understand why I’m lonely,” she says. “I’ve got a good job, a lovely family and lots of close friends. But most of them now are married and taken up with babies. I try to be happy for them, but there’s no one I can ring if I’ve had a bad day; there’s no one for whom I’m the most important one.” To read about loneliness, and where you can turn for help, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Shout #loneliness #hiddenepidemic

Skateboarders enjoy the Venice Beach skate park at sunset in Los Angeles, California, May 31st 2018.  Known as one of the birthplaces of modern skateboarding, Venice Beach is still regarded as one of the best spots by skateboarders around the world. Credit: AFP/Getty Images/Eric Baradat #skate #skateboarding #VeniceBeach #sunset

No tennis player has ever dominated a surface like Rafael Nadal has on clay. The 31-year-old Spaniard has won ten of his 16 grand-slam titles at the French Open, and will be hoping to make it 11 over the next fortnight at Roland Garros stadium. Only a brave punter would bet against him. Betfred, a bookmaker, is giving odds of 2/5 that he will triumph on the court—an implied chance of about 71%. Only three times since 2005 have the bookmakers pegged the men’s favourite at shorter odds. Yet that is more a reflection of a weakening field than a sudden resurgence in Mr Nadal’s play. That the champions and contenders of today are older than those of yore is well-documented. In Paris, Mr Nadal simply seems to be the last man standing. #tennis

From @1843mag: The Economist's US technology editor shares her experiences of reporting from Silicon Valley. “Compared with the cold, impenetrable fortresses of Wall Street, tech firms project an image of being more like bouncy castles – approachable and fun. This easy-going reputation, a remnant of Silicon Valley’s early days, is as out-of-date as a typewriter. These companies are desperate to control the media’s narrative: they go to great efforts to keep tabs on reporters like me, whose job it is to keep tabs on them.” To gain insight into the relationship between big tech and the press, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: Michel Streich #siliconvalley #bigtech #dispatch

Models wait before participating in a sustainable fashion show using recycled or biodegradable materials, in Kisumu, Kenya on May 31st 2018. The event was one of several leading up to the United Nations' World Environment Day on June 5th. This year's theme is "'Beat Plastic Pollution", and Environment Day falls one year after the ban of single use plastic bags in Kenya. Credit: AFP/Getty Images/Yasuyoshi Chiba #sustainablefashion #fashion #Kenya #worldenvironmentday #plasticpollution

"Wilder Mann", a sculpture by the Dutch artist Carolein Smit at the Grassi Museum of Applied Arts, Leipzig, Germany, May 31st 2018. Smit's mysterious sculptures are being shown in the exhibition "L'Amour Fou", which runs from June 2nd to September 30th. Credit: DPA/Sebastian Willnow #art #sculpture #Grassimuseum

From @1843mag: “Padman” is a feel-good movie from India that tackles a strict cultural taboo: menstruation. A villager is scandalised to discover that his wife, like millions of Indian women, uses rags to deal with her “five-day test match”. So he sets out to introduce affordable sanitary napkins to villages across the country. “Padman” may have performed modestly at the box office, but the fact that it has been made and seen at all in India is an achievement. It has been banned in Pakistan. To read more about “Padman”, and discover what else the world is watching, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #padman #cinema

Workers mount a Trojan horse on a pedestal in Iphofen, Germany on June 1st 2018. A special exhibition titled "Heinrich Schliemann - Troy" opens at the Knauf-Museum on June 15th 2018, to showcase the work of German archaeological excavator Heinrich Schliemann Credit: AFP/Karl-Josef Hildenbrand #Troy #trojanhorse #archaeology

From @1843mag: For the last several centuries, a community of free-diving women from a volcanic island off the coast of South Korea have been hunting for marine delicacies on the sea floor. Today’s expedition, in which each diver will harvest a kilo or more of sea urchins, will last about five hours. The water is ice-cold and the descent painful; though many women have never learnt to relieve pressure in their ears, some stuff gum into them and cover them with duct tape. A few have gone deaf. Empty phials of painkillers glisten in the craggy, volcanic rocks, among the violet husks of sea urchins. To meet the free-diving women of Jeju, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Photograph: @davidhogsholt #southkorea #seafood

A giant panda wanders through a village in Wenchuan County, Sichuan province, China on May 31st 2018. This sociable giant panda went out for a relaxed stroll, delighting local residents. According to researchers at the China Conservation and Research Centre for the Giant Panda, the panda is an 11-year-old female named Zhenzhen. She was born at the San Diego Zoo, United States, and was moved to China in 2010. She had been raised in captivity since then and was recently released into the wild as part of a special breeding project. After hours of exploration in the village, Zhenzhen was brought back to the research centre. Credit: AP/Chinatopix #giantpanda #Zhenzhen #conservation

Dunes made from tiny grains of solid methane have been discovered by scientists at the border of Pluto's Al-Idrisi mountain range. An international team of researchers, geographers and planetary scientists used images like this one, taken by NASA's New Horizons spacecraft on December 4th 2015, to analyse the planet's surface. The methane dunes can be seen pushing up against mountains on the freezing planet, which has an average surface temperature of -230 Celsius. Pluto's atmosphere has a surface pressure 100,000 times lower than Earth's, which researchers suspect is too low to allow the methane grains to become airborne. Mild winds blowing across Pluto's surface have forged these ripples. Credit: NASA/AFP/JHUAPL/SWRI #Pluto #methanedunes

Children show off their basketball skills at a kindergarten in Pingliang, Gansu Province, China on June 1st 2018. Various activities were held around China to celebrate International Children's Day. Credit: Xinhua/Yang Xin #InternationalChildrensDay #China #basketball #girlssports

Final preparations are made to displays inside Chichester Cathedral before its biennial Festival of Flowers in Chichester, Britain. Over 50,000 flowers will be used in 80 floral arrangements, to depict this year's theme of "This Earthly Paradise". The festival runs until June 2nd 2018. Credit: PA/Andrew Matthews #FestivalofFlowers #flowers #ChichesterCathedral #floral

This week we have two covers. In America and Asia we look at the risks posed by surveillance technology. China’s authoritarian government has perfected digital monitoring as a tool of control. We have a chilling report from Xinjiang, a western region of China. Our Technology Quarterly explains how police and intelligence agencies in Western democracies use the same technology to deter crimes. The results are effective yet deeply troubling.

In our European edition we look at  Italy’s crisis. Although the country can find a way out of its immediate troubles, the long-term outlook is more worrying. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Behind Saudi Arabia’s ambitious plan for economic and social transformation – which aims to wean the country off reliance on oil revenues, strip down the power of clerics and dispel a reputation for medieval obscurantism and misogyny – is the story of two friends, Ahmed Mater and Ashraf Fayadh. One is now Saudi Arabia’s most illustrious artist and cultural commissar. The other languishes in a dark prison. From @1843mag: At first glance, Rotterdam’s Benthemplein looks like a pleasant but ordinary city square. Look a little closer, however, and you begin to notice an array of wide, stainless-steel gutters zig-zagging around it. Benthemplein is actually one of five water plazas in Rotterdam which funnel the flow of excess rain and sea water. Like thousands of coastal cities from Shanghai to New York, Rotterdam is under threat. This has led to a shift in thinking: instead of working against the water, why not re-engineer the city to work with it? To discover how Rotterdam is being made waterproof, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: De Urbanisten (HO) #architecture #rotterdam #greenarchitecture #urbandesign

The finishing touches are added to the sculpture "Waste of Space" by British artist Nick Wood at London Zoo, Britain, on May 24th 2018. The sculpture represents the amount of single-use bottles that are purchased every minute in Britain. Credit: EPA/ Neil Hall #WasteofSpace #bottles #NickWood #plastic

As the sun sets a Filipino boy plays on the resort island of Boracay, Philippines, May 25th 2018. From @1843mag: Diners tend to focus on how dishes taste and smell, and particularly, in the age of Instagram, on how they look. Most consider texture only when it confounds their expectations, or seems somehow wrong. Yet without it, food becomes unrecognisable. In experiments, only 4% of people can identify cabbage once it’s been pureed and sieved, despite its notoriously pungent flavour. As Josie Delap discovers, attitudes to texture are overwhelmingly cultural. In China, gristly chicken feet and rubbery slices of jellyfish are gastronomic delicacies; others may not find them overly appetising. To learn more about food texture, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Shutterstock #foodtexture #chinesefood

Refreshments are sold in front of graffiti that reads "Ortega murderer!" in Granada, Nicaragua, May 22nd 2018. Almost all tourists have fled from Granada, the so-called "Paris of Central America", since a wave of protests broke out against the government of Daniel Ortega, leading to pillaging and violent clashes that have left dozens of people dead and wounded. Credit: AFP/ Inti Ocon #Granada #Nicaragua

IN 2015 the refugee crisis in the eastern Mediterranean made headlines when a picture of a dead three-year-old Syrian boy, face down on a beach on the southern tip of Europe, brought home the tragic consequences of conflicts raging in Africa and the Middle East. Alan Kurdi’s desperate escape ended within five minutes of leaving Bodrum in Turkey, when the overloaded inflatable boat that carried him capsized. The journeys of those fleeing their homes to make new lives elsewhere capture headlines and animate politics. But millions more are forced out of their homes only to remain inside the borders of their countries. The number of such internally displaced people is shocking and has risen in recent years. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Ubiquitous in Asia in objects from chopsticks and bowls to scaffolding and screening, bamboo has often been disregarded as a material for large-scale architecture. But Vo Trong Nghia saw no sense in that. After training as an architect and founding his own firm, he began working with bamboo, figuring out how to bend and form it with heat, then lash lengths of it together into columns and pillars using rattan and bamboo nails. The result has been a series of cathedral-like structures like the Café Indochine in Kontum in central Vietnam. To read more on building with bamboo, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @samy_rio #architecturelovers #bambooarchitecture

A Quechua woman weaves in Tinki, Peru on May 23rd 2018 . Many Quechua families, especially women in high-altitude isolated communities have little or no access to education or economic opportunity. Working with the not-for-profit social enterprise "Threads of Peru", these women are being empowered, and using their knowledge of traditional weaving techniques, which go back around 5000 years, to bring their product to market. A Mustela nivalis weasel is seen in its white winter coat in the Bialowieza Forest, Poland.  The population of white-coated weasels in a Polish forest declined sharply as climate change reduced the number of snow-covered days by half, researchers stated on May 24th 2018. Snows in high-altitude regions of the Bialowieza Forest disappear nearly a month earlier now than 50 years ago, well before the weasels' fur moults into a brown summer coat. Without this earth-coloured camouflage they are exposed to foxes and other predators, threatening their survival. Photo released by "Nature" on May 24th 2018. Credit: AFP/Nature/Karol Zub #weasel #snow #wintercoat #forest #nature

Our cover this week looks at the love affair between business and Donald Trump. Whereas political elites often treat the president with disdain, business elites tend to like the tax reform and deregulation he has to offer. The rub is that America’s resurgence is skewed toward tech giants, not firms with factories. Worse, corporate America is failing to count the real costs of the Trump presidency. #TheEconomist

Donald Trump remains hugely popular with the Republican base, with job approval ratings of 85% or even more, according to some surveys. Ahead of the mid-terms, primaries are taking place on May 22nd in Arkansas, Georgia and Kentucky, while voters in Texas settle several primary runoffs. Congressional ballots are held every two years. When they take place halfway through a presidential term, they are known as mid-term elections. The next one will be held on November 6th 2018. All 435 seats in the House of Representatives and one-third of the 100 seats in the Senate are contested. Many elections for governor and most of the state legislatures take place on the same day. Credit: AP/Kelly P. Kissel #election #USA #voting

The food industry has failed to meet a sugar reduction target set by the government, according to a report published by Public Health England (PHE) on May 22nd 2018. Only yoghurt, some breakfast cereals and spreads and sauces have met the PHE target of making a 5% reduction in the sugar content of their products in the past year. By 2020 the British government wants to see the sugar content of foods we take home and buy in cafes reduced by 20%. Dr Alison Tedstone, chief nutritionist at PHE said “Too many children and adults suffer the effects of obesity, as does society, with our NHS under needless pressure. Obesity widens economic inequalities, affecting the poor the hardest.” Credit: lightwise/123RF #nutrition #health #sugar #England

May 20th marked the end of “mental-health awareness week”, a campaign run by the Mental Health Foundation, a British charity. Roughly a quarter of British adults have been diagnosed at some point with a psychiatric disorder, costing the economy an estimated 4.5% of GDP per year. Such illnesses have many causes, but a growing body of research demonstrates that in young people they are linked with heavy consumption of social media. A survey by the Royal Society for Public Health found that Britons aged 14-24 believe Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat and Twitter have detrimental effects on their wellbeing. They said that these social networks gave them scope for self-expression and community-building, but exacerbated anxiety and depression.

From @1843mag: Code governs nearly every aspect of our lives. Turn on your TV, use a credit card, press the accelerator in your new car, listen to music on anything other than vinyl, or read this post and each of your desires is fulfilled by code. But like most of us, Andrew Smith has spent his life entirely ignorant of how code works. As the line between tech and politics increasingly blurs – code is used by terrorists to spread viruses and hostile powers to hack elections – he wondered whether his ignorance made him a bad citizen. To explore the challenges and rewards of learning to code, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: James Wilson. @freecodecamp #learningcode

From @1843mag: In one month Neymar, one of the world’s greatest footballers, will step out with his Brazilian teammates onto the turf at the Rostov Arena in Russia to face Switzerland in their first game of the 2018 FIFA World Cup. The team will be dressed in its distinctive canary-yellow strip. Underneath, each player will also wear a black vest with a tracking device slotted into a pouch between the shoulder blades. Called Apex, this tiny black computer contains sensors that transmit data about players' performance in real time. This GPS tracking technology is helping footballers win games. To discover how, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Getty #FIFA #WorldCup #GPStracking

From @1843mag: Zanele Muholi’s self-portraits are so dark they glow. In this series, called “Somnyama Ngonyama” (“Hail the Dark Lioness”), Muholi has turned the camera inwards, in an examination of “what it means to be black, 365 days a year”. The image is part of a sequence celebrating the life of Muholi’s mother Bester, a domestic worker in apartheid South Africa who had to leave her own children to care for a white family. The artist fashioned regal crowns out of the articles of workaday servitude: scouring pads and clothes pegs. To discover more about how Muholi’s photographs explore race and gender in modern South Africa, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. @muholizanele #ZaneleMuholi

From @1843mag: Despite Copenhagen’s attempts to hog the glory, Stockholm was an active partner in the creation of New Nordic Cuisine, which emphasises foraged food and local seasonal ingredients. The movement marked a departure from traditional Swedish food such as meatballs and Surströmming (fermented Baltic sea herring). However, Stockholm has kept innovating and has increasingly fallen under the influence of another food culture – Japan. Residents view a mural depicting Haiti's independence heroes, ahead of the country's Flag Day celebrations. In 1803 Haitian revolutionary leader Jean Jacques Dessalines tore up a French tricolor and tasked his goddaughter, Catherine Flon, with stitching together the country’s first independent flag. It consisted of a red and a blue stripe, without the central white stripe of Haiti's coloniser. On May 18th 2018 the flag's 215th anniversary will be celebrated, as a symbol of the country’s quest for liberation. Photo taken on May 14th. The Lyle's flying fox (Pteropus lylei) is native to many countries including Cambodia, Thailand and Vietnam. Also known as the fruit bat, it is among the largest species of bat with a wingspan of up to 5ft (1.5 m). This bat has well developed eyesight and a powerful sense of smell. It feeds on nectar, pollen and fruit and can hunt over a range of up to 40 miles (50km). Photo taken in Vietnam on May 9th 2018. Credit: PA/Belga/Philippe Clément #nature #bats #Vietnam

From @1843mag: On hot and sticky days in countries as far flung as Brazil, Jamaica and Vietnam, bright roadside carts slung with long poles of sugarcane are a common sight. These are pressed between iron rollers to extract their chartreuse juice or sold whole for locals to chew on. Despite the first part of its name, sugarcane water (which has no refined sugar), has health benefits: rich in iron, magnesium, potassium and calcium, it helps fight colds and fevers. Mainly, though, it tastes deliciously refreshing. Drunk pure, it feels like stretching out on a sun lounger. To discover more about this summer’s coolest drink, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Image: Andrew Kist #sugarcane #drinks

Michael Pendry adds a white origami dove to "Les Colombes", his art installation at Salisbury Cathedral, Wiltshire on May 10th 2018. The artwork, which features a flock of around 2,500 doves flying the length of the nave, opens to the public on May 12th 2018. Community groups in Salisbury have been encouraged to write their own messages and fold their own doves. The unveiling will take place just over two months after the novichok nerve agent attack on a Sergei and Yulia Skripal. While the clean-up continues in the city, Mr Pendry hopes the artwork carries a message of resilience, peace and hope. Credit: Getty Images/Matt Cardy #publicart #MichaelPendry #SalisburyCathedral #art

From @1843mag: Meghan Markle on the cover of 1843. The royals have combined medieval grandeur and constitutional significance with celebrity appeal. But were you to start from scratch and scour the country for a family to unify modern Britain, the Windsors would not be the obvious choice. They occupy a tiny, archaically upper-class niche. An American television star doesn’t at first glance seem the ideal candidate for the monarchy’s mission. Yet Ms. Markle may be better equipped for the role than the family into which she is marrying. From @1843mag: The bedroom of architect Palinda Kannangara’s house in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The suburb where the house sits is surrounded by marshland that soaks up monsoon floodwaters and hosts a profusion of birdlife. In recent years much of the area has been reclaimed, and a new flyover built. Kannangara’s house acts as an environmental editor, its perforated brick façade allows the breeze in but keeps blazing sunlight, heat and traffic noise at bay. The building itself has a sensual materiality. Brick, concrete and timber lend the building a comfortably worn air. To discover how this house in the heart of Colombo offers a retreat from the city’s heat and haze, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #Architecture #SriLanka

In 2017 the number of people without access to banking services fell to 1.7bn, down from 2.5bn in 2011, thanks largely to the rise of mobile-payment apps. Physical banks and ATMs can be expensive to setup, especially in rural areas, but the rise of mobile banking has meant that for the first time, hundreds of millions of people living in the developing world now have access to finance. According to the Findex, an index compiled by the World Bank, only 69% of adults around the world have bank or mobile-money accounts. But 78% of wage-earners without bank accounts have mobile phones. So mobile-payment services should have plenty of room for further growth. #finance #mobilebanking #money

From @1843mag: A magnificent male Andean cock-of-the-rock, a species found in the cloud forests of Colombia. The Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, a mountain range on the northern coast, is a special sort of avian paradise. Its slopes rise steeply out of the Caribbean; its highest peak, the snowy Cristóbal Colon, is around 64 kilometres (40 miles) away from the tropical coastline, as the crow – along with a wide range of other birds – flies. The variety of microclimates has given rise to the astonishing array of bird species: around the same number as Canada in an area 600 times smaller. To discover more about Colombia’s wealth of beautiful birds, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Image: Nature Picture Library #birds #Colombia

The first and only treetop nature trail in Switzerland photographed at Mogelsberg on May 11th 2018. The trail is 500 metres long and meanders at different heights through the forest reaching up to 50 metres above ground, breaking through the canopy to give visitors a spectacular view. Credit: EPA/Gian Ehrenzeller #trees #forest #nature #walk #Switzerland

Factory farming reaches new heights in China. The average Chinese person today pigs out on 40kg (88lbs) of pork a year, up from 12kg in 1980. Although China constitutes just one-fifth of the world’s population, it consumes half of its pork. Unfortunately for Chinese carnivores, however, the country has had trouble rearing enough pigs to meet growing demand. China is the third-largest market for American pig exports. To meet domestic demand producers are building facilities like the Yangxiang high-rise pig farm, Yaji Mountain Forest Park in Guangxi province, where the raising of pigs has reached a new level of industrialisation. Photos taken on March 21st 2018. Credit: Reuters Staff #animalwelfare #intensivefarming #agriculture #pigs #China

Among the most evocative sights and scents of springtime in England, dappled sunlight playing on a carpet of bluebells at Blickling Estate, Norfolk. Credit: PA/Joe Giddens #bluebells #Spring #England #flowers #woodland #scent

Our cover this week analyses the $100bn bet on technology startups by Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank and the man behind the Vision Fund. In scale and ambition the fund rivals the entire venture-capital industry. Whether it succeeds or fails—and the risks are high—it promises to leave its mark on tech investing for years to come. #TheEconomist

In this image, released by the US Geological Survey on May 9th 2018, a wall of molten lava moves along Makamae Street in Leilani Estates, Big Island, Hawaii on May 6th 2018.  Fissures have been appearing in areas of activity. Five of Hawaii's volcanoes are currently showing some level of activity, forcing thousands of people to evacuate their homes and raising the possibility of explosive eruptions occurring in coming weeks. The Hawaiian Volcano Observatory assesses the current threat level from the Kilauea volcano, the most active in Hawaii, as "Very High Threat Potential". Credit: AFP/US Geological Survey #Hawaii #volcano #lava

Mahathir Mohamad holds a press conference in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on May 10th 2018. Coming out of retirement at the age of 92, the former prime minister pulled off a surprise victory over Najib Razak, the incumbent, who had been damaged by a corruption scandal and by rising living costs. Mr Mohamad switched allegiance from the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), which he once led, to lead the Pakatan Harapan (PH), an alliance of opposition parties. PH won 122 of the 222 seats up for grabs in the national parliament. It also won control of six of the country's 13 states. Credit: AP/Andy Wong #Malaysia #election #MahathirMohamad

Iranian demonstrators set American flags alight outside the former US embassy headquarters in Tehran, May 9th 2018.  Iranians reacted with a mix of sadness, resignation and defiance to US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the landmark nuclear deal. He promised “This will make America much safer,” as he signed a memorandum re-imposing all sanctions lifted by his predecessor, Barack Obama. Foreign governments and firms have up to six months to stop buying everything from Iranian oil to carpets or face tough secondary sanctions from his Treasury department. For many, Trump's decision marked the death knell for hopes that Iran might finally escape decades of isolation and US hostility. Credit: AFP/Atta Kenare #nucleardeal #DonaldTrump

Rose petals are harvested at a plantation in Anning, Yunnan province, China on May 5th 2018. Pastries made from edible rose are popular in this region and a single factory can use around 30 tonnes of petals in a year. Credit: Reuters/Wong Campion  #roses #flowers #harvest #China

Scientists working on a remote salt flat in White Sands National Monument, New Mexico have found footprints and animal tracks that show ancient humans stalking and probably killing a giant sloth.  At seven to eight feet tall, tightly muscled, with swinging fore legs tipped with wolverine-like claws, the sloth was formidable and lived until around 11,000 years ago. Matthew Bennett, a professor at Bournemouth University, England says what is special about these prints, and sets them apart from any other fossil trackways in the world, is that this discovery records the interaction between humans and ice age giant megafauna.  Photo released May 8th 2018.  Credit: Bournemouth University/Cover Images #palaeontology #WhiteSandsNationalMonument

Vladimir Putin about to take the oath of office, for his fourth term as Russia's president, in the Grand Kremlin Palace in Moscow on May 7th 2018. The former KGB agent has ruled Russia as prime minister or president for over 18 years. Credit: AP/Mikhail Klimentyev/ Kremlin Pool Photo #VladimirPutin #inauguration #Kremlin

From @1843mag: One of Monet’s early cityscapes, this painting of the Boulevard des Capucines in Paris was shown at the first Impressionist exhibition in 1874, where some critics derided it for its apparently slapdash, unfinished appearance. But with his use of seemingly haphazard dabs of paint, Monet captured the kaleidoscopic visual experience of being immersed in the busy energy of the modern metropolis. This is just one of the works on display in “Monet & Architecture”, an exhibition @national_gallery in London which explores the relationship between Monet’s paintings and the built environment. To discover more about Monet’s eye for architecture, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #Monet #exhibition #art

A final fire dance is performed before the government implements the temporary closure of Boracay beach resort, Philippines on April 25th 2018. Boracay’s beach has earned the island world renown. Over 2m tourists visited in 2017, spending 56bn pesos ($1.1bn). Yet businesses seem reluctant to invest in disposing of their sewage in the way required by law. Rodrigo Duterte, the famously blunt president, claims to have told his environment secretary, Roy Cimatu, “I’ll give you six months. Clean the goddamn thing.” Inspectors found that only 383 of the 578 places they had checked by late February were connected to the sewage system and that, anyway, the system needed repairs. Credit: AP/Aaron Favila #Philippines #fire #silhouette #Boracay

From: @1843mag: A new exhibition @gardenmuseum in London is the first museum show in three decades devoted to painter and horticulturist Cedric Morris. The show sets out to demonstrate how closely Morris’s two passions intertwined. This painting depicts the first spring flowering after Morris began breeding irises in the summer of 1934. It’s one of his most arresting still-lives. Morris's absorbing, restless flower paintings are perhaps better termed “flower portraits”, for they are animated by the characters and quirks of the subjects Morris loved better than any other. To discover more about Cedric Morris and his plants with personality, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #exhibition #art #flowers

From @1843mag: Auguste Rodin, the French sculptor, first visited the British Museum in 1881. He was immediately entranced by the museum’s collection of ancient Greek marbles, particularly the sculptures from the Parthenon in Athens known as the Elgin Marbles. Rodin saw in them a sincere naturalism. Expressive of emotion and movement they offered valuable lessons for modern art. “The Kiss”, one of Rodin’s most famous works, is full of intense feeling. This sculpture is currently on display in “Rodin and the art of ancient Greece” an exhibition @britishmuseum in London. To discover more about Rodin’s creative relationship with the classical, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #art #Rodin #sculpture

When a bomb detonates in Kabul, Afghanistan, the media rush to the scene. Horrific images are broadcast by video journalists, heaving their cameras and massive bags of kit. On April 30th a blast occurred in a district near the United States Embassy. It was followed by a second explosion at the same spot 40 minutes later. A suicide bomber disguised as a television cameraman deliberately targeted journalists. Ten reporters were among the 31 people killed. The attacks bring to 26 the number of journalists killed worldwide so far in 2018. The rate has generally been declining since a peak in 2009. #journalism #danger #Kabul #Afghanistan

From @1843mag: It’s virtually impossible not to be charmed by meerkats and this group, standing tall on top of their burrow, are as comical as they come, their haughty expressions at odds with their prim hand gestures. Wildlife photographer @franslanting shot this band of meerkats in the early morning sun of the Kalahari desert. A self-taught photographer, he was a scientist before he became entranced by the wonders of the natural world and determined to convey its beauty to us. See more of Lanting’s captivating photography by clicking on @1843mag and following the link in their bio. #FransLanting #photography #meerkats

The newly restored Temperate House in Kew Gardens, London on May 3rd 2018. It contains 10,000 plants and will reopen its doors on May 5th 2018, following a five-year restoration programme that cost £41m. Kew Gardens houses a world-class collection of plants and seeds, some of which are the only surviving examples of their species. A programme of cloning and growing from seed has allowed the reintroduction of some extinct plants to their native regions. The world's largest Victorian glasshouse opened to the public in 1840. Charles Darwin frequently corresponded with William Hooker, the director of Kew, while writing "On the Origin of Species" (1859). Credit: EPA/Facundo Arrizabalaga #KewGardens #Kew #Victorian #plants #gardens

In this photo released by the U.S. Geological Survey,  a plume of ash rises from the Puu Oo crater on Hawaii's Kilaueaa Volcano, in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on May 3rd 2018. Hawaii's Kilauea volcano has erupted, sending lava shooting into the air in a residential neighbourhood and prompting mandatory evacuation orders for nearby homes. Credit: U.S. Geological Survey via AP #volcano #Kilauea #Hawaii

A large wedge tornado forms near the city of Culver in Kansas. It is late, but not unprecedented, for the first tornadoes of the year to hit Kansas in May. As the United States seeks to eliminate nuclear weapons from North Korea, our cover this week looks at how arms control is unravelling. President Donald Trump is poised to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal. The limits on the nuclear arsenals of Russia and America are set to lapse by 2021, leaving them unconstrained for the first time in almost half a century. The chances are increasing that nuclear weapons will spread and that someone, somewhere will miscalculate. #TheEconomist

Patriarch Kirill of Moscow and All Russia lays flowers at a temporary memorial near the Zimnyaya Vishnya (Winter Cherry) shopping centre, Kemerovo on May 3rd 2018. Rowers skim along the Potomac River as the sun rises over the Jefferson Memorial in Washington, DC on May 2nd 2018. The memorial honours Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826), the third president of the United States. When the location of the memorial was chosen many people objected, as a number of the famous flowering cherry trees that line the Tidal Basin had to be removed to make way for it. In 1939 President Roosevelt laid the cornerstone of the monument and in 1943 the dedication ceremony was held. It was not until 1947, when wartime restrictions on the use of metals had been lifted, that the bronze statue of the president could be added. Credit: AP/J. David Ake #JeffersonMemorial #rowing #sunrise #WashingtonDC

Basilica di San Marco is one of the architectural gems of Venice. This detail shows the central gable of the facade, where St Mark, the patron saint of Venice, stands over a winged lion, the symbol of both the saint and the city. On April 25th 68 AD Mark the Evangelist died in Alexandria, apparently lynched by a mob. In 828 some of the martyred saint's remains were smuggled out of the city and brought to Venice. The cathedral that bears his name was completed in 1092. Credit: Rose Simonds #Italy #Venice #StMarksSquare #architecture #cathedral

The sun rises behind a baobab tree (Adansonia digitata) in the Okavango Delta, Botswana on April 25th 2018. The baobab is Africa's tree. It is found in 31 African countries. Some experts say a baobab may live for anything from 500 to 5000 years. It is the living elder on a continent that reveres elders. The baobab stores water it then draws on in times of drought, making it a reliable provider. Its leaves and white flowers serve as salad for humans. Its black seeds provide a substitute for coffee. The white pulp of the fruit is a good source of nutrients including calcium and vitamin C. The bark can be made into rope, roofing material, and clothing. Credit: Reuters/Mike Hutchings  #baobab #trees #Botswana #sunrise

On November 8th 2017 Rodrigo Koxa, a Brazilian surfer, rode what has now been judged to be the biggest wave ever surfed. World Surf League made the announcement on April 28th 2018. The judging panel determined the wave, at the Praia do Norte, Nazare, Portugal, was 80 feet (24.38 metres) high. Credit: AP/Pedro Cruz #extremesports  #surfing #waves #Portugal

Is your job vulnerable to automation? A new paper by the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries, looks at how easily different kinds of jobs could be automated in developed economies. It assessed the automatability of each task within a given job, based on a survey of skills in 2015. Overall, the study finds that 14% of jobs across 32 countries are highly vulnerable, defined as having at least a 70% chance of automation. A further 32% were slightly less imperilled, with a probability between 50% and 70%. At current employment rates, that puts 210m jobs at risk across the 32 countries. In general, workers in rich countries appear less at risk than those in middle-income ones. But wide gaps exist even between countries of similar wealth.

From @1843mag: The 19th-century Caffè degli Specchi in Trieste embodies the hybrid history of the Italian city. Here you can order a prosecco with a board of cheese and pršut: Slovenian ham in a Viennese café in an Austro-Hungarian square in Italy. Trieste has long been popular with expats and exiles, including Sir Richard Francis Burton, an explorer, and James Joyce, the writer who coined a phrase commonly cited by visitors: “triste Trieste”, an elegy to its lingering atmosphere of sadness. From @1843mag: Claude Monet visited Venice for two months in 1908 and was captivated by “the unique light” of the city. He chose to paint from viewpoints made famous by numerous artists before him, such as this one, of Santa Maria della Salute, from across the Grand Canal. But unlike his predecessors, Monet depicted Venice as a depopulated city, which accentuates the other-worldly quality of this painting. This is just one of the works on display in “Monet & Architecture”, an exhibition @national_gallery in London which explores the relationship between Monet’s paintings and the built environment. From @1843mag: As you wind through the pines on the way to Kaapsehoop, a town three hours from Johannesburg, you may spot wild horses. The offspring of military mounts abandoned by the British after the end of the second Boer war, there are now about 200 stallions and mares roaming the landscape. Kaapsehoop Horse Trails is a rustic retreat home to 35 free-range horses, which are rounded up by motorbike for guests to ride. The region is also wonderful for hiking, with well-signed routes through the forests to vistas overlooking the De Kaap Valley. To discover more about the natural treasures to be found outside Johannesburg, click on @1843mag and follow the the link in their bio. Image: Alamy #Johannesburg #travel #horses

Veric Lang, 19, visits the newly opened National Memorial For Peace And Justice in Montgomery, Alabama on April 26th 2018. The memorial is dedicated to the legacy of enslaved black people, African Americans humiliated by racial segregation, and those terrorised by lynching. Conceived by the Equal Justice Initiative, the physical environment is intended to foster reflection on America's history of racial inequality. Credit: Getty Images/Bob Miller #peaceandjustice #Alabama #AfricanAmerican #race #equality

From @1843mag: Knafeh or kunafa – a savoury-sweet confection of gooey cheese, shredded pastry and syrup – is said to hail from the Palestinian city of Nablus. One of the earliest references to it is in the writings of a 14th-century Arab historian, who wrote that Caliph Sulayman (AD 674-717) from the Umayyad dynasty liked it so much that he ate 20 portions of it every evening. Under the Ottoman empire, knafeh spread further afield. Today it can be found as far west as Turkey and as far east as Azerbaijan, but Nablus will always be knafeh’s spiritual home. To discover more about the Levantine pastry fit for a prince, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Image: Alamy #food #MiddleEast #knafeh

Today North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in met for talks on the southern side of Panmunjom, the “truce village” on the shared border, April 27th 2018. The meeting is the first between Korean leaders in more than a decade, and the first summit of its kind for Mr Kim. The two leaders declared intentions for a “permanent peace regime” by turning the armistice that ended the Korean War in 1953 into a peace treaty this year. Their commitment to a nuclear-free peninsula was reiterated, but without specifying concrete steps towards that goal. Credit: Getty Images/Korea Summit Press #NorthKorea #SouthKorea #nuclear #peace

Our cover this week argues that a basic level of universal health care is sensible, affordable and practical—including in poor countries. Over half the world goes without essential care; those who get to see a doctor often receive rotten treatment. Universal care would bring broad social benefits, including to the economy. Countries such as Costa Rica and Chile, which spend a fraction of what the United States does and yet enjoy a similar life expectancy, demonstrate the scale of the opportunity. #TheEconomist

The birth of the fifth in line to the British throne on April 23rd was heralded with great fanfare. Reporters waited outside the Lindo Wing, a luxurious private maternity ward in London. Yet the price of delivering the new prince was probably slightly less than that of an average American baby. In 2015, the Lindo Wing charged £5,670 ($8,900) for 24 hours in a deluxe room and a non-Caesarean delivery. A survey by the International Federation of Health Plans in 2015 found that the average fee for such a delivery in the United States was $10,808. That rises to roughly $30,000 for care given before and after pregnancy, according to Truven Health Analytics. Insurers cover most of the cost, but parents are still left to pay around $3,000.

A statue honouring suffragist leader Millicent Fawcett is unveiled in Parliament Square, London, England on April 24th 2018. It is the first monument of a woman to stand in Parliament Square, and the first designed by a woman, artist Gillian Wearing. The statue was commissioned to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Representation of the People Act 1918, which granted some women over 30 the right to vote for the first time. Credit: Getty Images/Dan Kitwood #MillicentFawcett #women #feminism #womensrights #suffragist #votesforwomen #London

US President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron walk down the West Wing colonnade together at the White House in Washington, D.C on April 24th 2018. The two leaders—one a brash former reality-television host, the other an erudite philosophy graduate—could scarcely be more different. But they have struck up a strangely warm relationship. Mr Macron will hope to secure something for his efforts, and is particularly keen to try to stop Donald Trump walking away from the Iran nuclear deal. His speech to Congress is likely to focus not only on Franco-American ties but on liberal values in a dangerous world.
