From @1843mag: This week the Pulitzer Prize for music went to @KendrickLamar – the first time somebody who isn't a classical or jazz musician has won. On the winning album, “DAMN.”, Lamar examines himself and finds a sinner. Rapping over the spare rhythms of trap, a style from the Deep South, Lamar confesses that he is wracked with lust, crippled by fear, and guilty of pride, greed and hypocrisy. But there is hope: Lamar is a man of faith. On this moving, carefully crafted album, which is threaded with references to the Bible, he dispels his demons by summoning not just the Word of God, but the words of Lamar. To read @1843mag’s take on “DAMN.”, click on their handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: @stan_chow #KendrickLamar

A photo of the Lagoon Nebula, released by the European Space Agency on April 19th 2018, to celebrate the 28th anniversary of the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope.  The whole nebula, about 4000 light-years away, is an incredible 55 light-years wide and 20 light-years tall. This image shows only a small part of the turbulent star-formation region, about four light-years across. This stunning nebula was first catalogued in 1654 by the Italian astronomer Giovanni Battista Hodierna, who sought to record nebulous objects in the night sky so they would not be mistaken for comets. The observations were taken by Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 between February 12th and 18th 2018. Credit: AFP/ESA/NASA #NASA #HubbleSpaceTelescope #space #nebula

Our cover this week looks at Donald Trump’s takeover of the Republican Party. His organising principle is loyalty—not, as with the best presidents, to a principle or a vision, but to a leader: himself. In the past the Oval Office has belonged to vain men, some of whom have lied or bullied or undermined presidential norms. None has been as blatant as Mr Trump, but the cult of loyalty protects him, just as it harms America. #TheEconomist #DonaldTrump #Republican

The astonishing Keukenhof gardens in Lisse, Netherlands are open, but only until May 13th 2018. The park was designed in 1857. Joey, the life-size puppet horse created for "War Horse", the award-winning play by Michael Morpurgo, meets two of Police Scotland's finest during a photo call at the Festival Theatre in Edinburgh. The play opens there on April 18th and runs until May 12th 2018. Joey was designed by the Handspring Puppet Company and is operated by three actors. Two are in charge of the legs while the third controls the head and neck. The mastery of movement in all the puppets, and their reactions and interaction with the actors, has been acclaimed for its remarkable realism. "War Horse" premiered on October 17th 2007 at the National Theatre, London and has toured in Britain and abroad ever since. Credit: PA/Jane Barlow #horses #theatre #Scotland #Edinburgh

Conservationist Daphne Sheldrick died on April 12th 2018 at the age of 83. Born and raised in Kenya, Dame Daphne spent the first half of her career working alongside her British husband David, who founded Kenya's biggest national park, Tsavo East. Through the late 1970s and 1980s, Kenya’s elephants were increasingly threatened by poachers; their babies survived as best they could—or not at all. Daphne Sheldrick developed a milk formula, allowing her to hand-rear hundreds of orphaned elephants. After her husband's death in 1977, she founded the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust (DSWT), best known for rescuing and reintegrating orphaned elephants into the wild. Credit:  Tom Stoddart/Getty Images #conservation #elephants #Kenya #DaphneSheldrick

Good morning. A baby Zanzibar red colobus monkey (Procolobus kirkii) peeks out between blades of grass in Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Park, Zanzibar, Tanzania. Because Zanzibar is an island, its population of monkeys developed in isolation, with distinct characteristics. Unfortunately many non-native trees have been introduced to the island which are irresistible to the Zanzibar red colobus, including Indian Almond and mango whose leaves carry toxins that are harmful to them. The monkeys eat charcoal in an attempt to mitigate the effects of the poison, but their numbers are still falling and the population has dropped dangerously low to around 2,000 individuals. Credit: Naturepl/Fiona Rogers #monkey #Tanzania #wildlife

Wood anemones carpet the Hallerbos forest in Halle, Belgium on April 13th 2018. Soon the bluebells that the wood is so famous for will take over and the floor of the forest will turn blue. Credit: AFP/Getty Images/Belga/Nicolas Maeterlink #forest #Hallerbos #Halle #Belgium #flowers #bluebells

From @1843mag: Azzedine Alaïa’s death last November sent waves of grief across the fashion world. The Tunisian-born designer rose to prominence in the 1980s with close-fitting dresses that earned him the nickname the “King of Cling”. A master of precision, he designed his clothes by draping material onto live models and cutting around the human frame. Next month @designmuseum in London, an exhibition planned with Alaïa in the months before his death will open, featuring 60 pieces. What was intended as a celebration of his work will now serve as a timely examination of his legacy. To discover more about what to see and do this spring, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #azzedinealaia Image: Maison Alaïa/Design Museum

From @1843mag: Macau’s glitzy casinos draw millions of mainland gamblers each year, but its unique combination of Chinese and colonial Portuguese culture makes it popular with foodies and history buffs too. Macau’s government has been criticised for failing to protect its heritage, but does a better job at it than Hong Kong. The north island is home to the charming old town, the Portuguese colonial architecture providing a contrast to Macau’s swanky hotels, casinos and theme parks. To the south of Macau, connected by three bridges, is Taipa and the Cotai strip of resort casinos – Asia’s version of Las Vegas. To discover more about travel to Macau, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #travel #HongKong #Macau Photo: 500px

From @1843mag: The Miramare castle near Trieste. With its vaunted past, Trieste is a city full of the vestiges of fallen empires. The city has long been a favourite of expats and exiles, including Sir Richard Francis Burton, an explorer, and James Joyce, the writer who coined the phrase “triste Trieste”, an elegy to its lingering atmosphere of sadness. The harshness of the "bora" wind affects the mood as much as it does the limestone cliffs of the surrounding plateau. Yet even when the bora rages there is a strange sense of community in the collective melancholy. To discover more about this city where cultures, religions and empires once collided, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Photo: @christopher_kennedy_photo #Italy

After the hurricane: Swipe to see how America has let down its Puerto Rican citizens. At least 64 people perished during the storm. Perhaps another 1,000 died in the aftermath, including old people who suffocated after their hospital respirators packed up. As an oversees territory, with most of the rights of a state, less a vote in general elections or in Congress, Puerto Rico was due the same emergency response as any other part of America. Its 3.4m inhabitants got so much less, in such desultory fashion, with such horrible consequences, that the storm has rekindled a painful debate about the island's relations with America. #PuertoRico #HurricaneMaria #America #light

From @1843mag: When Japan’s markets opened to the world in 1854, Japanese art began to flood Europe. Paris’s impressionists were entranced, but no one absorbed the aesthetic of the “ukyio-e” genre of coloured woodblock prints as much as Vincent van Gogh. With its bold outlines and fields of colour and its truncated, shadowless figure, this painting – “L’Arlésienne”, or “the girl from Arles” – demonstrates how Van Gogh incorporated lessons from Japanese prints into his style. This is just one of the pictures currently on display in “Van Gogh and Japan”, an exhibition at @vangoghmuseum in Amsterdam. To discover more about the artist’s love affair with Japan, click on @1843mag and click on the link in their bio. #VanGogh #exhibition

L’Hermione is a replica of the French frigate that transported Lieutenant General Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette to Boston on April 27th 1780. The voyage was his second trip to America to support his close friend George Washington in his fight against British rule. General La Fayette was heavily involved in the politics of both America and France and as a soldier in both the American and French Revolutions. He died at home in Paris on May 20th 1834. The replica ship arrived in the southern French port of Marseille on April 12th 2018. Credit: Press Association/Arnault Serriere/ABACAPress.com #sailingships #France #sea

Our cover story this week describes how Germany is becoming more diverse, open, informal and hip. Post-war German history has moved in cycles of about 25 years. First came the era of reconstruction. Then the federal republic began to reckon frankly with its war guilt. In its latest phase, from the 1990s, Germany has reunified, become a normal country again and shed some of the fetters of its past. Now the wheels of history are turning once more. With the right leadership, Germany could be a model for the West. #TheEconomist

Peak Ryan: Paul Ryan, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, has announced that he will not stand in November's mid-term elections. Mr Ryan sided with President Trump on many issues including his fierce opposition to The Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). He has also opposed some of Mr Trump's initiatives, particularly the introduction of  trade tariffs. He called on the White House “not to advance this plan”, which triggered threats of retaliatory tariffs of up to 25% on products including Harley-Davidson motorcycles and cranberries. Harleys are made in Mr Ryan's home state of Wisconsin which, as luck would have it, is America’s top cranberry producer. Part of a collection of 698 elephant tusks that were crushed at a public event at the foot of the Eiffel Tower in Paris on February 6th 2014 to raise awareness of the illegal trade in ivory. According to The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) around 20,000 elephants are still being poached and killed for their tusks each year. The recorded population of African savanna elephants declined by 30% between 2007 and 2014. The British government said on April 3rd 2018 that it will introduce a ban on the sale of ivory, no matter how old, to help protect the world's elephant population. The ban is the toughest in Europe and will impose a maximum five-year prison sentence for offenders. Credit: AP/Remy de la Mauviniere #ivory #wildlife #Britain

The exterior of @bernssteakhouse gives little away. But for the oenophile, this unassuming restaurant in a semi-residential neighbourhood in Tampa, Florida, is one small step below heaven. With more than 500,000 bottles in its cellars, it has the largest-known private wine collection kept by a restaurant. But it’s not just about quantity: Bern’s also stands apart from its peers in its list of rare aged wines. That Bern’s has remained under the radar is extraordinary – but that may soon change. The restaurant’s remarkable collection of the world’s great wines is luring wine connoisseurs to Tampa in their private-jet loads. As the founding partner of @olsonkundig, a Seattle-based architecture practice, Jim Olson has designed museums, hotels and churches. But no building encapsulates the spirit of his work better than this one. His structures are as much about life outside as inside. The house stands in a forest of ancient firs, its central section stained dark so that it almost disappears into the hilly landscape behind it. Over the years, he has framed the house’s views of the Puget Sound and Mount Rainier with a series of “magic windows” where the edges of the glass are so well hidden you hardly realise the panes are there. To discover more about this magical forest retreat, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Credit: Kevin Scott #treehouse

June Ding, a 27-year-old Beijinger, is no shrinking violet. Animated, affable and razor sharp, she studied at Yale and holds a graduate law qualification. Elsewhere in the world June would be a definite catch but many men in China have a tendency – some would say a cultural obligation – to reject women with equivalent education and salaries. Nearly 90% of high-school graduates attend university and women represent more than half of this cohort. As female education has advanced, a dangerous paradox has emerged: the higher their degree, the less likely women are to marry. To discover more about the challenges faced in the marriage market by women in urban China, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #China Photo: @EdwardKB

This week’s cover looks at murder in poor countries. In 2016, 68% of all violent deaths were murders; war caused just 18%. High murder rates have local roots, including drug crime and the prevalence of young men, but everywhere rapid, chaotic urbanisation makes things worse. Latin America, with 8% of the world’s people but 38% of its murders, shows what curbs the killing and what fuels it. The good news is that, though many of the emerging world’s problems are intractable, murder need not be one of them. #TheEconomist

People carry signs bearing the "I Am A Man" slogan as they gather on Beale Street in Memphis, Tennessee to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Dr Martin Luther King, April 4th 2018. "Am I Not A Man And A Brother?" became a catchphrase used by British and American abolitionists in the 18th century. During the Memphis sanitation strike in 1968, part of the Civil Rights movement, "I Am a Man" signs were used in answer to that question. King was shot and killed as he stood on the balcony of the hotel where he was staying in Memphis to support the striking sanitation workers. Winnie Madikizela-Mandela  died aged 81 in Johannesburg on April 2nd 2018. She married Nelson Mandela in 1958. While he was in prison she raised their two daughters and was tormented by the apartheid police. She spent 491 days in solitary confinement for political activism and was later banished to a dusty township for eight years. Many South Africans consider her a mother of the nation, but her legacy is troublesome. She was convicted of ordering the kidnapping of four boys in Soweto, including a 14-year-old whose throat was slit by her bodyguard. Her seething anger, in contrast to Mr Mandela's famed forgiveness, came to define her. She will receive a state funeral on April 14th. Credit: Reuters/Siphiwe Sibekoo #WinnieMandela #SouthAfrica #apartheid

At the end of the 1860s, plaster-casting was all the rage in the museum world. It was the Victorian equivalent of virtual reality. Henry Cole, director of the South Kensington Museum (now the @vamuseum), persuaded 15 European princes to share plaster casts of their countries’ greatest artworks with each other. He believed this would democratise art: people who could not afford to visit Europe on a Grand Tour could now view the continent’s treasures up close. In 1873 two galleries dedicated to plaster casts opened at the V&A. Visitors perused a replica of Michelangelo’s “David” and a huge cast of Trajan’s column from Rome. To discover more about how the Victorians did VR, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #art #technology

Molo Audace, a windswept pier in Trieste. With its vaunted past, Trieste has long been a favourite of expats and exiles, including Sir Richard Francis Burton, an explorer, and James Joyce, the writer who coined the phrase “triste Trieste”, an elegy to its lingering atmosphere of sadness. It is greyer than other Italian cities and more sepulchral than most ports. The harshness of the "bora" wind affects the mood as much as it does the limestone cliffs of the surrounding plateau. Despite its sadness, or perhaps because of it, Trieste has an undeniable allure. To discover more about this city where cultures, religions and empires once collided, click @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Photo: @christopher_kennedy_photo #Trieste #Italy

Though originally a pagan tradition, pisanki were adopted by Christianity to become the traditional Easter egg and symbolise the revival of nature and the resurrection of Jesus Christ. A visitor looks at a portrait of the 18th century Italian adventurer Giacomo Casanova, in the world's first museum dedicated to him in Venice, Italy. The new National Music Centre in Calgary, Canada, houses two concert venues, a radio station and the Canadian Music Hall of Fame. Its architect, Brad Cloepfil, wanted to make each space distinct, so he arranged them across a series of nine towers. But the building also needed a sense of cohesion, and for that he used sound, turning the entire structure into the architectural equivalent of a mixing desk. He left the main concert hall open and connected the towers with curvaceous atriums and soaring “acoustic canyons” tiled with metallic sheets. Each gleaming tile is set to minutely adjust the sound as it travels. To discover more about acoustic design, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Angus Mackenzie @nmc_canada

Murals decorate a building in Sonagachi red light district in Kolkata, Eastern India. Artists from different countries, in collaboration with the Durber Mahila Samannay Committee, are working together to paint different areas of Sonagachi as part of a social awareness campaign about sex workers' rights, and to raise awareness of the problem of violence against women.  Photo taken on March 28th 2018. Credit: EPA/REX Shutterstock/Piyal Adhikary #publicart #India #womensrights

Ex-gang members take a chemistry class at San Francisco Gotera, a prison in El Salvador. Many in the country say that the only way to quit a gang is in a body bag. But Pentecostalist churches offer a way out alive. “The Last Trumpet”, an evangelical movement founded in an El Salvador penitentiary, is sweeping the country’s prisons. More than a thousand of the 1,300 prisoners in Gotera have renounced their gang ties and declared themselves born-again Christians. To learn more about the church’s quest to rehabilitate prisoners, and to find out how successful they have been in saving the lives and souls of the country's criminals, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. This week our cover looks at how artificial intelligence will give managers extraordinary control over employees. Every keystroke, utterance and movement will be searchable by algorithms designed to gauge productivity and loyalty. Companies will gain efficiencies and employees will benefit from more fairness and feedback. But the AI revolution has an Orwellian side. In some jobs the choice will be between being replaced by a robot and being treated like one. #TheEconomist

Michael Rakowitz, an Iraqi American artist, poses for photographers after the unveiling of his sculpture "The Invisible Enemy Should Not Exist" on the "Fourth Plinth" in Trafalgar Square, London on March 28th 2018. The sculpture, made from empty date syrup cans from Iraq, is a replica of a Lamassu, a winged bull and protective deity which stood at the entrance to the Nergal Gate of Nineveh from 700 BC. It was destroyed in 2015 by members of Islamic State when they attacked many treasures housed in Mosul Museum in Iraq. After it was built, the Fourth Plinth wasn't given a permanent statue, so it is used as a platform for guest works of art. Credit: AP/Matt Dunham #Iraq #MichaelRakowitz #London #TrafalgarSquare #art

The Photographer’s Story: Andy Rouse, a wildlife photographer, took this photo of an African leopard (Panthera pardus) jumping a river in the Masai Mara, Kenya. “I followed this female leopard for two weeks. After a few days we were able to predict her routes and behaviour. On this particular day she was following the line of the river. As she rounded a corner I spotted a section of water ahead that I knew she would have to jump, so I hurried to set up the camera for high-speed action and framed the shot to capture her reflection. When she took a running jump over the water, I was ready. Prediction is an essential skill for any wildlife photographer!” Credit: Andy Rouse/NaturePL #leopard #MasaiMara #Kenya #wildlifephotographer

This courageous little girl was at the centre of one of the most important legal battles of the American civil rights movement. In 1951 her father, Oliver Brown, tried to enroll his 9 year old daughter at the all-white Sumner Elementary School in Topeka, Kansas. When the school blocked her enrolment Mr Brown became the lead plaintiff in a class-action lawsuit brought by the NAACP. The case became known as Brown v. Board of Education and led to the landmark U.S. Supreme Court ruling in 1954 that segregation in schools was unconstitutional. Linda Brown died on March 25th 2018 aged 76. Credit: AP #civilrights #education #America #USA #LindaBrown

Welcome to the revolution: On March 24th 2018, less than 40 days after a mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, hundreds of thousands gathered near Capitol Hill in Washington, DC to protest against America’s lax gun laws and implore Congress and President Donald Trump to fix them. The vast crowd—which included toddlers perched upon shoulders, students, teachers and parents—thronged down Pennsylvania Avenue. Thanks to the impressive efforts of the eloquent survivors of the Parkland shooting, the media have not yet moved on from the tragedy. Parallel marches took place in 800 locations across the world. Photo credits: Reuters, Getty Images, EPA, PA. #MarchForOurLives #NeverAgain #guncontrol

Animated, affable and razor sharp, 27-year-old Beijinger June Ding graduated at the top of her high-school class and then left China to study at Yale, earning a BA and a graduate qualification in law. But June’s love life offers a prime example of the obstacles Chinese women with advanced degrees can encounter when seeking a marriage partner. In paternalistic China, the propriety and practicality of traditional courtship still dominates. Most men she is set up with are looking for wives – blushing, tender, baby-making wives. Foreign-educated June doesn’t fit the bill. To discover more about the challenges China’s urban women face in the marriage market, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #China Photo: Edward Barnieh

A woman wearing a lightweight and highly sensitive brain imaging device developed by the University of Nottingham and UCL. The new brain scanner allows the subject to move around and can pinpoint the part of the brain responsible for activities like nodding, drinking tea, playing bat and ball. It has the potential to revolutionise the world of human brain imaging. Credit: Reuters/Wellcome #brain #brainscanner #magnetoencephalography #ucl #universityofnottingham

“My interest in design was sparked by the theatre”, says architect David Rockwell. As a child, Rockwell was involved with a local amateur dramatics group and helped to construct and paint the sets. But what really hooked Rockwell was his first visit to @radiocitymusichall in 1967. “I remember being transported, overwhelmed by its architecture. And what struck me most was the staircase.” Designed by Edward Durell Stone, the theatre exemplifies his brilliance with spatial choreography. The star is the curving staircase, with its gleaming bronze railing and gold leaf. To discover more about the design, and how it has influenced Rockwell, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #design Credit: Rana Faure/MSG photos

A California sea lion waits to be released into the Pacific Ocean in Newport, Oregon, United States on March 14th 2017. The federally-protected California sea lions are travelling into the Columbia River and its tributaries to snack on fragile fish populations. The state is trying to trap and relocate the sealions in attempt to save the endangered fish. Credit: AP/Don Ryan #californiasealion #fish #endangeredanimals #Orgeon

The exterior of @bernssteakhouse gives little away. The bland, white building is tucked in a semi-residential neighbourhood of Tampa, Florida, within spitting distance of a noisy expressway. But for the oenophile, Bern’s is one small step below heaven. With more than 500,000 bottles in its cellars, it has the largest-known private wine collection kept by a restaurant (here, Eric Renaud, the restaurant's wine director, selects a tipple from one of the cellars). But it’s not just about quantity: Bern’s also stands apart from its peers in its list of aged wines that can’t be found elsewhere. To discover more about the restaurant luring wine connoisseurs to Tampa, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #wine Photo: @melissalyttle

Donald Trump’s tariffs on steel and aluminium imports come into force from today, but such tariffs are easier said than done. History offers some tough lessons. In 2002 the employers of Gordon Jones, a steel-drum loader, were thwacked with a 30% tariff. “They say that these tariffs are supposed to help workers, to save steel jobs, but what about me?” Mr Jones asked a congressional hearing. More such complaints will come, since steel-consuming sectors account for far more American jobs than steel production. #steel #tariffs #DonaldTrump #America #UnitedStates

In 1959, with the help of a $500 loan from his father, Jim Olson of Seattle-based design practice @olsonkundig, built a wooden bunkhouse overlooking Puget Sound. The building was tiny – just 19 square metres – but as time went by he began adding to it. In 1981 he built two more cabins to create a bedroom and bathroom, and in 2003 he added a living room. He then brought the parts together under one roof, creating a series of covered walkways. The house stands in a forest of ancient firs, its central section stained dark so that it almost disappears into the hilly landscape behind it. To discover more about the growth of this magical lakeside retreat, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. #design Credit: Kevin Scott

Our cover this week looks at the biggest crisis in Facebook’s history. Its founder, Mark Zuckerberg, has apologised to its users for letting their data end up with Cambridge Analytica. But he seems not to grasp that Facebook faces a wider crisis of confidence. We suggest how the firm should fix itself. #TheEconomist

Boko Haram militants have returned some of the 110 girls abducted from their Nigerian boarding school in February 2018. It was a crisis that ended as suddenly as it had begun. On the morning of March 21st armed militants swept back into Dapchi, a remote town in north east Nigeria – and dropped off more than a 100 school girls they had snatched last month. It was a rare victory on a troubled security front for President Muhammadu Buhari – and a sharp contrast to the saga of the Chibok girls, kidnapped by Islamist militants in 2014, a year before Buhari came to power, many of whom remain in captivity. Credit: Reuters/Ola Lanre #Nigeria #Dapchi #DapchiGirls

Sudan, the last surviving male northern white rhino on the planet, has died aged 45. This photo, taken on May 3rd 2017, shows the rhino being fed by a caretaker at Ol Pejeta Conservancy near Nanyuki in Kenya. Sudan was being treated for age-related complications that led to degenerative changes in muscles and bones, combined with extensive skin wounds. When his condition deteriorated the veterinary team at the conservancy had to make the sad decision to end his suffering. With Sudan's death, the world is left with just two female northern white rhinos.  Credit: EPA/Dai Kurokawa #SudanRhino #whiterhino #endangeredspecies #Kenya #wildlife

Gang members clutch a Bible at the San Francisco Gotera prison. Many in El Salvador say that the only way to quit a gang is in a body bag. But Pentecostalist churches offer a way out alive. In 2009, a prisoner named Nilson Bonilla announced that God had chosen him to be pastor of a new congregation called the Last Trumpet, and he convinced six other prisoners to join him. The movement spread and as inmates began to be released, members of the Last Trumpet searched for a second home, where the pull of the gang could not reach them. To learn more about their quest, and to find out how successful they have been in saving the lives and souls of the country's criminals, click on @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. David Byrne’s subject is the ordinary. Now 65, Byrne the former star of Talking Heads, has made a lifetime study of everyday people, places and objects. He likes to look at things clinically yet with irony, which helps make the commonplace seem strange. As he has grown older, Byrne’s ambition has become bigger. Grappling with the question of how pop should respond to politics, he has now released his first solo album for 14 years, “American Utopia”. Byrne hopes that the album will encourage listeners to take a long, hard look at America and ask whether they like what they see. To discover more about Byrne’s very own American utopia, click @1843mag and follow the link in their bio. Photographer: @nadavkander @davidbyrneofficial #music

The story goes like this: when asked by one of his regular customers in 1971 for a bit of sauce for his chicken tikka, Ali Ahmed Aslam, the owner of Glasgow’s Shish Mahal, splashed in a tin of tomato soup, yoghurt and spices. The resulting curry, which he named chicken tikka masala, proved to be a hit. Unsurprisingly, Indian foodies have different takes on its origins: some believe it was invented by the royal chefs of the Mughal period; others that it first cropped up in the Punjab, coincidentally also in 1971. On the cover of the April/May issue of @1843mag is fashion designer @donatella_versace. Before her brother Gianni’s murder in 1997, Donatella acted as a combination of muse, assistant and sounding board, who worked for her brother behind the scenes. Gianni’s death was a shock to Donatella, who was thrust into the limelight. “I think the world was looking at me thinking ‘she’s not going to make it’, and I understand that. Because Gianni was a genius in fashion. And I struggled, I struggled to find my own voice”. Twenty-one years after her brother’s murder, Donatella has revived the family brand. Our cover looks at the battle between America and China for digital supremacy. A brilliant star: Acclaimed physicist Stephen Hawking has died at the age of 76. He was diagnosed with motor neurone disease aged 21 and given a life expectancy of two years. He confounded this prediction, making  cosmic discoveries for another half a century, in his quest to understand the origin of the universe. He gave this life advice to his children: “One, remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Two, never give up work. Work gives you meaning and purpose and life is empty without it. Three, if you are lucky enough to find love, remember it is there and don't throw it away.” From an Interview with Diane Sawyer, for ABC News, June 2010. Credit: PA/Kevin Dietsch #StephenHawking #physics #stars

Swipe to see why increasing debt in many African countries is a cause for worry. Today the median debt level in sub-Saharan Africa (as defined by the IMF) is over 50% of GDP. That is low by international standards, but interest rates are generally higher for African countries, which collect relatively little tax. Economic growth slowed in response to lower commodity prices. As a consequence, there is much less revenue to service debts. The pace of borrowing has picked up. The IMF reckons that five sub-Saharan African countries are already in “debt distress”, with nine more at high risk of joining them. #TheEconomist #Africa #debt

A kangaroo enjoys the white sand beaches of Australia’s South Coast. Stretching from Sydney’s southern reaches to the Victoria state border 500km away, the South Coast region in New South Wales has some of Australia's most stunning landscapes. Aside from the city of Wollongong, it is relatively undeveloped, with stretches of natural coastline dotted with national parks. Pigeon House Mountain is one of the highlights, with breath taking views from its tubular peaks. It’s about a four-hour hike to the top, during which you might find yourself face-to-face with a kangaroo: they abound (and bound) on the slopes. Photographer @franslanting was largely responsible for bringing the natural wonders of Madagascar, the fourth largest island in the world, to public attention through his photographic essays in National Geographic. Madagascar is not only home to an extraordinary variety of species, many of which are found nowhere else, but its topography is varied and dramatic. In this picture, Lanting looks down from a helicopter onto the limestone pinnacles of Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park, in the remote west of the country, a largely unexplored area which is home to all sorts of fantastic beasts. Jefreey Sadrac Mejía in rapt conversation at the National Association of the Deaf of Nicaragua (ANSNIC). ANSNIC was formed in the late 1980s by a group of deaf activists who, frustrated with the lack of an indigenous sign language in the country, came together to create their own. The emergence of Nicaraguan sign language (NSL) was not only a life-saver for Nicaragua's deaf; it offered linguists an unprecedented opportunity to witness the development of a new language. Discover more about NSL and how it has fundamentally changed how linguists think about one of civilisation's greatest mysteries by clicking on 1843’s handle and following the link in their bio #signlanguage

Ice wine is made from grapes that freeze on the vine. Freezing forces water out of the grapes, leaving just a tiny drop of nectar inside. Canada may not be the first place one thinks of as a wine-growing region, but the inhabitants of Canada’s Niagara peninsula know ice wine well. It is where 90% of global production takes place and where most of it is drunk. But that may be about to change. This sweet, syrupy but complex and extremely palatable wine is trickling into the more upscale outlets in Britain and across the world. To discover more about the rise of these rare wines, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #wine #Canada

Paulette Buye who is 12 years old, recovers in a hospital room in Bunia, after an attack on her village. She received a machete blow to the back of her neck.  Along with her mother and brother she also suffered machete lacerations to the legs. The family hid out in the bush for three nights before managing to reach Bunia and medical attention. The Hema and Lendu communities, cattle herders and farmers, have a long-running feud over land, a situation that has recently intensified. The Democratic Republic of Congo is becoming increasingly unstable as President Joseph Kabila seeks to maintain his grip on power two years after the legal end of his second term in office. Our cover this week warns against the damage that will be inflicted by America’s impending tariffs on steel and aluminium. For the first time in decades, America has a genuine protectionist in the Oval Office. Donald Trump could cause a trade war by invoking a spurious rationale that others will copy. The World Trade Organisation, already under strain, will be unable to stop it. Not since its inception after the second world war has the global trading system faced such danger. #TheEconomist

A young white-bellied pangolin winds itself around its mother’s tail. Already rare, pangolins are being hunted to extinction for their meat, their skin and their scales, which are prized in Far Eastern medicine. At the first scent of danger, the shy pangolin curls into a ball, like a scaly hedgehog. While this is some defence against their natural predators, it makes them easy prey for human hunters. Photographer @timflachphotography aims to create portraits that emphasise animals’ personalities, encouraging sympathy for the plight of endangered creatures. A student from the Ullens Centre for Contemporary Art (UCCA) in Beijing holds up his work. Chinese schools emphasise rote memorisation, not least because mastering Mandarin is so hard. The government considers critical thinking a dangerous quality for Chinese children to develop, and the system is skewed towards exams. But there are complaints from business that China’s schools encourage emulation rather than innovation. The student-led, unstructured art classes at the UCCA seek to fill this gap by teaching creativity. Parents hope that a creative education “might just help their kids become the next Steve Jobs”. Ladakh is no stranger to war. Over the centuries it has been embroiled in struggles between Tibet and China and subjected to Islamic raids from neighbouring Kashmir and Baltistan. Gleaming white gompas, like the Basgo monastery pictured here, are, in effect, glorified fortresses, perched like eagles’ nests on commanding pinnacles. Vestiges of war remain. At the Rizong monastery, the monks serve visitors sweet mint tea in the shade of an army parachute. At Alchi, an exquisite group of temples 1,000 years old, you can run your hands along prayer-wheels made out of gunpowder tins. To discover more about the fascinating history and staggering landscapes of Ladakh, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #Ladakh #Himalayas

ON FEBRUARY 14th Nikolas Cruz shot 17 people dead at a high school in Parkland, Florida. As information trickled out about the 19-year-old in the following days, one of the most surprising revelations was that he had received marksmanship training from a Pentagon-funded education programme. Classmates in the scheme, known as the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps (JROTC), say he was a “very good shot”. #TheEconomist

Nestling in a volcanic crater 1.2bn years old, Pilanesburg National Park is a popular weekend getaway for Joburgers. The park is home to a wide variety of animals, including a full house of the Big Five: lion, leopard, rhino, elephant and buffalo. One of the best places to spot wildlife is at the Mankwe Dam, where hippos burp and wallow in the cool water, springboks leap across the plains and dazzles of zebra munch on sun-bleached grass. The predators are most active at dawn and dusk, so plan accordingly to have the best chance of seeing a chase. In a small park in Moscow stand several boxy buildings. They look a bit like a futuristic spaceship, but their decaying façades suggest impending demolition. Yet inside, a team led by Alexei Ginzburg, a Russian architect, is working to restore them. Despite their sorry condition, these buildings are some of the most influential in the history of architecture. Narkomfin, as the complex is known, was designed by Ginzburg’s grandfather, Moisei Ginzburg, a leading figure in the avant-garde constructivist movement. Its influence was international, inspiring famous architects like Le Corbusier. To discover more about this neglected architectural treasure, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #architecture #design

A trio of reindeer. Svalbard, a Norwegian archipelago 650 miles from the North Pole, offers some of the northernmost land on the planet and thus a chance to see the land mammals and sea creatures (and the flora as well as the fauna) that live in this extraordinary environment. Tourist numbers have nearly doubled in the past decade, and there is no reason why they shouldn’t do so again in the next one. “The polar ice caps are receding. People want to see them now,” says Will Bolsover, founder of Natural World Safaris. To discover more about Svalbard’s stunning landscapes and the Arctic tourism boom, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: @nickcobbing #Arctic #travel #animals

Dani Arnold, a Swiss extreme mountaineer and Mammut Pro Team athlete, opens a new ice-climbing route on the world-famous Helmcken Falls in British Columbia, Canada. He named the new route "Power Shrimps" after distorted, spiky and twisted icicles. At 141 metres high The Helmcken Falls is the fourth highest waterfall in Canada. While other waterfalls freeze completely in winter, at the Helmcken Falls the water continues to flow even when temperatures plunge. This painting of an underground dance party shows us one reason why jazz was so divisive when it first arrived in Britain in 1919. For some, this scene, painted by William Patrick Roberts in 1923, would have been one of excitement. The room vibrates with energy as the horn of the gramophone juts out into the throng of dancers. For others, jazz represented immorality, with jazz clubs portrayed in the media as dens of drugs and vice. This painting is just one of the objects on display in “Rhythm and Reaction: The Age of Jazz in Britain”, a small but ambitious exhibition at @twotempleplace in London. To discover more about the colourful history of Britain’s jazz age, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #jazz #exhibition

The justly celebrated Panorama Route stretches for 80 breath-taking kilometres along the Mpumalanga escarpment in South Africa. Although you can drive the route in a little over an hour, that would be a waste of some of the most dramatic scenery in the southern hemisphere. So take your time and drink in the views. Must-see stop-offs are signposted from the main road: Pinnacle Rock and God’s Window are the first two, followed by the impressive Lisbon Falls. This week in our British edition, as the cabinet meets to hammer out a plan, we set out the right Brexit for Britain. Theresa May, the prime minister, seems to think the only way to honour the referendum is to quit the single market and the customs union. But Norway shows that Britain can take back control without cutting all its ties to Europe. In our other editions, we report on how Russia meddles in Western democracies. Last week Robert Mueller, the special counsel, indicted a Kremlin-linked group that had sought to sow division in America and tilt the 2016 election from Hillary Clinton to Donald Trump. Europe has been targeted, too. If the West is going to protect itself, it needs to treat Mr Mueller’s work as a rallying cry. #TheEconomist

After Congo's President Joseph Kabila broke a vow to hold elections by the end of last year, there were protests in Kinshasa and 12 other cities. Mr Kabila cracked down hard. In rural areas the violence is worse. More than 70 rebel groups trade bullets with the army or, more commonly, prey on civilians. The security forces are equally vicious. Some 2m people fled their homes in 2017, bringing the total internally displaced to 4.3m. The UN predicts that an army offensive launched last month against Islamist guerrillas near the border with Uganda will drive another 370,000 from their homes. At least ten of Congo’s 26 provinces are in the grip of armed conflict. Refugees are flocking into Uganda, Tanzania, Angola and Zambia.

Albert Einstein was the proud owner of a fantastically cool Levi’s leather jacket. He bought it shortly after coming to the United States in 1935, and wore it as an all-purpose, any-occasion piece of outerwear. In Einstein’s case, style and substance were inextricable. Just as his wild hairstyle grew out of his reluctance to waste time at the barber’s shop, so the jacket was an expression of his philosophy of low-maintenance style. Einstein would never have made any “best-dressed” lists in his day, yet it was his dedication to systematic nonchalance that lent him such unmistakable elan. This photograph, “Les Mées” by Leipzig-born photographer Andreas Gursky, was shot at a solar farm in France. In this work, signs of modern infrastructure intrude on the landscape. The soft undulations of this rural scene are covered almost entirely in black panels. Gursky is intensely interested in the regimentation and repetition of industrial society. His extraordinary work is some of the most valuable in contemporary art. According to the Office for National Statistics, Britain is the “loneliness capital of Europe”. Three out of four GPs say that they see between one and five lonely people a day; only 13% feel equipped to help them, even though loneliness has a detrimental effect on health equivalent to smoking 15 cigarettes a day. It may be that affluence is making things worse. We prize space, privacy and independence, and the richer we get the more of these we can afford, yet their corollary is being alone. Our economy works better if people move around to find work, yet mobility stretches the bonds of family and community. To discover more about Britain’s loneliness problem, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #loneliness

The photographer's story: Jo-Anne McArthur, a Canadian photographer, took this image as Pikin, a lowland gorilla, was being moved from her first rescue home to a larger area of safe forest in Cameroon. Pikin had been captured from the wild and was going to be sold for bushmeat when she was rescued by Ape Action Africa. At first she was sedated but during the journey she awoke. Luckily she was not only very drowsy, but she was also in the arms of her caretaker, Appolinaire Ndohoudou, and so she remained calm for the duration of the bumpy drive. Almost 20,000 nature fans voted for their favourite photo of the Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2017 competition. This image is the People’s Choice Award winner @NHM_WPY #gorilla #nature @weanimals

Hummus was first mentioned in a 13th-century Egyptian cookbook. Since then, everyone in the Middle East has tried to claim it as their own. Israelis see hummus as central to their culinary heritage (via Mizrahi Jews from the Levant and north Africa). As with much else in the Middle East, this territorial claim is divisive. In 2008, some Lebanese businessmen tried – and failed – to make hummus a protected food, like Greek feta cheese. Piqued by what they saw as an Israeli hummus-grab, Lebanon pressed its chefs to create the largest hummus dish in the world. And so began a yearly competition known as “the hummus wars”. To discover more about this food fight over hummus, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #food #hummus

Many visitors to China speed directly from Beijing to Xian, where the terracotta army of the country’s first emperor stands to attention in trenches. That is a mistake. Situated between the two is another treasure: Pingyao. The city dates from the 14th century, the height of the Ming dynasty, and is contained within high walls. It is one of the only preserved ancient cities in China. Once a flourishing silk route-city and banking town, the city’s fortunes changed with the collapse of the Qing dynasty in 1911. Its poverty proved to be its salvation. Long ignored, it escaped the ravages of the Cultural Revolution. To discover more about this relic of old China, click on 1843’s handle and follow the link in their bio. #travel #China #Pingyao

The Belgian town of Sint-Truiden grew up around a Benedictine abbey founded in the seventh century. When French revolutionary soldiers pillaged the town in 1794, the abbey was largely destroyed. But one part of it survived: this haunting brick building. From 1872 it was used as a chapel, and reworked inside with gothic-revival vaults and vivid decoration. The building has since been home to a music and drawing academy and a local theatre company. Vacant again for half a century, it has now been adapted by @klaarchitectuur, a firm specialising in crystal-clear modern buildings. In 1629, Charles I acquired one of the continent’s most spectacular collections: the Renaissance treasures amassed by the Gonzagas, Dukes of Mantua. The acquisition propelled him into the front ranks of art buyers – and forever changed English painting. The court’s new enthusiasm for art drew European painters to London. Amongst them was Anthony van Dyck, who became the principal painter of the court. He painted 40 pictures of Charles and his family, including this magnificent triple portrait of the monarch. This painting is just one of the artworks currently on display at the @royalacademyarts in London. Ladakh is a daunting, barren land of jagged peaks and dizzying ravines. But it is not an inhuman wilderness. Everywhere, the landscape of Ladakh is animated by marks of love and prayer. Every outlandish crag, every bend in the trail, every twisted juniper clinging on for dear life, every summit of every incline, every entrance to every valley receives affection: a garland of prayer flags, a cairn, or a gigantic prayer wheel. These are messages for the gods whose home this is. Each person who passes adds a touch, in prayer at least, so that the whole landscape feels charged with goodwill. In Cuba, human hair extensions are big business – rumours abound of women in Havana having their hair stolen by scissor-happy thieves looking to make a quick buck. Some girls decide to take matters into their own hands, selling their hair to upmarket salons. Belleza Latina, a beauty salon in Havana’s upscale Miramar neighbourhood, is also the city’s largest emporium of human-hair extensions. As well as famous singers, actresses and well-heeled Habaneras, its clients include tourists from nearby countries like Mexico, where human extensions are much more expensive, processed, and often mixed with synthetic hair. Two people chat using Nicaraguan Sign Language (NSL). Before the 1970s, being deaf in Nicaragua was isolating as there was no native sign language. Growing up in the 1960s, Javier López – a pioneer of NSL – communicated through rudimentary signs his father helped him develop. He first saw sign language on an American TV show in 1977. Armed with a Costa Rican sign language guide, Lopez and some deaf friends began to gather regularly. At first, they tried to pick up the Costa Rican vocabulary, but speaking in a foreign language felt unnatural. As a result, they scrapped this dictionary, and began trying to make one of their own. On his first jaunt to Britain in 1874, Alfred Sisley, a British citizen born in the Île-de-France, followed the Thames west into the Surrey countryside. This depiction of a weir upstream from Hampton Court Palace ranks amongst his finest paintings. A cloudy English sky, captured with dappled brushstrokes, glowers over the vibrant greens of the vegetation and the deep blues of the river. The Temple to Shakespeare, a garden folly built by David Garrick, an actor, reminds us that the city is not as far away as it seems. The modification of photographs is as old as photography itself. This famous portrait of Abraham Lincoln is in fact a composite image, with the body taken from a daguerreotype of John C. Calhoun, a former vice-president. When Lincoln’s head was added on, it was reversed or “flopped”, causing the mole on his right cheek to appear on his left cheek instead – a rookie error. Despite the march of technology, computerised manipulation has not radically changed photography’s relationship with truth. The camera never lies? It would be more accurate to say that it has never genuinely told the truth. Discover more about the history of image manipulation by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #photography #AbrahamLincoln

The Saiga antelope is an ancient species which once coexisted with hairy mammoths and sabre-toothed tigers. Recently, the number of these long-nosed antelopes has dropped dramatically – as a result of disease (thought to have been a by-product of climate change) and poaching (the males’ horns are used as painkillers and anticonvulsants in traditional east Asian medicine). By creating portraits that emphasise animals’ personalities, photographer @timflachphotography aims to bridge the “otherness” dividing them from humans, which he believes is essential to getting us to care about endangered creatures. To view more of Flach’s stunning animal portraits click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #animals #TimFlach

From @1843mag : Local regulations required that this house in Argentina be made out of bricks. Its architect, @DiegoArraigada, has used them to two different effects. At the front, where the house meets the street, he has created a brick wall covered in a patterned outer skin, which for all its decorativeness looks almost fortress-like. At the back, where the perforated brickwork encloses a hollow volume containing a terrace, the building is turned into a gleaming light box, casting its intricate pattern on the garden. Discover more about how architects are using bricks in surprising new ways by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #architecture#diegoarraigada

From @1843mag: A smashed @jeffkoons balloon dog, a large version of which once sold for over $58m. Often, damaged works of art end up in the vaults of insurance companies. Some of these pieces, though, end up being exhibited by the Salvage Art Institute, which calls itself a “haven” for written-off works. A selection of these works is now on show in “No Longer Art”, a show at BNKR Space, a gallery in Munich. One of the show's pleasures is physical: there’s a certain frisson in touching the metallic shards of the balloon dog. Handling pieces in this way leads to a philosophical question: why does art become valuable? Discover more about the afterlife of broken art by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #art

From @1843mag : This custom-made houseboat was designed to sit, like a shark-fin, in the middle of Lake Eildon in Victoria, Australia. Since the boat needs to travel, the double-decker’s exterior offers viewing rails and a streamlined hull. Inside, however, the boat has the cool, sharp palette of an iceberg, with minimalist furnishings and integrated cabinets to keep everything shipshape. The attention of architects and designers is radically improving life on water. A new book,“Rock The Boat”, explores their work, and shows that “aquatecture” isn’t all portholes and painted timber, but rather modern, innovative and resourceful. Discover more about building on water by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #Design

From @1843mag : There can be no more joyous sight than this flock of flamingos, a vast field of pink stretching back to an indigo twilit sky. Wildlife photographer @franslanting shot these birds in Lake Nakuru in Kenya’s Great Rift Valley, where millions flock to feed and court. It is this ability to capture the world of wild creatures as they go about their daily lives that sets Lanting apart from his peers. His pictures are without artifice. A self-taught photographer, he was a scientist before he became captivated by the wonders of the natural world and determined to convey its beauty to us. From @1843mag: The durian is a fruit which looks like a cross between a kiwi fruit and a hedgehog. Inside the flesh resembles a decayed kidney and smells like rotting rubbish. Its smell has got it banned from hotels and subway systems in Singapore; the sign proscribing it looks as if the city-state has outlawed spiky hand-grenades or a pernicious whoopee cushion. But our correspondent can't get enough of the fruit, which tastes like a combination of almonds, brandy and buttermilk. As a 20-something who buys durian she is a rarity; younger customers are falling out of love with the fruit. Discover how sellers are trying to change this by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Illustration: @michelstreich_illustrator

From @1843mag: Renovating a house in Venice is not for the faint of heart. Since the city is built on canals, materials have to be delivered on boats. Yet when @massimoadarioarchitetto, an architect, bought this 15th-century villa in Sestiere Castello, he set about updating it. In his kitchen Adario remade the window in warm brass, which will age in Venice’s salty sea air. Then he added Fior di Lotus lamps, which, like the voluminous Cameleonda sofa designed by Mario Bellini for @bebitalia, a furniture brand, feel timeless. “I always try to find my own way,” says Adario. “I never try to follow what is trendy at the moment.” To discover more click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Image: Barbara Rossi #Venice #architecture

From @1843mag: One of photographer @david_lachapelle's best-known magazine photo shoots featured rapper Tupac Shakur. The shoot, “Becoming Clean”, included a somewhat heavy-handed photograph of Tupac soaping up in a bathtub (he had recently been released from prison), along with a series of images in which the rapper posed as a slave on a cotton field. In these pictures LaChapelle sought to pay homage to rap’s roots in the “call and response” songs of slaves.  Later LaChapelle turned away from celebrity subjects and rejected materialism, in life as well as in his work. Discover more about LaChapelle's work by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #Tupac #DavidLaChapelle #photography

From @1843mag: Some 50km west of Sydney Harbour, the Blue Mountains are as beautiful as their name suggests, with forests and the requisite picture-book waterfalls. The region draws visitors all year round, but is a particularly smart choice in summer, when its elevation keeps temperatures much lower than on the coast. The misty town of Leura, a community of city escapees and true mountain dwellers, is the best place to use as a base. Situated halfway up the mountains, it’s cooler and within easy reach of the region’s big-ticket attractions, such as the old town of Katoomba and the dramatic Jenolan Caves. Discover where else to go should you wish to escape Sydney by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Image: Alamy

We have two covers this week. In most of the world we look at the Trump presidency one year in. Pinch yourself: the latest obsession is over the president’s sanity. Trump-watching is compulsive. But, as a measure of the first year of his first term, it is also incomplete and a dangerous distraction. In Asia we report on India’s missing middle class. Companies hope that up to 400m Indians are on the path to prosperity taken by China. But decades of state intervention mean that India’s middle class is tiny and growing inequality will keep it that way. Companies need to deal with India as it is, not as they wish it to be. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Ernst Haeckel, a German biologist born in 1834, made his fame drawing microscopic sea creatures. With his left eye he would look through the microscope, with his right he would attend to the sketch in progress. He did not do so in the name of art – he had no formal art training – but in the name of science. No camera could capture the world he saw down his lens. And what a world: it teemed with micro- and macroscopic organisms, like this jellyfish he discovered while wandering the beaches of Nice. Discover more about Haeckel's legacy by clicking on 1843's handle and click on the link in their bio. #ErnstHaeckel

From @1843mag: On his 30th birthday King Charles II entered London in triumph. His return marked the end of the Commonwealth, a decade-long experiment with republicanism following the execution of his father, Charles I, in 1649. His coronation was the most extravagant since that of Elizabeth I. He ordered new jewels to replace those melted down by the Parliamentarians. John Michael Wright’s portrait shows the king magnificently clothed in the costume of the Order of the Garter, with his crown, orb and sceptre. An exhibition at Buckingham Palace examines the role the arts played in rebuilding the legitimacy of the king. Discover more about the spectacle of Charles II's court by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio.

From @1843mag: The headquarters of China Guardian Auctions in Beijing. China’s oldest auction house lies two blocks from the Forbidden City. The building consists of a glass box sitting on top of a set of smaller structures in grey stone, their colour and size intended to mimic the hutong houses of old Beijing. It is the work of Ole Scheeren, a 46-year-old German and one of the rising stars of international architecture. The playfulness of his buildings is important to Scheeren. The president of the Aviation Safety Network (ASN) attributes the steady decline of accidents since 1997 to safety measures put in place by international organisations such as the International Air Transport Association and the International Civil Aviation Organisation. But America’s president, Donald Trump, has come up with a different explanation. ”Since taking office I have been very strict on Commercial Aviation,” he tweeted on January 2nd, going on to assert that “there were Zero deaths in 2017, the best and safest year on record!”. But the crash-free streak predates his term of office: no commercial jet operated by an American airline has suffered a fatal crash since 2009. Search "Daily Chart" on economist.com

From @1843mag: African elephants gather by a body of water. It is an ability to capture the world of wild creatures as they go about their daily lives that sets photographer @franslanting apart from his peers. Over three decades and across the continents – though most often in Africa – he has produced images of creatures that seem to drill deep into their psyches, creating in us, his audience, an extraordinary sense of empathy for them. His new book "Into Africa” is the culmination of countless trips to the continent's great plains, savannahs, forests, mighty rivers and lakes. View more of Lanting's stunning photography by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #FransLanting #photography #elephants

Economist pics of the year: The photographer's story: Kandy Freeman takes part in a Black Lives Matter protest in New York on January 14th 2017. Stephanie Keith says: "I took this photo across the street from Trump Tower just days before Trump's inauguration. As the sun was setting about 40 protesters arrived. Almost immediately I saw this woman. I thought she was so beautiful. I noticed that there were snowflakes in her hair and I thought, what a perfect metaphor since the right wing has named liberals "snowflakes", saying they are weak and easily take offence. I loved the contrast of her strength and the fragility of the snowflakes." Credit: Reuters/Stephanie Keith #NewYork #photography #UnitedStates #snow #BlackLivesMatter #portrait

From @1843mag: In 2015 Ole Scheeren, a German architect, completed the Interlace, a residential complex in Singapore containing 1,040 apartments. Many architects, faced with the challenge of fitting that many flats into a tight urban space, would have built vertically. But Scheeren made a set of 31 blocks, which he tipped on their sides and stacked on top of each other like Lego bricks. The result has a kind of boyish charm. The Interlace displays a childlike delight in knocking things over and piling them up again. The playfulness of his buildings is important to Scheeren. Discover more about how he became one of the world's most successful young architects by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #architecture

From @1843mag: Faustino Prieto with the legs of jamón ibérico, a delicacy that he and his family produce. Much of Spain’s fine jamón comes from pigs raised on the wilderness that sprawls across Spain’s south-western flank. The pig's diet of acorns, grass and roots is a major factor in one of the world’s most exquisite delicacies. A leg of the finest jamón ibérico de bellota can fetch thousands of dollars. Yet piles of boxes containing legs of jamón have started appearing in discount supermarket chains across Europe. Small-scale producers are furious at what they see as a power grab by Big Meat. Discover more about how producers are coping with supermarket versions by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio.

From @1843mag: When David LaChapelle, an American photographer, retreated from Los Angeles to an eco-farm on Maui, it marked a turning point in his career. LaChapelle, who had made his name shooting decadent advertising campaigns and fashion stories for Vogue and Rolling Stone, embraced fine-art photography and rejected materialism, in life as well as in his work. The “Aristocracy” series is a trio of images depicting private jets spiralling out of control amid clouds. This gorgeous swipe at the jet-setting classes belies the work that went into making this scene: models of private jets were submerged in tanks filled with water. Discover more about LaChapelle's work by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio.

The Geminids meteor shower dazzled stargazers across the northern hemisphere when it reached its peak early on December 14th 2017. The Geminids are one of the years’ most spectacular celestial events providing a flurry of shooting stars. Long winter nights and a favourable moon made this shower all the more spectacular with stargazers spotting up to 100 meteors streaming past every hour. The shower is caused by a rocky object called “3200 Phaethon”, which spits shooting stars from its surface. Scroll through our selection of pictures of the Geminids meteor shower from Turkey, Ukraine and Russky Island in the Sea of Japan. From @1843mag: An aerial view of some of the houses in Naples threatened by Campi Flegrei, a volcano that is far more dangerous than nearby Vesuvius. Campi Flegrei is a type of volcano known as a “caldera”. It was probably formed around 35,000 years ago when a volcano erupted and collapsed, creating a bowl-shaped depression in the landscape. Twenty thousand years later a second eruption contorted the caldera to give it its current shape: it is 15km across at its widest and extends beneath parts of Naples and under the Bay of Pozzuoli. It is one of the most heavily populated calderas in the world. Discover more about the danger lurking beneath Naples by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. From @1843mag: Photographer @claudiusschulze tried to get around Hamburg’s rising rent prices with a treehouse. He was met, however, with the gargantuan might of German building regulations, which led him to discover how much simpler it would be to build on water, where anyone can build a structure under 20 metres. Rather than developing an existing boat, Schulze decided to start from scratch, with only €6,000 and no boat-building experience. The result, a DIY studio-cum-cabin featuring reclaimed windows and a disco ball, shows the potential of thinking outside the box. Discover other examples of innovative “aquatecture” by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #architecture #design

From @1843mag: “Death: A Graveside Companion” is a delightfully dark book that draws together images of death with essays considering aspects of mankind’s relationship with it. In the process it raises profound questions. What does it mean to die? What should be done with a corpse? Is death the end? The essays are printed on paper the colour of sodden earth; drawings of grinning reapers stalk the reader from the margins. Nowadays we try not to think about death. Modern medicine keeps it at bay. But this sometimes disturbing yet unexpectedly affecting book reminds us that it is the most human thing of all. Discover more about the book and death itself, by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. @thamesandhudson

The sails of the Sydney Opera House are illuminated with the rainbow flag in Sydney, Australia on December 8th 2017. Australia's parliament voted to allow same-sex marriage on December 7th. Credit: Getty Images/James D. Morgan #samesexmarriage #gayrights #rainbow #Australia #SydneyOperaHouse

Things take longer to happen than you think they will,” the German economist Rudiger Dornbusch once said, “and then they happen faster than you thought they could.” This week Australia became the 25th country to allow same-sex couples to legally wed. This year alone Taiwan, Germany, Malta and Austria have also legalised gay marriage, or instructed lawmakers to do so.  It has been a rapid transition for gay rights since the Netherlands became the first country to legalise gay marriage in 2001. Equal marriage has now become standard across much of the West. Nonetheless, the vast majority of Asian and African countries are yet to approve even civil unions. Campaigners are now likely to turn their attention to those heavily populated regions.

From @1843mag: Renovating a house in Venice is not for the faint of heart. Since the city is built on narrow canals, materials have to be delivered on boats. Yet when Massimo Adario, an architect, bought this 15th-century villa in Sestiere Castello, he set about updating it. He stripped away the fake plaster ceiling, exposing the wooden beams underneath, and installed a graceful floating staircase and a marble floor with an architectural motif in white and gold. Now he can look out on the water from a house that feels fresh. To explore this salvaged Venetian villa further, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: The woman in “Ash Wednesday”, a watercolour by Jeanne Mammen, a German painter active during the Weimar Republic, is evidently recovering from a night out, with the shadow of a cat on the right suggesting a bad Kater (the German for “hangover”). But there is little sign of regret in her expression, only confidence. Unlike Mammen’s contemporaries, who often likened sexually liberated women to prostitutes, she looked at them with warmth. Mammen is one of the overlooked female artists finally being given attention in an exhibition at the @schirnkunsthalle in Frankfurt. From @1843mag: The Indian principality of Dungarpur is a world apart from Rajasthan’s bustling big four: pink Jaipur, blue Jodhpur and the golden deserts around Jaisalmer and Udaipur. Dungarpur’s palaces are tucked in a valley far from the main thoroughfares. Its royal history may sound familiar, starting with a house that branched off from the Mewar line in the 13th century and ambled its way into the 20th century with a succession of maharajahs who became expert in cricket and the construction of Art Deco follies. But its secluded location has kept it out of the Rajasthani mainstream. Discover more about how to beat the crowds to Dungarpur by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. From @1843mag: The painter Amedeo Modigliani arrived in Paris in 1906 from Tuscany, where he had been brought up in a cultured family immersed in the glories of the Renaissance. His portraits of this period respond to this new environment, from the nightlife of Montmartre to the shimmering colours of Cézanne. This portrait, “The Beggar of Livorno”, was made on a trip home to Italy, and its distinctive palette – the face modelled in planes of vivid colour – shows the impact of Cézanne, whose work Modigliani had seen in an exhibition in 1907. Discover more about Modigliani's work, currently on display @tate in the widest selection of his work ever seen in the UK, by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #art

Trees are spreading in almost every European country. Because many of these forests are young, the quantity of wood in them is growing faster than their extent. Europe’s planted forests put on a little more than 1.1m cubic metres of wood per day. Deforestation in South America and Africa rightly gets most of conservationists’ attention. That loss is huge—equivalent to about 4.8m hectares a year, which far outweighs gains elsewhere. Yet the foresting of rich countries is still one of the world’s great land-use changes. It seems just as unstoppable as the deforestation of poorer places. It has plenty of critics, too. To find out why trees are covering more of the land in rich countries, search "The foresting of the West" on economist.com

While visitors tend to flock to Cambodia’s temples and battlefields, visitors who venture beyond the favourite tourist spots will be richly rewarded. From @1843mag: From startling eye-ball rings to the colour-drenched beauty of orange lacquer cuffs, James Taffin de Givenchy makes jewellery that crosses over to art and shifts its value from stones to design. This intense French designer has a Madison Avenue studio where he has quietly used his simple style to crack America. From @1843mag: This shot by Swiss photographer Fred Boissonnas, taken in the early 1930s, borders on surrealism. It takes a few moments to realise that the shapes in the bottom right are people – female mourners in northern Egypt. The figures echo the domes, rounded buttresses and archways of the town in the background, while the darkness of their costumes is picked up in the foliage behind. This photograph belonged to a book Boissonnas was putting together for the king of Egypt celebrating the newly independent country. The German election in September produced a more fragmented Bundestag than previous ones. The far-right newcomers, Alternative for Germany (AfD), took third place, squeezing more mainstream parties. The SPD, burned by four years as the junior partner in government, achieved its worst result ever. It has ruled out another round, preferring to lick its wounds in opposition. As Mrs Merkel’s party also fared poorly, the only other viable majority would be a three-way coalition with two smaller parties, the Greens and the liberal Free Democrats (FDP). After weeks of negotiations, the FDP has walked away. Search "Germany’s coalition talks have broken down" to read our full piece #DailyChart #Germany #Bundestag #AngelaMerkel

From @1843mag: Claude Monet painted London's Palace of Westminster in a dazzling range of palettes and always from the same vantage point. Painting each day from 4pm to sunset he transformed its heavy limestone into an ethereal apparition, its form shifting enormously with changes in light. Over the course of several paintings in the “Houses of Parliament” series, the Palace becomes an anchor for the splendour of the sky above and water below. This “Sunlight Effect” (1903) rendition shows a blaze of afternoon light from the right of the canvas, which glistens on the river before fading. To view more artworks produced by impressionist painters, currently on display @tate, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #Monet

A severely malnourished baby receives medical treatment at al Sabeen Maternal Hospital in Sanaa, Yemen on November 20th 2017. Yemen is facing a humanitarian crisis, the result of political instability that dates back to 2011. This complicated conflict involving government forces, Houthi rebels, Jihadist militants from al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and rival affiliates of so-called Islamic State, has resulted in around 6,000 civilians being killed and 9,000 injured. A blockade imposed by the Saudi-led multinational coalition, in support of the government, threatens 20 million people. From @1843mag: This poster, on show at an exhibition in London about the Jewish immigrants who reinvigorated modern British design, was made by a pair of Polish designers who moved to London in the 1930s. Commissioned by the British government, "The Vegetabull" (1941) tried to persuade people to eat more vegetables at a time when meat was in short supply. The poster may have been stretching the truth with its claim that “a vegetable dish made with dried eggs or household milk is as good as a joint” but the bull, inspired by Italian painter Giuseppe Arcimboldo, is so delightful it doesn’t matter. Discover more about this group of immigrant designers by clicking on @1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #design @thejewishmuseum

From @1843mag: Bedouins rest with their camels around a campfire by night in Sinai. The photograph was taken by Fred Boissonnas, a Swiss photographer who in 1929 was employed by the king of Egypt to create a book celebrating the newly independent country. For this picture, Boissonnas lit up the darkness by chucking magnesium powder into the fire, adding a touch of magic to an everyday scene. The illumination of the rock face and the blur of the camel as it nods during the long exposure give the composition originality and life. A selection of the photographs Boissonnas took is currently on display at the Royal Geographic Society in London. Discover more about his work by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #egypt

From @1843mag: The Louvre Abu Dhabi, an offshoot of the famous French museum, is located on Saadiyat island just across the water from the city. Billing itself as a “universal museum”, it tells the story of human history through artefacts and artwork ranging from the first known piece of monumental sculpture to the paintings of Yves Klein. Whereas other 
museums, like the British Museum or the Met, have separate departments for Greek or Chinese art, this one explores how ideas have sprung up simultaneously but far apart, and then spread, met and influenced each other. This is a museum about globalisation. Discover more about @louvreabudhabi by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Image: Mohamed Somji #abudhabi #art

A decade after mobile phones began to spread in Africa, they have become commonplace even in the continent’s poorest countries. In most African countries, less than half the population has access to electricity. Yet in much of the continent people with mobile phones outnumber those with electricity. The devices have transformed the lives of hundreds of millions. Mobile-money services have in effect created personal bank accounts that people can carry in their pockets. By one estimate, the M-Pesa mobile-money system alone lifted about 2% of Kenyan households out of poverty between 2008 and 2014. Technology cannot solve all of Africa’s problems, but it can help with many. #DailyChart #TheEconomist

We have two covers this week. In Britain, the Middle East and Africa we analyse the downfall of Robert Mugabe, the last of Africa’s liberation-era dictators. During 37 years in power he ruined his country and immiserated his people. The wonder—and the shame—is that he lasted so long. Elsewhere we look at what they don’t tell you about climate change. Stopping CO2 from entering the atmosphere will almost certainly fail to keep global warming below the promised 2°C—for that you also have to suck out huge amounts of the CO2 that is already there. From @1843mag: Bob Dylan serenades civil-rights activists on a porch in Greenwood, Mississippi, in 1963. Like many of America’s traditions, the porch is at once derivative and indigenous. Some architectural historians think the concept was imported with and by west-African slaves. But other iterations of the same idea have also been implicated: Italian loggias, Greco-Roman porticos, English colonnades, early colonial architecture in the Caribbean. From @1843mag: To escape the noise, pollution and heat of Mumbai, go to Matheran, an Indian hill station in the Sahyadri mountain range where all forms of motor vehicles are banned. A quick – if hair-raising – taxi ride from the train station takes you up 800 metres to the gates, where visitors must pay a small fee to enter. The way into town is a pleasant stroll or horseback ride along unpaved red-soil paths. Matheran’s biggest draw is the peace, quiet and clean air it offers. Discover where else to go should you wish to escape Mumbai by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Image: 500px
