From @1843mag: During Japan's Edo period (1616-1868) tattooing was associated with the “pleasure quarters” of the country's larger cities. Courtesans would tattoo the names of their preferred clients on their upper arms, followed by the word "inochi" – life – with the last stroke of the word elongated to convey eternal devotion. Their clients sometimes followed suit. In this print by Kitagawa Utamaro I (c. 1798-99), a courtesan named Azamino tattooes her name onto the arm of her lover Gontarō. Woodblock prints like this one let us track the history of tattooing in Japan. Discover more about the tradition of "irezumi" by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #Japan #tattoo

The congregation cheers as Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe's wife, Grace Mugabe, addresses a church rally in Harare, Zimbabwe on November 5th 2017. Mr Mugabe, old and frail, presides over a fragile economy yet still controls his party, Zanu-PF. At 93, he is running yet again for president, with an election planned for the first half of next year. Though physically weak and forgetful, he still plays factions of the party off against each other to stay in control. At a party conference in December he is expected to strengthen a faction aligned with his wife at the expense of Emmerson Mnangagwa, who previously ran the security services and had been Mr Mugabe’s presumed successor. This is not Northamptonshire but Lahore; a gathering of the Jane Austen Society of Pakistan. From @1843mag: A Moroccan woman sits astride a motorbike in a shot taken by @hassanhajjaj_larache. The London-based photographer filmed female henna-tattoo artists, who drive to work every morning on their motorbikes, for his documentary “Karima". The colours, patterns and shapes of their outfits, which Hajjaj designed, reflect the vibrancy of North Africa and the influence of globalisation – some wear Nike headscarves and Louis Vuitton slippers. His photographs of these girl-biker gangs appear in the riotously fun “La Caravane”, his exhibition @SomersetHouse in London, which fuses global pop culture with Islamic aesthetics. From @1843mag: A boy and his adopted mother on a porch in Daufuskie Island, South Carolina, 1952. Like many of America’s traditions, the porch is at once derivative and indigenous. Some architectural historians think the concept was imported with and by west-African slaves. But other iterations of the same idea have also been implicated: Italian loggias, Greco-Roman porticos, English colonnades, early colonial architecture in the Caribbean. Read a cultural history of the porch by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Image: Magnum ##ushistory

From @1843mag: Hidden on an island in Mumbai's harbour is a set of ancient cave temples that rival anything the religious centres of north India have to offer. A brief ferry ride from the British-built Gateway of India takes you to the jetty, from where it is a short walk to the base of a hill. The temples themselves are magnificent: commissioned by a king of the Chalukya dynasty and carved out of the hillside by Hindu monks in the seventh century AD, they are covered with intricate reliefs of gods and goddesses. Discover where else to go should you wish to escape Mumbai by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: Alamy #Mumbai #India #travel

From @1843mag: Clothes made by Yves Saint Laurent, a French fashion designer depicted here reviewing his spring/summer 1962 collection board, projected a woman who was economically independent, and socially equal to men. It was a step forward for the women who wore his clothes and a giant leap for womankind. Now Saint Laurent’s story is being told in two new museums dedicated to the late designer, which opened this month in Paris and Marrakech. Daily life in one of Brazil’s most traditional tribes who live at the Waiapi indigenous reserve in Amapá state, Brazil. For the Waiapi, modern life is creeping ever closer and the forest dwellers are learning how to navigate between two worlds. The tribe is resisting moves to open the region of pristine rainforest known as Renca– the Portuguese acronym for the National Reserve of Copper and Associates – which was set up in 1984 and encompasses nine protected areas. The Brazilian government wants to abolish the reserve to attract investment from international mining companies. Photos taken between October 12th and 15th 2017. Credit: AFP/Sebastian Smith/Apu Gomes #Renca #tribe #Brazil #conservation #culture

From @1843mag: There is magic in seeing a host of fireflies twinkling in ancient woodlands. Yet what may appear to be a lovely light show is actually, scientists have begun to discover, a secret and astonishingly precise language. The conversation, however, is dulled by light pollution, which is encroaching into the fireflies’ habitat. With this picture @timflachphotography invites the reader into a blue, glimmering fairyland that is becoming harder and harder to see in the wild. To view Flach's other portraits of endangered animals click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #timflach #photography

"Decisions" by Carolyn Watson, an entry in the 2017 National Geographic Nature Photographer of the Year contest. A young bald eagle tentatively feeds on a chum salmon carcass in the Nooksack River. Hundreds of eagles come to feed on these inland waters every winter, coinciding with the annual run. The eagle spent several minutes picking indecisively at the fish, often looking around to determine a clear path to fly out with the fish. Ultimately it opted to surrender the prize and fly back up to the cottonwoods reflected in the water. Soon a dozen seagulls would come and finish the meal. Credit: Carolyn Watson/2017 National Geographic Nature Photographer of the Year @natgeo #nature #photography

A dramatic view of Catalonia's separatist flag, the Estelada, as it flutters above independence supporters in Barcelona. With a slim majority, 70 votes out of 135, and with the opposition having walked out, the Catalan parliament in Barcelona voted on October 27th to declare independence and constitute Catalonia as a republic. Minutes later in Madrid, the Senate overwhelmingly approved the government’s request to exercise its constitutional power to intervene in Catalonia. Mariano Rajoy, Spain's prime minister, announced the immediate dismissal of the Catalan government and parliament, and called a fresh regional election for December 21st. Credit: Reuters/Yves Herman  #photography #Catalan #Catalonia #Spain #Barcelona #photojournalism

Fats Domino, the legendary American pianist, composer, band leader and blues singer, has died in New Orleans at the age of 89. His hits included "Ain't That A Shame", "Blueberry Hill" and "Blue Monday". Antoine Domino was born into poverty in 1928, in that most profoundly musical of cities New Orleans. His prodigious talent was recognised early and in 1949 he released his first record "The Fat Man", which sold over a million copies. Mr Domino was a lifelong resident of New Orleans and his home in the Lower 9th Ward was one of those destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. In response he set about fundraising for other victims. Credit: Getty Images #obituary #FatsDomino #blues #music #NewOrleans #America #Louisiana #UnitedStates

A young child, whose only protections are skill and a safety helmet, climbs to the summit of his team's human tower where he will support the final member, an even younger child called the "enxaneta" during the St. Ursula festival on October 22nd 2017 in Valls, Spain. The competition between teams is fierce and injuries do sometimes happen. Catalan human towers, called "castells", are an intrinsic part of Catalan national tradition and regular performances occur across Catalonia. Castell groups date to the 18th century, though only in recent decades has the tradition spread across Catalonia. From @1843mag: “First They Killed My Father” is the opposite of Angelina Jolie’s usual blockbusters. It is modestly budgeted, with few special effects, despite being the biggest film ever shot in Cambodia. Jolie, here shown on set, presents viewers with atrocities that took place decades ago in a country that most Western viewers would struggle to find on a map. Yet from this grim subject-matter she has made a quietly revelatory film that shows war and genocide through a child’s eyes without a single false or cloying note. Read 1843's cover story interview with Jolie by clicking their handle and following the link in their bio. #FirstTheyKilledMyFather #AngelinaJolie

From @1843mag: Ramen is Japan’s soul food. One in every four meals eaten outside the home is a bowl of the steaming noodle soup. The Japanese even consider instant ramen noodles to be their best invention of the 20th century – beating anything dreamed up by Sony. It is also an Instagram hit. Yet many who are hashtagging #ramen might be surprised to learn that ramen originated in 19th-century China, when Chinese migrants brought chuka soba (Chinese noodles) to Japanese ports such as Yokohama and Nagasaki and sold them to local workers. Discover more about ramen's surprising history – and how to construct the perfect bowl – by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: Stockfood #Japan

Our cover story this week looks at places left behind by globalisation. Affluent areas are pulling away from poorer ones. To tackle this divergence, politicians need a different mindset. For progressives, alleviating poverty has demanded welfare; for libertarians, freeing up the economy. But assuaging the anger of the left-behind, we argue, means realising that places matter, too #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Night markets are hardly new. Asia is stuffed with them. From Singapore’s hawker centres to the jostling markets of Bangkok, cheap, excellent food is available late into the night. But now, a new class of market is emerging in a growing number of Western countries, open at night, defined by the excellence of their food and their all-inclusiveness. From @1843mag: Inspired by William Klein and the street photographers in America, Daidō Moriyama has spent his life bouncing from city to city in Japan, taking photos of a country undergoing massive cultural change. The title of his memoir, “Memories of a Dog” (1984), is a reference to the animalistic way he explores the city. He roves hungrily, looking up from the gutter, guided by his instincts. From @1843mag: A holiday in the Arctic isn’t on the top of everybody’s list, but it has multiple attractions. For those who want to do something others haven’t done, it’s about as far off the grid as you can go. For those who want extreme experiences, it offers one of the toughest environments on the planet. For those with a penchant for wildlife, it provides the chance to see some of the world’s most remarkable creatures up close, such as these walruses. They are vast, Jabba the Hut creatures, weighing over a tonne; their skins are warty and knobbly; their tusks are maybe a metre long. Around one million bars of soap are discarded each day in America. Shawn Seipler stayed in a lot of hotels while working for his tech company. He realised that huge amounts of complimentary soap was being discarded.  In 2009, together with family and friends, using vegetable peelers and working out of his garage in Orlando, he began processing pieces of donated soap from hotels into fresh new bars. Clean the World, his company, works with 5,000 hotels and has provided over 41 million bars of soap to needy families across 118 countries.  In Kenya they've achieved a 60% reduction in hygiene-related illnesses for over 4,000 school children, increasing attendance by over 45%. Credit: Cover Images #soap #recycling #health #entrepreneurs

From @1843mag: across the harbour from the southern tip of Mumbai, Alibaug is one of a strip of settlements that are to Mumbai what the Hamptons are to New York. The best way to experience Alibaug is to be invited along by a well-off Mumbai family, many of which have over the past two decades colonised beachfronts and built palatial weekend homes in which to relax, mingle and strike deals. If no invitation is forthcoming, take the ferry to Mandwa jetty on the mainland. And if you find yourself tiring of the sea, the Karnala bird sanctuary, an hour’s drive inland, is home to some 200 species of bird. Police recovered 23 firearms in Stephen Paddock's suite at the Mandalay Bay hotel in Las Vegas. Twelve were semi-automatic rifles that had been modified with bump stocks, small pieces of equipment that allow semi-automatic guns to fire nearly as rapidly as automatic weapons—or roughly nine rounds a second. In addition to the arsenal found at the hotel, they found 19 guns at Mr Paddock’s home in Mesquite, a dusty retirement community 85 miles from the Las Vegas Strip, and seven at his residence in Reno. Nothing about the massive collection of weaponry—the types of guns found, the quantity or the modifications— was immediately deemed illegal. To read our full  report on gun control in America search "What happened in Vegas" via economist.com

From @1843mag: After sharing secrets in a surprise memoir, John le Carré returns to telling tales in an enthralling novel which breathes new life into old characters. An ex-spy, Peter Guillam, is summoned from retirement to explain the disappearance of files relating to a covert cold-war operation called Windfall. “A Legacy of Spies” sees le Carré reactivating his “unsleeping spies of yesterday” – not least “tubby, bespectacled, permanently worried George Smiley.” The result is a late-career triumph, and with luck neither Smiley’s swansong nor his creator’s parting shot. From @1843mag: Humans have always dreamed of better, fitter, longer-lasting bodies, but technological progress has been slow. Now, there are signs that a digital revolution in health care is imminent. It will be more personalised, and potentially more useful, than anything the world has seen before, promising to help us manage our health and inform us about the risks ahead. Recently, apps such as @teladoc in America, @babylonhealth in Britain and Min Doktor in Sweden have started to offer access directly to qualified doctors or therapists on a mobile phone. From @1843mag: like many of America’s traditions, the porch is at once derivative and indigenous, a synthesis of multifarious influences into an American original. Some architectural historians think the concept was imported with and by west-African slaves. But other iterations of the same idea have also been implicated: Italian loggias, Greco-Roman porticos, early colonial architecture in the Caribbean. No matter their origin, porches have always been a place to relax. In this picture taken in North Carolina in 1939, locals take it easy at the Crossroads General Store. Discover why the Southern porch still defines the character of houses in the region by clicking 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: @librarycongress

This week we have two covers. In Europe we report on Spain’s constitutional crisis. With Catalonia about to declare independence, Mariano Rajoy, the Spanish prime minister, is trying to hold his country together by resorting to the courts and to force. He may have the law on his side but, by failing to negotiate, he is only driving Spain apart. Elsewhere our cover looks at the bull market in everything. No one could mistake the past eight years for the roaring twenties, but the prices of assets, from stocks and bonds to property and cryptocurrencies, are high and heading higher. Should you celebrate or prepare to bail out? #TheEconomist

India’s capital, New Delhi, is in crisis over what to do with its rubbish. The megacity produces around 10,000 tonnes of solid waste every day. No proper processing facilities exist and most of it ends up dumped onto Delhi’s three mountainous landfills. Methane produced by the untreated rubbish causes the sites to regularly catch fire. On September 1st 2017 parts of the 45-metre high Ghazipur dump collapsed, killing two people and knocking several cars into a nearby canal. Despite orders from the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi, the municipality continues to dump waste on the site. Credits: Reuters, EPA, AFP #NewDelhi #India #Ghazipur #rubbishdump #waste

From @1843mag: Twenty kilometres north-west of Athens, Aspropyrgos is home to Greece’s major steelworks, brick manufacturers, quarries, power plants and petroleum refineries. The majority of the town’s 40,000 inhabitants arrived from far-flung corners of Europe and Asia by sheer historical happenstance. As Greece’s recent misfortunes have led to a recrudescence of nationalism, Aspropyrgos has seen rising ethnic tensions, which have proved to be beyond the control of the debilitated state. Discover more about the town exemplifying Europe's divisions by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: @simonnorfolkstudio #Aspropyrgos

From @1843mag: Dressed in muslin gowns, they sip tea and nibble on cucumber sandwiches. A maid refills the silver teapot while her mistress and her guests discuss the merits of Lyme Regis over Bath. Outside in the garden, birds hop on a damp lawn. It could be afternoon tea in Mansfield Park, the seat of the Bertram family in Jane Austen’s novel – except that the trees are banyans, the birds are Indian hoopoes and the maid wears a shalwar kameez. This is not Northamptonshire but Lahore; a gathering of the Jane Austen Society of Pakistan. From @1843mag: It’s near midnight and 1843's editor is sitting in an inflatable rubber boat a few yards from the edge of the ice, watching a distant polar bear. He’s not putting on much of a show – staring glumly into a hole – but there’s a lot else going on: a couple of reindeer, moving slowly across the frozen land; an Arctic fox, brown against the white, running fast; a black guillemot, with smart white patches on his wings, paddling around our little boat with his bright red legs visible in the clear water. A holiday in the Arctic isn’t on the top of everybody’s list, but it has multiple attractions. People listen to Masoud Barzani, president of Iraqi Kurdistan, during a rally calling for an independent Kurdistan in Erbil on September 22nd 2017. Iraqis in areas under control of the Kurdish Regional Government voted in an independence referendum on September 25th. Outside the Kurdish enclave there is little support for the non-binding poll. The region is far from ready for statehood, with its government steeped in debt. Mr Barzani, in the 12th year of his eight-year term, is using the referendum to rouse nationalist fervour. At this point, many Kurds would prefer their leaders to focus on governing Kurdistan better, rather than seceding. Nevertheless, the referendum is likely to pass. From @1843mag: The idea for this house in Constantia, in the wine country outside Cape Town, came when the owner bought a book on the world’s treehouses and resolved to have one of his own. So @malan_vorster, a firm of architects, devised a house which borrows from the structure of trees. The architects chose types of wood that need no treatment and age naturally. The outside is clad in western red cedar, the resins of which protect it against the weather and will, over time, fade to a pale, bleached blond so that the house blends into the forest around it. From @1843mag: “First They Killed My Father” is the opposite of Angelina Jolie’s usual blockbusters. It is modestly budgeted, with few special effects, despite being the biggest film ever shot in Cambodia. Instead of big Hollywood names, it stars Khmer-speaking non-professional actors. Instead of escapist popcorn fun, Jolie presents viewers with atrocities that took place decades ago in a country that most Western viewers would struggle to find on a map. Yet from this grim subject-matter Jolie has made a quietly revelatory film that shows war and genocide through a child’s eyes without a single false or cloying note. Read 1843's cover story interview with Jolie by clicking on their handle and following the link in their bio. #Cambodia

This week we have two covers. In Britain we look at the man increasingly likely to be Britain’s next prime minister. Going by his programme in June’s election, Jeremy Corbyn, Labour’s leader, would be dated and damaging, though not necessarily disastrous. But going by his recent statements and lifelong beliefs, he could lead Britain in a radical and dangerous direction. Elsewhere we look at China’s economic ascendancy. Even as its firms inspire awe, fears are growing in the West that the world will be dominated by an economy that does not play fair. On September 30th 2017, following a six-year renovation project, 11 Conti-Monnaie de Paris opens as a flagship museum in the centre of Paris. Since 1775 the building has been used to mint the country’s coins and medals. In 1958 the growing demand for coins meant that mass production was moved to Gironde but the core functions of engraving, minting, and packaging remained on the Paris site, which covers 36,000 m2 (bigger than seven football pitches). In addition the new building houses 150 artisans whose work can be viewed, the permanent collection of 170,000 objects illustrating the history of minting and a programme of temporary exhibitions of modern and contemporary art. From @1843mag: An exhibition tracking Rachel Whiteread's 30-year art career has opened at Tate Britain. Whiteread specialises in using plaster or resin to capture a missing object; she describes herself as “mummifying the air in a room.” House (1993) is a cast of the entire interior of the last terraced house remaining after a large-scale demolition in Bow, east London. It was pumped full of liquid concrete and its exterior walls peeled away, leaving an imprint of its architectural lines. A monument to a rapidly changing area, “House” solidifies a century of domestic life. Discover more works from Whiteread's career by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: Edward Woodman #Whiteread

From @1843mag: In the autumn of 2014, the last year for which there are data, over 38,000 American students studied in Britain, making it the leading destination for Americans learning abroad. This is a distinction Britain has enjoyed each year since 1998, when the Institute of International Education, an American charity, started keeping records. For Americans, the UK is a country familiar enough to be comforting – people speak the same language, share a history and a cultural heritage. Or at least, that is what they might assume. Discover what every American student should know before they study abroad in the UK by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Illustration: @jamieedlerillustration #UK #USA #education

Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2017: "Arctic Treasure" by Sergey Gorshkov (Russia). This image was one of the finalists in the @nhm_wpy 2017 competition for "Animal Portraits". Carrying its trophy from a raid on a snow goose nest, an Arctic fox heads for a suitable burial spot on Wrangel Island in the Arctic Ocean. The island suffers long, harsh winters and is ice‑bound for much of the year.  Most of the eggs stolen by the foxes are buried in shallow holes in the tundra, where the soil stays as cold as a refrigerator. These eggs will remain edible long after the brief Arctic summer is over. Wildlife Photographer of the Year is developed and produced by the Natural History Museum, London. Credit: Sergey Gorshkov #ArcticFox #nature #WPY53

From @1843mag: Humanity has gone to great lengths to prevent pregnancy; the Ancient Egyptians even used mashed crocodile dung as a vaginal suppository. The pill has revolutionised women’s reproductive health since its introduction in the 1960s, but continues to have significant side-effects for some. Now digital technology is offering a less disruptive solution. Earlier this year, @naturalcycles became the first fertility-tracking app to be approved for prescription by doctors as a contraceptive device in Britain and the European Union, and was shown to be as effective as the pill. Discover how the revolutionary device works by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Illustration: #NomaBar #fertility #contraception

Bill and Melinda Gates, usually heroically optimistic philanthropists, are increasingly worried about the future. According to a report published by their foundation this week, some aspects of global progress are under threat thanks to changes in demography and insufficient funding. For instance, projections for HIV suggest that a 10% cut in global donor funding for treatment—a not unduly pessimistic assumption—could lead to 5.6m more deaths by 2030 than if spending remains on track. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Darren Aronofsky’s surreal horror farce, “mother!”, has been the most talked-about, shouted-about, booed-about and cheered-about film at this year’s Venice Film Festival. Critics took to social media to call it the most astounding, traumatising and mind-bending experience of their lives – or else a load of self-indulgent tosh. To our critic, it seemed to be somewhere in between, although it’s undeniable that Aronofsky, the director of “Black Swan” and “The Wrestler”, has been uncompromising in putting his own vision on screen, for better or worse. Discover more about this nicely puzzling – but ultimately narcissistic – film by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #mother! #Aronofsky

Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2017: "Romance among the angels" by Andrey Narchuk (Russia) was shot in the Sea of Okhotsk.  This image of mating Sea Angels was one of the finalists in the @nhm_wpy 2017 competition for "Behaviour: Invertebrates". Sea Angels are molluscs with wing-like lobes which they use as swimming paddles. They hunt sea butterflies and swimming sea snails, using specialised feeding parts to prise them from their shells. Each individual has both male and female reproductive organs. They will go on to lay between 30 and 40 eggs each after fertilisation. Wildlife Photographer of the Year is developed and produced by the Natural History Museum, London. Credit: Andrey Narchu #SeaAngels #nature #WPY53 #photography #sea

Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2017: "Sewage surfer" by Justin Hofman (USA), taken on Sumbawa Island in Indonesia. This image was one of the finalists in the @nhm_wpy 2017 competition and received "The Wildlife Photojournalist Award". Seahorses hitch rides on ocean currents by grabbing floating objects with their delicate prehensile tails. Indonesia is second only to China as a contributor to marine plastic debris, which is forecast to outweigh fish in the ocean by 2050. Indonesia has pledged to reduce the amount of waste it discharges into the ocean by 70 per cent. Wildlife Photographer of the Year is developed and produced by the Natural History Museum, London. Credit: Justin Hofman #seahorses #nature #WPY53 #photography #environment

Minzayar Oo, an award-winning Burmese photojournalist, was arrested by the Bangladeshi authorities on September 7th 2017. He and Hkun Lat, his assistant, have been charged with providing false information to the authorities because they travelled to Bangladesh with tourist visas, and denied bail. Mr Oo, who works for the respected British photo agency Panos Pictures, was on assignment for GEO, a German magazine, covering the Rohingya refugees in the Bangladeshi town of Cox's Bazar. Photojournalists need proximity to their subject and cameras can make them easy to identify. Without their work we wouldn't be so able to understand the world around us. Credit: ZNP/Zarni #Bangladesh @GEO #Myanmar #Rohingya #photojournalism  @panospictures

NASA's Cassini spacecraft has just plunged to its destruction on September 15th 2017, ending a 13-year tour of the Saturn system, a crash deliberately engineered by NASA. The last portion of Cassini's mission began in late April 2017 as it performed 22 dives per week through the gap between Saturn and its rings. Today it had a one way ticket. No spacecraft has ever ventured so close to Saturn before. And so ends one of the most successful space missions in history. Swipe to see some of the extraordinary images captured by Cassini during its 13-year voyage of discovery. Credit: NASA/JPL/Caltech/Lunar and Planetary Institute #Cassini #Saturn #NASA #space #astronomy #planets

Our cover this week is on cancer. Science will win the technical battle against the disease. An elderly Rohingya refugee clings to her rescuer as she wades ashore in Dakhinpara, Bangladesh on September 12th 2017. The boat they arrived in from Myanmar crashed into the shore, tipping everyone out. The 1m Rohingyas who live in the western state of Rakhine have long suffered persecution. Recent reports suggest that around 290,000 of them have fled Myanmar since violence erupted in their state. Most Rohingyas have remained remarkably pacific in the face of extraordinary provocation. The militant group Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army (ARSA) have issued a statement indicating that they intend to observe a cease fire and have asked the Myanmar government to reciprocate. Credit: Getty Images/Dan Kitwood #boat #Myanmar #Rohingya #Bangladesh

Can animals claim copyright? That was the question contested in a groundbreaking legal battle between wildlife photographer David Slater and animal rights group PETA. Cheeky primate Naruto took his own "monkey selfie" when Mr Slater spent a week following a troupe of macaques through an Indonesian jungle in 2011. The landmark case ended with American judges ruling that copyright protection could not apply to the monkey. PETA's appeal on the monkey's behalf was dismissed, but Mr Slater will give a quarter of the funds he receives from selling the famous photo to charities dedicated to protecting the crested macaques in Indonesia. Credit: David J Slater/Wildlife Personalities Ltd #monkey #photography #selfie #nature #conservation #wildlife

From @1843mag: Steve McCurry first visited Afghanistan in 1979, the year after the Soviet-backed Marxist revolution, which exploded into a prolonged and bitter civil war. He has been going back ever since, producing images that both confirm and explode our monochromatic impression of a place he clearly loves. His photo Kabul (2003) shows the toll which the years of fighting and sanctions and insurrection has taken on the city. In this picture, a young orange-seller displays his wares on the boot of a bullet-strafed and abandoned car. From @1843mag: You visit Venice to stroll through the alleys, bridges and squares that make up the most beautiful public space in the world. The walk that is richest in architectural delights and historical significance follows the route from the Rialto Bridge to St Mark’s Square. It's a little more than half a mile, and shouldn’t take you longer than ten minutes. It will, though. Much longer. For during the warm months of the year the route is jammed with a slow-moving flotilla of tourists. Discover how Venice is suffocating under the weight of tourism – and whether the city can be saved – by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. From @1843mag: Harry Benson, a photographer for the “Daily Express”, covered the Beatles for 32 months from early 1964, and ended up defining their image. For “The famous pillow fight photograph. 3am. Georges V Hotel”, Paris (1964) he encouraged them to indulge their reputed fondness for a pillow fight. John Lennon replied it would make the band look childish. Then he blindsided Paul McCartney with a pillow. The public saw happy, irrepressible scamps enjoying the most wholesome bedroom pursuit imaginable. “Every photographer comes down to one picture,” Benson notes, “and that is mine.” Discover more of Benson's portraits of the band by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #Beatlemania #TheBeatles #HarryBenson

Some of the postcards displayed in the RCA Secret exhibition at the Royal College of Art in London, England on September 8th 2017. The annual event sees artists creating work on postcards which are then displayed anonymously. The customer only finds out the artist's name upon purchase, and funds from all sales are used to support RCA students. The exhibition runs between September 9th and 15th 2017. Originally designed to help calm children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder or autism, the fidget spinner swept across the world earlier this year as a toy that everyone could play with. Retail sales have undoubtedly slowed recently, says Mark Austin of ToyWorld, a trade publication—good news for the schools that have banned the toys as too distracting for pupils. But the spinner has created a new “fidget” category of playthings. And the global toy industry has learned lessons from its surprising success. Search "Fidget revolution" via economist.com for the full toy story #fidgetspinner #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: The idea for this house in Constantia, in the wine country outside Cape Town, came when the owner bought a book on the world’s treehouses and resolved to have one of his own. @malan_vorster, a firm of architects in Cape Town, devised a house which borrows from the structure of trees themselves. The house, which sits on stilts two metres high in a forest clearing, consists of four cylinders, each with a trunk-like column running through its centre and branching at the top to hold up the ceiling. Our covers this week: In continental Europe we look at the task ahead for Angela Merkel, the likely victor in Germany’s forthcoming election. In her first three terms, Mrs Merkel has been unadventurous—a steady hand in charge of a contented country. In her fourth, and possibly last, term she must grapple with the gathering threats to Germany’s prosperity. Elsewhere we describe what it means for machines to read faces. Not only can they instantaneously connect identities to databases, but they will also increasingly be able to decipher what people are like and what they are thinking simply from how they look. The benefits could be huge, but so could the threat to privacy, fairness and the familiar habits of everyday life #TheEconomist

Korean People's Army (KPA) soldiers cheer while watching fireworks during a mass celebration in Pyongyang for scientists involved in carrying out North Korea's recent nuclear blast, the largest to date.  Citizens of the capital lined the streets on September 6th 2017, to cheer a convoy of buses carrying the specialists into the city, and toss confetti over them as they walked into Kim Il-Sung Square. On the twentieth anniversary of her death, Mother Teresa is remembered in a street mural in Bangalore, India on September 5th 2017. She was born on August 26th 1910 to Albanian parents in Skopje, Macedonia and died on September 5th 1997 in Calcutta, India. She began her missionary work with the poor of Calcutta in 1948, and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979. From @1843mag: When he began searching for freshly-landed stardust eight years ago, Jon Larsen, a Norwegian jazz musician without a university degree, thought he would probably be unsuccessful in separating it from the dust of our own planet. Scientists knew how important it was to understand these tiny rocks and the clues they gave us to our own planet’s formation. They also knew that there was a prospect that they might give us a hint as to how life started afterwards. Yet they had all failed to find fresh examples. Find out how Larsen succeeded against all the odds by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: @espenras #micrometeorites

From @1843mag: Baron Raimund von Stillfried, an Austrian aristocrat and photographer, travelled to Yokohama in the 1860s to create photo souvenirs for the sudden influx of Western tourists. He often made use of painted backdrops shipped from the other side of the world (this one depicting Mount Fuji came from Vienna) and Japanese artists were employed to hand-colour the photographs. From @1843mag: In 1947, Chincoteague was a small fishing village on Virginia’s eastern shore. Head over to Assateague to see the wild ponies in their natural habitat, and book a front-row seat on a boat for the annual Pony Swim (pictured), when ponies are herded through the water to auction in Chincoteague. From @1843mag: Todd Rose, the director of the Mind, Brain and Education programme at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, argues that the myth of an “average” person, around which today’s educational systems are built, stunts people’s intellectual growth and damages their lives. Very few pupils are average: they learn in different ways, at different speeds and along different paths. Silicon Valley’s biggest names have bought into his theory and many of America’s school district leaders have signed a pledge to move towards “personalised, digital learning”. From @1843mag: LSD works by interacting with serotonin, the chemical in the brain that modulates dreaming and consciousness. These scans, from Imperial College London, show a riot of colour in the volunteers’ brains (row two), compared with those who have taken a placebo. They reveal that, under LSD, much more of the brain contributes to visual experience than it normally would. Subjects perceive images they do not actually see. In Silicon Valley, where everyone is striving to be as creative as possible, the ability for LSD to open up minds is particularly attractive. From @1843mag: Every age has interpreted prehistoric creatures in its own way. This is partly down to improvements in scientific understanding as more evidence is uncovered. But as Zoë Lescaze explains in her new book “Paleoart”, artists have also mined “the marvellous and macabre veins of prehistory, pinning wistful dreams and deadly nightmares onto bones, inventing new archetypes as they went along.” In Edouard Riou’s 1863 engraving “The Ichthyosaur and the Plesiosaur” (pictured), the creatures clash like ships of the line from the Napoleonic era. From @1843mag: Steve McCurry took his most famous photograph in Afghanistan in 1984: “Afghan Girl”, a portrait of a young refugee. This image was taken 18 years after McCurry’s first Afghan girl and is both her mirror and her inverse. This girl, presumably another refugee, is about the same age and, like the first, stares into the camera with a level gaze and clear blue eyes. Her gaze is more resigned, less defiant, as if the years of Sharia law under the Taliban, followed by the American-led NATO invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, had robbed her of any hope of returning to her country. Diamonds in the sky: Swipe left for photos of the spectacular Perseid meteor shower, which peaked overnight from August 12th-13th 2017, across the northern hemisphere. Clear night skies meant stargazers were treated to dozens of shooting stars streaking overhead every hour. The Perseids are seen annually as Earth passes through a trail of dust and debris left behind by the comet Swift-Tuttle. They are so named because they appear to radiate from the constellation of Perseus. The dust particles hit the Earth’s atmosphere at more than 200,000kmph and vaporise at an altitude of about 100km, giving the appearance of bright streaks of light zipping across the sky. Credits: Reuters/ EPA/ Getty Images/ AFP/ Press Association #perseid #meteor #meteorshower #stars

From @1843mag: That fake news shifted copies has been known since the earliest days of printing. In 1835 John Herschel, an eminent British astronomer, pointed a powerful telescope “of vast dimensions” towards the Moon from an observatory in South Africa. He saw giant man-bats that spent their days collecting fruit and holding animated conversations; goat-like creatures with blue skin; a temple made of polished sapphire. Or that, at least, was what readers of the "New York Sun" were told in a series of newspaper reports. Discover the true history of fake news by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Image: Library of Congress #fakenews #misinformation #history

From @1843mag: George Washington made his home on a Virginia plantation known as Mount Vernon. Over 45 years, he slowly enlarged the farmhouse built by his father into a 21-room mansion. It was the project of a lifetime, and he continued to supervise construction during the revolutionary war. Many high-profile guests passed through, including the Marquis de Lafayette, who gave Washington the key to the Bastille, which hangs in the central hall. Visitors can have a nose around the house, which looks much as it did during Washington’s time. Chancellor Angela Merkel with Monika Grutters, State Minister for Culture and Hubertus Knabe, Memorial Site Director, visit a former Stasi prison in Berlin-Hohenschoenhausen, Germany on August 11th 2017. Mrs Merkel says the government is committed to helping maintain the memorial at a former East German secret police prison, calling it an "authentic and painful" reminder of communist era excesses. Thousands of political prisoners passed through this jail, including nearly all the prominent figures who opposed the regime of the German Democratic Republic (GDR). From @1843mag: In Mongolia, shamanism is flourishing, thanks in part to the country's recent mining boom. Shamans intercede with spirits on the behalf of miners, in a form of spiritual insurance against the damage that mines inflict on the natural world. “Defacing and polluting nature is a great offense to Mother Earth,” says Byambadorj, a master shaman depicted here performing a rite. The apparent conflict between mining and animism does not trouble him. Quite the reverse. With the injection of funds that miners and other rich clients bring, shamanism has become big business. Discover more about this unlikely industry by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: @gillessabrie #Mongolia #shamanism

This image has won the 2017 National Geographic Travel Photographer of the Year Contest. "The power of nature" is a powerful eruption of Colima Volcano in Mexico on December 13th, 2015 taken by Sergio Tapiro Velasco. He writes: "That night, the weather was dry and cold, friction of ash particles generated a big lightning of about 600 metres that connected ash and volcano, and illuminated most of the dark scene. On last part of 2015, this volcano showed a lot of eruptive activity with ash explosions that raised 2-3 km above the crater. Most of night explosions produced incandescent rock falls and lightning not bigger than 100 meters in average." Credit: Sergio Tapiro Velasco  http://www.natgeo.com/travelerphotocontest #volcano #photography

A pedestrian passes a row of boarded up houses in east Baltimore on August 8th 2017. Baltimore has too many problems to address at once. A former steel and manufacturing hub, it has lost 75,000 factory jobs since 1990. As a result, around a quarter of Baltimoreans are stuck in poverty, with few obvious ways out. The police department last year was the subject of a damning report from the Department of Justice, which concluded that many of its officers were poorly trained, racist and incompetent, especially in their bungled efforts to patrol poor, black neighbourhoods. Photo taken on August 8th 2017.  Credit: AFP/Mandel Ngan #Baltimore #dailylife #poverty #America

An armed police officer guards ballot boxes at a tallying centre in Nairobi, Kenya on August 7th 2017. On August 8th Kenyans will pick a president, governors, MPs and senators. Yet instead of being excited about the chance to elect a new government, many are terrified. On July 31st Chris Msando, the chief technician in charge of the electronic voting system, and someone trusted to ensure it worked fairly, was found dead in Nairobi, the capital, his arm broken and his body displaying signs of torture. Who killed Mr Msando is far from clear. Elections in Kenya are bitterly fought, often violent and nearly always disputed. This murder suggests that this year will be no different. Credit: EPA/Dai Kurokawa #Kenya #election #Nairobi #democracy

From @1843mag: Every three days Nathan (not his real name), a 27-year-old venture capitalist in San Francisco, ingests 15 micrograms of lysergic acid diethylamide (commonly known as LSD or acid). The microdose of the psychedelic drug – which generally requires at least 100 micrograms to cause a high – gives him the gentlest of buzzes. It makes him feel far more productive, he says, but nobody else in the office knows that he is doing it. “I view it as my little treat,” he says. “It’s like taking spinach and you’re Popeye.” Read 1843's story on how Silicon Valley’s avant-garde is using LSD as a career enhancement tool by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Illustration: @joe_wilson_draws #LSD #acid #microdosing

People assemble for an election campaign rally in the village of Doldol in Laikipia County, Kenya on July 25th 2017. On August 8th Kenyans will pick a president, governors, MPs and senators. Yet instead of being excited about the chance to elect a new government, many are terrified. On July 31st Chris Msando, the chief technician in charge of the electronic voting system, was found dead in Nairobi, his arm broken and his body displaying signs of torture. Who killed Mr Msando is far from clear. The opposition blames the government, and several analysts suspect they are right. The killing removes one of the few people trusted to ensure that the voting system works. Credit: Reuters/Baz Ratner #Kenya #KenyaElection #democracy

From @1843mag: In the 1870s, Western tourists flocked to Japan in vast numbers, eager to experience a country that had only recently opened up to visitors. One photographer from this time, Baron Raimund von Stillfried, an Austrian aristocrat, played a crucial role in fashioning Japan’s international image. His beautifully produced albums – carefully hand-coloured by Japanese artists and bound in leather with gilt-edged leaves – were popular with well-heeled tourists as keepsakes of their visit. See some gorgeous examples of his work by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. Photo: Baron Raimund von Stillfried / The State Library of Melbourne, Victoria #Japan #postcards #photography

From @1843mag: "For my 1981 Samurai collection," writes Giorgio Armani in 1843's August/September issue, "I mixed ideas of armour, corsetry and traditional prints into a series of outfits designed to be worn by strong, powerful young women. The collection made an impression on @missgracejones, who was already famous for her sculptural beauty and powerful voice. The clothes were perfect for Grace – strong and incisive – so much so that she wore one of the jackets for the cover of her album “Nightclubbing”, which is one of the most enduring and powerful images of her. This week our cover looks at how tensions in North Korea might spiral into a war nobody wants. A limited strike to stop North Korea testing its missiles could escalate alarmingly easily into a nuclear conflict. With Kim Jong Un, there are no good options: war is reckless; diplomacy is worth trying, but unlikely to succeed. That leaves containment and deterrence #TheEconomist

Retiring today, at the age of 96, Prince Philip acknowledges the cheers of Marines as he carries out his final royal engagement. A homemade remedy of turmeric and oil is applied to an injured bird that was rescued in Bhaktapur, Nepal on August 1st 2017. Turmeric (Curcuma longa), a member of the ginger family, is widely used in South Asia as an antiseptic and anti-inflammatory. The powdered root is used both as a medicine and an ingredient in cooking. Curcumin, the active ingredient in Turmeric, is currently the subject of scientific research. It has been shown to produce changes in genetic markers of a gene involved in depression and anxiety, asthma and eczema, and cancer. Whether these changes could be beneficial is what scientists are investigating. Credit: Reuters/Navesh Chitrakar #turmeric #spices #tradition #Nepal #birds

"IF I should die, think only this of me;
That there's some corner of a foreign field
That is for ever England. There shall be 
In that rich earth a richer dust concealed; 
A dust whom England bore, shaped, made aware,
Gave, once, her flowers to love, her ways to roam, 
A body of England's breathing English air, 
Washed by the rivers, blest by suns of home." Rupert Brooke 1887–1915

From @1843mag: When Wallace Chan, a jeweller, began his gemstone carving apprenticeship in 1973, his master gave him a picture of a tiny jade cicada from the Chinese Han dynasty (200BC-220AD). At first, he wondered why the master wanted him to imitate something so ugly. "But the more I delved into the history of the cicada, the more excited I became," says Chan. "These creatures were symbols of resurrection." His love affair with the insect culminated in his shoulder brooch from 2012, “Stilled Life” (pictured). Discover the significance of the cicada in Chinese culture by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio.. #Chinese #handicrafts #cicada #jade

The shore of Lake Bracciano, northwest of Rome, Italy on July 27th 2017. Authorities have have severely restricted the amount of water that can be pumped out of Lake Bracciano, which supplies much of the Italian capital. Poor rainfall, high temperatures and leaking infrastructure have caused problems for farmers across Italy. People living in Rome may now find water restrictions imposed on them too. From @1843mag: For fans of Russian literature, little matches the thrill of wandering around the grounds of Yasnaya Polyana, the Tolstoy family estate located 200k away from Moscow, where Leo wrote “War and Peace” and “Anna Karenina”. Inside Tolstoy’s home, everything is as it was when he died in 1910. That the estate survived the tumult of the 20th century is a testament to Russian reverence for his writing. During the second world war, museum workers sent the exhibits to Siberia before Nazi forces occupied the premises; note the gash German soldiers left on Tolstoy’s leather couch. Discover our other picks for escaping the Russian capital by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio. #Russia #Moscow #Tolstoy

From @1843mag: Katsushika Hokusai was his own harshest critic. The 18th-century Japanese artist didn’t like anything he made before the age of 70, and he didn’t think he would become a “true artist” until he turned 90. On his deathbed, aged 88, he prayed for a reprieve of just a few years in which to achieve his full potential. Focusing on the last 30 years of his life and art, an exhibition at the British Museum in London brings together his major paintings, drawings, illustrated books and woodblock prints. Catch it before it closes on August 13th, and check out our other global cultural highlights by clicking on 1843's handle and following the link in their bio.. #Japan #illustration #exhibition #woodblock #Hokusai

From @1843mag: In central Kenya, on a spectacular plateau called Laikipia, hundreds of Samburu – members of a cattle-herding tribe from farther north – have invaded ranches and wildlife conservancies. With their herds in tow; they have burned buildings, shot people and fought with police. There is a colonial tinge to the conflict: the conservation business here is largely white. But this fight is not a remnant of the age of empire. It is brilliantly, terrifyingly modern – a test of whether weak states can stand up to climate change, population growth and ethnic populism. To find out how the conflict’s resolution will hint at the future of Kenya, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Nichole Sobecki #Kenya #Laikipia

A key White House post remains unfilled: First Pet. Donald Trump is the first American president without a pet in nearly 150 years.  According to the Presidential Pet Museum, the White House has been home to over 300 animals, ranging from dozens of dogs, horses and birds to the occasional bear, tiger and alligator. But although animals are beloved by Americans of all political stripes, their appeal in the Oval Office has not been quite so bipartisan: Democratic presidents have averaged six pets each compared with nine for Republican ones. To read our data team’s analysis, visit the Graphic Detail blog on economist.com #TheEconomist #infographic #datavis #petsofinstagram

From @1843mag: The view across a valley along an old military highway which runs through the country of Georgia. The wild Caucasian highlands have inspired the passions and pens of some of Russia’s greatest writers, and feature in the works of Pushkin, Tolstoy and Gorky. “A Hero of Our Time” by Lermontov starts: “I was travelling along the military road back from Tiflis [the old name for Tbilisi]”. The 1914 edition of Baedeker’s guide described it as “one of the most beautiful mountain roads in the world”. Today, the scenic highway is still luring travellers to the Caucasus with its grand landscapes and warm welcome. From @1843mag: Women in Mozambique are among the 1,400 farmers in southern Africa growing small red chillies just for Nando’s (@nandosuk). The global success of the restaurant is built on the flavour imparted by these chillies in its signature peri-peri sauce. In its original form, peri-peri dates back to the 15th century when Portuguese colonisers in Mozambique added locally grown chillies to their lemon-grilled chicken. It spread throughout southern Africa, evolving as it went. In northern Mozambique, coconut plays a strong role. In the south, lemon and garlic are more dominant. The Economist has two covers this week. In most editions we report on Liu Xiaobo, China’s Sakharov, who died today. A prisoner of conscience and winner of the Nobel peace prize, Mr Liu was a resolute advocate of democracy and showed extraordinary courage. The Communist Party wants the world to forget about him. There is a danger that it will. In our Africa edition we ask whether Rwanda, under Paul Kagame, its ruler since 1994, deserves to be seen as a model. It is efficient, the streets are clean and safe and the economy is growing. But the miracle is tarnished by repression and fear. As Mr Kagame seeks re-election—a formality—his admirers should note that rulers seldom improve in their third and fourth decade in power. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: At the press screening of “Okja” at Cannes in May, there was a chorus of boos when Netflix’s logo flashed onscreen. Here was the new film from Bong Joon-Ho, the acclaimed Korean director of “The Host” and “Memories of a Murder” – and yet it was financed by an online streaming service. That meant that it would be released on the internet and in cinemas simultaneously, an unconscionable faux pas as far as Cannes’s cinephiles were concerned. Two hours later, though, the boos had been replaced by cheers. To discover how "Okja" won over the crowd at Cannes, and why it would never have been made by a conventional Hollywood studio, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #Netflix #streaming #Okja

From @1843mag: Frank Lloyd Wright was not only a radical architect but also an immensely popular one. It helped that he was a character – oracular, entertaining, irascible. Yet it’s not witticisms but accomplishments that ground an architect’s reputation. His work has been the subject of at least 16 previous shows at the MOMA. The curators of this latest exhibition, “Unpacking the Archive”, were faced with the challenge of how to present him in a new light. Instead of devising a single overarching theme, they invited scholars to dig into a trove of material belonging to the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation Archive. Soldiers watch fireworks explode over Kim Il Sung Square, Pyongyang, North Korea on July 6th 2017. The display celebrated the successful test launch of a Hwasong 14 intercontinental ballistic missile two days earlier. The missile appears to have flown for 37 minutes before splashing down some 930km from its launch. According to David Wright of the Union of Concerned Scientists, it had a lofted (heightened) trajectory, reaching an altitude of 2,800km. On a more conventional trajectory, the same missile would have a range of about 6,700km. That would be enough to reach Alaska, but not Hawaii or California. Credit: AP Photo/Jon Chol Jin #NorthKorea #nuclear #missile #fireworks

One of the Brazilian armed forces’ central tasks is policing a 150km band alongside the country’s land border. International criminal gangs have long been drawn to the porous frontier. It is even said that Pablo Escobar, the notorious Colombian drug lord, owned a cargo plane that sits in the border town of Tabatinga. Brazil's army, however, is increasingly tied up in this sort of routine patrol work, and over-reliance on the army is unhealthy for a democracy. To read more about the world's 15th-biggest standing army, search "Brazil's armed forces" on our website economist.com #TheEconomist #Brazil

The Photographer's Story: Hamish Frost shot this snow cave nestled below Point Five Gully at Ben Nevis, Scotland on July 2nd 2017. He explains: "There are usually some snow patches in Scotland which survive the summer, however due to the unusually mild winter it's looking unlikely that any will this year. If this is the case, it will be only the sixth time since the 1700's. The tunnels are formed by water from higher up the mountain flowing beneath the snow. Meltwater raining down from the ceiling made for a pretty challenging day, trying to keep the camera equipment dry whilst we explored further into these incredible natural structures." Credit: Cover Images/Hamish Frost #Scotland #BenNevis #snowcave #photography #snow #mountains

From @1843mag: When a friend opts to date someone who is old enough to be their parent, a common response is to see if the decision passes the “half their age plus seven” test. The rule, whose origins remain mysterious, has been passed down through generations as a way of justifying or, more commonly, pouring scorn on other people’s couplings. It’s fine for a 22-year-old to go out with an 18-year-old. It’s not OK for a 38-year-old to go out with a 23-year-old, however a 26-year-old would be fair game. That's the theory. Is there proof? We examined the evidence, from divorce rates to life expectancy. To find out what the best age gap in a relationship really is, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio.

Michael Bond, the author who created Paddington Bear, has died at the age of 91. The little bear arrived at Paddington Station, London from deepest, darkest Peru in 1958. Paddington soon settled down to life in Windsor Gardens in Maida Vale, eating marmalade sandwiches, visiting nearby Portobello Road market and having many adventures. He would go on to appear in more than 20 books, which were translated into 30 languages. Mr Bond, also a resident of Maida Vale, was a wonderfully generous man throughout his life, hosting innumerable events for children, especially those with special needs. Credit: Eyevine/Rebecca Reid #MichaelBond #Paddington #PaddingtonBear #obituary #bear #London #PaddingtonStation

An aerial view of thousands of bicycles in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province, China on June 26th 2017. In cities all over the world, shared bicycles have become a colourful addition to street life. Most schemes work on the principle that a user hires a bicycle at one of a number of docking stations dotted around a city. While this helps to reduce carbon emissions, one downside is that riders may abandon bikes wherever their journey ends. The Hangzhou city authority has collected more than 20,000 sharing bicycles in an effort to tidy the streets. Credit: Getty Images/VCG #bicycles #sharingbicycles #Hangzhou #China

A Sri Lankan man adds to a pile of rubbish dumped on a street in Colombo, June 26th 2017.  Sri Lanka has suffered a record 200 deaths from dengue fever this year and, according to the country's health minister, a garbage disposal crisis is partly responsible. Rotting garbage has been piling up in many parts of the capital since the country's main rubbish tip collapsed in April, crushing dozens of homes and killing 32 people. With nowhere to dispose of the rubbish, municipal collection has drastically slowed leading to huge piles on the streets, which authorities claim are encouraging mosquito-breeding. Credit: AFP/Ishara S. Kodikara #SriLanka #Colombo #rubbish #garbage #pollution #denguefever #mosquito

Pride Worldwide: In a riot of rainbow colours, cities across the world celebrated Gay Pride over the past few days. Swipe left to see photos from Pride events in Mexico City, Chicago, Durban, San Francisco, New York, Naples, Manila, Istanbul and Toronto. Pride is both a jubilant celebration of progress in human rights and a remembrance of past and current struggles. In Manila, religious groups shouted slogans at Pride marchers and in Istanbul the march, banned by authorities, was met with arrests and tear gas. There are still many places in the world where to hold such an event would be unthinkable. Clearly the fight for global LGBT equality is yet to be won. Credits: AP, AFP, Getty Images, EPA #gaypride #Pride2017 #rainbow #photogallery

From @1843mag: More people than ever are choosing to be cremated, yet crematoriums are often grim places. There's a new wave of architects who are keen to change that. Willow Row in Cambridgeshire (pictured) is the first round barrow to be built in Britain for 5,500 years. The company’s owner, Toby Angel, wanted to create a space which, while open to people of all faiths and none, has an atmosphere of sacredness. A six-foot, diamond-shaped sentinel stone welcomes visitors; behind it is the softly domed barrow. Sound is reduced to a low, comforting hum. To discover more about new design work that's aimed at reconceiving death, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Hisao Suzuki #crematorium #design #architecture

The number of people who have been forcibly displaced from their homes reached 65.6m in 2016, the highest level since records began, according to a new report from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. A third of these are refugees and asylum-seekers who have fled abroad; the rest still live in the same country. Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) gang members arrive at the maximum-security jail in Zacatecoluca, El Salvador on June 22nd 2017. Extortion by gangs is an unavoidable feature of life in El Salvador. A vast, meticulously organised network touches every business, from kerbside tortilla-sellers to multinationals. Large stretches of country, including the centre of the capital city, are controlled Mara Salvatrucha and two other gangs. Salvadoreans pay $756m a year, about 3% of GDP, to gangs, according to a study by the country’s central bank and the UN Development Programme. El Salvador’s shockingly high murder rate is largely due to wars between them for control of territory. Credit: Reuters/Jose Cabezas #ElSalvador #dailylife #MaraSalvatrucha

From @1843mag: Women in Mozambique are among the 1,400 farmers in southern Africa growing small red chillies just for Nando’s (@nandosuk). The global success of the restaurant is built on the flavour imparted by these chillies in its signature peri-peri sauce. In its original form, peri-peri dates back to the 15th century when Portuguese colonisers in Mozambique added locally grown chillies to their lemon-grilled chicken. It spread throughout southern Africa, evolving as it went. In northern Mozambique, coconut plays a strong role. In the south, lemon and garlic are more dominant. To discover how the world fell in love with a flavour, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #Nandos #periperi #spice #flavour #food

Bath-time blues: Allt Ruadh of Crannich, a Highland bull from Peebles gets a thorough wash and brush-up before his competition at the 177th Royal Highland Show on June 21st 2017 near Edinburgh, Scotland. From @1843mag: Since 1953, an annual blind wine-tasting contest dubbed “the Varsity” has been held between teams from Oxford and Cambridge university. While the rowing team may be a more popular university pursuit, the dedication of the student wine connoisseurs is unrivalled. Yet one academic study after another has found little scientific basis for wine criticism. From @1843mag: The maxim that “you get what you pay for” could have been coined for modern air travel. Never has the metaphorical distance between the front and back of a plane felt so gaping. Today’s economy-class passengers overwhelmingly choose their flights on the basis of price, with little regard for the level of service they receive. Even as we moan that airlines are squeezing more seats into cattle-class, few of us click onto the second page of a Skyscanner search to find something more convivial. To discover whether first class is a luxury worth paying for, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: @jamieedlerillustration #travel #luxury #businessclass

From @1843mag: When jeweller Wallace Chan was first asked to carve an imitation Han-dynasty jade cicada he was an 18-year-old apprentice and wondered why there was a demand for something so ugly. But the more he looked into the history of the cicada, the more excited he became. These creatures – which spend much of their lives underground, and then come to the surface to shed their outer shell and reveal themselves fully formed – are symbols of resurrection. Having spent over 40 years carving this symbolic insect, Chan has perfected his craft. To learn more the history of the cicada and Chan’s jewellery, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #WallaceChan #jade #jewellery #China #cicada @wallacechanart

Each year there are more than 112m blood donations. A single one can save up to three lives. Most of those lives are in rich countries, and not just because of better health care. Nearly 30% of blood donations occur in Europe, which has about a tenth of the world’s population. Sub-Saharan Africa, which has a larger share of the global population, accounts for less than 5% of blood supplies. Our analysis shows that blood donations relative to a country’s population are strongly correlated with wealth. But where a country is located matters a lot, too. To read our full analysis search "The global inequality of blood supplies" on economist.com

From @1843mag:  Along the route on which the old military highway runs through Georgia, giant sculptures of the heads of local poets are dotted by the roadside. The wild Caucasian highlands have long served as literary inspiration and feature in the works of Pushkin, Tolstoy and Gorky. “A Hero of Our Time” by Lermontov starts: “I was travelling along the military road back from Tiflis [the old name for Tbilisi]”. The 1914 edition of Baedeker’s guide described it as “one of the most beautiful mountain roads in the world”. To discover how the scenic Georgian highway is luring tourists (think monks and moonshine), click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio.  Photo: @tom_parker_photographer #Caucasus #Chkheri #Georgia

Helmut Kohl, the former German Chancellor, has died at the age of 87. Mr Kohl was head of government for 16 years from 1982 to 1998 and oversaw the fall of the Berlin Wall on November 9th 1989 and the subsequent reunification of Germany. Angela Merkel, the current German Chancellor was a protégé of his. In this photo Helmut Kohl waves as he stands in front of the Brandenburg Gate during the opening ceremony of the Berlin Wall, December 22nd 1989. Credit: AP #Obituary #HelmutKohl #Germany #Berlin #BerlinWall #reunification #BrandenburgGate

Holy bat-signal, Batman! In honour of the late Adam West, who died on June 9th 2017, the iconic bat-signal is projected onto City Hall in Los Angeles, California on June 15th 2017. Mr West played Gotham City's caped crusader in the Batman tv series between 1966-1968. With its trademark comic-book-style graphic exclamations, memorable catchphrases, terrible puns and deliberately hammy acting, the show and its distinctive theme tune became part of the soundtrack of many childhoods. At the age of 88, Batman has gone to the great bat-cave in the sky. Credit: Reuters/Mario Anzuoni #UnitedStates #America #California #Batman #AdamWest #comics #superhero

From @1843mag: Cristóbal Balenciaga was as peculiar as his designs. To the despair of fashion editors, he insisted that they use his moody models, like Dovima (pictured) – known as "the monsters" – when shooting his clothes. He gave only one interview in his life and banned the press from attending many of his shows. He was rarely seen in public. Yet he is the man who reinvented the female silhouette, and changed fashion forever. In recent years drones have become a vital component of air power. America’s armed forces have a fleet of more than 11,000 drones, compared with just a handful in 2001. Peter Singer of the New America Foundation, a think-tank, says around 80 countries now have military drones, including about 20 with armed ones, either already in use or in development. But the vast majority are unarmed surveillance aircraft of various shapes and sizes. For our full report search "Drone technology has made huge strides" on economist.com

Her political career has been defined by caution. So it is cruel for Theresa May, and delicious for her enemies, that it may have been ended by one big, disastrous gamble. Eight weeks ago she called a snap election, risking her government for the chance to bank a bigger majority against an apparently shambolic Labour opposition. With the Conservatives 20 points ahead in the opinion polls, it looked like a one-way bet to a landslide and a renewed five-year term for her party. But there followed one of the most dramatic collapses in British political history.  #TheEconomist #Election2017

Together with another candidate (dressed as Elmo) and party workers, Prime Minister Theresa May waits for the results to be declared in Maidenhead, her own constituency. In the early hours of June 9th 2017 Mrs May was re-elected but the Conservative Party suffered heavy losses across England. In contrast the Labour Party, led by Jeremy Corbyn, made significant gains across the country. In Scotland both parties took seats from the Scottish National Party. Britain will have a hung parliament. The Conservative Party will rule but without the 326 seats needed for an overall majority. Credit: AFP #election2017 #Britain #politics #England

Photo gallery: Londoners returned to work this morning following the murders and assaults around London Bridge on June 3rd 2017. It was the UK's third terror attack in as many months. Two of the three perpetrators killed at the scene by armed police have been named as Khuram Butt and Rachid Redouane, aged 27 and 30. Some streets around the crime scene remain cordoned off, as security services try to establish whether the men, who used a van and knives on passers by, were part of a wider Islamist network. Tales of courage and compassion from both members of the public and the emergency services have been widely reported. The attack left seven people dead and 48 injured, 18 of whom remain critically ill. Credits: Getty, AFP, EPA #London

From @1843mag: When architect Alberto Campo Baeza was asked to design his first building in Mexico, he saw it as an opportunity to express not just his own style but to pay tribute to a Mexican architect who influenced him: Luis Barragán. Widely regarded as one of the great architects of the 20th century, Barragán is known for houses where unadorned exteriors belie the brightness within. Campo Baeza’s homage in Monterrey carries a similar hint of luxurious monasticism. Outwardly modest, it contains treasures within. The biggest indulgence is hidden on the roof: a swimming pool with a view of the mountains. To discover the house's other delights, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Javier Callejas Sevilla

“Sgt. Pepper” is one of a select group of albums to have sold more than 10m units in the United States, with 5m in Britain (the third-highest in the country’s history). Its cover, with the Fab Four sporting garish military dress in front of a wall of famous figures, is rivalled only by the zebra crossing on Abbey Road in the iconography of the world’s most famous band. Rolling Stone magazine voted it the greatest album of all time. Yet when rating Beatles songs, the same Rolling Stone included only two from “Pepper” in the top 50.  On Spotify, not a single track from the album appears in the top 25 most played. Despite this, the record has left a huge imprint on music's history. To find out why search “Sgt. Pepper at 50" on economist.com

From @1843mag: There’s no better way to get a feel for the ancient Russia of onion domes and wooden homes than by travelling along the Golden Ring, a stretch of picturesque old towns north-east of Moscow. Along the way is Suzdal, a town with dozens of golden-domed churches, little in the way of industry, and a quaint charm that lends itself to strolling among the grazing livestock and reading by the riverside. When you arrive, check in to the Heliopark Hotel (pictured), which has cabin-style rooms and an array of Russian banya (steam baths) on the shores of a small lake. To learn more about the Golden Ring and to discover other must-see destinations outside Moscow, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Getty

After spending 196 days in space, Expedition 51 crew members Oleg Novitskiy of Russia and Thomas Pesquet of France landed their Soyuz MS-03 spacecraft in Kazakhstan at approximately 10:10 a.m. EDT June 2nd 2017. Novitskiy and Pesquet will ride helicopters to nearby Karaganda for a traditional welcoming ceremony. Before leaving the ISS Pesquet tweeted, “It’s been a fantastic adventure and amazing ride. We got a lot of work done up here. Now it’s time to come back to the planet. See you soon!”. Credit: Reuters/Shamil Zhumatov #internationalspacestation #ISS #cosmonauts #astronauts #Expedition51 #space #nasa #spacecraft

Don't try this at home: Bee keeper Bui Duy Nhat lets thousands of wild bees land on his body in Núa Ngam commune, Vietnam on May 26th 2017. Nhat, 41, has been learning about the behaviour of wild bees since 1993 and is now one of a few specialists in Vietnam who can engage in "bee bearding". Without using any protective gear, apart from over his ears, Nhat can gather the wild bees in around 20 minutes. According to Nhat he attracts the bees by capturing the queen bee and keeping her on his person, causing members of the bee hive to land on his body. Credit: EPA/Pham Ngoc Thanh #bees #wildbees #beebearding #Vietnam

This week our cover features Britain’s election on June 8th. Although the Conservatives are much better than Labour, the leaders of both have turned away from a decades-old vision of an open, liberal country. Our vote goes to the Liberal Democrats - not because we think that they can win, but as a down-payment on a new party of the radical centre, essential for a thriving, prosperous Britain #TheEconomist

Blind Indonesian women listen to an instructor as they read the Koran in Braille during the holy month of Ramadan at the Indonesian Association of Visually Impaired People (PERTUNI) centre in Medan, North Sumatra, Indonesia, June 1st 2017. Muslims around the world mark the holy month of Ramadan through prayer and abstinence between sunrise and sunset. Credit: EPA/Dedi Sinuhaji #Ramadan #Indonesia #braille #Koran

NASA released this photo on May 31st 2017. It shows several bright bands of plasma on the Sun connecting one active region to another, even though they are tens of thousands of miles apart recorded over two days, May 17th and 18th 2017. Connecting lines are clearly visible in this wavelength of extreme ultraviolet light.  NASA has announced that a new mission aims to brush by the sun, coming closer than any spacecraft in history to its scorching heat and radiation in order to reveal how stars are made. After liftoff from Kennedy Space Center in Florida in July 2018, the Parker Solar Probe will become the first to fly directly into the sun's atmosphere.  Credit: AFP/NASA/GSFC/Solar Dynamics Observatory #space #NASA #ParkerSolarProbe #sun

An Indonesian hamlet nicknamed "Rainbow Village" in Semarang, central Java, May 23rd 2017.  The village of about 200 modest homes on a hillside used to be a typical, low-income Indonesian neighbourhood. But residents of the Wonosari community in Semarang decided an extreme makeover was needed, and received money from the local government and several companies to carry out the project.  Credit: AFP/Suryo Wibow #Rainbowvillage #Indonesia #KampungPelangi
Boys jump into the Arabian sea during a hot sunny day in Mumbai, India, May 31st 2017. Credit: EPA/Divyakant Solanki #Mumbai #India

On thin ice: A polar bear tentatively tests the strength of Arctic sea ice, August 22nd 2015. US media sources Axios, CNN, CBS, ABC and Politico reported that the White House is expected to announce a withdrawal from the 2015 Paris climate agreement, once details of the process have been worked out.  The landmark deal aimed to cut global carbon emissions to curb global warming. This photo released on May 30th 2017 shows recently-rescued Chibok school girls awaiting rehabilitation at the The National Centre for Women Development, Abuja, Nigeria.  At a ceremony welcoming 82 girls to the rehabilitation facility Aisha Alhassan, Nigerian Minister of Women Affairs, said all the girls will complete their schooling in September, but didn't specify where. The release of the schoolgirls, while obviously positive, does not herald an end to the activities of Boko Haram. The extremist group still holds over 100 of the Chibok girls it kidnapped from their boarding school in a town in Borno state, north-eastern Nigeria. Credit: AFP/PGDBA & HND Mass Communication/Sunday Aghaeze #education #girlseducation #Chibok #Abuja #Nigeria

Copenhagen's famous statue of The Little Mermaid has been painted red in an apparent act of protest, May 30th 2017. On the ground in front of the statue, "Denmark defend the whales of the Faroe Islands" was written, most likely a reference to the hunting of pilot whales in the North Atlantic islands during the summer months, according to Danish media. Faroe Islanders are permitted to drive herds of pilot whales into shallow waters, where they are stabbed to death. The meat and blubber are shared afterwards. Officials say there are approximately 100,000 pilot whales around the Faroe Islands and around 800 are hunted and killed each year. Credit: AFP/Scanpix Denmark/Ida Marie Odgaard #TheLittleMermaid #Copenhagen #Denmark #protest #whale #art

Celebrating the Lord's birth on May 25th 2017 in Nkamba, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Members of the Kimbanguist church believe Jesus Christ was born on May 25th rather than December 25th.
