An image, released by NASA on May 25th 2017, made from data captured by the Juno spacecraft shows Jupiter's south pole. The oval features are cyclones, up to 600 miles (1,000 kilometres) in diameter. The cyclones are separate from Jupiter's trademark Great Red Spot, a raging hurricane-like storm south of the equator. Credit: AP/NASA/JPL-Caltech #Jupiter #NASA #Junospacecraft #Juno #space #astronomy #planets

A rare megamouth shark (Megachasma pelagios) in a photo taken on May 22nd 2017 in Tateyama, Chiba, Japan. The deep-water shark is rarely seen alive. This female was accidentally caught in a fixed fishing net off Chiba Prefecture. While she was feed, she was subsequently transfered to an under sea cage where she died the following day. The species was first recorded in 1976, since when only around 110 individuals have been observed and most of those were already dead. Credit: Getty Images/The Asahi Shimbun #shark #megamouthshark #seacreature #sea #nature #Japan

Enjoying the fine spring weather in a very British way on a stoney beach in Lyme Regis, Dorset, England on May 25th 2017. A solitary cow stands amidst the debris of burnt houses after recent wildfires in the Siberian settlement of Strelka in Krasnoyarsk region, Russia on May 25th 2017. Credit: Reuters/Ilya Naymushin #cow #wildfires #Siberia #Russia #Krasnoyarsk

From @1843mag: In central Kenya, on a spectacular plateau called Laikipia, hundreds of Sambura – members of a cattle-herding tribe from farther north – have invaded ranches and wildlife conservancies. They have come armed with assault rifles, their herds in tow; they have burned buildings, shot people and fought with police. There is a colonial tinge to the conflict: the conservation business here is largely white. But this fight is not a remnant of the age of empire. It is brilliantly, terrifyingly modern – a test of whether weak states can stand up to climate change, population growth and ethnic populism. To find out more about the conflict, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Nichole Sobecki

The Frecce Tricolori (officially called the 313° Gruppo Addestramento Acrobatico) put on a dazzling display for leaders of the G7 countries meeting at Taormina, Sicily, Italy on May 26th 2017. Much has changed on the world stage since the last G7 meeting. Prime Minister Theresa May, President Donald Trump and President Emmanuel Macron all attended for the first time since taking office. Credit: Getty Images/Dan Kitwood #G7 #Italy #aerialdisplay #aerobatic #Sicily #FrecceTricolori

From @1843mag: Traditional ideas of masculinity persist in the workplace, even though men are now expected to do more of the household chores – and work longer hours. This means that among professionals, fathers are reporting they are just as frustrated with their working hours as mothers, and are often just as distressed about not spending enough time with their children. But uncertainty over how other men will view them makes them less likely to take advantage of child-friendly policies, and far more resistant to becoming stay-at-home parents themselves. To learn more about the trials of modern manhood, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: Shout #alessandrogottardo #work #fathers #masculinity #manhood

From @1843mag: “The Handmaid’s Tale”, @Hulu’s TV adaptation of Margaret Atwood’s dystopian novel from 1985, is without question the bleakest, most pitiless television drama for years. The show imagines a world in which, after a mass fertility crisis, a fundamentalist Christian movement America has taken part of America by force and made the Bible the rule of law. It's a tale about how a complacent present can lead to a terrifying future – which is what makes it feel especially relevant today. From @1843mag: Along the route on which the old military highway runs through Georgia, the Gergeti Trinity Church towers over the Chkheri river. With its cracked frescoes and smoky incense, the 14th-century church is magnificent; whatever their private beliefs, Georgians are extravagantly observant in public. Silver and gilded icons glimmer in the rays of light that pass through the window-slits. A vendor sells smoked fish near the Golden Mosque in Quiapo, Manila, Philippines on May 26th 2017 a day before the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.  More than 1.5 billion Muslims around the world marked the start of Ramadan on the evening of May 26th and will observe it until evening on June 24th 2017. During Ramadan observant Muslims around the world abstain from food and drink between sunrise and sunset. Because it follows the lunar calendar, Ramadan shifts by 11 days a year in relation to the Gregorian calendar. The Trabant is an iconic symbol of the Deutsche Demokratische Republik (East Germany), and affectionately known as the Trabi. This week we have two covers. In America we look at prisons which, as a British politician once said, are an expensive way of making bad people worse. Rather than locking up as many people for as long as possible, governments should seek to combine punishment, deterrence and rehabilitation. Some already are. 
Elsewhere we report on the state of the ocean. It plays a huge role in the climate. It provides 3bn people with at least a fifth of their protein. But humanity treats it with contempt. Better technology, including sensors and drones, will make governing the ocean easier. But the challenge is daunting. #TheEconomist

Lewis Hamilton driving for Mercedes during the first practice session of the Formula 1 Grand Prix De Monaco 2017 on May 25th 2017. The race takes place on May 28th 2017. Sir Roger Moore has died at the age of 89. Roger Moore was probably best known for playing James Bond in seven of the Bond films. In his early screen career he specialised in playing well-to-do jet-setter types, having become a household name on British television as Simon Templar in "The Saint" and Lord Brett Sinclair in "The Persuaders", roles in which classic sports cars were almost as important as the actors. The prestigious Chelsea Flower Show opens to the public on May 23rd 2017. Every year since 1913 the show has been held in the grounds of the Royal Hospital Chelsea, London. The Katskhi pillar is a natural limestone monolith with a monastery on the top, near the village of Katskhi in Imereti, Georgia. The Katskhi pillar is almost 40 metres (130 ft) high and the monastery dates from the medieval period. In 1995 efforts were made to restore and reinhabit the buildings. Monks use a metal ladder for climbing, and cargo is lifted separately using ropes. Photo taken on May 18th 2017. Credit: AP/Shakh Aivazov  #monastery #Katskhipillar #Georgia #architecture #photography

Objects made of uranium glass are on display at the "Magic of Uranium Glass" exhibition at the Zamoyski Museum in Kozlowka, Poland on May 19th 2017. The colour of uranium glass varies from yellow to green depending on the degree of oxidation and the concentration of uranium ions. It is strongly fluorescent in ultraviolet light. Credit: EPA/Wojciech Pacewicz #uraniumglass #uranium #glass #fluorescence #ZamoyskiMuseum #Poland #exhibition

From @1843mag: Thomas Kaplan owns more Rembrandts than any other individual in the world – which helps to explain why he is the first foreign collector to have an exhibition at the Louvre (@museelouvre). The Paris museum rarely borrows from private collectors, and never from foreigners. But even in France, museums are changing: they make a lot of money out of blockbuster exhibitions, which need to draw from collections all over the world. By showing Kaplan's, the Louvre proves it is top dog and his pictures get sprinkled with the fairy dust the art world calls “validation”. To discover how Kaplan acquired his impressive collection, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #Louvre #Rembrandt

Stork chicks sit in a nest at the Rehabilitation Centre of Protected Animals in Przemysl, Poland on May 19th 2017. The chicks were born to a disabled stork couple, who built their nest and will raise their young on the ground. Storks nesting in urban areas often use chimney pots or other high vantage points to build their nests. Credit: EPA/Darek Delmanowicz #stork #nest #birds #nature #photography #Poland

From @1843mag: Tim Steiner, a former tattoo-parlour manager from Zurich, makes a living showing his tattoo at art institutions. The garish design, which covers his back, is the work of Wim Delvoye, a Belgian artist, and features roses, a skull, bats, Japanese fish and a praying Virgin Mary. In 2008 it was sold to a German art collector, Rik Reinking, for €150,000 (Steiner received a third). The contract stipulated that he must exhibit himself three times a year and when he dies, Reinking has the right to flay him and preserve his skin. To learn more about the strange ways that tattoos are moving from the underground to the art gallery, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. #tattoo #ink #art #gallery #WimDelvoye

This photograph taken by a drone shows people enjoying an open-air swimming pool in Hamburg, Germany on May 17th 2017. Three new outdoor pools have opened in the city. Credit: dpa/Axel Heimken #Hamburg #Germany #swimming #drones

One competitor takes the opportunity to grab a snack while a judge makes his careful inspection, at the 122nd Devon County Show in Clyst St Mary near Exeter, Britain on May 18th 2017. Although primarily an agricultural livestock and produce showcase, it is also seen as a barometer for the health of the agriculture sector in the region. Credit: Getty Images/Matt Cardy #agriculture #Britain #England #pigs #countryside #rurallife #Devon

From @1843mag: On @KendrickLamar’s latest album "DAMN.", the rapper examines himself and finds a sinner. Rapping over the spare rhythms of trap, a style from the Deep South, Lamar confesses that he is wracked with lust, crippled by fear, and guilty of pride, greed and hypocrisy. But there is hope: Lamar is a man of faith. On this moving, carefully crafted album, which is threaded with references to the Bible, he dispels his demons by summoning not just the Word of God, but the words of Lamar. To learn more about Lamar's musical evolution, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Illustration: @stan_chow #KendrickLamar #rap #hiphop

The Solar Egg sauna designed by artists Mats Biger and Lars Bergströmt sits on the outskirts of Kiruna, Sweden. The Solar Egg is five metres tall and features a gold-plated stainless steel shell that magically reflects the landscape around it. Inside, the pine-clad interior surrounds a handmade wood-fired burner, encased in an iron cage in the shape of an anatomical heart. The burner is filled with large stones to conduct heat up to 85 degrees celsius. Photo taken on May 16th 2017 Credit: Cover Images/ Jean-Baptiste Bélange #art #sculpture #Sweden #Kiruna #solaregg

South Sudanese children play at the UNHCR refugee camp of al-Algaya in Sudan's White Nile state on May 17th 2017. The UN has said that more than 95,000 South Sudanese have entered Sudan so far this year, as thousands continue to flee war and famine in the world's youngest nation. South Sudan, which split from the north in 2011, has declared a state of famine in parts of the country, saying a million people are on the brink of starvation . Credit: AFP/Ashraf Shazly #Sudan #SouthSudan #refugees #dailylife

From @1843mag: the Troitse-Sergiev Lavra, Russia’s holiest of holy sites, was founded in the 14th century by St Sergius of Radonezh, one of Russia’s most revered saints, and has attracted well-wishers ever since. It would be worth visiting the site just for a glimpse of the stunning blue-and-gold cupolas of the Assumption Cathedral – and it's just an hour outside of Moscow. Looking like a prop from the set of Indiana Jones... A giant stone ball has been discovered in a forest near the village of Podubravlje, Bosnia and Herzegovina on May 11th 2017. Resident Suad Keserovic, who is looking after the find, says the sphere is about 3.38 metres in diameter and estimates the weight at 35 tonnes. This week, our cover argues that, 50 years after the six-day war, Israel needs a Palestinian state—for the sake of its own democracy. Palestinians have grievously damaged their case through decades of violence, but occupation is turning Israeli politics towards ethno-religious chauvinism. With Donald Trump arriving in the Middle East in search of the “ultimate deal”, it is not too late to strive for peace. #TheEconomist

A striking choice of snails is available from the market in Bouaké, Ivory Coast. Giant African land snails are considered a pest as they breed rapidly and destroy crops, having voracious appetites for a wide variety of vegetation, fruit and vegetables. Each snail carries both sperm and eggs, though they rarely self-fertilize, and are capable of laying around 200 eggs up to six times a year. It takes a lot of preparation work to cook giant snails and they need to be handled carefully and cooked thoroughly, with crushing, gutting and boiling, and a suitably spicy sauce. Photo taken on May 17th 2017. Credit: AFP/Issouf Sanogo #snails #market #cooking #IvoryCoast #dailylife
People take part in a weekly yoga class on the front lawn of Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, May 17th 2017. Credit: Reuters/ Chris Wattie #yoga #Canada

Emergency workers attend the scene of an incident where several people were injured when a vehicle struck pedestrians in Times Square in New York City on May 18th 2017. Reports indicated that many people have been hurt and one person killed. The vehicle, which was possibly being driven at speed, mounted the pavement striking the pedestrians. Credit: EPA/Gary He #NewYork #America

Displaced Iraqis evacuate their homes in a neighbourhood of western Mosul on May 17th 2017, during an ongoing offensive by Iraqi forces to retake the area from Islamic State (IS) fighters. Iraqi forces continue to pound Islamic State in the last pockets of resistance in western Mosul, where it is believed that just a few hundred IS fighters remain. Queues at Chinese hospitals are legendary. The acutely sick jostle with the elderly and frail even before gates open, desperate for a coveted appointment to see a doctor. Scalpers hawk waiting tickets to those rich or desperate enough to jump the line. The ordeal that patients often endure is partly the result of a shortage of staff and medical facilities. But it is also due to a bigger problem. Many people who seek medical help in China bypass general practitioners and go straight to hospital-based specialists. In a country once famed for its readily accessible “barefoot doctors”, primary care is in tatters. To read our full analysis search "Shod, but still shoddy" via economist.com

This week’s cover in most of the world features our interview with Donald Trump. Speaking in the Oval Office, America’s president sets out the ideas behind Trumponomics. His target is jobs and growth; his tools fairer trade deals, tax cuts and deregulation. Yet his underlying economic nationalism defies orthodoxy and fails to deal with the real challenge: how to cope with the turbulence from new technology. 
In continental Europe our cover is devoted to Emmanuel Macron. France’s new president lacks experience and the backing of an established party. He is taking power in a country that fights reform. And his message is that France must be open to change, because change brings progress. He deserves to succeed. #TheEconomist

From @1843mag: Damien Hirst is up to his old tricks. “The Warrior and the Bear” is one of 200 works on show at his new exhibition in Venice, “Treasures from the Wreck of the Unbelievable”. At well over £50m, its budget is Hollywood in scale – and so is the story it's based on. Cif Amotan II, a slave-turned-billionaire who lived 2,000 years ago, spends his wealth collecting treasures. He has the works loaded on a massive ship. But the ship is lost at sea, and the precious cargo lies at the bottom of the ocean, until Hirst discovers it – or so he says. From @1843mag: Watch any video of robots playing football on YouTube and prepare to be unimpressed. Robots repeatedly walk into each other while the ball lies stationary half a metre away; a robot goalkeeper fails to dive as the ball rolls slowly past it; and players fall over as the force of their own kicking motion unbalances them. But these clips aren’t representative of the best teams, which can be seen playing at Robocup, the robot football world cup. From @1843mag: Dora Maar was Picasso’s lover and muse for nearly nine years. They met when he had separated from his wife and already taken up with a sensual young mistress. Maar offered him intellectual and creative stimulation. In return he allowed her to photograph the creation of “Guernica”, his masterpiece about the Spanish civil war. In a new book, Louise Baring places Maar in the midst of artistic Paris after 1918. Her work (pictured) was exhibited alongside that of Salvador Dalí, Max Ernst and René Magritte. One small section of The Wave, an exquisite sandstone rock formation in the Paria Canyon-Vermilion Cliffs Wilderness in Arizona. The Jurassic age stone was eroded into spectacular ridges by water, and when that receded exposure to wind continued to sculpt the soft rock. The area is managed by the Bureau of Land Management who control access, as the sandstone is fragile and easily damaged by tourists tramping over the formations they have come to admire. The trip is not for the faint-hearted - getting there involves (depending on the route taken) a round trip hike of some 8.3 miles (13.4 km). Photo taken on May 28th 2013. Credit: AP/Brian Witte #photography #nature #Arizona #thewave #nationalparks #tourism #BLMNational #America

Every three years the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries, tests high-school pupils across the world on maths, reading and science. Its latest Programme for International Development (PISA) study, conducted in 2015, assessed more than half a million students in 72 countries. For the first time, it also asked respondents in 53 countries broader questions about their social and emotional well-being, addressing their relationships with peers, parents and teachers. The findings suggest that students’ family circumstances and psychological well-being matter just as much as schooling does for their eventual performance. To read our full analysis search "Competitiveness at school may not yield the best exam results" on economist.com

We can all recognise sweet, salty, sour and bitter food – but, until recently, the concept of umami was hard to digest. Over the past few years, umami – Japanese for "delicious taste" – has begun to creep out of professional kitchens and into the consciousness of home cooks through so-called "umami-bombs" that, in the form of miso, kimchi and tubes of mixed umami ingredients, have begun to appear on supermarket shelves around the world. All are designed to turn up the intensity of the flavour. To find out how umami-rich ingredients, like these spoons of miso pastes, are making our food tastier, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. The third in a selection of winners from World Press Photo: Long-Term Projects - First Prize. Title: 'Black Days Of Ukraine'. "Luhansk is a pro-Russian ‘People’s Republic’ in the Donbas region of Ukraine. The photographer first went to Luhansk in the early summer of 2014, and witnessed conditions change as hostilities intensified. He believes that the most important side to any conflict is the third one: that of the ordinary people caught up in the violence. Civilians in Luhansk and Donetsk had to survive often without running water or electricity, under repeated shelling, experiencing the destruction of their homes and the deaths of friends and relatives." Credit: Valery Melnikov, Rossiya Segodnya #WorldPressPhoto #photography

When mass schooling started in the 19th century, architects designed utilitarian spaces that looked like factories. Today there is a growing understanding of how buildings shape learning, for good and ill. In 2015 Britain’s most prestigious architecture gong, the Stirling prize, went to Burntwood School in London (pictured). Paul Monaghan, director of @ahmmarchitects, the firm that designed Burntwood, said that schools "need to elevate the aspirations of children, teachers and the wider community.” To find out more about how architects from Denmark to Japan are rethinking school design to foster new ways of learning, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. The first in a selection of winners from World Press Photo: Contemporary Issues - First Prize, Singles.  Title: 'Taking A Stand'. "In Baton Rouge  Iesha Evans (27) stands her ground at a rally against police violence against black men, outside the Baton Rouge Police Department in Louisiana, USA, on 9 July. Evans had travelled to Baton Rouge to protest the death of Alton Sterling, who was shot at close range while being held to the ground by two white police officers on 5 July. The fatal shooting of Mr Sterling came at a time of heightened tension in the US over the deaths of black men at the hands of the police. Evans was arrested at the protest, but released that evening." Credit: Jonathan Bachman/Reuters #WorldPressPhoto #photography

The photographer’s story: Romain Jacquet-Lagrèze moved from Paris to Hong Kong in 2009. From 2011 to 2016 he documented the city’s high rises from a new angle. The results can be seen in "Hong Kong Upside Down" at the Blue Lotus Gallery, Hong Kong from May 6th to June 24th 2017. "Some photos from the series have become records of now-demolished buildings or drastically changed places. A few others have become iconic shots of Hong Kong. A few spots shown in the photos have even become attractions for selfie-takers. At one place in Quarry Bay, you can now bump into tour guides showing off to overseas crowds and fashion photographers shooting models." Credit: Cover Images/Romain Jacquet-Lagrèze #photography #RomainJacquet-Lagrèze #HongKong

On Boxing Day in 1862, 38 Dakota men and boys were hanged in Mankato, western Minnesota. A festive crowd was watching. Fifteen years ago, a descendant of one of these Sioux men, Jim Miller, envisaged the grisly event in a dream in which he saw himself galloping over ground he did not recognise with men he did not know, until they arrived at Mankato. Today, Miller organises an annual 330-mile ride that begins in icy South Dakota and ends at Mankato on Boxing Day. To find out how this annual pilgrimage exemplifies a cultural re-awakening among native Americans, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: @marlonkrieger #America #USA #nativeAmerican #Sioux #horse #riding #history #culture #Dakota #winter #snow #landscape

Paying a high price for looking cute: The slow loris is classed as "vulnerable" by the World Conservation Union and some species are now critically endangered. This is in part caused by the pet trade. Native to Yunnan Province, southern Guangxi and parts of South-East Asia, a human environment is tortuous to them. Their large eyes are designed to hunt for insects at night. Their sharp teeth, which traders extract to make them easier to handle, are there to crunch bugs, strip rind from fruit and take sap from trees. Here, one of 18 rescued animals is looked after by staff at the Beijing Wildlife Rescue and Rehabilitation Center in Nanning, China on April 18th 2017. Credit: Reuters #wildlife #nature #endangeredspecies #slowloris #conservation

In most of our editions this week we report on the growing tensions on the Korean peninsula. The nuclear threat posed by Kim Jong Un will be extraordinarily hard to manage. 
In continental Europe we look at the first round of France’s presidential election, on April 23rd.  The candidate we support is the centrist, Emmanuel Macron. But the polls are nail-bitingly close.

And in Britain we analyse Theresa May’s decision to call a snap election. With Labour on the ropes, the prime minister has a chance of turning her small majority into a stonking one. That could free her from her hardline Eurosceptic fringe - and lead to a softer Brexit.

On high: The world's first weed church is due to launch in Denver, Colorado on April 20th 2017, welcoming the first ever congregation of “Elevationists,” as it calls its members. From @1843mag: A common refrain about social media is that they make people behave worse than they do in “real life”. It is tempting to say that online identities are caricatures of the real you but social media don’t create new personalities; they allow people to express sides of themselves that "real world" social norms discourage. Snapchat allows for capering in the office without disturbing colleagues. Facebook and Instagram encourage pride in one’s achievements that might otherwise appear unseemly. To find out why we may come to see face-to-face conversation as the social medium that most distorts our personalities, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. Photo: Getty #selfie #personality #technology #tech #internet

Why smoking is still so widespread: The scientific evidence that smoking kills was first made public in the 1960s. Yet people continue to light up - even if fewer do so than before. According to new estimates in the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study published in the Lancet, the global prevalence of men who smoke daily fell from 35% in 1990 to 25% in 2015; the prevalence among women dropped from 8.2% to 5.4%. Men tend to puff more for cultural reasons. Cigarette adverts are more likely to target them and in some countries female smoking is considered a taboo. To read our full analysis search "In some places women are taking up the habit even as men quit" via economist.com

From @1843mag: The Maison de Verre, a structure of glass blocks and steel built in 1932, was the solution to a tricky problem. In the 1920s Parisian doctor Jean Dalsace commissioned the architect Pierre Chareau to design him a home. Dalsace intended to demolish a pre-existing building, but the woman on the third floor refused to move. So Chareau replaced just the first two storeys with a building the architect Renzo Piano describes as "a masterpiece of lightness". To find out more about the building Piano wishes he had designed, and how it inspired the Centre Pompidou, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: Steve McCurry's most famous picture is that of the Afghan girl with green eyes, but it's not his favourite. He prefers this one, which was taken in 1994 on his first visit to Myanmar. The country was under a dictatorship and much of life centred around Buddhism. Temples were vibrant places. Building began on the Mingun Pahtodawgyi in 1790. It looks as if it was carved out of a cliff, but in fact it's built from thousands of tiny bricks. From @1843mag: Not satisfied with reusable rockets, vacuum trains and underground roads, restless entrepreneur Elon Musk now hopes to build a working brain-machine interface that would let users control computers simply by thinking. Musk has named the interface “neural lace”, which science-fiction fans will recognise from the “Culture” novels of Iain M. Banks. It's not the first time Musk has turned to Banks for inspiration – his mobile landing pads for rockets are named for sentient spaceships in the same series. To find out why Banks is the key to understanding the thinking of today’s tech titans, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: While most of the world is migrating to cities, growing numbers of metropolitan Italians are taking up farming. Many of the volunteers at Valli Unite, an agricultural co-operative nestled in the gently rolling hills of eastern Piedmont, had lived in cities all their lives but felt a need to go back to the land. Making a living, though, is not easy, and the work is backbreaking – sometimes literally. From @1843mag: On Boxing Day in 1862, 38 Dakota men and boys were hanged in Mankato, western Minnesota. A festive crowd was watching. Fifteen years ago, a descendant of one of these Sioux men, Jim Miller, envisaged the grisly event in a dream in which he saw himself galloping over ground he did not recognise with men he did not know, until they arrived at Mankato. Today, Miller organises an annual 330-mile ride that begins in icy South Dakota and ends at Mankato on Boxing Day. To find out how this annual pilgrimage exemplifies a cultural re-awakening among native Americans, click on 1843's handle and follow the link in their bio. From @1843mag: In summer Orkney's neolithic sites are crowded with tourists, but in winter you might have them all to yourself. Reached by boat, the neolithic village of Skara Brae was covered by a large dune until 1850, when a storm revealed it. Today, visitors can wander the small round houses, fitted out with stone dressers, stone cupboards and stone box beds. From @1843mag: A new generation of young Chinese writers is experimenting with science fiction to criticise society. Hao Jingfang's novella, “Folding Beijing”, follows Lao Dao, a sewage worker toiling in the underbelly of a Beijing divided into three segments: an elite 5m live in “First Space”, 25m more occupy “Second Space” and a teaming underclass of 50m are in “Third Space”. In China the story was hotly discussed online, not just for its literary merits, but also for its social criticism – so much so, the authorities closed down discussion threads. From @1843mag: Can sending a current of electricity through your head make you happier, healthier and more relaxed? That's what Thync and Halo Neuroscience, start-ups based in America, claim. They have designed gadgets that use neurostimulation to gently deliver low currents of electricity across the skull. They purport not only to improve mood and sleep quality but to lower anxiety and enhance the performance of a range of people, from Parkinson's sufferers to snipers. This week we have two covers. In Britain and continental Europe we examine Brexit. Ever since last summer’s referendum on leaving the European Union, the prime minister, Theresa May, has been able to depict Brexit as a Utopian fantasy. Now that negotiations are beginning for real, Britain is due a brutal encounter with reality.

Elsewhere, we analyse the state of the Trump presidency. Blocked by Congress, stuck in the courts and beset by a Russian scandal, Donald Trump is in a hole. That is bad news for America and the world #TheEconomist

An artist's impression shows new stars bursting to life inside material expelled from supermassive black holes. European astronomers at ESO's Paranal Observatory in Chile are studying an ongoing collision between two distant galaxies, known collectively as IRAS F23128-5919. The group discovered colossal winds of material originating near the supermassive black hole at the heart of the pair's southern galaxy, and have found the first clear evidence that stars are being born within them. The findings are the first confirmed observations of stars forming in this kind of extreme environment. Credit: EPA/M. From @1843mag: When the ancient Islamic practice of calligraphy and Western graffiti come together, a new art form is born. Arabic calligraphy serves as inspiration for many Middle Eastern contemporary artists seeking to create street art with an Arab identity. In Manshiyat Naser, where Cairo's rubbish collectors live, French-Tunisian artist eL Seed has created a mural spanning more than 50 buildings. From the right angle, it forms a phrase: "He who wants to see the light of the sun must first wipe his eyes." Just for fun, there is a red slide that provides an alternative to the stairs. The European Project has sometimes given the impression of being in perpetual crisis. Indeed, its spiritual father, Jean Monnet, saw this as the best way to advance to his preferred goal of “ever closer union”, arguing that “Europe will be forged in crises, and will be the sum of the solutions adopted for those crises.” Yet as the union prepares to celebrate 60 years since its founding treaty was signed in Rome on March 25th 1957, it is in deeper trouble than ever. From @1843mag: While most of the world is migrating to cities, growing numbers of metropolitan Italians are taking up farming. Alessandro Piana and Enrica Gherpelli left Genoa with their two young children three years ago to move to Cremolina, a hilltop village of 1,100 residents, to produce saffron. The heart of their enterprise is La Rienca – an anagram of Gherpelli's name – a not-quite-finished greenhouse that will eventually house 100,000 aeroponically grown saffron-producing crocuses. This week we have two covers. In Europe we ask what can be done to fix the European Union. As leaders gather to celebrate the club’s 60th anniversary, the project is in trouble. If it is to survive, the EU must become a lot more flexible.

In the rest of the world our cover examines the extraordinary expectations surrounding Amazon. Never before has a company been worth so much for so long while making so little money. If it fulfils its ambitions, it may attract the attention of an even stronger beast: government #TheEconomist

Economist Zoom: Rural sub-Saharan Africa is littered with broken water pumps: at any time around a third are broken, despite billions of dollars spent by donors. Our West Africa correspondent Rachel Savage travelled to Gambia to visit villages trialling pumps powered by pay-as-you-go mobile technology. These pumps could save time and effort for the women and children who still have to haul up dirty water from the wells. Read the full story via economist.com by searching “Pay as you pump” #WorldWaterDay #water #Gambia

The photographer's story:  As part of a project to mark World Water Day, photographer Dusan Stojancevic captured images of Cambodians inside water droplets to show the impressive strides the country has made in bringing clean water to its population. Since 2000, 33% more people in Cambodia have access to clean water. Dusan celebrates that progress in his photo series, “It’s the first time I’ve used this technique with people as the subject”. This photo, taken on February 2nd 2017, shows a farmer posing with his crops after a drought-resistant irrigation system was installed in his village.  Despite such progress, 663 million people worldwide still don’t have access to clean water.  Credit: WaterAid/Cover Images  #WorldWaterDay

Taking America’s political temperature: Among the first elections under President Trump, voters in Georgia's 6th congressional district will go to the polls on April 18th 2017. The winners in that round will go forward to a final runoff vote on June 20th. The seat became vacant when former Representative Tom Price was promoted to health secretary. He had held the position since 2004, being re-elected with a very healthy 61.6% of the vote in 2016. Jon Ossoff is the leading Democratic candidate, hoping to overturn that result. From @1843mag: On Boxing Day in 1862, 38 Dakota men and boys were hanged in Mankato, western Minnesota. A festive crowd was watching. A descendant of one of these Sioux men, Jim Miller, envisaged the grisly event in a dream 15 years ago, in which he saw himself galloping over ground he did not recognise with men he did not know, until they arrived at Mankato. Today, Miller organises an annual 330-mile ride that begins in icy South Dakota and ends at Mankato on Boxing Day. To find out more about the ride, and how it exemplifies a cultural re-awakening among native Americans, search "Dreams of their forefathers" on 1843magazine.com. Photo: @marlonkrieger #America #USA #nativeAmerican #Sioux #horse #riding #history #culture

From @1843mag: In an age when products are constantly being replaced by something better or cheaper it seems astonishing that, 8,000 years since people started farming sheep for wool, a new generation of designers has begun using this age-old material in new ways. Australian artist Jacqueline Fink creates large-scale sculptural installations, throws and wall-hangings using hanks of merino wool, often knitted with metre-long needles. Making the most of the material’s bulk, she undermines perceptions of knitting as staid and old-fashioned. The death has been announced of the hugely gifted and widely acclaimed poet Sir Derek Walcott. Born on the Caribbean island of St Lucia, he was awarded the Nobel prize in literature in 1992. “White Egrets” (2010), which was published when he was 80, won Britain’s most important poetry award, the T.S. Eliot prize. Unlike most contemporary poets, who write in compressed phrases and short lines, Derek Walcott’s work is voluminous. “It’s better to be large and to make huge gestures than to be modest and do tiptoeing types of presentation of oneself,” he once explained. Credit: Camera Press/Gino Begotti #obituary #DerekWalcott #poet #poetry #StLucia #Caribbean

From @1843mag: The title of a new exhibition at the Royal Academy, “America after the Fall”, refers to the Wall Street crash of 1929, but it’s hard to ignore its Biblical implications. Nor should you: this tightly edited selection of 45 paintings from the 1930s is a hymn to the loss of innocence of a generation afflicted by the Great Depression. The power of Grant Wood's “American Gothic” (1930), the most famous painting in the show, lies in the ambiguous way in which it seems both to channel the nostalgia of the era and undermine it. To find out more about the flourishing creativity of this seminal period, search "How American art boomed after the bust" on 1843magazine.com. @royalacademyarts #art #painting #America #history #AmericanGothic

From @1843mag: Is Stefan Simchowitz the most hated man in the art world? He is a "flipper", a new breed of art dealer who buys low, sells high and claims to be bringing new people and money into the market. Despised by gallerists, who complain that flippers make the market more volatile, he has been called "Sith Lord" and "Satan". To find out more about Simchowitz – pictured holding test prints of works by Petra Cortright – and why his strictly-for-profit approach is so controversial, search "Art Market Vs. Predator" on 1843magazine.com. Photo: @StefanSimchowitz #art #investment #artmarket #StefanSimchowitz

From @1843mag: Imagine taking a sip of a clear chilled liquid with a light, indefinable alcoholic scent. Roll it around your mouth, swallow and suddenly your senses are flooded by the pure sensation of playing in snow. This bottled cocktail is one of the fabulous concoctions of Tony Conigliaro. He designs drinks to trigger memories and emotions in the imbiber. His Silent Neon Flower (pictured) uses gin flavoured with jasmine to evoke a floral-scented post-human world. To find out more, search "Drinks Cabinet: Infusions" on1843magazine.com. Photo: Addie Chinn #drink #gin #infusions #flower #memory #alcohol #spirits #cocktail #emotion @tonyconigliaro

The kokerboom, also known at the quiver tree or aloe dichotoma, is a succulent plant with the ability to store water in its stems and leaves, making it highly adapted to cope during drought. The Western Cape of South Africa is currently in the midst of a severe drought. Photo taken in Worcester, South Africa on March 1st 2017. Credit: EPA/Nic Bothma #trees #SouthAfrica #Worcester #nature #plants #WesternCape

Where is France’s populist party National Front on the rise? This year's French election reveals the faultline between the country's cosmopolitan cities, at ease with globalisation, and its in-between places where farmland gives way to retail sprawl and a sense of neglect. Our data team mapped out unemployment rates and support for the populist party. To read our analysis, search "Where France’s National Front is on the rise" on our website economist.com #theeconomist

The Northern Lights, or aurora borealis, appear in the sky over Bifrost, Iceland on March 1st 2017. From @1843mag: Nicaragua has not always been the most peaceful destination – it's built around nine active volcanoes and has a turbulent history including revolution and civil war – but it's a magical place to travel to. Tibetan Buddhist monks use metal funnels, called chak-purs, to gently release coloured grains onto a sand mandala at Doane Hall of Art, Allegheny College in Meadville, Pennsylvania on March 3rd 2017. The college is hosting the event as part of their Year of Mindfulness. The monks, from Drepung Loseling Monastery in India, began creating the artwork on March 1st and will apply the final grains on March 4th after which, in keeping with tradition, it will be destroyed. The monks will sweep the sand into an urn. Half of the contents will be given to those watching and the other half poured into a nearby lake or river. Credit: AP/Erie Times-News/Christopher Millette #Buddhist #art #mandala #tradition #AlleghenyCollege #Tibetan #Pennsylvania

The photographer's story:  Based in Quito, Ecuador, Santiago Borja Lopez's work as a commercial airline pilot takes him over regions of the world that experience dramatic natural phenomenon.  From his ringside seat he captures astonishing photographs of weather events. On February 22nd 2017, he caught an impressive lightning bolt arcing from a cloud down towards the earth: "I'd never seen lightning like this. The photo was taken over Ecuadorean Amazonia on a hot evening while we were flying to Europe." For 20 years pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, who was born in South Korea, travelled between his adopted home in Toronto, Canada and North Korea. Making over 100 visits, he brought humanitarian aid as well as building an orphanage, nursery and nursing home. On January 31st 2015, during a routine visit, he was arrested, charged with “subversion". This photo was taken during his 90-minute trial, when he was sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour. Since then his appearance and health have deteriorated significantly. On March 1st 2017 it was announced that Torkel Stiernlof, the Swedish Ambassador, was recently allowed to meet for 40 minutes with the 62-year-old pastor. Credit: AP/Jon Chol Jin #NorthKorea #HyeonSooLim #Canada #Toronto

Milking venom from a deadly funnel web spider at the Australian Reptile Park in Sydney. A diamond isn't forever. The supply of new diamonds is expected to peak in the next few years, before beginning a slow decline. De Beers, the world’s biggest diamond company, faces many uncertainties, from synthetic diamonds to changing relationships with polishers and cutters. Meanwhile, the power of the engagement ring is waning, as millennials in Western countries seem keener on memorable experiences than on bling. What will happen to the future of forever? To read our analysis, search "A report from De Beers’s new diamond mine" via our website economist.com

Just released by NASA/ESA: Since its launch in 1990 the Hubble Space Telescope has observed the expanding dust cloud of supernova remnant SN 1987A several times and in this way helped astronomers gain a better understanding of these cosmic explosions. Supernova SN 1987A is located in the centre of the image amidst a backdrop of stars. The bright ring around the central region of the exploded star is composed of material ejected by the star about 20,000 years before the actual explosion took place. Credit: AFP/NASA, ESA/R. Kirshner (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation) and P. Challis (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics) #space #HubbleSpaceTelescope #ESA #NASA #astronomy

Aurora borealis over trees in Wapusk National Park, Manitoba, Canada. The aurora borealis, also called the Northern Lights, is a coloured light display that is visible in the night sky, usually only at high latitudes. It occurs when charged and energetic particles from the Sun are drawn by Earth's magnetic field to the polar regions. Hundreds of kilometres up, they collide with gas molecules and atoms, causing them to emit light. Read our related article in the Science section on Economist.com. Credit: Science Photo Library/Dr. P. Marazzi #auroraborealis #northernlights #Canada #light #nightsky

Scientists have discovered four new species of miniature night frog, all small enough to sit comfortably on a fingernail, including this 13.6mm Vijayans Night Frog (Nyctibatrachus pulivijayani). The researchers spent five years exploring the lush Western Ghats mountain range in India. They reported that the tiny amphibians are found in abundance but had likely been overlooked until now because of their size. Credit: AFP/S.D. The photographer's story:  Visitors must abseil 100 metres to experience the Waitomo Caves, a huge limestone cave system in New Zealand's North Island. Photographer Ben Babusis says "The most impressive cave I entered was called The Lost World. I received special permission to take my camera gear down. We could hardly see the bottom when we left the platform. After a 20 minute descent, we finally landed on the ground. I wanted to capture light beams as they slowly moved across the floor of the cave. Shooting this was challenging because of the incredible contrast, with extremely dark and bright areas." Photo taken on February 20th 2017 . Credit: Cover Images/Ben Babusis #caves #caving #NewZealand #extremetourism #nature #tourism

From @1843mag: Human-rights lawyer Amal Clooney and Nadia Murad, a Yazidi refugee and former prisoner of Islamic State, addressing the UN last September. Rohingya refugees gather in the hope of getting relief supplies at the Leda refugee camp in Chittagong, Bangladesh on February 15th 2017. The Nautical Aliya aid ship, carrying emergency supplies, aid-workers and 2,200 tons of rice, docked near Cox's Bazar where thousands of Rohingya have taken refuge. Around 70,000 Rohingya Muslims have fled to Bangladesh from Myanmar since October last year, after the Burmese army launched a campaign it calls 'clearance operations' in response to an attack on border police. The Rohingya are an often persecuted Muslim minority group, regarded as illegal immigrants from Bangladesh. Credit: Getty Images/Allison Joyce #Rohingya #refugee #Bangladesh #Myanmar

What do you think is the most vital thing about the world’s oceans? To mark the World Ocean Summit, which will be held between February 22nd and 24th 2017, we invite you to share an image you have taken on the theme of “the ocean” by 2:00pm (GMT) on Thursday, February 16th 2017.

The Tornado steam locomotive crosses the Ribblehead viaduct in Appleby, North Yorkshire, England on February 14th 2017. The steam train is the first to be built in England since 1960. It was entirely funded by private donations and took 18 years to complete. The Tornado will run two return journeys, Tuesday toThursday each week. The inaugural run is part of celebrations to mark the reopening of the Settle-Carlisle line after landslides in February 2016 closed a long stretch. Economist Zoom: Our media editor gets up close and personal with virtual reality gaming at the Sundance Film Festival where he donned the “Synesthesia Suit”. Developed in Japan, this full-body velcro suit stimulates the wearer with physical sensations, like little buzzes and vibrations, using voice coil actuators to enhance the feeling of immersion in a VR game. Gamers in a way already inhabit alternative realities, playing in vividly imagined worlds with almost cinematic graphics. VR is a natural step towards making those games feel even more real.

Seagull attacks are a big problem in coastal settlements, here's an excerpt from our print article "Fighting them on the Beaches": Savouring the moment before the first bite of a pasty on a beautiful sunny day, Pamela, a holidaymaker, gazed across Porthgwidden beach in St Ives, on the Cornish coast. She didn’t see the seagull until it was too late. The bird missed the pasty but took a chunk out of her hand. Blood poured down her arm and the seagull squawked away. It is difficult to fight back against the feathered fiends. All species of gull are protected, making a widespread cull impossible. Yet polls suggest that most Britons - normally sentimental about animals - would like the legislation changed. Credit: Alamy #birds #seagull #seaside

The photographer’s story: Michal Krzysztofowicz, Data Manager for the British Antarctic Survey at the Halley Research Station, challenged himself to take one picture each day for the whole year. The result is Antarctica366 (it was a leap year), showcasing stunning photos of life at the southernmost continent, where temperatures can drop to -56˚C.  Michal says “I have been into photography for several years and when I came to Halley for the second time I decided it would be a good idea to have a personal project to see me through the winter”. One of his highlights was spending a day among Emperor Penguins, on the Brunt Ice Shelf. Credit: Michal Krzysztofowicz/British Antarctic Survey/Cover Images #ValentinesDay #EmperorPenguins #Antarctica

Breakfast time in the Loisaba Conservancy, Laikipia, Northern Kenya. The Zebra's stripes could be a defence against biting insects. Scientists found that stripes attracted fewer flies than solid, uniform colours. They also found that the least attractive pattern of stripes was precisely those of the sort of width found on zebra hides. Zebra stripes do, therefore, seem to repel insects. Exactly why is unclear but it might be related to the insect's ability to see polarised light, which imposes a sense of horizontal and vertical on an image. Possibly, the mostly vertical stripes on a zebra confuse the fly's tiny brain. Horses can now benefit from zebra-striped fly sheets. Credit: AFP/Tony Karumba #Kenya #zebra #stripes #wildlife #nature

Dawn breaks at the Kutapalong Rohingya refugee camp in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh on February 8th 2017. Rohingyas are a Muslim group whose persecution in their mainly Buddhist home state of Rakhine in Myanmar is long-standing but has recently escalated. Last year the Bangladeshi prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, ordered officials to resettle the 30,000-odd refugees living in camps near Cox’s Bazar, a tourist spot with the world’s longest unbroken beach. The chosen location is a barren island in the Bay of Bengal, called Thengar Char. The island is exposed and prone to flooding during spring tides.  Credit: Getty Images/Allison Joyce #refugees #Bangaldesh #Myanmar #Rohingyas #photography

To the general public, Australia hardly leaps to mind as a gambling hotbed. Yet industry insiders know it is far and away their most lucrative market: according to H2 Gambling Capital (H2G), a consultancy, betting losses per resident adult there amounted to $990 last year. That is 40% higher than Singapore, the runner-up, and around double the average in other Western countries. To read more about our analysis, search "The world’s biggest gamblers" via our website economist.com #TheEconomist #gambling

To mark the bicentenary of the Crossing of the Andes in 1817, a group of people is retracing the epic journey.
